HEADLINE: PERIPHERALS;
Phantoms of Physics Made Visible

BYLINE: By L. R. SHANNON

 BODY:
MAXWELL'S DEMON, a figment of the imagination of the 19th-century physicist James Clerk Maxwell, could reduce entropy, or disorder, with little or no expenditure of energy. Although nothing like the demon exists in the real world, you can play with it in one of the eight Physics Demonstration Programs published by Physics Academic Software.
Intended for classroom instruction or independent study at the high school and undergraduate levels, these computer animations also deal with manifestations of things entitled longitudinal waves, waves on a string, two sine waves, a chain reaction, a moving charge, a radiating dipole and a thin lens. The programs were written by Robert H. Good of the department of physics at California State University at Hayward. 
 Two of the other physics programs are Chaos Demonstrations (by Julien C. Sprott of the physics department of the University of Wisconsin and George Rowlands of the physic department of the University of Warwick, England) and Physics Demonstrations, also by Professor Sprott. The editor of the series, an American Institute of Physics project in cooperation with the American Physical Society and the American Association of Physics Teachers, is John S. Risley of North Carolina State University.
The 22 chaos demonstrations range from a driven pendulum through the Mandelbrot and Julia Sets and the Game of Life. All are nicely done, and many are quite beautiful. The 10 physics demonstrations simulate concepts like wave speed on a rope and the Doppler effect. Quizzes, references and ideas for instructors round out the packages.
Physics Simulation Programs is $49.95, with disks for both I.B.M.-compatible and Apple II computers; a 10-copy Lab Pack is $149.95. Chaos Demonstrations is $69.95, or 10 for $199.95, for the PC only. Physics Demonstrations is $49.95, or 10 for $149.95, also for the PC only.
The three programs mentioned here were selected because they are reasonably accessible to a writer who learned physics when Newton was a pup. But the company produces other programs for more advanced students. If you want a catalogue, information or orders, contact the Academic Software Library, North Carolina State University, Post Office Box 8202, Raleigh, N.C. 27695, or phone (800) 955-8275.
 
Publish or Perish

A book with the intriguing and eccentrically punctuated title "Stop Stealing Sheep & find out how type works," by Erik Spiekermann and E.M. Ginger, is a gentle little introduction to a field, publishing, into which the computer has dropped a lot of unsuspecting souls in the last few years. There are examples of typography, both very good and screamingly bad, much advice and many aphorisms.
"Stop Stealing Sheep" is $19.95. It is published by Adobe Press of Mountain View, Calif., and may be ordered by calling (800) 428-5331.
Oh, yes, the title. Frederick Goudy, the great American type designer, once said, "Anyone who would letterspace lower case would steal sheep." In other words, unnecessarily adjusting the spacing between lower-case letters would be esthetically dishonest.
"Everybody's Guide to Successful Publications," by Elizabeth W. Adler (Peachpit Press; $28), is aimed at people who want to get a message across in print effectively and economically. It deals with the whole process of producing a newsletter, report, advertisement or whatever, from the initial planning and budgeting to the final distribution. There is advice on typography and design, and even on writing style. The desktop publishing forum on Compuserve, the information service, brings together desktop publishers from all over the country, and beyond, to exchange tips, ask for and give help and generally have a good time with people who speak the language. "The Best of the Desktop Publishing Forum on Compuserve," by Thom Hartmann, Brad Walrod and Don Arnoldy (Peachpit Press; $25), is an anthology of these exchanges.
The trouble with the printed forum is that you cannot join in; the advantage is that the editors have put together the discussions in a form that is much easier to follow. The real thing usually has a large number of threads, or topics, running at about the same time, running from "Remind me to buy you a beer next time we meet at a trade show" to "It is readily apparent from the primary 'OPI' servers that the option to use EPS files as the placement provides the most flexible option to the implementation of 'APR.' "
Much of the book consists of listings of all the files in the Desktop Publishing Forum, as of Sept. 19, 1992. Peachpit Press is in Berkeley, Calif. The number for orders is (800) 283-9444.

HEADLINE: Better Law for Tribal Gambling

 BODY:
In the five years since Congress set rules for gambling on Indian reservations, the boom in new games has been matched by a boom in lawsuits. Tension between sovereign tribes and sovereign states makes it clear the law needs fixing.
The Indians' right to operate gambling establishments was confirmed by the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act in 1988. There are now more than 100 sites, run by 61 tribes in 18 states. Their spread has been an economic boon to long-suffering tribes with few other resources, but unwelcome to people who don't want full-blown gambling halls in their states. 
 The law lets tribes run any type of gambling their home state already permits. If casino-style "Las Vegas Nights" for charity are allowed, Indians may have round-the-clock casinos. States resist for various reasons -- not least, money. Indian casinos divert gamblers from state-sponsored games and add to the cost of roads, police and other services. Like gambling everywhere, they attract crime and prey on compulsive gamblers.
Therefore, to establish a casino -- or pari-mutuel racing or other high-stakes games -- the law requires a "compact" between a tribe and state officials, setting rules for the enterprise. If they can't agree, the tribe may go to court and force mediation, but some states have sought to block this by claiming constitutional immunity.
Connecticut's Mashantucket Pequot tribe had to fight two governors to get permission for its new and highly successful casino near the Rhode Island border -- so successful that it could afford a $100,000 "soft money" gift to the Democratic National Committee last year. The Pequots' success has already created pressure for more. New York has recently negotiated a compact with its Oneida Indians for a casino in mid-state. A second, near the Canadian border, is in the works.
For good or ill, organized gambling is spreading through most of America, as it often does when times are poor. But 49 governors have petitioned Congress to clarify the 1988 law.
The governors seek tighter definition of the types of gambling permitted, tighter regulation of tribe-sponsored games on non-reservation land, and clearer guidelines for negotiating compacts. They have good reason; as a difficult compromise, the law was necessarily vague.
It's a problem for tribes, too. Tribes involved in gambling, or trying to be, want less state intrusion on their sovereignty, not more. At the least, the matter of state immunity to suits must be resolved.
The subtlety of competing sovereignties makes all these issues delicate ones. One could wish for a higher cause than gambling. But the greater cause for Congress to address is balanced consideration for America's native peoples.

HEADLINE: Welfare Recipients Need Education and Jobs, Not Bank Cards

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I read with increasing dismay "Welfare Recipients Are Joining the Age of Plastic" (news article, March 14). Underlying the article is the notion that streamlining the administration of welfare payments with bank cards is effective reform because, among other things, it "lessens" the stigma of using food stamps. 
 Without disregarding the very understandable fear of street crime and the salutary objective of reducing administrative costs, I believe any reform that leads a beneficiary to believe she is "self-sufficient" and "independent" without moving her toward employment and real economic security is not likely to end welfare as we know it.
My dismay is predicated on the experience of one who spent the first 20 years of her life in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and who observed the unintended consequences of welfare as we know it, particulary the disintegration of two-parent families.
I vividly recall my upstairs neighbor fleeing out the door whenever the caseworker made a home visit because his wife was on Aid to Families with Dependent Children and the impact of their deception (fraud) on their children.
The stigma of waiting with my mother in the welfare office to receive surplus food and emergency assistance strengthened my determination to escape the poverty trap. Then -- as now -- the ticket out of poverty was not a more streamlined and less stigmatizing welfare bureaucracy; rather the ticket out was education (in my case, a one-way ticket to San Francisco to attend Stanford Law School after graduating from the City College of New York).
The focus of welfare reform should be to provide recipients with education, training and work experience to learn skills that will enable them to lead productive lives.
The only difference between the state as banker and the neighborhood banker is that between dependence and hopelessness in one case and responsibility and self-respect in the other.
 
FAYE M. ANDERSON
Washington, March 16, 1993

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Is Facing New Hurdles

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
The North American Free Trade Agreement, which already faces a number of political obstacles, now faces two more -- plans by Ross Perot to speak out against Congressional approval, and the emergence of deep misgivings about it in the House of Representative's huge freshman class -- members of Congress said today.
Mr. Perot is scheduled to testify before a House panel on Wednesday about the plan to lower trade barriers among Canada, Mexico and the United States, and he is expected to repeat some of the strong criticisms of the pact he made during the fall Presidential campaign. 
 Mr. Perot is also considering a half-hour television commercial devoted to attacking the agreement, said a person familiar with preparations on the subject who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
 
 
Political Generation Gap
 At the same time, a political generation gap on trade issues appears to be undermining the agreement's prospects in the House. This year's bumper crop of House freshmen appears less ideologically inclined to support free trade than were the older representatives they replaced.
For example, an informal count of the 63 Democratic freshmen by the House leadership shortly after the November election found that only 5 of them supported the deal. By contrast, 27 of the Democrats who left the House last year had voted in 1991 to give President George Bush the authority to negotiate the pact and submit it for fast-track consideration with no amendments allowed.
Republican freshmen are also less inclined than their elders to support the pact, said Representative Jim Kolbe, the six-term Arizona Republican who has organized his party's support for the pact on Capitol Hill. "It is more of a generational gap than anything else, but it's also related to party," he said, contending that lawmakers who grew up during the Depression or World War II had a more international outlook.
Representative Karen Shepherd, a freshman Democrat from Utah, said the freshmen, who make up a quarter of the House, were skeptical of the pact. "I'm one of the few who will stand up for it, at least in principle," she said. "Most say it can't be fixed."
Representative Bart Stupak, a freshman Democrat from Michigan who replaced a Republican supporter of the original fast-track authority, is one of the strongest opponents of the pact. "Nafta would be particularly damaging to workers in our manufacturing sector," he said.
Representative Karan English, a freshman Democrat from Arizona, said she thought it was too early to see a generation gap. Many freshmen now questioning the pact are eager to learn about it, she said. Still, she was reluctant to accept the agreement as intrinsically a good idea. "It's not enough to say we have a great plan and it will work; we have to say how it will work," Ms. English said.
While it did not seem likely that either Mr. Perot or the reluctant freshmen could torpedo the pact by themselves, the combination has alarmed the White House, which is reassessing its strategy.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said in an interview today that it was still too early to assess the pact's eventual prospects. He also said that three side agreements now being negotiated on labor, environmental and trade-volume issues would help the political prospects of the overall deal.
"When we come back with a package on the issues that people are concerned about, that will make a difference," Mr. Kantor said.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said the White House would "just wait and see what" Mr. Perot said.
An aide to Mr. Perot said he would appear on Wednesday before the House Small Business Committee only because he had been invited to do so by its chairman, Representative John J. LaFalce, Democrat of upstate New York.
To be sure, the overall betting of many members of Congress is still that the trade pact will be approved by Congress if President Clinton produces strong side agreements and also lobbies hard for party unity on the vote. "I don't think this is a lost cause for him; this is eminently doable," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat and senior member of the Ways and Means Committee's trade panel.
Yet the problems lying ahead of the Administration are clearest in the cases of Representatives like Ms. Shepherd and Ms. English. Both are moderate Democrats from the Southwest, the region seen by many economists as the most likely to benefit from the pact.
Both of them also went on a recent Congressional trip to Tijuana, Mexico, and said the environmental and labor problems they saw there had made a deep impression .

GRAPHIC: Photos: Representative Jim Kolbe, left, six-term Arizona Republican, has organized his party's support for the North American Free Trade Agreement on Capitol Hill. Representative Karan English, a Democrat from Arizona, said she was reluctant to accept the free trade pact as intrinsically a good idea. (Photographs by Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. D2)

HEADLINE: Months After Order on Gay Ban, Military Is Still Resisting Clinton

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
Two months after President Clinton ordered the Pentagon to prepare an executive order lifting the ban on homosexuals in the military, little work has been done, senior Congressional and Defense Department officials say.
In fact, these officials say, some steps have been taken to undermine the order. The Navy is showing lawmakers a commander's sworn statement describing the disruption caused by a gay sailor's presence at a California naval base. And an Army panel studying the effect of lifting the ban is warning that doing so could hurt recruiting so badly that the military might have to return to the draft. 
 Defense Secretary Les Aspin has not yet appointed members to the Pentagon study group that will direct the Administration's effort to draft a new policy. And with no guidance from the panel, some of the services seem to be pursuing strategies to keep the ban.
In January, after days of negotiation and rancor, the Administration and Congress struck a compromise to allow the military to continue its ban for six months while the Defense Department drafted the executive order to lift it. But some military officials are trying to derail the new policy by highlighting problems with it.
 
'We Can't Fight It Openly'
 "The military would love to fight this, but we can't fight it openly," said one Army official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
The Pentagon has until July 15 to present details of a new policy to Mr. Clinton, and senior Administration officials insist they will work out a proposal acceptable to military leaders and Congress by then.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said in an interview that he was unaware of any efforts by the military to undermine the new policy and that the Pentagon's planning was "proceeding as it should be." He said the Pentagon study group and a second team of personnel experts, from the Rand Corporation, would begin work on April 1.
 
'Plenty of Time' Left
 "We have plenty of time to carry out the study group," said Lieut. Gen. Robert M. Alexander of the Air Force, who is temporarily the Defense Department's chief personnel official and who will probably serve on the panel.
But time is running short. The Senate Armed Services Committee is to begin hearings on homosexuals in the military next week, and although Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the committee, has promised that the hearings will be "fair, thorough and objective," he opposes lifting the ban.
The Senate hearings will first examine the history of homosexuals in the military and then look at how other countries have handled the issue. Mr. Nunn said the committee would visit military installations to interview troops and by June would hear from advocacy groups and senior military officials in Washington.
"If I were the Administration, I'd be reviewing all the questions Nunn has raised, because like it or not he is the adversary on this one," said a senior member of the Senate staff.
By contrast, senior civilian officials at the Pentagon, preoccupied with Bosnia and Somalia, base closings and next year's military budget, have spent little time on the issue. Mr. Aspin and Deputy Defense Secretary William J. Perry are the only senior Pentagon officials nominated by the White House and confirmed by the Senate, leaving dozens of important positions vacant.
The services have filled the vacuum with their own campaigning.
The Navy, for example, has distributed to two Congressional committees a sworn statement from the commander of Petty Officer Keith Meinhold, a 12-year Navy veteran who was discharged last year after disclosing on national television that he is gay.
 
Citing Navy Procedure
 A Federal court later ordered the Navy to reinstate Mr. Meinhold, an airborne sonar operator. The statement by his commander, Capt. Gregory Markwell, was taken in connection with a Government appeal and asserted that Mr. Meinhold's presence had hurt morale and that some other airmen had refused to fly with him.
A Navy spokesman, Comdr. Craig Quigley, said that the Senate Armed Services Committee's Republican staff requested the deposition last Friday and that Navy procedure required that the same document be given to the committee's Democratic staff, as well as to the Republican and Democratic staffs of the House Armed Services Committee. But Navy officials who support the ban have been quietly advertising the availability of the statement for several weeks.
Further, a five-officer Army team studying the implications of lifting the ban said in working papers that any such policy would "force the military to experiment with profound cultural and life style changes not accepted by the majority of Americans."
The Army group also warned that recruiting might be hurt to the point where "the country may be forced to consider abandoning the all-volunteer force and returning to conscription," said the working papers, which were presented last week to Lieut. Gen. Thomas P. Carney, the Army's personnel chief, and whose contents were first reported last week by the Scripps Howard News Service.
 
Each Sevice Has Panel
 Each of the armed services has formed its own working group on the gay issue that will eventually work with the Pentagon panel.
The working papers of the Army's team, headed by Brig. Gen. Thomas C. Jones, suggest that the group is compiling evidence to demonstrate how lifting the ban would harm the military.
The Air Force's 20-member working group, headed by Brig. Gen. William B. Davitte, "is taking the position that we've been told change will take place, so how can we best do that," said one officer involved in the review.
The Navy has selected Rear Adm. Scott Redd to head its study team but has not actually created it yet, preferring to wait for guidance from the Pentagon panel, said one Navy officer.
Gay-rights advocates are reluctant to criticize the inaction on this issue, partly because they fear alienating their allies within the Defense Department and partly because their own lobbying efforts have lagged.
Thomas B. Stoddard, coordinator of the Campaign for Military Service, a new coalition of rights groups that oppose the ban, said that its grass-roots lobbying campaign was revving up. Gay veterans and their supporters started a six-week nationwide bus tour last week that will end with a rally in Washington on April 23.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 26, 1993, Friday / March 27, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about President Clinton's news conference comments about the possibility of restricted military assignments for gay troops referred incorrectly to a leading advocate of homosexuals in the military. The advocate, who was quoted on his reaction to the comments, is Thomas B. Stoddard.

An article on Tuesday about military resistance to President Clinton's proposals to allow homosexuals in the military misstated the date of a gay rally scheduled for Washington. It is April 25, not April 23.

HEADLINE: U.S. Power, Less Than Super

BYLINE: By Stephen Sestanovich; Stephen Sestanovich is director of Russian and Eurasian Studies at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Lose Yeltsin, lose the peace dividend. From Richard Nixon on down, commentators treat the prospect of higher defense spending as the clinching argument for increasing Western aid to Russia. Secretary of State Warren Christopher made the same case yesterday in his speech before the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations. Yet the pay-me-now-or-pay-me-later choice they and others pose is less hard-boiled analysis than wishful thinking, and it reflects a failure to imagine the immense problems that will flow from the failure of Russian democracy.
Increasing the defense budget bought security during the cold war. It will buy much less if things now go wrong in Russia. The real cost we face is not the loss of the peace dividend, but the loss of American pre-eminence. 
 A post-Yeltsin government is likely to make a major effort to save our peace dividend -- and theirs -- by convincing us that the cold war is still over. And it won't be so hard: Russian conservatives can't pay for an arms race any more than Russian liberals can.
In the past few months, there has been a clear convergence in their positions on defense and foreign policy. Liberals now favor increased sales of sophisticated military equipment to the third world to keep Russian arms manufacturers in business. And conservatives say they recognize that the military-industrial complex has to be sharply cut back.
A change of government could push this convergence further still. In power, Russian conservatives might well discover virtues in the very arms control agreements that they now call humiliating. Their favorite, Vice President Aleksandr Rutskoi, has already endorsed the Start 2 treaty; as president, he would be likely to change his stance (although to please his supporters he might prepare a list of provisions whose terms he would like to see "improved").
As for President Clinton, his stake in protecting his economic program will give him a powerful incentive to conclude that a new government in Moscow does not pose a greater military threat to America after all.
In contrast, Russia's neighbors cannot afford to be complacent. Germany, Poland, Ukraine, China, Japan, South Korea, Turkey, Iran and others will worry about being on the receiving end of more belligerent Russian nationalism. Almost all of them will turn to Washington for security guarantees, military assistance and in some cases even the stationing of U.S. troops.
To most such inquiries, however, it will be hard for the U.S. to give a satisfying answer. One obvious idea will be to reconsider the ongoing withdrawal of U.S. forces from Western Europe, where troop levels are already down to 167,000 from the cold war norm of 300,000. (Congress last year set a target of 100,000 troops for 1995.) But the practical difficulty of reversing this process would be only half the problem. Restoring our ability to fight a war in the middle of Germany has little relevance to the dangers created by a less cooperative and possibly revanchist Russia.
Conservative nationalists in Moscow don't aim to reacquire what was East Germany. But they do want to draw Ukraine back into some sort of political union, and they may be prepared to use military pressure to help matters along. Given this possibility, does anyone seriously believe that the U.S. will make a military commitment to Ukrainian independence? To do so now, as a preventive step, would be needlessly inflammatory; to do so later, too dangerous. Inevitably, the Western response to Ukrainian appeals will be far more muted, a combination of diplomatic warnings to Russia and offers of mediation. Meanwhile, the chance that Ukraine will voluntarily give up the strategic nuclear forces that were left on its territory when the Soviet Union collapsed will shrink to nil.
The Ukrainians will not be alone in seeking help -- nor in failing to get it. The rest of the old Warsaw Pact will be in a similar state of alarm. Western security guarantees to Poland or Hungary may not seem as inconceivable as the same commitment to Ukraine. But they and other Eastern European states have already found it impossible to get serious consideration for full NATO membership. At a time when no one thinks they are threatened, they have been told, in effect, come back in five years. When Russia begins to talk ominously about its natural sphere of influence, Western reluctance to get involved will only grow.
America's traditional allies can count on firmer-sounding reassurances. Yet, no matter how much we pledge to stand by them, they too will see that the threats to their security have increased. Our inability to address the anxieties of countries directly affected by a resurgent Russia will make the international environment look much more menacing to Germany and Japan. As a result, American guarantees may seem less and less adequate for their security. Neither country's Government wants to build nuclear forces, but a more nationalist Russia will make the subject harder to avoid.
The eclipse of a pro-Western Government in Russia will destabilize international politics, but it will not revive the cold war. Nor will it call for cold war solutions. Instead, it will reveal the precariousness of the American claim to be the only superpower. As new conflicts arise to which we have no real response and as other governments (including our closest friends) are forced to take more responsibility for their own security, our influence will inescapably wane.
Those who warn about the impact on our defense spending if Russia's democrats are ousted are right that America stands to lose a lot. But they greatly understate the problem by not acknowledging how little we will be able to do for those whose security is directly threatened. An extra hundred billion dollars here and there in the Pentagon budget doesn't deter military conflict the way it used to. The fact that we will have no good response later is the most powerful argument to do what can be done now. Real doubts can be raised about all the many types of aid that have been proposed for Russia, but these doubts are nothing compared with the frustration and powerlessness we will feel once Russian democracy fails.

HEADLINE: Clinton Would Consider Segregating Gay Troops;
For Yeltsin's 'Courage,' President Vows Plan to Support Russia

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
President Clinton today brushed aside criticism that he was too closely tied to President Boris N. Yeltsin, saying that Mr. Yeltsin's decision to circumvent the Russian Parliament was "appropriate" and that he would give Mr. Yeltsin "an aggressive and quite specific plan" of aid at their summit meeting.
"Boris Yeltsin is the elected President of Russia, and he has shown a great deal of courage in sticking up for democracy and civil liberties and market reforms, and I'm going to support that," Mr. Clinton said, adding that he would begin briefing Congress this week on his aid proposals. 
 Senior Administration officials said that among the proposals Mr. Clinton was considering were these:
*Housing loan guarantees, to build homes for demobilized Russian troops.
*An enterprise fund to make seed loans to emerging Russian capitalists.
*A technical aid package to help develop the potentially lucrative Russian energy industry.
*Easier terms for the long-promised currency stabilization fund from the West.
*An American-led effort with the Group of Seven industrialized democracies to reschedule some of Russia's $80 billion in foreign debts to provide some $15 billion in relief on interest and principal.
 
U.S. Backing Helps Yeltsin
 State Department officials said reports from the United States Embassy in Moscow have suggested that the backing for Mr. Yeltsin from the United States and other major Western countries like Britain, France and Germany, appeared to be helping generate support for the Russian President among Muscovites and giving pause to his parliamentary opponents.
These reports apparently encouraged Mr. Clinton to come out forcefully and personally in Mr. Yeltsin's behalf today, even though the American President acknowledged that outsiders could only have limited influence events in Moscow.
The President, speaking at his first formal news conference, held in the East Room of the White House, appeared to choose this moment in the Russian political crisis to lend his personal weight to the American backing for Mr. Yeltsin. Mr. Clinton dismissed criticism from some conservative foreign policy specialists like former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger that the Administration was betting too much on the Russian President.
 
Endorses Referendum
 "At this moment, Russia is in a constitutional and political crisis," Mr. Clinton said in his opening remarks. "President Yeltsin proposes to break the logjam by letting the people of Russia decide on April the 25th. That is an appropriate step in a democracy."
Despite Mr. Clinton's forceful words, he did not seem as comfortable talking about Russia as he did answering a range of tough and complicated questions on domestic affairs, from the spotted owl to homosexuals in the military.
When it came to Russia, while he strongly backed Mr. Yeltsin, the President seemed to be trying to find the delicate line between endorsing Mr. Yeltsin enough to help him, but not to the extent that the Russian leader might think he could engage in anti-democratic measures, or to leave the impression that Mr. Clinton was naive about the hard realities of Russian politics.
 
A Throwback to Reagan
 Mr. Clinton's first news conference, which lasted 45 minutes, seemed athrowback to the Reagan years. President Bush usually chose to hold his news conferences in the more drab, crowded White House press room. But like Mr. Reagan, President Clinton began and ended by striding alone down the long red-carpeted hallway leading through the White House to the cream-colored East Room, with network cameras tracking his every pace.
The questions from the media were split between foreign and domestic issues. Mr. Clinton's demeanor was as congenial and smiling, except when he seemed rattled by a question on unhappiness in the American military toward him.
Mr. Clinton spoke with scant reference to the three-by-five cards that Mr. Reagan depended upon. When he was done, he bounced off the podium, clearly pleased with his performance, and joking that he liked the encounter with the press so much he might do it again sometime.
It was clear from his opening statement, which began with the need to support Mr. Yeltsin, that Mr. Clinton wanted to send the signal that when the first popularly elected President in Russia was on the ropes, the Clinton Administration did not waver in its backing.
In his efforts to help Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Clinton said that if the Russians want to move the site of the summit next month to Moscow he would be ready to consider the idea. But the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, who today met with Secretary of State Warren Christopher, said after several hours of talks that there were "no changes" contemplated in the meeting, which is scheduled to be held in Vancouver, British Columbia, April 3-4.
"We have agreed upon an agenda and a place for this meeting and we are concentrating not on revision of all this but on preparing a good stage for Presidents to have productive summit," Mr. Kozyrev said. "Everything is O.K. and under control."
 
Russia's First Elected Leader
 The Washington Post carried a lengthy article this morning on its Op-Ed page by Mr. Kissinger, which said: "Once again, American policy toward Russia is being presented largely in terms of supporting a particular Russian leader. First it was Mikhail Gorbachev; now it is Boris Yeltsin. I questioned then and doubt now whether it is wise to gear American policy so totally to any individual whatever his merits."
Mr. Clinton seemed to refer to that article, and others like it, when he responded to a question whether he was getting too close to Mr. Yeltsin, as the Bush Administration had with Mr. Gorbachev.
"I don't think so," he said. "I know some people say, well, what's the difference in this and the Gorbachev situation before, and is this the same sort of problem? I've tried to be supportive of reformers throughout Russia and, indeed, throughout all the former Communist countries and the former republics of the Soviet Union. But he is, after all, the first elected President in a thousand years. He has the mandate of having been voted on in a free and open election where people were free to vote and free to stay home, something that was not true previously. And that is something you would expect me to do."
 
List of U.S. Interests
 Mr. Clinton, though, tried to temper his remarks by placing his support for Mr. Yeltsin in the context of broader, immutable American interests. But he recited these with none of the passion contained in his remarks about the Russian President.
"The United States has three interests in our cooperation with Russia," Mr. Clinton said, referring to note cards. "One is to make the world a safer place, continue to reduce the threat of nuclear war and the proliferation of nuclear weapons. Two is to support the development of democracy and freedom for the people of Russia -- and indeed for all of the Commonwealth of Independent States. And three is to support the development of a market economy."
Mr. Clinton said Americans "have no reason to be concerned" about who is in command and control of Russia's arsenal of 30,000 nuclear warheads during the power crisis. "We are monitoring that very closely," Mr. Clinton said. "We feel good about it."

HEADLINE: ATTORNEY GENERAL SEEKS RESIGNATIONS FROM PROSECUTORS

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
Attorney General Janet Reno today demanded the prompt resignation of all United States Attorneys, leading the Federal prosecutor in the District of Columbia to suggest that the order could be tied to his long-running investigation of Representative Dan Rostenkowski, a crucial ally of President Clinton.
Jay B. Stephens, the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, who is a Bush Administration holdover, said he had advised the Justice Department that he was within 30 days of making a "critical decision" in the Rostenkowski case when Ms. Reno directed him and other United States Attorneys to submit their resignations, effective in a matter of days. 
 While prosecutors are routinely replaced after a change in Administration, Ms. Reno's order accelerated what had been expected to be a leisurely changeover.
 
Says He Won't Resist
 At a news conference today only hours after one by Ms. Reno, Mr. Stephens said he would not resist the Attorney General's move to force him from office, and he held back from directly accusing her of interfering with the Rostenkowski inquiry.
But Mr. Stephens left the strong impression that Ms. Reno's actions might disrupt the investigation as he moved toward a decision on whether to seek charges against the Illinois Democrat, who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
"This case has been conducted with integrity," Mr. Stephens said, "and I trust the decisions in this case will not be made based on political considerations."
Nonetheless, lawyers who have followed the investigation have said that Mr. Stephens has been concerned that the Democratic Administration might try to upset his investigation.
 
Has Denied Wrongdoing
 Mr. Rostenkowski has repeatedly denied wrongdoing, and he has not been accused of any impropriety. But if he is indicted, he would be forced by House rules to relinquish his chairmanship, a development that some lawmakers have said could seriously jeopardize Mr. Clinton's efforts to steer his economic and health-care proposals through Congress.
Mr. Stephens and his prosecutors began the investigation that led them to review Mr. Rostenkowski's activities in mid-1991, focusing initially on low-level employees at the House post office who absconded with money. There have been several guilty pleas as prosecutors have worked their way up the ranks at the mailing operation.
Mr. Rostenkowski has been under scrutiny since last year, when his office records were subpoenaed in an inquiry into whether someone in his office used his expense account fraudulently to obtain cash from the post office. Since then, some of his aides have testified to a grand jury and investigators have examined his use of campaign funds.
 
Denies Any Connection
 In announcing her order at her first news conference as Attorney General, Ms. Reno denied there was any connection between her action and the Rostenkowski case and said Mr. Stephens had been treated like other United States Attorneys."
Ms. Reno said United States Attorneys "are absolutely integral to the whole success of the Department of Justice," and her aides said today that she did not intend to immediately remove any whose presence was required to complete an investigation.
One official suggested that even Mr. Stephens might be asked to stay on until a successor is named, saying Ms. Reno had made no decisions about who she may choose on an interim basis.
All 93 United States Attorneys knew they would be asked to step down, since all are Republican holdovers, and 16 have resigned so far. But the process generally takes much longer and had usually been carried out without the involvement of the Attorney General.
 
Battles of the Past
 Ms. Reno is under pressure to assert her control over appointments at the Justice Department. She was Mr. Clinton's third choice for Attorney General and arrived after most of the department's senior positions were already filled by the White House.
The comments of Ms. Reno and Mr. Stephens evoked the pitched battles of the past, when independent United States Attorneys resisted removal by new administrations.
In 1969, for instance Robert Morgenthau, now the Manhattan District Attorney, resisted efforts by the Nixon Administration to replace him as United States Attorney in New York until he was given what he called an "ultimatum" by President Richard M. Nixon to leave office.
In 1978, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell removed David W. Marston as United States Attorney in Philadelphia, provoking charges, never proved, that a lawmaker under scrutiny by Mr. Marston's office had urged President Jimmy Carter to remove the prosecutor.
 
Four-Year Terms
 United States Attorneys are appointed to serve four-year terms at the pleasure of the President. It was unclear whether Ms. Reno initiated the request for resignations or whether it was pressed on her by the White House. The Attorney General said it was a "joint decision."
Ms. Reno said she wanted the resignations "so that the U.S. Attorneys presently in position will know where they stand and that we can begin to build a team."
Some Administration officials dismissed Mr. Stephens's veiled assertions about the Attorney General's motives as "absurd," as one put it, saying that what was surprising was that it had taken so long before the Justice Department could begin putting its own appointees in place.
 
Abortion Clinic Violence
 On other topics, Ms. Reno said she would work with Democrats in Congress to prepare legislation to give Federal agencies a larger role in protecting abortion clinics.
Her comments came after she had ordered a review of current law, which she said was inadequate "to prevent or to help prevent physical interference with access to abortion clinics."
She also ruled out a Federal inquiry into the death of Dr. David Gunn, a physician who was shot to death as he entered an abortion clinic in Pensacola, Fla., apparently by a man who said he was an anti-abortion activist. "Florida law on this subject is more effective than Federal law," said Ms. Reno, a former Florida prosecutor.
Ms. Reno also said she had not decided whether to replace William S. Sessions, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who has been found to have violated ethics rules.

SECTION: Section B; Page 8; Column 1; National Desk; Education Page

LENGTH: 1963 words

HEADLINE: Lessons of South Carolina: What Secretary May Try for U.S. Schools

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SUMMERTON, S.C.

 BODY:
When Richard W. Riley -- then Governor, now President Clinton's Secretary of Education -- first looked hard at South Carolina's schools in 1983, he saw an educational backwater. The state trailed nearly all others in test scores and money for schools. Rural towns like this one did not even have working microscopes in science classrooms.
It was the start of his second term. Within a year, mounting a campaign that offered toll-free education phone lines and educational town meetings, Mr. Riley pushed through changes hailed at the time as the nation's most wide-ranging education effort. By spending more money on public schools, imposing higher standards and holding the schools responsible for results, the law helped South Carolina post some of the biggest test score increases in the country, even if the state's scores still lag behind many others. 
 "It brought South Carolina from the dark ages into the light," said Jo Day, a first-grade teacher at Joseph Keels Elementary School in Columbia.
 
From Statewide to Nationwide
 The lessons Mr. Riley learned along the way are the ones he plans to apply to America's schools: rally public support to build coalitions to fight for education; insist that schools set goals and test for results; spend money to help schools meet higher standards; ask schools to develop comprehensive plans for change, and keep tinkering with the results. Many of these principles are incorporated in the Clinton Administration's first big education bill, expected to be unveiled next week.
The admirers of the 60-year-old Secretary expect him to do for American education what he did for South Carolina: apply his persuasive powers, his gift for winning allies and his grit to a cause he cares deeply about.
"He has a bone-deep commitment," said Bill Youngblood, a lawyer in Charleston who heads a business-education group charged by the state with monitoring South Carolina's education laws. "You feel it within a few seconds of the time you meet him. It affects you."
But Mr. Riley's experience in South Carolina also shows how difficult, complex and slow a task he and his department will face. Despite considerable progress, South Carolina still ranks low compared with the nation as a whole, and test scores have not improved in the last two years. This plateau suggests the limitations of the basic-skills, top-down approach many states adopted in the mid-80's.
And time has also demonstrated other needs the law did not meet -- ones Mr. Riley and his aides say they will emphasize at the national level: teacher training, more extensive early childhood programs, flexibility for local schools, consolidation of the melange of social services for poor children in schools, and more emphasis on the sophisticated analytical skills that employers want.
 
A State System Near the Bottom
 When Governor Riley began lobbying for education in 1983, South Carolina's schools, by universal agreement, were in big trouble. "You're talking about a state that by many measures was right down there with Mississippi and Louisiana at the bottom of the barrel," said John C. Norton, now vice president for information of the Southern Regional Education Board and then an education reporter.
But when Mr. Riley asked legislators to raise taxes to increase financing for schools in 1983, they rebuffed him, fueled by opposition from business groups.
The Governor responded with tactics like those Ross Perot and Mr. Clinton would later make famous. He held question-and-answer sessions, set up toll-free numbers and deployed county coordinators to whip up enthusiasm for his proposed changes. In education meetings across the state, Mr. Riley asked participants to commit to further action in their communities. In all, said Terry K. Peterson, an aide to Mr. Riley, about 100,000 people were involved.
South Carolina's Education Improvement Act was passed in 1984. It raised the state sales tax by a penny on the dollar to pay for remedial and advanced classes, higher teachers' salaries, early-childhood programs, and new basic-skills tests, including a high school graduation exam. Schools that improved scores and attendance got cash bonuses; the state intervened in school districts whose scores and other indicators dipped below set levels.
South Carolina's law was similar in many respects to changes Governor Clinton made in Arkansas: increasing the sales tax to spend more money on education, setting higher academic standards, expanding early childhood programs, and raising teacher salaries. Yet experts rate South Carolina's education changes as the most comprehensive in the country.
And by comparison with Arkansas, another state ranked near the bottom by most measures of education, South Carolina's improvements were often remarkable, although they were powered by a more robust economy. From 1983-84 to 1989-90, per-pupil spending rose 50 percent after inflation, compared with 25 percent in Arkansas and in the United States as a whole; in the 1980's, teachers' salaries in South Carolina rose 25.6 percent, compared with 11.3 percent in Arkansas and 19.7 percent in the United States.
In 1983, just 42 percent of South Carolina's eighth graders passed a basic-skills math test and 56 percent passed a reading test. Teacher salaries, which averaged $16,523, and the state's per-pupil spending, $2,080, placed it 46th in the nation.
By 1991, 73 percent of students were passing the math test and 75 percent passing the reading test in eighth grade. Teacher salaries had risen to $28,340, 38th in the nation. Per-pupil spending increased to $4,537, 40th in the nation.
In addition to raising test scores, the education law and subsequent revisions fired public enthusiasm about education and created a coalition of politicians, business executives and educators that continues to push for improvement in the schools.
Mr. Riley wants to generate similar excitement about education nationwide. "We got so much into it, it really became a movement in our state," he said in an interview last week. "If you develop a feeling in this country of reaching for high standards and quality education throughout the system, an almost patriotic feeling -- that kind of an upswell has to come from national leadership."
 
Two Schools, Two Results
 Joseph Keels Elementary School in Columbia is a kind of showcase for Mr. Riley's educational improvements. Because it has continually improved test scores, the school has won state incentive awards that not only bought Keels Elementary rooms of new computers, but also prompted teachers to change how they were serving their mostly black, poor and working-class students.
The principal, Shirley Henderson, and a group of teachers decided to put $90,000 of their money into training teachers in new educational techniques. They also developed a program, including full-day kindergarten, to prevent early school failure. They won a grant to keep the computer lab open through the summer. And they began an after-school program for students whose parents need to leave them in school until 6 P.M.
The teachers are so enthusiastic they complete one another's sentences. "We are much better teachers than we were five years ago," said Ms. Day, the first-grade teacher. And Sandra McLain, a third-grade teacher who won a place on a national committee developing science curriculum standards, added, "But not as good as we will be tomorrow."
Fifty miles southeast of Columbia, here in Summerton, it is easier to see how far South Carolina has come and how far some parts still need to go. A rural town of worn wooden shacks, trailers and a handful of more gracious houses on the white side of town, Summerton has no industry and virtually no tax base. Change has come slowly to a town marred by continuing racial division and the political cronyism that comes when the school district is the biggest payroll in town.
Scotts Branch High School is in a cheerless, worn building of the 1950's, when it was built for black students in an effort to stave off desegregation. The money from the Educational Improvement Act bought the district new computers, remedial classes, and some classes for gifted children. Milton Marley, the superintendent, proudly cites the first two grants the schools have ever won for improving test scores this year and last year. The science classroom now has laboratory sinks and microscopes. But a sense of deprivation still hangs heavily here, as evident as the scarred and rutted linoleum.
A science teacher tries gamely to interest her students in a demonstration of convection and radiation. Students light candles, moving their hands above the flame as she coaxes them to guess how the heat is reaching their fingers. A kind of torpor pervades the classroom and the school.
 
Some Progress, But Not Enough
 As Mr. Riley sets out to apply some of the solutions he tried in South Carolina to the country, he may be guided by what worked and what did not in his home state. Mr. Riley intends to continue a push begun by the Bush Administration for national curriculum standards and a national testing system.
In South Carolina, Mr. Riley raised standards, but also poured money into remedial programs to help the one-third of the state's children who could not meet even basic-skills standards.
But educators in South Carolina are rethinking remedial programs because not enough students made progress, an experience that may influence Mr. Riley as he redesigns the biggest Federal remedial program for poor children, Chapter One.
South Carolina has also struggled with the highly charged issue of how to hold schools accountable for results and how best to measure student progress.
While many schools like Keels Elementary flourished under a system of rewards and punishments based on achievement, many educators continue to question whether the tests fairly measured student progress and whether they overemphasized basic skills.
Some school districts, feeling pressure to raise scores, based their curriculum on the tests and issued rigid guidelines. "You could go into a school district, and at 10 on Tuesday morning at every school in the district, teachers were all teaching the main idea in a paragraph," Mr. Norton said.
Mr. Riley's closest allies agree with the state's new Superintendent of Education, Barbara S. Nielsen, that schools now need to emphasize, and new tests need to measure, more sophisticated analytical skills. "We need problem solving, the ability to work on a team, the training necessary to understand work -- things you can't measure by filling in a bubble with a No. 2 pencil on the basic-skills test of our reform of 10 years ago," Mr. Youngblood said.
South Carolina has continued to revise its education laws as the state's needs have changed. A successor to the 1984 law, called Target 2000, was passed in 1989 under Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr., a Republican who succeeded Mr. Riley and remains a leader in education nationwide. The legislation offers grants to schools that emphasized some of these new skills and established an ambitious arts education program.
But there is a clear sense in South Carolina that deeper changes are needed. "It's time to refocus," said Mary Jones, superintendent of the Kershaw County School District, who helped plan the original 1984 law. "We tried to implement this on top of a system that was already in place that was not working."
And as Mr. Riley embarks on his new task, the question remains exactly how he will put into practice the lessons he learned in South Carolina.
"This reform was very progressive for its time," Mr. Norton said. "The question is, has he learned from that, and now does he see that was only part of the way home?"

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Wall St. seems to like Rochester Telephone's plan to split in two.

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
THE Rochester Telephone Corporation, a peanut in the elephantine world of telecommunications, is receiving a great deal of attention from Wall Street after proposing a bold plan to end its near-monopoly in local phone service in exchange for freedom from regulation that has hurt profits.
Under a plan filed in February with the New York Public Service Commission, Rochester Tel would split into two entities. One, a company known for filing purposes as R-Net, would run the phone network in Rochester and provide basic phone services to all comers -- a new Rochester Tel unit and new competitors. This other company, known for now as R-Com, would buy services from R-Net and resell them to the public with a greater chance of making higher profits. 
 New competitors in local service would buy services from R-Net on the same terms as R-Com. The plan affects about 30 percent of Rochester Tel's $804 million in 1992 revenue. Another 40 percent of its business involves local service in 14 other states, and the rest involves a Northeastern long-distance carrier and some cellular properties.
New York regulators are expected to begin hearings on the plan in the next month or so. But analysts say it may take a year or more before regulators finish reviewing the plan.
The company's stock had risen from $37.125 at the time of the announcement Feb. 3 to $38.375 on Friday. Yesterday, in what analysts said was profit taking, the stock fell $1 a share, closing at $36.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
To understand the local phone market, imagine that Procter & Gamble owned all the nation's laundry detergent factories, the trucks for delivering it, and the supermarket shelf space for the boxes. Competing against such a Procter & Gamble would be prohibitively expensive. But one alternative would be to have P.& G. lease factories and trucks to competitors while they build up their own companies.
That, in broad outline, is what happened with the breakup of A.T.& T. and what would also happen under Rochester Tel's plan.
The plan may well be a model for other local carriers. Like a more widely publicized plan by Ameritech, the regional Bell company in the Midwest, the Rochester Telephone plan is designed to position the carrier as a nimble competitor, hold down rates for residential customers and unlock value for shareholders.
Analysts say the smaller Rochester Tel is likely to encounter less resistance than Ameritech from regulators and potential competitors, giving its plan a better chance for approval.
Rochester Tel competitors would presumably come out of the woodwork if the plan was approved. Possible competitors include A.T.& T., MCI and Sprint, as well as small companies that serve businesses, like Metropolitan Fiber Systems and Teleport Communications Group.
Other competitors might be cable television companies. New equipment and digital technology would allow operators like Time Warner to offer phone service over much the same cable network that now carries television. Moreover, an alliance with a long-distance carrier like MCI could offer an attractive discount package of both local and long-distance service.
Under its plan, Rochester Tel would freeze phone rates until next year and then raise rates by no more than the inflation rate through 1997. Thus, Rochester Tel expects the typical $23 residential bill to rise slowly in the plan's first years.
John E. Money, telecommunications analyst at Argus Research in New York City, said the Rochester Tel plan "was absolutely and philosophically right on." If the plan is approved, he expects Rochester Tel's stock price to rise at least 10 percent to 15 percent and probably more.

HEADLINE: Japan Gets New Demands on Chip Imports

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, March 24

 BODY:
The United States pressed on Tuesday for continued improvement in sales of foreign-made computer chips in Japan, even though Tokyo had already met the main goal of a semiconductor trade agreement.
At a meeting in Hawaii, United States Government officials told the Japanese that it would be a "reasonable expectation" for foreign chip makers to average 20 percent of the Japanese market for all of 1993, according to one American official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. 
 But the Japanese Government, which fears that the semiconductor agreement will become a precedent for setting quotas in other trade treaties, said it would be "inappropriate" to set any new, specific targets.
The debate came at a meeting to assess progress of the 1991 semiconductor trade agreement between the United States and Japan, which called for American and other non-Japanese products to get 20 percent of Japan's semiconductor market by the end of 1992.
In a separate meeting in Hawaii between representatives of the American and Japanese electronics industries on Monday, the American manufacturers also called for new "quantifiable targets," saying that such goals were found to be clearly effective in opening Japan's market.
In newly calculated data that came as a shock to both sides late last week, the 20 percent goal was met in the fourth quarter of 1992, when the foreign market share jumped an unprecedented 4.3 percent, to 20.2 percent.
Although this gain may have been an aberration, it defused what had been expected to be a tense meeting with American officials threatening to impose trade sanctions on Japan.
Officials from both sides said that the meeting in Hawaii was constructive and that they had agreed on several steps to continue helping American and other non-Japanese semiconductor companies sell in Japan.
The United States conveyed the view of the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, that averaging 20 percent foreign share in 1993 would be a "reasonable expectation." But American officials did not seem to press this issue too hard, one Japanese negotiator said.
"They didn't ask anything concrete," the Japanese official said. "They just conveyed that message."
American officials say that achieving an average of 20 percent for 1993 would insure that foreign market share in Japan did not slip.
The fact that market share rose above 20 percent in the fourth quarter of 1992 was considered somewhat of a fluke. The Japanese companies, under severe prodding from their Government, made a last-ditch effort to buy more foreign chips. At the same time, the overall size of the Japanese market declined because of the economic slump here.
But if the economy recovers, foreign market share could fall again. Japanese officials are already saying that market share could be expected to "fluctuate" from now on.
The American officials say that the trade agreement calls for "steady and gradual" improvement in market access through the life of the agreement, which runs until 1996. The agreement also states that market share, which will continue to be calculated quarterly, is the main method used to measure progress in market access. Thus, they say, the agreement implies that market share should continue to improve.
Japanese officials are worried that the Clinton Administration will view the semiconductor agreement as a model for other agreements.
Although the Administration's trade policy is still unclear, President Clinton and advisers have at times talked about taking a tough approach to Japan.
At his news conference on Tuesday, President Clinton said "the persistence of the surplus the Japanese enjoy with the the United States and with the rest of the developed world can only lead one to the conclusion that the possibility of obtaining real, even access to the Japanese market is somewhat remote."

HEADLINE: A Risky Partnership

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
When President Clinton called the White House Monday from Little Rock, where he was visiting his critically ill father-in-law, several aides told him they thought he could conduct his first news conference today with only perfunctory reference to the crisis in Russia.
"Make a short statement, then say the situation is too delicate for further comment, that was the advice," one adviser reported today. 
 "But he didn't want to do that. He told us this was an issue he wanted to link himself to in a strong, positive, public way, not just through Administration spokesmen. He wanted to make Russian reform his cause as much as Boris Yeltsin's."
So that was what Mr. Clinton did, at this, his first full-dress news conference as President. The conference had been a long time in coming, but it was hardly his coming-out party; Mr. Clinton has been to a lot of dances already, answering questions in almost every setting imaginable in his first two months in office.
 
No Pomp in Old Circumstance
 Today, in the stagey East Room forum originally devised for Ronald Reagan, the President seemed loose and jolly, if understandably more guarded on the dicey situation in Russia than in discussing a wide range of other domestic and foreign topics.
There were hedges, of course, in his comments on the perils that the Russian President faces, notably an effort to identify the United States with all Russian democrats -- not just Mr. Yeltsin. But in promising to present a substantial aid program in the next few days and in passing the word that he would gladly meet Mr. Yeltsin in Moscow instead of in Canada if that would help, Mr. Clinton was taking a bold approach for one so inexperienced.
"We are not bystanders," he said. And at another point: "I intend to go in there with an aggressive and quite specific plan for American partnership."
Like many other American Presidents, Mr. Clinton sought to make Russians seem like Americans, a dubious proposition in the best of times. Of Muscovite-in-the-street interviews on television, he said: "They sound almost like our people might sound talking about some fight we were having here. They've been remarkably levelheaded about it, and I think we have to let it play out."
 
The Activist From Arkansas
 The difference, of course, is that Russia has no established institutions into which political animosities can be channeled. The potential for an explosion, in which the United States could be seriously hurt, is therefore great.
So if Mr. Clinton's approach is bold, it is also quite risky. The White House concedes that it has only limited power to help Mr. Yeltsin; as Mr. Clinton said today, it will be the Russians who will decide their own fate.
But the President thinks he must be seen to be trying to achieve all he can, even at the margins. He told a friend last week that it would be better to try and fail, than to sit on his hands and allow his critics to accuse him of having passively lost Russia, as Harry S. Truman's enemies for so many years accused him of having "lost" China.
Between now and April 25, the date of Mr. Yeltsin's referendum, one aide said, "help will have to be symbolic." Mr. Clinton's comments today were part of the symbolism, as will be the very fact of the summit meeting early next month. As things now stand, Vancouver, British Columbia, remains the site because, as the Russians have suggested strongly in the last 24 hours, moving it would make Mr. Yeltsin look too weak.
 
Trying to Round Up Aid
 The President is also reportedly preparing for a major effort to push Japan into a more cooperative position on the question of aid to Russia.
"They're going to have to drop their insistence on those islands," the aide added, alluding to Tokyo's demand that its long-standing territorial dispute with Moscow over four Kurile islands be settled before it discusses major aid for Russia.
In the diplomatic maneuvering over the next few weeks and months, the Administration would also like to win a commitment for further help from Germany. But the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl has already spent heavily to help the Soviet Union and then Russia, with only limited results, and it faces huge bills in modernizing eastern Germany.
The big question preoccupying American planners is how to get money past or around the Government in Moscow and into the hands of people who will put it to good use, whether to alleviate economic distress or to start new businesses.
With so few alternative channels open, and with the central bank's status unclear, no solutions are obvious, and selling aid to the American public will almost certainly require a convincing explanation of how it will reach worthy recipients rather than disappear into bureaucrats' pockets.
Mr. Clinton also faces some opposition from foreign-policy specialists; Henry A. Kissinger warned him in a Washington Post essay today to tread carefully. But he faces much more formidable resistance from a public that is weary of foreign adventures, skeptical about Russia and eager to use scarce resources to create jobs and improve health care at home.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Andrei V. Kozyrev, the Russian Foreign Minister, approached a stand of microphones to reassure reporters on the status of the coming summit meeting after he met with Secretary of State Warren Christopher. It will be a productive summit, he said. "Everything is O.K. and under control." (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Corn and Soybeans Climb On Strong Export Report

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Corn and soybean prices climbed yesterday on reports of strong American corn and soybean exports and hopes that President Clinton's support for President Boris N. Yeltsin might soon translate into agricultural aid for Russia.
In other commodity markets, pork prices retreated in the face of an increased supply, lumber and cotton prices sagged, and oil prices rebounded sharply. 
 Despite a thin burst of buying after President Clinton's first news conference, grain traders were reticent to put too much stake in Mr. Clinton's support of the Russian President, who faces possible impeachment.
Traders showed more immediate interest in United States corn exports, which are running well ahead of a year ago, said Dale Gustafson of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. A donation of 210,000 metric tons of corn to the former Soviet republics and a 200,000-metric- ton offer of subsidized corn to Ukraine helped the market.
May corn pushed through technical resistance at $2.26 to rise 2.75 cents, to $2.27 1/2 a bushel at the Chicago Board of Trade.
May soybeans also knocked down resistance at $5.91, the upper end of a two-month trading range. May soybeans jumped 6.25 cents, to $5.91 1/2 a bushel. Soybean buying was prompted by larger-than-expected weekly exports and weather-related delays in the South American crop.
Wheat prices retreated as traders evened up positions, with May finishing 1 cent lower at $3.40 a bushel.
Lumber futures fell steeply in light trading as the futures market for spruce continued to swing wildly. Mr. Clinton made reference to balancing competing interests regarding the timber industry. The May lumber contract dropped $3.40, to $424.50 for a thousand board feet at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
Oil prices rose in a technical bounce and the belief of many traders that supplies of oil products had declined in the latest week. Late yesterday, the American Petroleum Institute issued its weekly report showing that crude oil stocks had declined to 330.9 million barrels in the week ended March 19, from 343 million barrels the week before, while gasoline stocks had fallen to 232.9 million barrels, from 237.4 million barrels.
May crude oil rose 27 cents, to $20.03 a barrel. April heating oil gained 0.94 cent, to 58.11 cents a gallon, and April unleaded gasline firmed 0.86 cent, to 57.12 cents a gallon. April natural gas jumped 7.5 cents, to $2.117 for million British thermal units.
