HEADLINE: The Circus Is Just One of His Acts

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Consider, for a moment, the kaleidoscopic and far-flung interests of Kenneth Feld, owner of the world's largest live entertainment company.
A replica of the space shuttle that Mr. Feld owns and leases to the Kennedy Space Center is visited by 5,000 to 7,000 people a day and is now on its way to South Korea for an exposition. Ice skaters employed in his five Walt Disney World on Ice shows are twirling in arenas from Milwaukee to East Asia. 
 The illusionists Siegfried & Roy are in the third year of a record-breaking run at the Mirage Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev. The finishing touches are being put on a "George Lucas's Super Live Adventure," a multimedia spectacle that Mr. Feld is taking to Lucas-mad Japan in late April. And on Broadway, David Shiner and Bill Irwin are packing them in to "Fool Moon," a critically acclaimed comedy that Mr. Feld is co-producing.
And tomorrow, the cornerstone of Mr. Feld's business, the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, 123 years old and three rings full of brand-name recognition that rivals Kleenex and Coke, opens a five-week run at Madison Square Garden.
"We are the Wal-Mart of the entertainment business," Mr. Feld said in an interview in the small office his company keeps on West 45th Street in Manhattan. "We give a great product at the best price there is."
Mr. Feld has cause to sound satisfied.
At a time when much of show business is in retreat, victimized by recession, high ticket prices, television and videocassette recorders, Irvin Feld and Kenneth Feld Productions, the corporate umbrella under which the circus and all of Mr. Feld's other shows operate, had its best year ever in the 12 months ended Jan. 31, Mr. Feld said. And he says the prospects for 1993 seem bright.
"The trends for the first six months are incredible," Mr. Feld said. "I don't ever remember seeing anything like the increases we are seeing in terms of advanced ticket sales."
Price is one reason his shows remain so popular, Mr. Feld believes. In most of the 90 cities the circus plays each year, the top ticket costs $15. (Madison Square Garden is an exception; ringside seats cost $27.50).
"It's a business that is very price sensitive," Mr. Feld said. "If you raise prices by $1 a ticket you can see a reaction."
A privately held company, Feld Productions will not talk specifically about how much money it takes in, let alone how much it makes. Indeed, for the last six years Mr. Feld has told any reporter who asked that annual revenues were around $250 million.
"I used that number once, and then I decided not to give any more numbers out," he said. But other people who follow the company's operations say revenues are probably double that amount.
A slight, unassuming, engaging man, Mr. Feld, who is 44, has been running the company that owns the circus since 1984, when his father, Irvin, died.
Widely hailed as the "man who saved the circus," Irvin Feld, his brother Israel and Judge Roy Hofheinz, who built the Houston Astrodome, bought the ailing Ringling Brothers-Barnum & Bailey Combined Shows Inc. from John Ringling North in 1967 for $8 million.
 
Moved Circus Indoors
 None of the new owners had any circus experience. Irvin Feld, who had been promoting rock-and-roll concerts, made two decisions that were critical to the circus's future: to attract bigger crowds, Mr. Feld got rid of the big top and moved the circus indoors. And to keep his product fresh, and spread out production costs, he created a second unit in 1969.
One new show would be created each year, and each unit, the red and the blue, would be on the road for two years. Between them, the two circuses will do 550 shows in 90 cities across the country this year.
Those were not Irvin Feld's only innovations; he also created Ringling's Clown College in 1968, which Kenneth Feld likes to call "research and development spending."
"With an acrobat or an aerialist who perform a specific act, even if it's great or memorable, I still have a problem with them in the third year, because by then everybody has seen the act," he said. "But if I get a good clown I would like to keep him or her forever."
Now, Mr. Feld is thinking of creating a broader circus college to nurture talent, now that the collapse of Communism and the breakup of the Soviet Union have threatened the many state-supported circuses throughout Eastern Europe that have been a source of many Ringling acts.
 
Florida Elephant Farm
 An eye on the future also led Mr. Feld to set up a 20-acre elephant farm in Florida more than seven years ago. At age 123, the circus can fairly be called a mature enterprise. So to spur growth, Mr. Feld has chosen to stretch his entrepreneurial legs into areas of entertainment his father might not have considered. And he appears to have bolstered the company's huge concession operations, which add mightily to Ringling's bottom line.
"His father was far more conservative in nature," said Tim Holst, Ringling's vice president of talent and production. "Kenneth is pragmatic, but he will take far more risks. The ice shows were a tremendous risk, to take that many on the road and keep them out there. Kenneth handled all of that."
Some circus purists say such moves may make good business sense, but they fear that in the bargain the quality of the circus has suffered.
"Kenneth's father had a love affair with the circus that was beyond business," said John Culhane, author of "The American Circus." "He would pocket a loss if he brought something that was really great to the circus. You can count on getting your money's worth at a Kenneth Feld show, but I wonder if that sort of commitment is still there."
 
Bringing 'Movies to Life'
 The George Lucas project, which Mr. Feld has been working on for the last two and a half years, illustrates the kind of calculated risk he is willing to take.
Developing what he called "the biggest traveling arena show that has ever been done, one that brings the movies to life," will cost the company around $20 million. By choosing to open in Japan, where Mr. Lucas's films remain wildly popular more than five years after their release, Mr. Feld limited his exposure.
"It is 100 percent financed by the Japanese, and by sending it over there I have a six-month window over there to refine it, a period where in essence I can do no wrong," he said.
Based on the advance sale, Mr. Feld said he expected that the show, which will carry a top ticket price of $60, would be seen by at least one million people during its 22-week run.
In the United States, the show might tour, or it might be permanently based "someplace where there is a heavy, heavy tourist industry," Mr. Feld said.
And that is just one aspect of the company's overseas operations. The ice shows now perform in 22 countries, and Mr. Feld took the circus to Japan in 1989-90.
A change of rail gauges in Mexico will allow the circus to take a unit into Mexico next year, and Mr. Feld is planning to take a new, smaller unit to play in South America.
 
Made in Far East
 The company maintains extensive relationships with suppliers throughout the Far East from China to Taiwan. These factories manufacture everything from toys to plastic lights sold at the circus and the Disney ice shows.
"We sell four to five million lights a year," Mr. Feld said, at prices ranging from $8 to $10. The ubiquitous snow cone of chopped ice and syrup, Ringling's biggest seller, has been repackaged in a plastic mug with 3-D characters on the outside. It sells for $4.50, compared with 75 cents previously.
Indeed, the range of items offered at Ringling concession stands has grown so long that Mr. Feld has established a consumer hot line to field complaints. The concession business operates under the name of Sells-Floto.
Despite huge operating and production costs -- 350 people are on the road with each circus 48 weeks of the year, and developing a new show costs $9 million to $10 million annually -- Mr. Feld says the entertainment operations are profitable. But it seems certain that Sells-Floto, which operates separately from the entertainment arm, is the business that generates the bulk of the company's earnings.
"Concessions are a huge business in any entertainment industry," said Greg Parkinson, executive director of the Circus World Museum in Baraboo, Wis. "Ringling has developed it into an art form."
Bucking a longstanding tradition, Ringling last year stopped selling its wares at seats during a performance and shifted to stalls in arena lobbies. And Mr. Feld got his vendors to spruce up their personal appearance and to wear neckties.
Mr. Feld conducts seminars for his sales staff, pays them bonuses if sales are up from the previous years and says he is pleased with the results.
Still very much a hands-on operator who approves virtually everything that goes into his shows, Mr. Feld no longer travels as much as he once did, personally recruiting all the acts and performers he employs. And with an eye to the future, he has been transforming performers in his various shows into line executives.
Mr. Holst, for example, is a Clown College graduate who toured with the circus for 13 years before moving to Ringling's corporate headquarters in Tysons Corner, Va.
"The business has changed dramatically since my father died eight and a half years ago," Mr. Feld said. "It has grown by leaps and bounds, and you don't do that by yourself. I've got what I think are the best people in the business, and they are unique in that they have worked their way up through the business, and who know about the culture, the life style."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Retreats Broadly After Bundesbank's Move

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The German Bundesbank injected anxiety into the foreign exchange market yesterday with an interest-rate announcement that sent the dollar skidding against the German mark and most other major European currencies.
Meanwhile, the Japanese yen, after spurting overseas to another record postwar high against the dollar, lost some of its gains in New York. Traders grew less nervous that major industrialized nations favor a higher yen as a way to trim Japan's trade deficit. 
 Gold prices retreated after moving higher Monday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery closed at $331.90 a troy ounce, down $1. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $331.60 a troy ounce, off $1.10 from late Monday.
During European currency trading, Germany's central bank announced an agreement to repurchase money market securities as a way to supply banks short of cash with fresh funds.
Currency traders feared the resulting demand for short-term securities would drive German rates higher, further hurting demand for dollars after last week's disappointing rate cut by the Bundesbank.
"We're all on the edge of our chairs trying to figure out what will be going on tommorow," said Robert Ryan, senior trader at the Bank of New York.
In European trading, the dollar fell to 1.6312 German marks from late Monday's 1.6375. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.6303 marks at 4 P.M., down from late Monday's 1.6380.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at another record low of 115.33 yen, down 0.69 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 115.70 yen. But the dollar rose in New York to 115.95 yen from late Monday's 115.63 yen.
The dollar rose against the British pound. In London, the pound fell to $1.4840, from $1.4880 late Monday. Later in New York, the pound fetched $1.4840, less than late Monday's $1.4870.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, were: 1.5105 Swiss francs, down from 1.5140; 5.5475 French francs, down from 5.5705; 1,579.00 Italian lire, down from 1,581.00, and 1.2473 Canadian dollars, unchanged from late Monday.

HEADLINE: The Right Stuff for Russia

BYLINE: By Bill Bradley; Bill Bradley, Democrat, is senior Senator from New Jersey.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The need to clarify U.S. policy toward Russia has been heightened by the political crisis in Moscow. Our long-term interests there can be promoted by practical aid and people-to-people programs.
Boris Yeltsin's solution to the impasse between a popularly elected President and a Parliament that, under the Constitution, is the supreme organ of the state shows he believes the answer to the problems of emerging democracy is more democracy. He has cast his fate on the seas of his own waning but still significant popularity. 
 In an atmosphere in which individuals regularly switch opinions and sides, the U.S. should not try to intervene in Russia's day-to-day politic concerns such as: Should the Parliament impeach Mr. Yeltsin in light of the Constitutional Court's ruling yesterday that his announcement of emergency powers violated the Constitution? Should concessions be made for the support of Vice President Aleksandr Ruskoi? Russians, not Americans, will decide these problems. But Washington ought to keep open the lines of communication to all sides.
Beyond the political drama are the large issues that Russian society is debating: whether it should seek integration with the West or exist apart from the West. Whether it will focus inward on its gargantuan economic, environmental and ethnic problems or look imperially toward the former republics of the Soviet Union and beyond.
Whether free enterprise and private property will be actively promoted or barely tolerated. Whether more power should be dispersed to the oblasts and autonomous republics of the Russian Federation or exercised exclusively from Moscow.
Whether Russia should adopt a model of economic development that is economically and politically liberal or one in which, like China, it would seek Western capital, technology and markets but deny individual freedom while preserving collectivist controls.
If Russia opts for the Chinese model, America and Europe could end up espousing open trade, free markets and democracy but be unable, in the 21st century, to advance our values and compete freely in a vast area from Kaliningrad to Shanghai that plays by different rules and starts from different cultural principles.
I hope President Clinton thinks about the long term. Since August 1991, America has moved at a dangerously slow pace, giving Russians who want to retard reform an opportunity to blame us for our empty promises.
To play a more constructive role, we need to see America's relationship with Russia beyond tomorrow's headlines and with emphasis on improving the lives of American and Russian citizens.
With the defeat of Communism, there is no ideological conflict between our nations. We should make it absolutely clear that we support both Russia and our own values. This means respecting the human rights of the 25 million Russians who live as minorities in the former Soviet republics, avoiding encouragement to the movements for self-determination in the 20 autonomous republics of the Russian Federation such as Checheno-Ingush and Tatarstan, and giving Russian history and culture the respect they deserve.
Such actions will make clear to all Russians that we are not anti-Russian. It was the expansionist Communist system, not Russian culture, that we opposed.
America's values and interests are served by helping Russia become a democracy with a market-oriented economy that raises its living standards, with a smaller defense establishment, with a firm commitment to guarantee individual human rights and with the acceptance of free-flowing capital, trade and ideas.
In other words, our objective should be to normalize relations with Russia and the other former Soviet republics and to bring them into the international system as full members.
Russia's main worry lies to the east, where an emerging Chinese colossus with a booming economy and a modernizing military maintains its territorial claims on Russia, and to the south, where the peoples of Islam, full of religious fervor and rapid birth rates, yearn for greatness. A strong U.S.-Russian relationship can reassure Russia and hedge against changes that would injure U.S. interests in Europe and Asia.
The Clinton Administration should adopt a tangible and nonbureaucratic program that has a permanent effect and not only helps Russia but also Ukraine, the Baltics, Kazakhstan and the other former republics on the road to reform.
With U.S. leadership, the West should reduce the burden of foreign debt on the economy by rescheduling it, which the Administration apparently is contemplating, and promoting debt-equity swaps; it should replace the 17 Chernobyl-type reactors that are time bombs threatening Europe and the world with radioactive emissions, and send far more humanitarian aid (medicine, food, infant formula, syringes) for pensioners and children.
In addition, the World Bank should provide insurance coverage (similar to that offered by the Overseas Private Investment Corporation) to private investors in the farming and energy sectors. We need to push multilateral financing for trade in oil and gas equipment, and provide additional assistance to nuclear scientists and scientific institutes to convert from military to civilian pursuits.
We should help Russian refugees from the former Soviet republics get resettled and started in private farming by giving the green light to lending by the World Bank, and should combine help for a social safety net with radical monetary reform that could stabilize the ruble, provided that Russia caps its money supply and controls inflation.
In addition to its support for international financial institutions, this program would cost the U.S. $3 billion to $5 billion a year: between 1 and 2 percent of our defense budget.
The most important long-term consideration is to maximize the personal ties of Russians, Ukrainians, Balts, Kazakhs and others with Americans. A Russian friend in Moscow said: "In the 1930's, when the Soviet Union was building Stalinist Communism, thousands of Americans came to Russia to help. Now, when we're trying to build a market-oriented democracy, few Americans offer to help. Why?" I did not have a good answer.
We should begin a large-scale exchange program bringing tens of thousands of Russians here annually. Last year, there were nearly 50,000 Chinese in our colleges, as there has been for a decade, and 127,000 students from Taiwan, Japan, India and Singapore. There were only 1,200 Russians.
Nothing short of a large-scale sharing of ideas, people and training will accomplish our goals of economic prosperity and political security for Russia, its neighbors and ourselves.
I hope that President Clinton encourages Americans to reach out generously toward the peoples of Russia, Ukraine and the other republics. There should be 30,000 Russian high school students living with American families for a year, 10,000 Russians in small business in towns across America, 10,000 college students at our universities and thousands of former military officers learning modern banking, finance and accounting in the West.
We can help young people learn what life in a market-oriented democracy with a heart is all about. They will see America's openness, generosity and pride at work. Their experience would bring our peoples together in countless ways, creating bonds that would last a lifetime. As the Russians get ready to decide their future in the streets or, preferably, at the ballot box, we should step forward on many fronts with solid help for their country.

HEADLINE: Small Businesses Need More Time for New Insurance Law

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am outraged that the New York State Legislature has enacted a community rating insurance law which will have a devastating effect on the state's small businesses. Because of it my company will lose health insurance April 1. We were insured by Liberty Mutual and informed of what to expect in mid-February. 
 The alternative is to see the family policy rise to $11,500 a year and our individuals rate rise by $2,400. Since I cannot afford to pay these costs, the alternative is to pass them on to our employees. Is that what the Legislature had in mind, at a time when the only sector of business that is attempting to grow in New York is small business?
With most major corporations in New York cutting back, downsizing and laying off, the only hope is the small-business community, and this is the very group targeted. The law applies only to companies with fewer than 50 employees. The net result will be more unemployment and no hiring by small businesses.
The idea to create a fair system of health insurance is good, but the execution, timing and targeted group does not make sense. Instead of spreading the risk, we have lost 10 major insurance carriers, crippled small business and forced employees to absorb exorbitant costs or face no insurance coverage at all. This law will surely add to the country's uninsured population.
Since my business started in 1981, I have watched our rates rise by 500 percent before enactment of this law. The problem is not our employees. The problem lies with an abusive legal and medical system. Instead of trying to curtail the problem, the Legislature has put the burden on the little guy. To compound matters, because of my company's corporate status, I cannot as a principal and officer deduct my insurance and will be taxed additionally on this new higher rate. So will my employees if a cap on health insurance benefits paid by employers is enacted.
What happens April 1, when many small businesses have not had ample time to secure other health insurance? What happens to their employees, to their families? Has the Legislature, in its haste to enact this law, thought about those who will have medical problems and emergencies, and how they will cope with the tragedy our Legislature has handed them?
It is imperative that this deadline be extended, so that we can provide for our employees, and the insurance industry can adjust and prepare in some way other than a state of panic and confusion.
 
JEFFREY A. HEATH
New York, March 11, 1993
The writer is president of Management Recruiters of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Clinton Would Consider Segregating Gay Troops;
Remarks Are Contrast With Earlier Stand on the Military

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
Facing resistance from the military over his pledge to allow homosexuals to serve in the armed forces, President Clinton said for the first time today that he would consider proposals to segregate troops by sexual orientation.
Mr. Clinton's comments at a White House news conference contrasted sharply with his public statements during the Presidential campaign and in the first days after he was elected. Mr. Clinton said then without qualification that he would end discrimination against homosexuals in the military. 
 The President's remarks surprised people on both sides of the issue and raised eyebrows in the Pentagon, where officials studying ways to deploy gay soldiers said they had never considered segregation a serious option.
 
Alarm and Welcome
 Organizations that had been urging Mr. Clinton to reverse the ban on homosexuals expressed alarm, saying his comments reflected a retreat. But opponents welcomed the President's remarks for the same reason, citing them as evidence that Mr. Clinton was giving in to pressure from top generals who have asserted that the ban was needed to preserve military discipline and spirit.
Shortly after taking office, Mr. Clinton had sought to put the controversy to rest by delaying immediate action on his pledge, instructing Les Aspin, the Defense Secretary, to write a new policy by July 15 that would examine whether homosexuals should be barred from ground combat and warships, as women are now. In recent weeks, Mr. Clinton has avoided public discussion of the issue.
Asked by reporters whether he would support segregation of homosexual members of the service, Mr. Clinton referred to the report being drafted in the Pentagon. "That depends on what the report says," he said. "That's why I'm waiting for the Secretary of Defense to issue the report. But I wouldn't rule that out, depending on what the grounds and arguments were." [Transcript, pages A9-A10.]
 
Supreme Court Nomination
 Mr. Clinton did not comment on how homosexuals might be separated from heterosexuals -- in separate units or separate living quarters within the same unit.
Mr. Clinton addressed several other domestic issues, including how he would select a replacement for Justice Byron R. White, who has announced his retirement from the Supreme Court. Asked whether he would ask potential nominees their position on abortion, Mr. Clinton said: "I will not ask anybody how they will vote in a specific case. I will endeavor to appoint someone who has an attachment to a belief in a strong and broad right to constitutional privacy."
The President also said he thought that most Americans would pay "a little more" in taxes for a better health-care system. As the Senate voted today on the framework of his budget, he predicted that he would persuade reluctant Senators to vote for his economic plan this week.
He also said that in the coming days he would propose eliminating the practice of evading campaign spending limits through big contributions to political parties rather than candidates. And he said his efforts to resolve the longstanding dispute over protection of spotted owls in the Northwest's timber country "will probably make everybody mad."
 
On the Defensive
 It was the questions on homosexuals in the military that seemed to put the President the most on the defensive, to the point that he found himself defending his ability to lead the armed forces. "No, I don't have a problem being Commander in Chief," he insisted. Dismissing the notion that his not having served in the military had generated some opposition to his proposal to end the ban against homosexuals, he said, "A lot of service officers disagreed with the position on gays in the military before I even took office."
While Mr. Clinton said he would wait until the Pentagon report was completed before making a decision on whether gay soldiers should be treated differently from heterosexual ones, groups on both sides said his comments raised the prospect that he was backing away from his initial stand, that soldiers should be punished or rewarded on the basis of conduct and job performance, not sexual orientation.
Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the chairman of the Armed Forces Committee who is Mr. Clinton's chief foe on allowing openly gay people in the military, suggested recently that he opposed even permitting the segregation of homosexual soldiers. He said he feared that would be unconstitutional.
Mr. Clinton disputed that notion today, saying, "The courts have traditionally given wide berth to the military to make judgments of that kind in terms of duty assignments."
Recently, Mr. Clinton toured a warship for the first time when he flew to the carrier Theodore Roosevelt off Norfolk, Va. During the tour he viewed the triple-decker berths in the crew's sleeping quarters. Administration officials said that caused the President to begin rethinking his position.
Thomas S. Stoddard, coordinator of the Campaign for Military Service, a coalition opposing the military's ban, said the President's comments were "slightly alarming." But he added, "I believe on study and reflection, the President would reject any distinction based on sexual orientation."
Senator Dan Coats, an Indiana Republican who favors keeping the ban and opposes a compromise on segregation, said: "I'm hoping that this is a thoughtful reconsideration of whether or not this is the time to have the Pentagon preoccupied with this subject. The President is discovering that this is a far more complex and difficult issue than he initially realized."
 
Criticism of Japan
 George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said the President had not made any decision about whether to support segregating the troops, but that "he's certainly saying that he's open to it."
Fielding questions on other topics at the news conference, Mr. Clinton issued a surprisingly harsh condemnation of Japan's trade surplus with the United States, which reached $49.42 billion last year. "The persistence of the surplus the Japanese enjoy with the United States and with the rest of the developed world can only lead one to the conclusion that the possibility of obtaining real, even access to the Japanese market is somewhat remote," he said.
By contrast, the Bush Administration and many economists have contended that the size of the trade surplus has less to do with the openness of the Japanese market than with macroeconomic problems in the United States, such as a low savings rate here.

HEADLINE: New York State Plan Would Require Jobs To Be Part of School

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
The New York State Commissioner of Education is proposing to make work as integral a part of the requirements for high school graduation as math, reading and science.
The proposal is intended to address concerns that public schools are not giving students even basic job skills. If it is approved by the State Board of Regents on Friday, New York would become the first state in the nation to require high school juniors and seniors to work before they graduate, according to the National Governors Association. 
 What Dr. Thomas Sobol, the Commissioner of Education, is asking the Regents to endorse is a broad policy change to include work in the school day and as a prerequisite for a diploma. Details of how the plan would work -- including how many hours students would be required to work, what kinds of jobs would qualify for graduation credits and how jobs would be found for every one of the state's more than 300,000 juniors and seniors -- have not been decided.
But the proposal would in the most basic sense change the way schools teach, refocusing education to include work experience and lessons about work skills in all curriculums and calling on private businesses and labor unions to participate. If the plan is approved, it would be put into place gradually in schools around the state over the next five years.
Under Dr. Sobol's proposal, the work programs could vary widely from district to district and student to student. One senior might work as an apprentice to a welder, another as a part-time lab technician and a third as a manager of a student-run business.
 
Job Skills AreIs Goal
 In all cases, though, the goal would be the same: to give students a taste of the work world, to teach them specific job skills and to prepare them for a job market in which even entry-level jobs can require advanced knowledge of math, science and computers.
"We have reached a point in history when social and economic trends create a crisis for many young people in the transition from education to employment," Dr. Sobol wrote in his report to the Regents. "Research, our constituents and the public tell us that students are not prepared for this new workplace as well as they should be."
The proposal, which the Commissioner's staff has worked on for the last two years, has triggered a debate in Albany and across the state over the role of public education in preparing students for work.
Proponents, including many labor unions, say America is losing high-paying jobs because its high school graduates are less skilled than their European and Japanese peers.
"You can see that systems in these other countries produce kids vastly more skilled at 18 than American kids are at 26 or 27," said Marc S. Tucker, the president of the National Center on Education and the Economy, a think tank in Rochester. "It's a pretty big difference with major implications not only for the economy but also for the kids."
But critics, including organizations representing school boards and principals, say a work program will add a new layer of responsibility for administrators already spread thin by state mandates. But more fundamentally, they contend that the program will make public schools less a training ground for the mind than for business.
"Having students work for credit is making schools into something they are not," said Louis Grumet, the executive director of the New York State School Boards Association. "Schools are there to have kids learn and think and create. If they are working, when are they going to do those things?"
 
Work Force Considered
 The Commissioner's proposal -- which integrates the findings of a series of studies in recent years by various state agencies and committees, including one headed by Lieut. Gov. Stan N. Lundine -- comes as states are considering ways to better prepare students for the work force. In addition to the work experience, the proposal would also require lessons about work skills, like managing time, handling money and using computers, in all courses at all grades. All student would then have to have assessments of those work skills by the 10th grade to insure they have mastered basic jobs skills.
Jack A. Kadamus, the Assistant Commissioner for the Office of Workforce Preparation and Continuing Education, said that the idea was not to track some students into vocational training and others into college, but rather to prepare all students to work in an increasingly technical world, especially those students who do not go on to college.
"That's not necessarily getting done in schools now," he said.
 
Flexibility Is Stressed
 If approved, the proposal, which would initially cost $1.2 million, would create six pilot projects in the fall of 1993, like one already begun by Cornell University at six schools in Broome County.
Mr. Kadamus said the details of the work programs would have to be worked out by the Commissioner's staff over the next few years as the pilot programs begin -- and in the end would leave room for school districts to mold them to their needs.
"We don't have a set model," he said. "We have a set of ideas, of principles, we're asking the Regents to adopt."
Mr. Lundine, whose task force on work and education last year offered many of the same sort of recommendations integrated into Dr. Sobol's proposal, said that with the proposals New York would take the national lead in training all students to compete in the work force.
"We have largely ignored what has been called the forgotten half, the students who do not go on to college," Mr. Lundine said. "I think this is going to be one of the most important and most thorough reforms adopted in education in decades, perhaps this century."

HEADLINE: SENATE DEMOCRATS UNIFIED ON BUDGET

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Democratic Senators held ranks today and defended President Clinton's economic program against a fierce volley of political potshots from Republicans.
By a vote of 52 to 47, the Democrats rejected the most serious Republican threat to the Clinton budget plan, an amendment that would have scrapped the President's proposal to raise taxes on the Social Security benefits of the most affluent retirees. Only four Democrats voted against the President. 
 But as Congress neared approval of the Clinton plan, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, called for even deeper cuts in the budget deficit, saying he feared that it would rise again late in the decade. [Page D1.]
Today's vote on the Social Security benefits was an important test because it showed that for the time being Democrats were willing to stand fast behind the President, even on the most difficult issue politically.
The Democrats also defeated a Republican proposal for much deeper spending cuts than those Mr. Clinton wants, more spending for the military and none of the Clinton tax increases. The vote, basically along party lines, was 57 to 42.
The Republican amendments came as the Senate was considering the outline of Mr. Clinton's budget. Their defeat showed beyond doubt that the basic budget plan would be approved intact on Thursday. The more crucial votes -- on exactly which taxes will be raised and which programs cut -- will not come until later in the year.
 
Vote on Spending Plan
 After the budget vote on Thursday, the Senate will take up Mr. Clinton's $16 billion spending bill, which is intended to stimulate the economy and create jobs over the next two years. The discipline displayed by Democrats today indicated that the stimulus package would probably pass, but Senators said the President might have to accept some modest compromises to get it through.
The House of Representatives approved slightly different versions of the budget plan and the stimulus bill last week. The differences between the House and Senate measures will be reconciled by conference committees.
To underscore the importance of the Social Security vote and how close the outcome had been expected to be, Vice President Al Gore made a rare appearance to preside over the Senate this morning in case his vote was needed to break a tie.
But the debate on the budget in general and the Social Security amendment in particular lacked the emotion that might have been expected on such sensitive topics. Senators from both parties tried harder to score politically than to illuminate the issues involved.
A higher tax on the Social Security benefits of some retirees is a central part of the Clinton plan to cut the budget deficit. The President would increase the portion of Social Security benefits that are subject to income taxes to 85 percent from 50 percent for couples with total incomes, including retirement benefits, of more than $32,000 and single retirees with incomes above $25,000. The Social Security payments of taxpayers with incomes below those thresholds are not now taxed and would not be under the Clinton plan.
Social Security has been the heart and soul of the Democratic Party's philosophy for more than 50 years, and rare is the Democratic politician who has not used the issue to gain leverage over Republican opponents.
 
Prime Time Debate
 So this time Republicans tried to turn the tables. With the debate on Tuesday night televised live in prime time on C-Span, the cable channel, they flailed at the Democrats with one oratorical jab after another.
"Our nation's seniors did not create this budget deficit; Congress did," Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, said in an almost empty Senate chamber. "I will not be party to balancing the budget on the backs of our nation's seniors."
Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, said the President's proposal made a mockery of his campaign promise not to raise income taxes on anyone but the very wealthy. And Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, even accused Mr. Clinton of wanting to tax the elderly on the potential income they could get if they rented their homes, an accusation that had no basis in fact but was meant to stick in the craw of the television viewers.
Democrats for the most part stayed away from the debate, apparently confident they had the votes to beat back the Republican onslaught. But occasionally they entered the fray, saying that the deficit had to be reduced and that the best course was to follow the Clinton prescription. The higher Social Security tax would raise more than $30 billion over five years, one of the largest tax increases in the President's plan.
 
Democratic Counterattack
 "Our colleagues are now making an effort to derail President Clinton's momentum," Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, said when the Senate went back into session this morning. "Do we want to give President Clinton a chance, or do we want to torpedo President Clinton's program before it gets under way?"
The only Democrats who voted with the Republicans were Howell Heflin and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and Bob Krueger of Texas. A fifth, Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, was absent.
But the Democrats had some partisan gamesmanship up their sleeves also. After the Social Security vote, Senators Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and Jim Exon of Nebraska offered an amendment that they termed a compromise. It expressed "the sense of the Senate" that the Finance Committee should try to find a way not to raise the taxes of single retirees with incomes below $32,000 and couples with incomes below $40,000.
The amendment was approved, 67 to 32, with every Democrat in favor except Charles S. Robb of Virginia, who voted "no," and Mr. Inouye, who was absent.
"Sense of the Senate" measures have no binding effect and are often ignored after the vote is taken, but Senator Lautenberg immediately issued a news release taking credit for liberating more than one million retirees from the effect of the proposed new tax.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN MOSCOW;
Clinton Meets Russian On Assistance Proposal

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia asked President Clinton today to help stabilize his country's teetering economy by purchasing its oil, lifting trade restrictions, rescheduling the repayment of its debt and lobbying for the country's admission to the club of industrialized nations.
Mr. Clinton in turn pledged to continue his efforts on behalf of Russia by telephoning foreign leaders, asking Americans for support for an extensive economic aid package and avoiding potentially inflammatory comment on Russia's political turmoil. 
 In an Oval Office meeting intended to signal Mr. Clinton's seriousness about supporting President Boris N. Yeltsin in the crisis, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kozyrev discussed ways to speed the development of the Administration's proposal, which is expected to be announced before the summit meeting scheduled 10 days from now in Vancouver, British Columbia.
In a speech at American University today and in the meeting with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Kozyrev insisted that his country did not want American "aid." "We want specific projects, but not a sum of money," he said.
Rather, he outlined the broad cooperation Russia is hoping for, and while Administration aides would not comment on specific suggestions, they later said they had not ruled out any of them.
 
Help 'in Our Interest'
 "It is very much in our interest to keep Russia a democracy, to keep moving toward market reforms, and to keep moving toward reducing the nuclear threat," Mr. Clinton said before he met with Mr. Kozyrev. "It will save the American people billions of dollars in money we don't have to spend maintaining a nuclear arsenal, if we can continue to denuclearize the world.
"It will make the American people billions of dollars in future trade opportunities," he said. "And it will make the world a safer place."
The Administration has been trying to emphasize the benefits of such support over the potential costs.
"The notion of providing help is unpopular in the United States -- and in Russia, as a matter of fact," Mr. Kozyrev said, "so we discussed opportunities for cooperating between two great countries. And what is very important, that President Clinton is very action-oriented, he is very businesslike, and he just is not about to talk. I feel that he is about to act."
 
Talks With Other Leaders
 Mr. Clinton spoke about the Russian aid issue by telephone with Prime Ministers John Major of Britain and Brian Mulroney of Canada. Canada and France have been pushing to move up the date of the economic summit meeting scheduled for July in Tokyo to address Russian aid. But the United States and Britain appear to be leaning toward Japan's stand that a meeting of foreign and finance ministers should be held in mid-April.
Mr. Kozyrev proposed a "concrete program of action" that would include lifting trade restrictions on high technology exports, working together with the United States on military conversion projects and developing a timetable for debt rescheduling.
"Cooperation in the area of conversion of Russian and U.S. defense industries may become the driving force in the entire program," Mr. Kozyrev said. "Joint efforts to dismantle the bloated military-industrial complexes of both sides will go a long way toward building confidence and symbolizing the end of confrontation."
Mr. Clinton said today that he was planning to speak with Mr. Yeltsin. Their last communication came on Tuesday when Mr. Clinton sent condolences on the death of Mr. Yeltsin's mother.
In an interview tonight on the CBS News program "48 Hours," President Clinton was asked whether he thought Mr. Yeltsin would hold onto his office.
He responded: "He's a very resilient fellow, you know. He's like all of us in public life. He is not perfect. I'm not perfect. We all have our problems. But he is a genuinely courageous man, genuinely committed to freedom and democracy, genuinely committed to reform, and I think now he is more open perhaps than in the past to try and work out some kind of accommodation with others who would negotiate with him to keep reform going even though they may have some different ideas."
After the White House meeting today, Mr. Kozyrev signaled that Mr. Yeltsin was willing to meet with Parliament members who have opposed his reforms.
"It is for Russians and Russian people to pass final judgment, and the President calls for a vote, a popular vote," he said. "And I think this will be the decisive event. But on the whole the President is always open to compromise with those political forces who are not out to just reverse the reform and revanche the democracy."
On the question of Russian admission into the group of seven industrialized nations, some members have spurned American suggestions that its membership be expanded.
Mr. Kozyrev said the question was still "on the table."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher would not endorse the idea of Russia's joining, but said its role in the coming meeting would be "very important."

HEADLINE: U.S. IS CUTTING AID TO LATIN DRUG WAR

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Congress and the Clinton Administration are quietly reversing a Bush Administration anti-drug initiative that sent hundreds of millions of dollars to South American governments.
In January, Democrats in Congress slashed military and economic assistance for Peru, Colombia and Bolivia after concluding that the program was failing to produce the desired effect: encouraging the South American nations to reduce production of drugs, principally coca leaf and its refined product, cocaine. 
 Now the White House is preparing to go further as part of an extensive classified review of Government programs aimed at stopping drug shipments before they enter the United States. The expected additional cutbacks would represent a substantial step away from the Bush strategy, introduced in 1989, which focused on halting cocaine trafficking at its source.
 
Shift to Domestic Programs
 Officials involved in the review of the $3 billion international drug-fighting budget said it was the first step in of a Clinton Administration plan to shift anti-drug resources from foreign intervention to domestic programs -- education, treatment, and local and state law enforcement -- intended to reduce the demand for drugs in the United States.
One sign of a new approach to drug fighting came shortly after Mr. Clinton's inauguration, when he ordered a severe cut in the size of the drug policy office. Although he promised to elevate its new director to Cabinet rank, he has not yet nominated anyone to fill the job, and officials said the White House and its National Security Council staff had begun to take charge of the spending debate.
No final decisions have been reached in the review of international drug policy, and some officials insisted that budget figures being prepared by the Administration for next year appeared to leave intact some international drug-fighting programs, including overseas operations of the Drug Enforcement Administration.
But representatives of the Departments of State and Defense, the Drug Enforcement Administration and other agencies were said to be struggling in anticipation of the expected realignment to protect their own programs at others' expense.
 
Worry Over Deeper Cuts
 Officials described an atmosphere of unease they said had been created by the aid cutbacks and the expectation that the White House review will lead to wider drug-budget reductions.
"Everyone thought that narcotics was sort of a sacred cow and that there might just be some tinkering here and there," said one top official involved in drug-control efforts. "Frankly, all this has caught everyone just a little bit flat-footed."
The study is one of more than two dozen being conducted by the new Administration on different aspects of national security policy. But officials said the drug policy review was one of the more highly charged of the studies because it follows a a near-doubling in anti-drug spending under the Bush Administration, with the sharpest increases in international drug-fighting programs.
Officials said the efforts by Congress and the White House to cut the anti-drug assistance to Peru, Bolivia and Colombia reflected a recognition that coca crops and cocaine production remained virtually undiminished despite the extensive transfer of weapons, military training and economic aid to those countries since 1989.
 
Some Gains in Colombia
 Colombia in particular has made some progress in tracking down drug traffickers. But the officials said all the programs were vulnerable to an increasing public aversion to foreign aid programs, even when used to help fund a drug war that once seemed sacrosanct.
Under final allotments made by Congressional appropriations committees without objection from Clinton aides, the United States this year will dispatch no more than $174 million in counter-narcotics aid to the three Andean countries, a 35 percent cut from last year's total. The package represents 45 percent of what the Bush Administration had requested.
The cuts have set off quiet protests from each of three nations, which regard United States aid as essential to their efforts to reduce coca farming and the production and export of cocaine.
The Government's overall anti-drug budget -- more than $12 billion this year -- doubled in size under Mr. Bush, with the international programs the fastest growing part. The Pentagon alone received a quadrupling in spending on military efforts to detect drug trafficking abroad, and the direct aid given to the three Andean countries soared from almost nothing in 1989 to the Bush Administration's record request for $387 million for this fiscal year. It was this request that the Congressional Democrats cut back in January.
 
Charges of Fund Diversion
 But the assistance programs have also run into controversy, with South American governments accused of diverting some of the military aid to fight guerrillas instead of drug traffickers. Peru and Bolivia, which together account for more than 90 percent of the world's coca supply, have also repeatedly failed to meet the eradication targets set by the United States as a condition for economic aid.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Protect a Songbird But Give Builders Leeway

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 24

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration will play the first major card in its environmental policy Thursday by proposing to list a small Southern California songbird as threatened rather than endangered.
The Administration's action on the bird, the California gnatcatcher, has been widely expected as a sign of a new policy direction toward protecting species while also encouraging economic growth. The decision is to be announced in Washington by Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, who oversees the Fish and Wildlife Service. 
 An advance copy of the new rule provided by environmentalists shows that Mr. Babbitt will designate the bird as "threatened" under the Endangered Species Act, a status that requires less stringent measures of protection than the designation of "endangered."
 
Thousands of Jobs at Stake
 The four-inch-long gnatcatcher has emerged as the chief symbol of the clash between endangered species and economic development. Developers have been fighting Federal protection because the bird occupies 200,000 acres of prime housing land in depressed Southern California; its listing could affect thousands of construction jobs. Environmentalists have petitioned to give the bird the endangered listing, saying that 90 percent of its habitat has been destroyed and that only 2,000 pairs of the birds remain in the state.
The "threatened" listing will allow Mr. Babbitt to issue a special rule whereby developers can destroy the bird's habitat in some areas if they agree to participate in a new state program that might require them to give up other land deemed crucial to the bird's survival. The program would set aside a large enough area to preserve the coastal sage scrub ecosystem inhabited by the gnatcatcher; theoretically, this would not only insure the survival of the bird but also avert legal battles over other dwindling plants and animals in the ecosystem.
 
Looking for Compromise
 Mr. Babbitt has been pressing for such an approach to species protection all over the country. The gnatcatcher is the first animal for which he has drawn an actual rule. The Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group based in New York, had petitioned to list the bird as endangered, a step that would have made further development in four Southern California counties extremely difficult. With the consent of the council, Mr. Babbitt did not meet the March 17 deadline to respond to the listing petition while he worked out a political compromise.
Mr. Babbitt's action tries to mesh the Federal law with the new California program mounted by Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, to allow housing projects to proceed if developers agree to set aside land to preserve the central ecosystems of certain species.
It remains to be seen how developers and their environmental adversaries will respond to the proposed ruling, which is contingent on adoption of five-year interim guidelines for the land involved. The guidelines, being prepared by a scientific review panel appointed by the state, would govern exactly how much development could take place while the habitat is fully studied.

HEADLINE: Durables Orders Up 2.2% in Month

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Offering fresh evidence that the economy is gaining strength, the Commerce Department reported yesterday that February orders for durable goods -- factory machinery, aircraft, autos, military hardware and other expensive, long-lasting items -- rose a healthy 2.2 percent, the fourth increase in the last six months.
But like most recent Government reports, this latest measure of the economy's health also suggested weaknesses that could dilute the recovery in coming months. 
 Orders for new commercial aircraft, for example, go up one month and down the next. In February, they rose very sharply, after having fallen in January. Excluding aircraft, durable goods orders fell by seventh-tenths of 1 percent in February.
"It is hard to say what this mix of numbers is telling us, but they seem to be saying that the economy does not look bad," said Kathleen Menth, supervisor of the statisticians who gather the durable goods data at the Census Bureau, an arm of the Commerce Department.
The February increase nearly reversed a 2.3 percent January decline. Rising consumer demand, coupled with the apparent tendency of some manufacturers to rebuild inventories, helped to explain the strong February report, economists said.
A three-tenths of 1 percent increase in unfilled orders, the third consecutive monthly rise in this category, suggested that manufacturing output would remain strong this spring. A rise in unfilled orders indicates that manufacturers are busy and taking longer to fill buyers' orders.
But economists cautioned that some of February's demand was a result of strong retail sales from Thanksgiving through January. Consumer buying fell off in February, which could affect future durable goods orders.
"Quite frankly, as we look ahead, we might find ourselves with another slowdown in the manufacturing sector as consumer demand declines," said Nancy Lazar, a senior economist and executive vice president of the ISI Group, a Wall Street consulting and investment firm.
The Commerce Department said that durable goods orders, seasonally adjusted, reached $135 billion in February. That nearly matched December's performance and was well above all other months last year, when monthly durables orders never exceeded $127 billion.
The February rise of $2.9 billion, from $132.1 billion in January, included a $3.7 billion jump in commercial aircraft orders. That increase bucks a trend, here and abroad, of declining aircraft orders from airline companies.
Orders for military equipment, which also gyrate from month to month, fell 24.5 percent in February after rising 10.5 percent in January. But there were gains in other areas, including autos and trucks, railroad and construction equipment, engines, some factory machinery and other nonmilitary capital goods. Orders for electronic equipment fell, however.
Actual factory shipments in February rose by a healthy 2.6 percent after having declined 2.7 percent in January.

HEADLINE: Haikou Journal;
For Treasure (and Pleasure), Their Special Island

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAIKOU, China

 BODY:
A middle-aged man in a business suit entered the nightclub and placed his order. A moment later, it was delivered: a pretty woman in a flowing robe eased into the seat beside him with a glittering lipsticky smile.
Filled with 50 or so love seats and sofas and about 15 private karaoke singing rooms, the International Trade Club represents the kind of life that people come from all over China to taste. There is easy money, easy housing and, sometimes, easy love. 
 Hainan Island, of which Haikou is the capital, is a tropical province that China has proclaimed its newest and largest special economic zone. Partly because it is separated from the Chinese mainland by a 13-mile strip of water, the authorities give it special dispensation to stray from economic and social orthodoxy.
As a result, many Chinese are leaving their homes to forge a new life in what is in some ways a Chinese equivalent of the Wild West.
"I agonized every day for two months about whether I should leave -- my family objected, I had a good job with a good employer and no one wanted me to go," said 31-year-old Yang Huping, who has now found a senior post at the local stock market. "Now I'm a Hainan resident and I like it. I can pursue my own desires and develop my own talents."
 
Money Is the Lure
 Fat-cat cadres from the north come here to sample the night life or the sandy beaches that officials here constantly compare to Hawaii's. Others, like the young woman in the nightclub, come to seek their fortune.
The woman, who refused to be identified, said she had obtained a leave from her position as an assistant to a senior official in Hangzhou. She added that she had not told her parents that her new job was to spend her evenings cuddling up to strange men and plying them with drinks.
The 200 hostesses at the club are not all prostitutes, and sex is conducted elsewhere after negotiations strictly between the hostess and the customer. The woman said she had decided that she would not return to hotel rooms with her customers.
"I've decided to give it a year," she said as she sat on a plush couch while waiting for her next customer. She said she could earn the equivalent of about $8,200 in 12 months -- not nearly as much as a prostitute but much more than the $420 that a typical worker earns in a year.
That kind of money is exactly the lure that attracts many Chinese to Hainan.
 
A Leader's Pet Project
 These days, millions of peasants are descending on China's major cities to help fuel the momentous growth there. But Hainan is getting white-collar workers -- technicians, engineers, managers, teachers and a lot of bureaucrats.
Hainan was made a province and a special economic zone in 1988, in the hope that it could become another Hong Kong. The island's development was a pet project of Zhao Ziyang, the former Communist Party leader, until he was ousted in June 1989.
Mr. Zhao had hoped to turn the entire island into a free port and to give it special privileges to attract foreign investors. Officials often said that Hainan was China's second-largest island, after Taiwan, and they seemed to think of it as a good prospect for pursuing Taiwan's miracle economy in the coming decades.
After Mr. Zhao was purged, Hainan fell from favor. It still grew extemely quickly, but it no longer is the centerpiece of economic restructuring. That honor now goes to Pudong, a part of Shanghai, and Hainan has been largely left to itself.
Now it is trying to turn itself into an export processing zone and a tourist center. A new international airport is being built at Sanya, near the beaches, and when it is finished next year Hainan hopes to attract sun-worshipers from all over Asia and the world.
 
Executives From the North
 Beijing still supplies Hainan's leaders and each brings a cabal of northerners, who barge in like cowboys entering a rodeo arena, ready to gain influence or income. Virtually all senior officials are from up north.
The result is a budding resentment among the local people, some of whom feel they are being turned into a virtual second class. At the Hainan Automobile Factory, a joint venture with Japan, most of the managers are from the mainland while the workers along the assembly lines are locals.
On a recent afternoon, a group of peasant women, wearing pointy straw hats to shield themselves from the sun, held a sit-in on the lawn of the Provincial Government building. Their land was being taken away for development and they protested that they were getting only a pittance in compensation.
Even locals who are well educated say they sense the slight. "Everyone with any kind of clout is from Beijing or the mainland," said an official researcher whose family has been here for generations. "Who gets rich? Not the locals, but the mainlanders."
 
Professionals Benefit
 Still, some local professionals are also benefiting from the province's free-and-easy policy. During the generally quiet trading session of the official foreign exchange swap center, Lin Yu hit his buzzer several times to signal a bid.
The 24-year-old Mr. Lin, who was born here, earned $175,000 for his firm last year trading Chinese yuan and dollars. His own salary, he said, is a secret.
"I'm a Hainan man," Mr. Lin said, adding his signature to a stack of contracts as customers surrounded his desk. "I have a base here. I don't even want to go to Hong Kong."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Situated 13 miles from the mainland, Hainan Island thrives as an enterprise zone where the cadres will not be corrupted -- too much -- by the free and easy life of the economically unorthodox. At a currency exchange in Haikou, not all the business of trading for dollars is done on the inside. (Sheryl WuDunn/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
If Government rides to the rescue of ailing airlines, will consumers get trampled in the process?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IF there is an economic recovery in progress, it's news to the airlines. The 10 largest have lost an awesome $10 billion over the last three years and Washington is scrounging for ways to help.
A soon-to-be-formed blue-ribbon commission, charged by Congress with the job of coming up with a plan by summer, will not lack for suggestions. The airlines and their unions are floating proposals ranging from loan subsidies to tax breaks to a get-tough policy on foreign competitors. But in the view of many economists, the proposed fixes put the cart before the horse. It is still not clear that anything important is really broken. 
 The industry is in trouble, practically everyone agrees, because the biggest carriers gambled and lost, expanding capacity into the teeth of an enduring recession in full-fare travel. What everyone does not agree on are the likely consequences.
If happier days await only a strong economic recovery, it would probably serve the public to let the markets (and the bankruptcy courts) work it out on their own. On the other hand, if hard times mean the liquidation of another big carrier or two, maybe, just maybe, it would pay to give them some financial breathing room.
From 1987 to 1992, the number of airline seats grew roughly in proportion to the number of passengers. But this apparent match, notes Daniel Kasper, an economist with Harbridge House consultants in Cambridge, Mass., obscures sobering truths.
To fill the extra seats, the airlines had to cut average fares. Adjusted for inflation, revenue per mile flown fell by nearly a fifth as business travelers became cagier about flying for full fare and vacationers insisted on exceptionally steep discounts.
What's more, the biggest carriers ignored the warning signs of stagnant demand in their lemming-like rush to exploit the anticipated economies of scale, providing more service to more cities. When Eastern and Pan Am went out of business, the decline in capacity was fully offset by growth at American, United and Delta. Today no large airline, with the exception of a maverick, Southwest, is making a profit. Most are hunkering down, mothballing jetliners and scaling back orders for new planes.
Who is to blame for the industry's sorry financial performance is a matter of dispute. To Robert L. Crandall, chief executive of American Airlines, the villains of the piece are Continental, T.W.A. and America West. These bankrupt carriers continue to fly under protection of the courts, competing with solvent airlines that devote huge sums to servicing debts.
But Severin Borenstein, an economist at the University of California, is skeptical of Mr. Crandall's argument. Forcing insolvent carriers out of business would "violate the whole principle of Chapter 11" reorganization under bankruptcy, he said. While Mr. Borenstein concedes that judges are inclined to give airline managers and workers the benefit of the doubt, he emphasizes that it does not make economic sense to shut down a carrier if it can still cover out-of-pocket operating costs.
More to the point, Mr. Borenstein notes, the Chapter 11 carriers have not been the aggressors in the price wars of the last few years. In fact, twice-bankrupt Continental has actually worked to chill the industry's fire-sale mentality by holding seats off the market at key moments.
That said, should Uncle Sam play Uncle Sugar for the industry? Alfred E. Kahn, former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board and the father of airline deregulation, offers a resounding "no." As long as there are too few passengers chasing too many seats, Mr. Kahn said, "there is every reason to believe the airlines would compete away" any tax breaks or subsidies from the Government. The best hope -- and Mr. Kahn's expectation -- is that a strong economy will solve the carriers' problems.
But one airline executive, who agreed to speak only off the record, is less sanguine. If the most vulnerable carriers, in particular Northwest, do not survive the recession, he says, more markets will be left with monopoly service. He suggests permitting money-losing airlines to defer payment of the 10 percent ticket tax.
Mr. Borenstein thinks the whole debate has a wrong turn. The Government's primary responsibility here, he suggests, is to protect consumers and taxpayers -- not the airlines' stockholders or their employees. Thus the public policy agenda ought to be the same now as a decade ago: the preservation of competition.
To Mr. Borenstein, that means, among other things, a more aggressive stance against price-signaling through the airlines' computerized reservation systems, a close look at allegations of predatory pricing and mandatory disclosure of travel agents' commissions. Today, he notes, travel agents routinely steer customers toward the airlines that secretly pay them the most.
In Government, consumers rarely come first. In politics, money talks, and the airlines and their unions are doing most of the talking.

HEADLINE: Suspect's Arrest in Blast Puzzles His Family in Egypt

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, March 24

 BODY:
In the gritty back streets in Kafr El Dauwar, 15 miles southeast of Alexandria, the arrest of Mahmud Abouhalima in the World Trade Center bombing was a mystery to his family. They said they had not seen their son since he left the country for Germany more than a decade ago.
"He has not been back and he was not arrested here," said Mohammed Halima, his father. 
 "I don't know if he is in Egypt," said his father, wearing a green and white striped robe, his head covered by a white skull cap. "He left 13 years ago and I have heard nothing from him or Mohammed. I don't know if the charges are true or false."
The row of small, two-story bungalows, built for workers at the country's second-largest textile mill just yards away, was home to Mr. Abouhalima until he left Egypt. His father, now retired, worked at the mill as a foreman and raised his children next door to his brother's family.
 
Subject to Strict Rules
 The cramped living room, with two bedrooms on the story overhead, matched every other dwelling along both sides of the street. A collection of porcelain horses, a red parrot and a white donkey, along with a few plates, were housed in a wooden sideboard with glass doors. On the table a glass vase held some artificial red carnations.
Several children, including a 15-year-old son, were in the living room until ordered out by Mr. Abouhalima's father who sat on the one couch with his bare feet pulled up in front of him.
Neighbors said they doubted that Mr. Abouhalima, whose father, a former weight lifter who ruled with a stern hand, could have taken part in the attack. They said Mr. Abouhalima and his brother, Mohammed, who also lived in the United States, were always subject to strict rules that allowed for little gaiety or socializing.
"He was a wisp of a kid," said one former classmate, "an indifferent athlete and not that ambitious. He was not like his father, who was a champion power lifter and hard. When he left Egypt he just wanted to get a job and make a living. He wasn't into this kind of thing."
An uncle, on his way home with a plastic bag full of vegetables, said that even before he left for Germany Mr. Abouhalima "was a very religious boy."
 
Center of Militancy
 And while Mr. Abouhalima as a young man learned to smoke, neighbors said, he never lighted a cigarette in front of his father or at home, and studiously avoided alcohol.
Mr. Abouhalima complained to relatives about religious persecution in Germany, especially after his German-born wife converted to Islam.
"His wife was thrown out of Germany because she converted," said his stocky uncle, wearing a battered pair of brown slippers and a blue robe. "In Germany, conversion to Islam is forbidden."
The mill town, with soaring unemployment and overcrowding, is a center of Islamic militancy. Many young men, bearded and in robes, congregated on street corners near the Halima home, located on Abu Halima Street. They wearily eyed an Egyptian and an American reporter and turned their backs when approached.
"Better not to even bring up the role of Islamic militants here," one neighbor said. "Don't even ask us about this."

HEADLINE: Angry Japanese Deplore Clinton's Remarks

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 24

 BODY:
Japan reacted harshly today to tough trade talk from President Clinton, angrily rejecting his strong suggestion that the Japanese market was closed and threatening a legal battle if the Clinton Administration imposed higher tariffs on Japanese mini-vans.
The latest exchange was set off by comments President Clinton made at his news conference Tuesday in Washington, in which he pressed the combative tone of his Administration on trade relations with Japan. 
 Asked if he had abandoned a campaign pledge to sharply increase the tariffs on the imported mini-vans by reclassifying them as trucks rather than cars, Mr. Clinton criticized the Bush Administration's decision not to take this step and said he was reviewing the issue.
Then, without a further question, he harshly criticized Japan's big trade surplus and went broadly after the Japanese, comparing the accessibility of their markets with those of other countries.
In looking at the history of American trade relationships, he said, "the one that never seems to change very much is the one with Japan." He went on, "That is, we're sometimes in a position of trade deficit, but we're often in a position of trade surplus with the European Community."
Then, in a remark that seemed to have particularly angered Japanese officials, he said:
"But the persistence of the surplus the Japanese enjoy with the United States and with the rest of the developed world can only lead one to the conclusion that the possibility of obtaining real, even access to the Japanese market is somewhat remote."
He said he was "astonished" that the Bush Administration overruled the Customs Service "and gave a $300 million-a-year freebie" to the Japanese "for no apparent reason," adding, "and we got nothing, and I emphasis nothing, in return."
Based on the number of mini-vans and sport vehicles imported from Japan, tariff revenue is estimated at $300 million a year more if the Bush Administration had supported a Customs ruling that the vehicles should be taxed as trucks at 25 percent, rather than as cars at 2.5 percent.
Mr. Clinton's remarks in effect rejected the assumptions of a decade of trade negotiations with Japan, which have assumed that the removal of barriers could open markets.
Japanese officials formulated several responses to the President.
This afternoon, Noboru Hatakeyama, Vice Minister for International Trade and Industry, said in a phone interview that a reclassification of the mini-vans as trucks without negotiations would violate the rules of the General Agreement on Tarriffs and Trade, or GATT, the world body that governs trade.
"I hope an influential country such as the United States is not trying to circumvent the GATT rules," Mr. Hatakeyama said, and he repeated a threat. "If they do, of course, we will go to GATT" and take legal action against the United States.
 
Tariffs and Deficits
 A senior Japanese trade official said last month that if Washington punished Japan with export restrictions, it would retaliate with similar penalties against American products.
Mr. Hatakeyama responded to Mr. Clinton's remarks about the closed nature of the Japanese economy by asserting that it was more open than America's, as measured by tariff levels, and that the trade deficit was largely the fault of the United States because it imported too much.
Japan, he said, is now America's largest market for agricultural exports and its second largest for manufactured goods, after Canada. "Therefore it is a mistake, or misunderstanding, to feel that market access to Japan is closed," he said. "If Japan is interpreted as closed, then every country except for Canada is also closed."
"What I am hoping," Mr. Hatakeyama added, "is that the Clinton Administration will come to an accurate analysis of the nature of the Japanese market. Japan is quite open."
He largely ignored the matter of the Japanese trade surplus with the United States, which is running close to $50 billion a year. Asked if that suggested difficulty in gaining access to Japan, as Mr. Clinton had argued, Mr. Hatakeyama replied that the problem existed more in the United States than in Japan.
"The United States maintains a great budget deficit, which is unfortunate and the reason for this," he said.
