HEADLINE: Forecasts by Drug Makers Send Clintons a Message

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The announcements of slumping pharmaceutical earnings that depressed drug stocks yesterday sent messages to Washington and investors alike, health-care analysts said.
Analysts noted that Merck & Company's announcement Tuesday that growth in profits was slowing would reach Hillary Rodham Clinton and the President while they were in the final five weeks of drafting plans for broad changes in the health care system. The Clintons have singled out drug prices for sharp criticism. 
 "It was a response to the finger-pointing of the Administration by the best company in the industry," said Tony Forstmann Jr., a partner at Forstmann-Leff Associates, a pension management firm, referring to Merck's announcement that earnings this year would be lower than expected. "Their earnings are probably stronger than they are saying," he suggested. "It makes no sense to have strong earnings now with the attacks from Washington."
Barbara Ryan, a securities analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons, said: "Portfolio managers view drugs as no longer a growth industry. Price-earnings multiples are down. Washington is all over them. Why report a good number?"
Analysts said Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., indicated that 1993 profits would grow 11 percent to 13 percent, down from earlier forecasts of 14 percent to 16 percent. They said the company hoped to increase unit sales volume by 8 percent to 12 percent. However, Merck said that the dollar's strength overseas could subtract 3 percentage points from sales growth in 1993. Sales last year were $9.66 billion.
But the political message may be just a side issue to fundamental changes in an industry that had been an investors' favorite until early last year.
Merck stock dropped to $32.75 yesterday, a two-year low, before recovering to close at $34.875, down $2.125 for the day in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The company said it was buying back some of its 1.15 billion shares, partly as a calming measure for the markets.
 
Other Stocks Also Fall
 Stock prices of other large drug companies also declined. Pfizer Inc. dropped $2.125, to $57.50;; Johnson & Johnson fell $1.125, to $39.50, and Bristol-Myers Squibb was down 12.5 cents, to $58.
Analysts said the lowered earnings expectations announced by Merck and other drug companies were an attempt to steer the Clintons away from including drug price controls in the health-care plan. Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, Merck's chairman, made that clear on Tuesday, when he said the drug market "certainly does not need price controls at this time."
But Susan Thrasher, a health-care analyst at Chancellor Capital Management, which manages $25 billion for pension plans, insurance companies and foundations, said economic realities outweighed the politics.
"What is hitting the pharmaceutical industry is not Hillary or Washington or Clinton," she said. "It's the changing fundamentals inside the industry."
Ms. Thrasher cited rising competition from me-too drugs -- which might be five or six similar-acting cardiovascular pills from different manufacturers, for example -- as well as low-priced generic versions; a dry period in the research pipeline for most companies, and a growing sense that there is a buyer's market in health care.
"The companies are losing control of what their top line looks like," she said, referring to sales dollars. As for profits, "they have to adjust the rest of the cost structure to keep control of the bottom line."
 
Job Cuts at Merck
 On that score, Merck said it would cut 1,000 jobs, or about 3 percent of its work force. That might be just the beginning. Viren Mehta, at Mehta & Isaly Worldwide Pharmaceutical Research, said Merck might shrink by 3,000 more jobs by 1996.
In a slimming gesture of their own, Dr. Vagelos and his senior executives will take a 10 percent pay cut, and middle managers will give up 5 percent, the company told analysts Tuesday.
Elsewhere in the industry, Bristol-Myers Squibb has announced a cut of 2,250 jobs, and Syntex, Ciba-Geigy and Searle have also announced layoffs. In view of national concern about joblessness, "the cut in employment is not something Clinton would like to see," Mr. Forstmann, of Forstmann-Leff, suggested.
Drug company jobs grew 36 percent between 1980 and 1991, to 297,000, while all manufacturing jobs declined 6 percent, according to the Labor Department.
Ms. Thrasher at Chancellor said most drug company job cuts had been in management and production.

HEADLINE: Report Notes Urban Woes In New York

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
After a decade of economic turmoil, the cities of New York State have emerged in worse condition than those elsewhere in the nation, but New York City and its Westchester County neighbors have in many ways fared better than their upstate counterparts, according to a report by Moody's Investors Service.
More than ever, the Moody's researchers found, the economic landscape of New York is divided between two regions, the densely populated south and the industrial north. For mayors, legislators and other officials, the findings could add to longstanding competition for school aid and other government support. 
 "All cities in New York are under economic strain, but when you look upstate and downstate, the causes are very different," said Michael Johnston, a Moody's vice president and one of the authors of the report. It analyzed the condition of the state's 15 largest cities.
 
Consideration of Need
 For state officials, "This report underscores the fact that we have to consider need when we administer programs to upstate and downstate communities," said Allan Sullivan, executive deputy commissioner of the New York State Department of Economic Development.
"There has always been competition for funds but it has too often been a contest of political clout instead of differing economic conditions in the state," he said.
The Moody's report said new influences, including a wave of immigration downstate, a loss of population in upstate cities and the increasingly high cost of living in the south, are reshaping the state's economic landscape. More familiar trends, including the loss of manufacturing jobs and the flight of affluent city dwellers to the suburbs, are also having an impact, it said.
Moody's, one of the nation's largest credit rating agencies, regularly examines the finances of cities, counties and states. Its ratings are critical to financial markets, which establish how much interest government agencies must pay to borrow money.
"New York cities are generally rated lower than the national average," the report said. Moody's has given ratings of A1 or better, its highest category, to only 9, or 15 percent, of 58 cities in New York, compared with 38 percent of all United States cities.
New York City, with a rating of Baa1, has a lower fiscal grade than most other major cities. In contrast, Chicago, Houston, Los Angeles and Miami are all rated by Moody's at A or better.
Mr. Johnston said the poor showing for cities in New York State resulted largely from the decline of the state's manufacturing economy.
The problems are not unique to New York, however. And while Moody's said its report yesterday was the first to compare municipal economies within a large industrialized state, similar forces may be at work in Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, Michigan and other states anchored by large cities and struggling under the weight of a recession and lost manufacturing jobs.
"For all the problems cities like New York seem to have, you just have to take a look at upstate New York and we don't seem so bad," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist of Chemical Bank in New York City, who said Moody's findings "square with reality."
 
Long-Term Factors
 Although much of Moody's research focuses on the fiscal policies of cities -- how much they borrow, collect in taxes and keep on reserve -- its report yesterday focused more broadly on population shifts, long-term economic changes and other factors beyond the direct control of municipal officials.
It said the state's largest cities continued in the 1980's, as they had since the 1950's, to lose their dominance as population centers. The cities had 49 percent of the state's residents in 1990, it said, down sharply from 67 percent in 1950.
But while the losses were partly reversed during the 1980's in New York City and four large municipalities in Westchester County, the 10 largest upstate cities continued to shrink, mainly because of the flight of affluent residents to the suburbs and more distant towns.
In 1990, the report said the 10 cities had 1.2 million residents, down by 6 percent from 1980. The upstate cities are Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse, Albany, Utica, Schenectady, Niagara Falls, Troy, Binghamton and Rome.
The population of the downstate cities -- New York, Yonkers, White Plains, New Rochelle and Mount Vernon -- grew by 300,000, or 3 percent, during the 1980's, the report said.
It ascribed the reversal to the huge waves of foreign immigration, confined largely to the downstate urban centers. In contrast to most of the upstate cities, where the percentage of foreign-born residents declined in the 1980's, the numbers of immigrants grew sharply in each downstate city, accounting for 23 percent of their residents in 1990, compared with 18 percent in 1980.
Mr. Johnston said the rising population of immigrants raised new questions about the economic health of the downstate cities. While population growth seemed certain to be strengthening the tax bases of the cities, "it remains unclear how much new demand it will create for social services," he said.
In another mixed measure of economic health, the income levels, housing costs and overall cost of living in the downstate cities, which has always been higher than in upstate, grew even more rapidly in the 1980's, adding to a wide gap between the regions.
 
Home Prices Soared
 From 1980 to 1990, the report found that median family incomes in the five downstate cities jumped 104 percent, to $46,250, while the median price of a home soared 252 percent to $250,000. The increases exceeded those elsewhere in the nation, and sharply outpaced those in the upstate cities.
The report said the median income in the upstate cities rose 69 percent in the 1980's, to $31,666, and the median price of a home rose 125 percent, to $71,428.
Moody's said the upstate cities ended the 1980's with a far greater reliance on manufacturing. "In upstate New York," it said, "manufacturing is still undergoing a long-term decline."
Among the upstate cities, it found that 26 percent of the workers in Rochester were employed in manufacturing. The figure was 23 percent in Niagara Falls, 19 percent in Binghamton and 16 percent in Buffalo.
By contrast, less than 15 percent of the work force in each downstate city was employed in manufacturing. In New York City, it said, manufacturers employed 12 percent of the work force in 1990.

HEADLINE: Perot Wants A Trial Run Of Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Ross Perot, who spoke out strongly against the North American Free Trade Agreement during the Presidential campaign, told a House committee today that the accord should be tried only on an experimental basis because of the big gap in wages between the United States and Mexico.
During a hearing that Administration and other supporters of the agreement had looked to with considerable alarm, Mr. Perot recited a litany of criticisms, emphasizing that American workers could not compete with Mexican workers earning less than $1 an hour. 
 But he stopped short of urging Congress to reject the pact, and told the House Small Business Committee that a group of intelligent people could draft an agreement protecting American workers in 30 days.
Mr. Perot did not make clear whether this would require an entirely new accord or whether it could be accomplished through the side agreement on labor issues now being negotiated by the Clinton Administration. He said he did not know what the details might be in an agreement protecting American workers. "That would take a lot of study, which I have not done," he said.
 
Pilot Program Advocated
 Mr. Perot repeatedly asked that a pilot program for the trade accord be put into effect, but had no specifics on how such a program might be designed. The nations subscribing to the pact, he said, should "have a clear understanding that either nation may decide to cancel this agreement, if in that nation's judgment, the pilot program is not successful."
During the campaign, the Texas businessman had criticized the agreement in strong and often-colorful terms, warning in a debate in October of "a giant sucking sound of jobs being pulled out of this country." But in the same debate, he did not rule out an eventual agreement with Mexico, saying, "We've got to proceed very carefully on that."
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, pointed out in a interview tonight that the accord allowed any of its members -- Canada, Mexico and the United States -- to withdraw at any time with six months' warning. He said that labor costs were a small portion of overall manufacturing costs, suggesting that Mr. Perot may have exaggerated potential job losses.
Kay R. Whitmore, chairman and chief executive of the Eastman Kodak Company, said in a telephone interview arranged by a business coalition that supports the agreement that he could not envision how it might be tried on a pilot basis, as Mr. Perot suggested.
"I don't know what a pilot program would be," he said. "I don't think you can pilot a trade agreement. You either do it or you don't do it."
Mr. Perot's arrival on Capitol Hill had caused worry among supporters of the agreement -- including Clinton Administration officials, some members of Congress and business lobbyists. With his wealth and private political organization, he could prove to be a significant ally to labor and environmental groups opposing the accord, lawmakers said in interviews earlier this week.
The White House responded by arranging for Mr. Kantor to call reporters after the hearing to rebut Mr. Perot's arguments. In addition, nearly a dozen Congressional supporters of the agreement held a news conference to defend the agreement.
 
Perot Musters Own Backers
 The business coalition, called U.S.A.-Nafta Inc., consists of 1,100 companies and trade associations that favor the pact. It offered reporters a choice of executives to be interviewed on the potential benefits of the accord for the American economy.
Earlier, Mr. Perot showed up at the House hearing with a small crowd of his supporters, who took turns waiting in the hallway and quietly sitting in the last two rows of the committee room. During an intermission, a swarm of young men and women took turns asking Mr. Perot for his autograph and hugging him while their friends took pictures.
Richard Angelica, a teacher from Steubenville, Ohio, said he was a supporter of United We Stand America, Mr. Perot's political group. He had already been visiting Washington when the group notified him that Mr. Perot would testify on the trade pact, which Mr. Angelica also opposes. "I think it's a poor idea -- we'll lose jobs," he said.
Mr. Perot, in a brief interview during the intermission, was unclear whether he would produce a television commercial attacking the trade pact, as some aides have suggested. "I haven't thought about it -- let's assume everybody wants us to do it, then I probably will," he said.
Later, he was asked whether Congressional rejection of the agreement would risk political instability in Mexico. "I hope there is no instability," he replied. "But we can't make a bad deal just because there's a threat."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Drop

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury prices declined yesterday as traders and investors continued to buy and sell in alternating waves that are keeping prices and yields in a tight trading range.
The price of the 30-year bond, which had gained 14/32 Monday and Tuesday, was off 22/32 yesterday to yield 6.82 percent, up from 6.76 percent Tuesday. The price of the 10-year note, which was up 11/32 Monday and Tuesday, was off 14/32 yesterday, to yield 5.96 percent, up from 5.90 percent. 
 After two weeks of trading since the yields on Treasury bonds and notes fell to the lowest point in many years, yields ended yesterday fairly close to the middle of their recent range, which for the 30-year bond is a 6.72 percent low to a 6.89 percent high.
Traders said that the Treasury auction of $15.25 billion of two-year Treasury notes went well, with the notes sold at a single yield of 3.92 percent.
 
But Market Drops
 But the market declined in the afternoon despite the success of the auction, which made it difficult to explain why trading moved as it did.
"Sometimes we just have to acknowledge that the market is in a trading range," said Donald fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc. "The market is waiting for the next conclusive sign on the real economy or inflation," he added. The next such report will be the employment report for March, which will be issued a week from tomorrow.
One explanation for yesterday's decline, especially in three- and five-year notes, is that the new-two year note appeared to be a better bargain than the slightly longer maturities, so traders sold them and used the cash to buy two-year notes.
John Costas, managing director of government trading and sales at the First Boston Corporation, referring to this kind of dealer selling and switching, said, "the arbitrage bid made it into a very good auction." But, he added, it was not the kind of trading that would drive prices higher and yields lower.
 
Durable Goods Up
 There was also news that would normally send prices lower and yields higher. In the morning, the Government reported that orders for durable goods rose 2.2 percent in February, when the forecast was for a small decline. Prices of bonds and notes declined on the report but then recovered.
Later in the morning, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, generated a flurry of headlines, telling the Senate Finance Committee that the deficit would be a problem in the future if more reductions were not made after the five years covered by the Clinton economic plan. He said that he had not directly endorsed the Clinton economic program over other plans to cut the deficit, although he was encouraged by Congress's efforts to approve it.
While such comments about the possible inadequacy of the Clinton program seem unfriendly for the bond market, several traders said that they did not appear to have much impact yesterday. But that does not mean that the comments cannot eventually affect the market as traders and investors consider what Mr. Greenspan said over the next several days.
It may take some time to try to figure out what message Mr. Greenspan might have been sending to traders and investors. He said yesterday that job growth was increasing but added that it was not at a pace that would worry him.
Such a remark can be interpreted in at least two ways: One is that the economy is growing faster, which might disturb some bond traders because that could mean inflation could increase this year above the 3 percent of 1992. This could mean that the Fed would increase short-term interest rates and that bond yields could rise.
But it could also mean that the Fed chairman would be comfortable with even a little faster economic growth and still not have to worry about inflation. This interpretation would make some think that short-term interest rates will not rise soon.
 
Auction Set Today
 The Treasury will auction $11 billion of five-year notes today. In late trading in the when-issued market yesterday, the yield on the five-year note had jumped to 5.20 percent from 5.13 percent the day before. If the yield holds at this level, it could increase the auction demand.
The yield on the two-year note, which was auctioned at 3.92 percent, had inched up to 3.93 percent by late in the day.

HEADLINE: Cray Withdraws Complaint

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 24

 BODY:
Cray Research, the American supercomputer maker, has withdrawn a complaint over a public research institute's decision to buy a competing Japanese-made computer, a high official of the company's Japanese division said today.
Yoshikazu Hori, president of Cray Research Japan, said officials decided they would not gain anything by pursuing the complaint. "We withdrew it," he said, "but it's absolutely not the case that we are satisfied." 
 Cray filed the complaint with the Japanese Government last July over the decision by the National Institute for Fusion Science to buy an SX-3 supercomputer from the NEC Corporation, a Japanese producer. Cray said its C90 computer was superior and had lost business because of a rating system that awarded more points to performance criteria where NEC was strong.
A Government review board rejected the complaint in October, saying it found no problems with the selection process.
Japan is now considering an economic-stimulus package that reportedly includes purchases of as many as 20 supercomputers. "We'd like to receive one-third of those orders," Mr. Hori said.
Under an agreement with the United States, Japan pledged that purchases by public institutions would be open, selection standards clearly defined, and competing computers thoroughly evaluated.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Fund Yields Are Mixed in Latest Period

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The average yields on tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were mixed in the latest week, according to the most recent survey by IBC's Money Fund Report.
Tax-exempt yields were up sharply in the week ended Tuesday for the second consecutive reporting period, as the supply of new municipal issues continued to outpace the demand. With so much new debt available, yields are moving higher to attract buyers. 
 The assets of tax-exempt funds declined by $546 million, to $102.2 billion, but the outflow was not considered unusual, according to analysts at the money market publication.
The average number of days to maturity of securities held in tax-exempt fund portfolios was down two days, to 52.
According to the IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Average, the seven-day compounded yield for tax-exempt funds rose 11 basis points, to 1.92 percent, with the average seven-day simple yield up 10 basis points, to 1.90 percent. Over 30 days, the average compounded yield was 1.83 percent, and the simple 30-day average yield was 1.82 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
Ignoring state and local taxes, the taxable bond equivalent yield of the average seven-day compounded yield is about 2.67 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket and about 2.78 percent for those in the 31 percent bracket.
Among tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, the Money Fund Report said, the Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market fund outperformed all other funds in its group for the third consecutive week, posting a yield of 2.68 percent. The yield was 13 basis points higher than the previous week.
 
Taxable Funds
 The assets of taxable money market funds rose $4.4 billion in the week ended yesterday, to $488.9 billion. Of the increase, the assets of institutional funds gained $4.9 billion, to $171.6 billion, and those of the retail funds declined $500 million, to $317.3 billion.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity remained at 60. In light of that lengthy period, analysts at the Money Fund Report said managers were maintaining a position that rates would continue lower.
The average seven-day yield of taxable funds fell a basis point, to 2.68 percent, and the seven-day simple yield also fell a basis point, to 2.65 percent.
Dreyfus Basic Money Market fund had the highest return among general-purpose taxable money funds, with a yield of 3.49 percent, the same figure posted by Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series in the previous week.
By comparison, banks are offering an average of 2.63 percent on their money market products, down a basis point from the previous week.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Jumps Against Yen On Profit Taking by Traders

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar soared against the Japanese yen yesterday as traders rushed to take profits from the yen's all-time high one day earlier.
The United States currency was broadly higher Against European currencies. The German mark fell against the dollar after a Bundesbank announcement that kept hope alive for a significant reduction in high German interest rates. 
 Gold prices rose in New York after falling overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery closed at $332.50 an ounce, up 60 cents. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $332.20 an ounce, up 60 cents from late Tuesday.
The dollar, quoted at a postwar low of 115.10 yen early Tuesday, recovered to 115.95 yen by late afternoon and jumped nearly 2 more yen by late yesterday in New York.
 
Japanese Economy Cited
 Dealers said the market was uncomfortable with the low levels, given the weak state of the Japanese economy. In addition, there was less speculation among traders that industrialized nations favor a stronger yen as a way to reduce Japan's trade surplus with its major trading partners.
The dollar also benefited from the German Bundesbank's announcement early yesterday that a key short-term market rate had not climbed as a result of its weekly repurchase operation. Some traders had expected a slight rise.
The mark rose in European trading but fell in New York.
In late Europe trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6279 marks, down from 1.6312 marks. In New York, the dollar rose to 1.6375 marks, from 1.6303 marks late Tuesday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 115.93 yen, up 0.60 yen from Tuesday's record low close there. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 116.85 yen. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar was quoted at 117.65 yen, up from 115.95 yen late Tuesday.
The British pound sank to $1.4825 in London, from $1.4840 late Tuesday. In New York, the pound was trading at $1.4770 late yesterday, down from $1.4840.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.5155 Swiss francs, up from 1.5105; 5.5685 French francs, up from 5.5475; 1,596.00 Italian lire, up from 1,579.00, and $1.2430 (Canadian), down from $1.2473 (Canadian).
Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.5085 Swiss francs, down from 1.5090; 5.5425 French francs, down from 5.5530; 1.8310 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8323; 1,592.50 Italian lire, up from 1,587.00, and $1.2445 (Canadian), down from $1.2481 (Canadian).

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Vehicle Sales Get a Boost From Trucks

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 24

 BODY:
Brisk sales of light trucks helped to push up overall sales of domestically built vehicles by 10.7 percent in mid-March, the nation's auto makers said today, although car sales rose only slightly from the sluggish level of a year earlier.
Car sales were 170,329 for the March 11-20 period, up 1.6 percent over the period a year earlier. But sales of light trucks -- which include mini-vans, sport-utility vehicles and pickups -- rose 24.6 percent, to 136,078. Total sales of vehicles built in North America, which are considered domestic vehicles for reporting purposes, were 306,407. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales for the period was 6 million, down from 6.5 million in early March but up from 5.8 million a year earlier.
 
Stuck at Same Level
 Automotive analysts have been watching sales creep higher in tandem with the economic recovery. But for the last three months, "there's been some concern that sales are stuck in first gear," said Jean-Claude Gruet, automotive analyst for UBS Securities Inc. in New York. "We're waiting for a move up to the next plateau."
He said that if car sales did not soon reach a 6.7 million annual rate on a sustained basis, auto makers would have to consider trimming second-quarter production, which would trickle through the economy and cause further weakness.
Dealers, too, have noticed that sales have not advanced consistently. "They're spotty; strong one day, slow the next," said Kevin Hall, sales manager of Foley Chrysler-Plymouth in Quincy, Mass. Regarding the strength of light-truck sales, Mr. Hall said Chrysler's mini-vans "are the best property I have."
 
G.M. Car Brands All Suffer
 The General Motors Corporation, the nation's leading producer, continued to show weakness in cars and strength in light trucks. G.M.'s car sales were 73,247 for the period, down 6 percent from a year earlier. Every G.M. car brand posted a year-to-year decline, including Saturn, which had previously been improving consistently. G.M.'s full-size pickups and Suburban utility vehicle were the mainstays of the auto maker's truck business, which gained 29.5 percent, with sales of 49,586.
The Ford Motor Company posted car sales of 49,538, a gain of 6.4 percent, and light-truck sales of 43,415, a gain of 13.1 percent. All of Ford's car lines except the Tempo and Mustang improved; the two aged models will soon be replaced.
Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication, estimated that the Chrysler Corporation posted car sales of 20,600, up 43.5 percent, and light-truck sales of 33,800, up 25.8 percent, in mid-March. Chrysler reports its sales only once a month.
The Toyota Motor Corporation sold 9,907 cars, up 4.9 percent, and 3,222 light trucks, a more than threefold increase. The Honda Motor Company sold 8,059 cars, down 25.5 percent. The Nissan Motor Company sold 4,912 cars, more than double the total a year earlier, and 3,970 light trucks, up 35.1 percent.

HEADLINE: A Philosophy Built It; Solar Logic Keeps It Warm

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: ORFORDVILLE, N.H.

 BODY:
It was the quintessential New Hampshire winter day: bright sun, snow underfoot as crisp as corn flakes and temperature around zero, cold enough to make the teeth ache. But that was outside.
Inside, Jonathan Sands waved a desktop thermometer with a gesture that suggested either Merlin with a wand or Perry Mason with the crucial piece of evidence. The thermometer said 75 degrees, although his 1,900-square-foot house has no boiler or furnace. It does have a wood stove, but the fire had gone out almost 12 hours earlier. 
 The house, in which Mr. Sands and his wife, Deborah Merrill-Sands, and their son, Sam, 4 1/2, are completing their second winter, is heated mostly by the sun, and by three cords of wood a season -- which would make a pile about 7 feet wide, 7 feet long and 8 feet high -- at a cost of less than $300.
Since they designed the house themselves and Mr. Sands did much of the labor himself, seeing that it all works is more than a matter of comfort; it is also a confirmation of skill and philosophy.
Mr. Sands's work in areas related to natural resources has taken him around the world (he once ran a small company in Bermuda that installed solar heaters for swimming pools); Ms. Merrill-Sands is a consultant to the World Bank and the Ford Foundation on agricultural issues. When they decided to build a house in New Hampshire, a few miles from where he grew up, he was determined to practice what he preached with a house that would rely as heavily as possible on "renewable" resources like sun and wood.
Heating here, about 20 miles up the Connecticut River from Hanover, N.H., requires about 50 percent more fuel to maintain a given temperature over the course of a winter than an identical house in New York City. For that reason almost everything built here is designed to take advantage of the sun and to seal out the cold. And Mr. Sands, who studied solar engineering at Hampshire College, in Amherst, Mass., agricultural engineering at Cornell and resource dynamics at the Thayer School of Engineering at Dartmouth, said, "It comes down to philosophy."
"It's deciding not to use more than your share," he said.
That philosophy also helped the Sandses pick the spot on their 70 acres to build when they returned from The Hague, where both had worked for the International Service for National Agricultural Research. There were other south-facing slopes -- the best spot for solar heating -- but this one was on a rocky ledge with thin top soil that was unproductive as meadow or forest land. They named the house Wolf Pine Ledge, for the scraggly pine that grows there.
Nothing in its appearance screams that it is a solar house. With a spacious main room and a cathedral ceiling, the house feels not snug, but open. This is possible because of a frame of hemlock from a local company, Outback Post and Beam.
The house relies mostly on techniques that have been proven elsewhere to varying degrees. But more so than most other houses, this one goes to extreme lengths to ease the heating burden. In most new houses here, that means thinking about the sun; for the Sands family, it means relying on it.
Life inside is comfortable but sometimes complicated. In a house with a conventional heating system, the residents simply set the thermostat; but here, maintaining the right temperature requires planning. In the beginning, Mr. Sands built fires on cloudy mornings, and if the sun came out later in the day, they had to open the windows or sweat. "You can't just plug it in and use it, like a toaster oven," Mr. Sands said of his house. He regularly consults weather forecasts on Compuserve, the computer bulletin board, before deciding how big a fire to build.
But if the family goes away for a weekend or a week, there is no heating system to fail; the sun and the incidental sources of heat, like the refrigerator, will keep the temperature in the upper 50's.
Houses like this one are not rare, although the Census Bureau found too few in 1990 to measure as a separate category. The Passive Solar Industries Council of Washington, a trade association of building materials manufacturers, architects and others, believes that half a million American houses are heated primarily by the sun, half of them built in the last 10 years. The American Solar Energy Society, of Boulder, Colo., puts the number far lower, at about 100,000.
The problem is also in the definition of a solar house, particularly of passive solar heat, which relies on the sun coming through windows, unlike the much less common "active" systems that use rooftop solar collectors.
The real test of whether a house really relies on the sun is whether it has an oil- or gas-fired furnace as a backup. Mr. Sands has considered adding a coil to his propane-fired water heater that would circulate hot water as a backup heat source. But the house is doing well without it.
Solar power is not for everybody. When building from scratch, it's possible to add big heating improvements at low cost, but few people start from scratch. And the builder has to be interested in more than just plain economics.
For example, Northeast Utilities, which generates much of the electricity used in the area, sells plans for solar houses that cut the heating requirement nearly in half. It estimates that a 2,100-square-foot Victorian built to comply with the local building code would cost $203,200, or $212,600 for a solar house, an increase of less than 5 percent. In New Hampshire, the solar version would save about 385 gallons of oil a year. At current oil prices, about 90 cents a gallon, that would be $346.50, not quite enough to pay the interest on the $9,000 additional construction expense. But someone enthusiastic about solar houses could reasonably assume that the oil price will rise slightly, because of President Clinton's proposed energy tax, and that minimizing oil use also makes environmental sense.
There are also intangible benefits, like enjoying the view of the grosbeaks and the blue jays at the bird feeder in silence, without the distraction of a whirring, clicking, whooshing heating system.
Mr. Sands, having saved much on labor, said his house cost about $80,000. How much of that is extra for making it solar he couldn't say, because he has never figured the cost of the house any other way.
The calculation is always muddied by the question of where to draw the line. An extra window, for example, may be for solar heating but may also be a nice touch in a house set in the evergreen hills. And a new house in this climate would be heavily insulated no matter how it was heated.
Here is how the Sands house works:
First, it is nearly completely airtight. In fact, when the clothes dryer runs, pushing exhaust air out of the house, the front door of the house swings open if not latched.
Second, the house is miserly with its openings to the outside. It has exhaust fans in each of the two bathrooms and in the kitchen area of the living-dining-cooking room. But the air does not go straight outdoors; it runs through ducts to the basement, where outside air is also drawn in.
The air to be exhausted is run through hundreds of tiny passages in the aluminum honeycomb of a heat exchanger, while the outside air runs through adjacent passages, in the opposite directions. Thus the outgoing air gives up most of its heat to the incoming air; if the temperature is 72 degrees indoors and 32 outdoors, the outside air will be warmed to 64 degrees by the time it enters the house, and the air being exhausted will be cooled to 40 degrees. The $800 heat exchanger, built by Newtech Energy Systems of Ontario, Canada, runs continuously on a 100-watt fan. The result is that the house, while airtight, is continuously vented.
(Mr. Sands is currently unemployed, but is an ambitious tinkerer. He is working on a mechanism to recover some of the heat from the water that goes down the drains and use it to heat water from the well.)
Third, the house was configured with the sun in mind. About 60 percent of the south-facing area is glass, while the north side has only a few small windows. In fact, the "south" side isn't quite facing south; it is angled 17 degrees to the east. ("Well, 15 to 19 degrees," admitted Mr. Sands, who laid out the foundation himself.) This is to let the house pick up a little more sun at daybreak, when the day is coldest, and a little less in late afternoon. In summer, the angle helps reduce the peak temperature of the house, although cooling is not a major challenge in this climate. Angling a dwelling this way has been understood for thousands of years, but ignored in the last 50 years of tract developments, whose builders relied on cheap fuel and didn't think much about the environment.
But energy streaming through the spacious vertical windows, called clerestory windows, is not enough if the sun does not shine around the clock. And when the sun is shining through all those windows, without something besides white pine floors acting as a thermal mass to absorb the heat by day, the house would get too hot during the day and would not save energy for use at night.
"Once the glass gets over 7 percent of the wall area, you're looking at the need for additional thermal mass," said Helen C. English, the executive director of the Passive Solar Industries Council.
Mr. Sands's solution was to put a concrete slab in the south side of his wood-frame house, covering 164 square feet of the living-dining area and abutting the white pine floor, at a cost of about $1 a square foot. The concrete is five inches thick, covered with an inch and a quarter of blue soapstone tile quarried from the same Virginia hills as the stone for the stove. During the day, the slab is heated by the sun, and at night it gives the heat back.
For extra heat, there is the stove, manufactured by the Tulikivi Group of North America, a branch of a Finnish company based in West Lebanon, N.H. Most wood stoves are metal and are designed to burn continuously, starving the fire for oxygen to keep it running. The Tulikivi burns with a roar for an hour or two, heating up its 8,000-pound mass until it is hot to the touch. It gives off the heat over many hours. Usually this works well, although if the stove has been left unused for days, warming it can take hours.
"Our biggest cost that no sane person would have done was the stove," Mr. Sands said. It was $9,000; a conventional stove is less than $1,000.
Mr. Sands describes his house as "passive solar." But a purist might quibble, because the house, with a peaked roof 26 feet off the living room floor, has a mechanical system for moving heat around -- a return vent at the top driven by a small electric fan. The fan draws air down through a duct, through the concrete slab and back into the room. (In summer, it pushes air out of the house.)
For the Sandses, there are still unfinished details. Many houses this far north, solar or not, use quilted window shades to hold in heat at night. But the Sands like the uncluttered look of the white pine windowframes, and they are still looking for window treatments that will blend in.
And then there are hanging questions, like the four feet of heavy-duty electric cable dangling from the peak of the ceiling.
"The client really wanted a fan there and the contractor really didn't want to put one in," he said. Mr. Sands was his own contractor; the "client" is his wife.
The problem, he said, was that the decorative ceiling fan might look nice, but it would be so high off the floor that it would not circulate the air to the area at the bottom where the family actually lives; all it would do is mix the air in the top 20 feet or so, thus reducing the efficiency of the return vent at the roof's peak.
He said he would probably cut the cable and install a junction box in case he had a need later for electric power on the ceiling; the client, he predicted, would eventually agree.
 
 
 
BEFORE YOU PICK UP THAT HAMMER . . .

IF you are building a house or renovating an old one, your local electric utility probably wants to talk to you.
Northeast Utilities (P.O. Box 270, Hartford 06141), which serves large parts of Connecticut, Massachusetts and New Hampshire, sells a book, "Operation Solar," for $2 .
Among other free services, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (851 Howard Street, San Francisco 94103) will put house models on a three-axis table adjusted for latitude, month and hour. The table rotates under a spotlight to simulate the motion of the sun, and video cameras inside and outside the model record sun and shadow pattern.
The Passive Solar Industries Council sells a $50 book on design strategies, customized for local climate and construction practices: 1511 K Street NW, Washington 20005.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 623 words

HEADLINE: Russia's Unnoticed Revolution

 BODY:
Ten million new capitalists. No, they're not Koreans, Americans or Western Europeans. They're Russian. In a matter of months, tens of thousands of Mom and Pop shops and hundreds of large enterprises have been privatized -- turned over to workers, managers and outside investors, some foreign. By the end of April, when the number may reach 10 million, Russia will be well launched on an astonishingly quick traverse from Socialism to capitalism.
While the West fixates on Russia's political turmoil that threatens to bury Boris Yeltsin's reform Government, an economic revolution goes on largely unnoticed. Privatization hasn't always been pretty or fair. But it has been popular. It's been very, very quick. And, for Mr. Yeltsin, quick counts for a lot. When Russians go to the polls next month, he's counting on the new capitalists to back his pro-market reforms. 
 Privatization may be more than Mr. Yeltsin's ticket to political victory. It also creates an opening for Western help. Previous Western efforts to spur reform -- for example, with debt relief and funds to stabilize the ruble -- fell apart when Moscow was unable to provide assurances that it could manage economic policy so that the Western money wouldn't be wasted. Privatization is different. It's happening. All Mr. Clinton and other Western leaders need to do is push it along.
Mr. Yeltsin recognized that capitalism couldn't work without capitalists. Yet he couldn't sell state-owned factories because, without markets, no one could know their value and few Russians had any savings.
Faced with the same dilemma, the Solidarity-led Government in Poland created what first seemed a textbook-perfect plan. The plan would give state-owned enterprises to a few large mutual funds. Ownership of the funds, in turn, would be turned over to Polish citizens. The idea was to privatize companies but keep ownership concentrated so the owners would be able to keep the managers in check.
The plan's features added up to elegant economics, but dreadful politics. It failed to involve ordinary citizens. Three years later, the plan remains just that -- a plan, bottled up in Parliament.
Mr. Yeltsin chose a different tack. Borrowing from the Czechoslovaks, he involved citizens from the start. The plan typically turns half a company's shares over to its workers and managers -- in an attempt to buy their allegiance. Most of the company's other shares are put up for auction; ordinary citizens bid for shares with vouchers provided free by the Government.
Nearly every Russian citizen is participating; few have sold their vouchers for cash, which they're entitled to do, rather than holding them to buy shares.
But the plan could backfire, having been built more for speed than care. By spreading ownership thinly across the population, it might produce companies that are ungovernable. Businesses owned by millions will be controlled by no one, permitting managers to run riot with shareholders' assets. Privatization could unravel if the Yeltsin Government falls or if hyperinflation erupts. And as yet, participation is uneven across regions.
The threats are severe, but the West could make a difference. Prof. Andrei Shleifer of Harvard, an adviser to the Russian privatization minister, suggests two important props: Western seed money to encourage foreign companies to forge partnerships with Russian ones; and Western guarantees against political confiscation for foreign investors.
The political landscape in Russia looks bleak these days. With inflation escalating and production falling, the economic landscape doesn't look much better. But a crucial component of Mr. Yeltsin's reformist vision, privatization, is providing grounds for hope.

HEADLINE: Essay;
A Virgin No More

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Now we know why President Clinton resisted for two months the serious test of a formal news conference: the traditional format reveals his weaknesses.
He and his staff are patting each other on the back for not having made a gaffe and for anticipating the likely questions. Here is a more astringent view of Mr. Clinton's first foray into communications reality -- answering sustained professional questioning from grown-ups. 
 1. Ease up on the Staging. Clinton adopted the Reagan Grand Entrance, the long red-carpet walk created by Michael Deaver to add royal pomp to the proceedings and strike awe in the viewers. Its pomposity is wholly out of character for Bill Clinton; news conferences are Presidential business, not state ceremony.
And what's with the ferns? Sprouting up around the lectern were a half-dozen potted plants, separating the speaker from the audience by presenting the President as a flowering fount of knowledge. Al Gore's greenery influence is getting out of hand.
2. Cut the opening commercial. He began by reading (too fast and without feeling) a statement about supporting reform in Russia, then vitiated its effect with a long, dull pitch for his economic program. This mishmash was presumably intended to show a domestic President unconsumed by foreign affairs; instead, it showed him self-conscious about appearing to be.
Advice: Unless there is big news to break, go directly to questions.
3. Focus on an unambiguous lead story and stick to it. The President's purpose here was to show support for the embattled Boris Yeltsin. But by laying out America's "three interests . . . with or without President Yeltsin in authority," he diluted that support. Later he started to speak strongly for the Russian leader, but veered off on the last word: "Boris Yeltsin is the elected President of Russia, and he has shown a great deal of courage in sticking up for democracy and civil liberties and market reforms, and I'm going to support that." Not him, but that.
Obviously, Henry Kissinger's ambiguities got to Clinton, who is letting himself be torn between avoiding a charge of "Who lost Yeltsin?" and a charge of "Who stayed too long with Yeltsin?" Advice: If his aim is to strengthen the Russian, Clinton should make that decision and stop festooning it with escape hatches. 4. Be prepared for the unwanted tough question. Clinton surely knew he would be asked about gays in the military, but when Andrea Mitchell of NBC -- emerging as the most penetrating and fearless questioner in the White House press corps -- asked about the broader "difficulty with the Pentagon," the President looked as if he had been slapped with a wet fish.
He first fumbled by reaching for the illness of the Defense Secretary as an excuse, then quickly said Les Aspin was "either fully recovered now or on the verge of it." Either Mr. Aspin's absence is an excuse or it's not. Clinton ducked completely the repeated question about the Pentagon's failure to appoint a task force on gay rights, then erred in seeming to advocate non-combat limitations on homosexuals. I cannot believe this was a prepared answer.
5. Take control of the East Room. These sessions are not occasions to look bemused at confusion and to marvel at "self-selection" by shouting reporters. Advice: Point with a straight finger and stop making journalists look foolish by begging for the favor of your attention.
In his Presidential news debut, Clinton came across relaxed but uncertain. Contrast his confident answer about the "forest summit" with his walking-on-eggs responses on the Yeltsin summit. (The press fell short, too: not one question on dying Bosnia.)
Of course foreign affairs is trickier, but confidence can be gained by thinking through and rehearsing answers beforehand. Even a refusal to speculate about "hypotheticals" can be presented crisply; F.D.R. neatly turned aside what he called "iffy questions." It takes practice.
Regular news conferences impose discipline on an Administration, which must submit suggested answers to the White House beforehand; that forces decisions. The anticipated grilling also demands a President do his homework on every governmental subject. Clinton has been playing hooky and it shows.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Wealth Crosses The Pacific

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

DATELINE: ZHONGSHAN CITY, China

 BODY:
Boris Yeltsin's struggle for political survival, which rivets Europe and America, stirs mostly rhetorical yawns from East Asian leaders gathered here in southern China for a conference. To these government officials, business moguls and scholars, Russia is a long-term wreck about which outsiders can do little. Whether democratic or authoritarian, it is for them neither a threat nor, more importantly, a market.
What preoccupies East Asians today is not the old strategic mumbo-jumbo, but money. For the first time they are making it hand over fist as a region. And they want more -- as well as a bigger slice of the power salami. 
 The economic might that lodged in Europe during the Renaissance and crossed the Atlantic at the turn of this century is now traversing the Pacific. The pervasive new sense of economic dynamism gives East Asia its first glimmers of regional identity -- as well as self-confidence, optimism, a growing pride, a muscularity.
In the 1980's, in this region stretching from Singapore to Japan, the average gross national product grew more than twice as fast as it did in Europe and America. And that stunning gap will persist.
By 1990, East Asian trade with Western Europe and North America exceeded direct European-American trade. East Asia's savings rate -- 30 percent of G.N.P. -- dwarfs the West's -- 10 percent on average, much less in the U.S. And from savings come new investments.
Here in Guangdong Province, an area mired in poverty 10 short years ago, growth in the 1980's averaged an astounding 20 percent annually. This compares with 7 percent for the rest of China -- not bad either. In 1991, per capita income among Guangdong's population of about 70 million hit $1,230, very small by Western standards but an enormous leap forward in the developing world.
When you disembark from the Hong Kong ferry at Nansha and drive the 40 miles to the resort site of this Asia Society conference, you see scores of factories and high-rise apartments leaping from the mud alongside rice paddies. Thanks mainly to a rich network of overseas Chinese, more construction is under way in Southern China than anywhere else in the world today.
East Asians don't want anything getting in the way of this economic explosion -- not governments, not foreign policies, not protectionism, not American ideals, not America.
With few exceptions, leaders here are the world's most ardent advocates of freer trade. They feel East Asia has the skills to compete, and they want to knock down trade barriers. The U.S. and Japan, two flagging economic powerhouses, are the ones now dragging their heels.
Without exception, the East Asians at this conference worry that Washington will spoil everything by linking politics and economics. Specifically, they fear the U.S. will withdraw most-favored-nation trading status from China to punish Beijing for human rights violations, thereby disrupting regional trade.
"Economic growth is more important than political freedom," a Filipino businessman volunteered. "The Philippines, a former American colony, was the most subject to American idealism, and it's the place with the worst growth in the region. There is democratic gridlock in my country."
The consensus among Asians at the conference was that in their part of the world, government should be "for the people rather than by the people," as one Hong Kong businessman put it. Most argued strongly that authoritarian rule is the surest path to economic growth, and perhaps even eventually to democracy, as in Taiwan and South Korea. To them, Russia embodies the folly of putting the democratic cart before the economic horse.
The group not only questioned American ideology but bridled at American arrogance toward Asians. "Do you want to get even?" I asked. One particularly vehement Singaporean economist looked me in the eye, smiled, and said, "Yes."
But for all their new assertiveness, many Asian leaders here understand full well the political fragility underpinning their economic boom, and how easily booms go bust.
And for all their complaining about America, East Asians remain very much preoccupied by the U.S., still the biggest economic and security factor in their lives. It is a love-hate relationship -- with a little less love and a little more envy. Sensing their ascendancy and America's decline, they now want to redefine that relationship -- and they will.

HEADLINE: Whatever Yeltsin's Fate, Russia Can't Go Back;
Unemployment Crisis

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The fundamental economic issue in the contest between the Yeltsin Government and the Parliament is the choice between inflation and unemployment. The Government is right in its determination to halt accelerating inflation. That requires reining in the state budget deficit, which requires curtailment of the subsidies to wasteful and unprofitable enterprises. 
 But sudden elimination of subsidies will lead to mass unemployment. The Government's program provides for a social safety net, but it has not made a convincing case for having thought through the political and social consequences of unemployment.
The Central Bank, under the control of the Parliament, is right in its determination to prevent mass unemployment. Thus it has authorized the continuous expansion of money and credit to keep the inefficient subsidized enterprises in business. The bank's spokesmen pay lip service to the need for monetary stabilization, but their policies fuel inflation.
Mass unemployment could spell the end of such progress toward democratic market-based reform as the country has made. Even the British Government was forced by popular protest to abandon its very sensible plan to close 31 subsidized coal mines, which would have left 30,000 miners without jobs. Prospective unemployment in Russia ranges from Government estimates of 3.5 million to 6 million to the International Labor Organization estimate of 10 million to 11 million (out of a work force of 75 million). In the best circumstances, it would be difficult for a Russian Government to survive such a calamity.
The most strategic program the West could offer to Russia would help cushion the blow of the mass unemployment inevitable if there is to be sound economic reform. For a model, we can reach back into our own history to the last time massive unemployment threatened our political foundations. The public works programs of the New Deal then carried the country through the hardest times.
"The Perfect Gift for Mr. Yeltsin" (editorial, March 10), proposing United States support of an unemployment insurance plan for Russia, is on the right track. But, like our Great Depression, this is a time when investment in Russia's long-neglected infrastructure could be of strategic importance. Projects like highway and road building, for example, would provide large economic benefits in bringing farm products to urban markets and reducing transport costs. Labor-intensive projects in homebuilding, railbed maintenance, urban amenities and environmental restoration would also be suitable. A program of this sort would fit well with the Clinton Administration's commitment to investment in infrastructure in the United States.
With assistance from the West in providing job support for the unemployed, the Yeltsin Government would have a credible response to the opposition's legitimate concern about mass unemployment.
Russia's future will be shaped overwhelmingly by Russia's own politics and very little by Western well-wishers. But strategically selected help, like a public works program, may help tilt the balance in some small way.
 
JOSEPH S. BERLINER
Lexington, Mass., March 13, 1993
The writer is on the executive committee of the Russian Research Center, Harvard University.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Calls for More Cuts

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
With Congressional approval nearly clinched for President Clinton's economic plan, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, called today for even deeper cuts in the budget deficit, saying he was worried that it would begin rising again late this decade.
Testifying before the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Greenspan said the deficit would soar again late this decade unless Congress cut more over the five years covered by Mr. Clinton's plan and enacted new cuts after that. 
 Mr. Greenspan had given strong and crucial backing to Mr. Clinton's proposal shortly after it was disclosed in February and today he said he remained encouraged by Congress's efforts to approve it. But he went on to say that the Clinton plan by itself was not enough to remove the structural forces that have caused the Federal debt to balloon over the last decade.
 
Theory on Timing
 "I would argue strenuously that merely reducing" the deficit over the next five years "without addressing the period thereafter is not going to have the type of permanent effects that I think we need," he said.
Some analysts who watch the Fed suggested that Mr. Greenspan always thought the Clinton plan did not cut the deficit enough, but that he did not tell Congress that in February because that would have hurt the chances of Congress's approving the first credible deficit reduction plan in years. What is more, they said, if he had criticized the plan initially, bond markets might not have taken the Clinton plan seriously, and might have pushed long-term interest rates up rather than down.
But today, with the Clinton plan moving steadily through Congress, Mr. Greenspan apparently saw an opportunity to nudge Congress and the President to embrace even more deficit reduction. If they accept his invitation -- and there is no guarantee that they will -- that will no doubt push long-term interest rates down further, analysts say.
 
Worries About Inflation
 Mr. Greenspan said the bond markets were worried by the prospect of sharply higher deficits late this decade and the inflationary pressures these deficits might create. He predicted that long-term rates would fall a good deal further if Congress and the President tackled measures to attack the deficit after 1996.
Unless the issue of the post-1996 deficit problems are successfully addressed, "it will be very difficult to purge the inflation expectations that still exist in the system," he said.
In his prepared remarks, Mr. Greenspan apparently sought to mend fences with conservatives who have lambasted him in recent weeks for praising Mr. Clinton's deficit plan, which relies more on tax increases than spending cuts to reduce the deficit.
Although he said he was speaking in the abstract, rather than commenting on President Clinton's plan, the Fed chairman said that the best way by far to cut budget deficits was through spending cuts rather than tax increases, which he said depress the economy by discouraging investment and entrepreneurship.
"There is no alternative to achieving much slower growth of outlays if deficit control is our objective," he said. "This implies not only the need to make cuts now, but to control the growth of future spending."
But when Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat, asked which was worse, higher taxes or the deficit, Mr. Greenspan said the deficit was the greater evil.
 
Taxation Over Deficits
 "I do not like taxation," Mr. Greenspan said. "I think it's an inhibition to the system. But I like deficits less because I think they are a far more corrosive force."
He said he would prefer that all the deficit reduction be done on the spending side, but he acknowledged that this was politically impossible. He also took pains to explain that while he had often praised Mr. Clinton's economic plan for confronting the deficit head on, he never specifically endorsed it over other plans to cut the deficit.
To rein in spending, Mr. Greenspan said he would favor a constitutional amendment stating that increases in taxes or spending could be enacted only with a 60 percent super majority vote in the House and the Senate.
Mr. Greenspan said he also favored enacting sunset legislation under which all Federal spending programs would expire regularly. He said expiring programs that have merit would be reauthorized with little problems but programs with little justification would not receive the necessary votes.
The Fed chairman predicted that job growth would soon start to gather steam because the length of the workweek had risen to record levels. But he said the unemployment rate would probably not fall as quickly as he hoped.

HEADLINE: Balkanizing the Balkans

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 25

 BODY:
As the Bosnian war approaches its first anniversary next week, Serbian forces have embarked on a major offensive apparently intended to bury current peace plans beneath the upheaval and devastation on the ground.
Given their growing diplomatic isolation, the Serbs seem to have concluded that the only thing on their side is military might. And that isolation increased today when the head of the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government signed an international mediation team's peace plan in New York. [Page A12.] 
 The Serbs' thinking seems to be that they may as well be decisively employed now in capturing the areas of Bosnia that they covet and, at the very least, delay peacemaking plans until the situation in Russia is clearer.
 
Counting on Yeltsin's Defeat
 "The Serbs have been counting for months on Boris Yeltsin's defeat and ensuing support from Russia, and their hopes are high right now," said one Western diplomat. "Their offensive serves to delay diplomatic efforts to forge peace, as well as to unravel the maps the peacemakers have devised."
Russia is a traditional ally of the Serbs, and the Serbian Government headed by Slobodan Milosevic has been disappointed by Mr. Yeltsin's endorsement of sanctions and other measures against Yugoslavia, which now consists only of Serbia and Montenegro.
The focus of the Serbian nationalists' offensive in Bosnia has been the eastern region of that republic, particularly the pocket of Muslim-held territory along the border with Serbia around the town of Srebrenica. But there has also been a renewed onslaught on Sarajevo, featuring heavy shelling and increased probes against Bosnian Government defenses in the western fringes of the city.
In and around Srebrenica, where as many as 60,000 Muslims are now besieged, the objective seems clearly aimed at securing Serbian control of an area of strategic importance to Belgrade. It is a region envisioned by Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen, the international mediators on the Balkans, as being under Muslim control.
At a news conference here today, Cedric Thornberry, the deputy chief of the United Nations mission in Belgrade, said the Serbian offensive was moving forward, taking an average of one or two Muslim villages a day.
"If there is not a substantial diplomatic initiative, the whole area, including Srebrenica, could fall in the next 15 to 20 days," Mr. Thornberry said. "The consequences of this on the political side would be far-reaching because in the Vance-Owen plan this is seen as a basically Muslim province. In essence, the whole basis for the peace plan would be changed."
Serbian nationalist forces in Bosnia and the Yugoslav Army have effectively sealed off the area to reporters, so independent verification of the offensive is difficult. But Serbian leaders in Bosnia make no secret of their desire to take the area, which is important to them because it helps secure the road between Belgrade and Pale, the headquarters of the Bosnian Serbs, and because it affords them control of both banks of the Drina River, which for stretches forms the border between Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
"Eastern Bosnia is Serbian," Aleksa Buha, a top aide to the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, said in an interview this week. "Our goal is to defeat the enemy. Unfortunately when you fight a war, the goal is to disable the enemy."
In Sarajevo, the objectives of the new Serbian bombardment are less clear. But Western analysts expressed doubt that the offensive amounted to a preparation for an all-out attack on the Bosnian capital, which would cause enormous casualties on both sides and might provoke Western military intervention in Bosnia.
 
Strategy Backfired
 Rather, they believe, the artillery attack may have been intended to persuade the leader of the Bosnian Government, Alija Izetbegovic, not to sign the Vance-Owen plan. This, in turn, would have meant that Dr. Karadzic, the Bosnian Serbs' leader, would be less isolated in his rejection of the plan. But if this was the strategy, it backfired today when Mr. Izetbegovic signed the plan at the United Nations.
The Serbs also know that Sarajevo is the most powerful symbol of the war to the outside world and that its bombardment makes all peace calculations more difficult. At a time when Mr. Yeltsin is under pressure in Moscow, this suits them.
"A change of government in Russia is now Mr. Milosevic's greatest hope," said Vuk Draskovic, the leader of the main opposition party in Serbia, the Serbian Renewal Movement. "He is banking on it."
It seems clear that Mr. Milosevic's hand is not far removed from the current military activities of the Bosnian Serbs, even though the Serbian Government here clings doggedly to the claim that the Bosnian Serbs' affairs are beyond the control of Belgrade. The Bosnian Serbs receive most of their supplies and some of their manpower from Serbia, and Mr. Milosevic has the power to shut down this pipeline.
But at a time of economic hardship, with inflation running at more than 250 percent a month, fighting suits Mr. Milosevic because it is an effective distraction. Thus, turning up the military pressure in Bosnia at a time when peace negotiations are in an intensive phase appears to coincide with his interests.
Lieut. Gen. Philippe Morillon, the United Nations military commander in Bosnia, appeared to admit as much today by coming to Belgrade in an attempt to persuade Mr. Milosevic to halt the Bosnian Serb offensive.
Before leaving Tuzla in Bosnia, General Morillon said, "Mr. Milosevic alone can bring pressure on General Mladic." Gen. Ratko Mladic is the commander of the Bosnian Serb forces and has orchestrated the latest offensive.
After meeting with the Serbian leader, General Morillon said, "President Milosevic promised to help me in the implementation of every request I have made, that is, an immediate cease-fire, not only in the area of Srebrenica, but in the whole of Bosnia-Herzegovina."
But whatever Mr. Milosevic told the French general, Western diplomats believe the real thinking of the Serbs is abundantly clear. The Serbs, diplomats say, still reject a solitary state in Bosnia and Herzegovina and are trying by force of arms to insure that the nation is split into three states, the largest of which would belong to them.
