HEADLINE: Japanese Mix and Match Auto Plants and Markets

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GEORGETOWN, Ky.

 BODY:
Every so often on the Toyota Motor Corporation assembly line here, a Toyota Camry takes shape with the steering wheel on the right side. But more surprising than the steering wheel's location are the cars' destinations: the ports of Tawara, Japan, and Sheerness, England.
After a decade of making cars in America, Japanese auto makers like Toyota and Honda are turning their ships around and sending American-made cars to Japan, Taiwan, the Middle East and Europe. 
 It began as a trickle a few years ago, but exports are rising sharply and are expected to keep growing for a host of reasons. These include, Japanese auto executives say, the heightened efficiency of Japanese plants in the United States, the improved quality of American-made cars and the cost benefits of making cars in the United States instead of Japan.
 
 
An International System
 In an age of multinational corporations, executives and global markets, Japanese car companies like Toyota and the Honda Motor Company are pioneering the auto industry's first truly global manufacturing system. The idea is to perfect a car's design and production in one place and then churn out thousands of "world cars" each year that can be made in one place and sold around the globe.
 In the automotive industry, where developing cars for different markets can cost billions of dollars, what Toyota and Honda are attempting -- and what the Ford Motor Company is trying to mimic -- could sharply cut development costs, maximize the use of assembly plants and preserve the assembly-line efficiencies that are a hallmark of the Japanese "lean" production system.
In developing a strong export market, Honda is aiming for a "global base of complementary supply," said Roger Lambert, Honda's United States manager of corporate communications. "Japan can supply North America and Europe," he said. "North America can supply Japan and Europe, and Europe can supply Japan and the United States.
 
 
Two-Thirds of Strategy
 "So far, the first two are true," he added, referring to Honda's plants in Japan, North America and England. "This means you can more profitably utilize your production bases and talents."
 Politically, with Japan running a huge trade surplus with the United States, Toyota and Honda acknowledge that it is helpful for them to show Washington they are at least attempting to correct the imbalance by sending cars back home. Moreover, with an agreement last year to increase the flow of autos and parts from America to Japan, Toyota and Honda are only too happy to devise a way to ship their own cars back from the United States.
From a financial standpoint, in the decade or more that Japanese car companies make been building vehicles in the United States, the Japanese yen has risen about 50 percent against the dollar. That makes it less expensive to build cars in America, by some estimates giving American producers a cost advantage of $2,500 to $3,000 a car. That saving far outweighs the cost of shipping a car overseas.
But apart from the currency benefits, which can ebb and flow, is something of potentially longer-term importance, Japanese car makers said. Toyota is creating a system that for the first time allows the companies to manage their auto production levels between Japan and the United States. They are moving, the executives say, toward global manufacturing that can be fine-tuned on a quarterly basis according to economic conditions in different markets.
The strategy of Toyota and Honda contrasts with that of American companies that have historically erected foreign plants and elaborate international operations solely to supply local or regional markets. Although Ford plans to build a new small sedan in Europe and America, neither Ford nor the General Motors Corporation have used their foreign subsidiaries to develop and build cars for numerous markets around the world.
 "It was always more convenient and less costly to focus on the domestic market than to make the long-term commitment to foreign markets," said Robert A. Lutz, president of the Chrysler Corporation and a former Ford of Europe executive.
But even in Detroit, the Big Three auto makers have become more aggressive exporters to Europe and East Asia, sending Jeeps to Japan and mini-vans to Europe. Like the Japanese in America, they have benefited from the dollar's weakness and they are under pressure to demonstrate that their products are attractive elsewhere.
 
Fine-Tuning Production
 But the swing toward global management represents yet another step forward by the Japanese car companies in their drive for manufacturing efficiency, said Daniel T. Jones, an automotive industry researcher at the Cardiff Business School at the University of Wales and co-author of "The Machine That Changed the World," a book that analyzes Japanese car manufacturing.
"In the early days, it was brownie points to export to Japan," Mr. Jones said. "But it's more than that. The Toyota system depends on a tremendous amount of fine-tuning of the production system and eliminating all wasted productivity. Line balancing is an important part of the process -- to try and keep all plants at an optimum level. So you gradually slow each plant rather than penalize one plant a lot."
At Toyota, globalization has a production jargon all its own. Phrases like "line balancing," "leveling" of production and "continuous flow" help capture the notion of trying to wring maximum efficiency from assembly lines even when few cars need to be built.
In the last year, as Japan slid into recession and the Toyota labor force at one big plant, Tsutsumi, faced less work, executives at Toyota's Japanese headquarters decided that the Toyota plants in the United States and Japan should share the pain, said Alex M. Warren Jr., senior vice president of Toyota's Kentucky plant.
 
 
Avoiding Layoffs
 Instead of sharply reducing production and idling many workers, the Georgetown plant is gradually paring its daily production by about 7.4 percent, to 940 cars in May from 1,015 Camry sedans and station wagons last month. This month, 1,005 cars will roll off the assembly line a day; in April, 960. Over the same period, Tsutsumi is also gradually reducing its daily production, Mr. Warren said.
Avoiding layoffs is part of the Japanese production theology. But it has a point, too. Keeping workers occupied is particularly important in Toyota's system, which in both Japan and the United States emphasizes worker efficiency and multiple skills.
As car sales have waned in Japan's recession, the number of hours Japanese auto workers spend on the job has been cut from an average of 2,300 a year to 1,800, or more than 20 percent, said Mr. Jones, the auto industry researcher. Because the Japanese car companies demand a high level of worker participation to maintain high-quality manufacturing, they choose to slow the work rather than to lay off and rehire workers.
"The Japanese think of workers more as a long-term resource," Mr. Jones said. "The last thing they want to do is hire and fire workers."
The "leveling" of production, by keeping output humming but at a slower pace, also suits Toyota's production techniques, which call for lower inventories of parts from outside suppliers, compared with the much larger quantities of parts on hand at most American car plants. It is easier for Toyota or Honda suppliers to adjust their schedules if they are supplying the main plant on a "just in time" basis than if they were geared up for huge volumes in advance, Mr. Warren said.
None of this would work, of course, if the quality of the American-made cars was inferior. When Japanese companies started building vehicles in the United States in the early 1980's, they worried about whether American workers could duplicate the quality that helped to make Japanese cars so popular.
But Toyota officials say the quality of the company's American-made autos is indistinguishable from Japanese-made models. It has to be. In Japan, car buyers are so particular that some get down on the showroom floor to eyeball the alignment of the doors. Others are finicky about the finish coat of paint.
Last year, the Georgetown plant produced 240,000 Camrys, including 3,734 right-hand-drive station wagons that were loaded in a huge rail yard next to the plant here and transported by train to Long Beach, Calif., and then shipped to Japan. This year, 9,600 of the station wagons, which are made only in Kentucky, are headed for Japan. Later in the year, the company will export a coupe version to Japan, industry analysts say.
The station wagon is pitched in Japan as an American car, and its made-in-America imprimatur is emphasized in a sales brochure. A video for potential customers shows the wagon, renamed the Scepter, zipping through Kentucky's rolling horse country near the Toyota plant.
 
 
Japan as Growing Importer
 By 1996, Toyota Motor Manufacturing U.S.A. expects Japan to surpass Taiwan as its biggest export market, absorbing 95,000 cars from the United States. That is more than double last year's worldwide exports from its Kentucky plant and an assembly plant it operates jointly with General Motors in Fremont, Calif. The Georgetown plant sent 8,925 Camry sedans to Taiwan last year, in large part because Taiwan has trade barriers against imports from Japan.
 For Honda, which was exporting American-made cars even before Toyota, Japan is already the biggest export market. Without the exports to Japan, Honda's Ohio plant would have had five weeks' less work last year, said Mr. Lambert, the corporate communications manager at Honda.
"There is the basic economic value of strengthening our position by having an export market in rather tough economic times," Mr. Lambert said.
And Japanese customers' demands for high quality helped improve Honda cars no matter the market. "By paying attention to close panel fits and the tiniest of finishes we have improved the fit and finish for every buyer," Mr. Lambert said.

HEADLINE: Sanctions on North Korea May Get Tighter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
The United States and its allies in Asia may move to impose stiff sanctions on North Korea to pressure it to abide by the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today.
The measures would include denying the isolated Government oil, gas, other raw materials and even food, he told a House appropriations subcommittee. 
 South Korea's Foreign Minister, Han Sung Joo arrived tonight for talks with Mr. Christopher on coping with the North Korean nuclear threat. North Korea announced on March 12 that it was withdrawing from the treaty, which it signed in 1985, and earlier this year it barred international inspectors from two sites, raising concerns it was hiding a weapons program.
Mr. Christopher said the Security Council would take up the issue at the end of the month or in early April.
China, which has tried to mediate the dispute, said on Tuesday that it opposed any international sanctions against North Korea for withdrawing from the treaty. As a permanent member of the Security Council, China has veto power over any United Nations sanctions.

HEADLINE: KOHL, DUE IN U.S., LOSES SOME LUSTER

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, March 25

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, the strongman of Europe for most of George Bush's Presidency, went to Washington today for a meeting with President Clinton on Friday.
But the country he leads now looks far less economically formidable and politically self-confident than it did after reunification two and a half years ago. 
 For months, Germany's political system has been all but paralyzed by indecision about how to meet the problems of the swelling ranks of refugees from Eastern Europe, the spiraling costs of absorbing the ruined Communist economy of eastern Germany, and the growing expectations of its international partners.
For years, Germany has been calling on other countries to contribute to Russia and other former Soviet republics as much as Bonn has provided -- nearly $50 billion since 1989 -- to keep the forces of democracy and free markets from coming to grief there. Now that President Clinton is proposing a new program of aid to bolster President Boris N. Yeltsin, Mr. Kohl is expected to say Germany is broke and has done enough already.
 
Germany Faulted on Balkans
 Germany also showed on the eve of Mr. Kohl's departure that it was hardly in a position to lead Europe out of the morass in the Balkans. Mr. Kohl's coalition was so divided on what to do about one important issue relating to the war in the Balkans that it decided, in effect, to sue itself and buck the decision to a federal Constitutional Court.
The issue was whether the clauses against war-making in the German Constitution of 1949 would require Bonn to pull its crew members off NATO air-surveillance missions of military flights over Bosnia if, as expected, the Security Council authorizes force to keep Serbian aircraft from flying.
The Christian Democratic alliance of Mr. Kohl said the constitutional ban on "acts tending to and undertaken with the intent to disturb the peaceful relations between nations" did not apply to peacekeeping missions under the aegis of the United Nations.
But the Free Democrats said the Constitution needed to be amended, which can happen only with the consent of the Social Democratic opposition, before German troops could be put into potential combat situations beyond the country's borders.
Because no country really wants to take the first step into involvement in the Balkan war, and lately because of the political turmoil in Russia, the Security Council has repeatedly put off a vote on enforcing the flight ban.
 
Couldn't Agree on Policy
 Until Wednesday night, the Government kept putting off a decision because it could not agree on a policy.
German participation is key to the surveillance. The 18 four-engined American E-3A planes in the operation are based primarily at Geilenkirchen, near the Netherlands, and Germans make up about 30 percent of the 1,500 military personnel involved, NATO officers say.
Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel and the Free Democrats have made clear that for them, the problem is not German troops' staying on the planes but the necessity of changing the Constitution to let them.
So late Wednesday night, the Free Democrats and the Christian Democrats agreed that if the United Nations passes the resolution, Mr. Kohl's party would order troops to stay on the surveillance planes and Mr. Kinkel's party would then apply for a temporary injunction and a quick court ruling.
The opposition Social Democratic leader, Hans-Ulrich Klose, today sarcastically called this "a really classy way to govern." His party has challenged German participation in the naval blockade of Serbia, and it is not willing to go along with a constitutional change to permit broader participation in peacekeeping missions.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Continue Drop

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time claims for jobless benefits dropped by 2,000 in the third week in March for the third straight decline, the Government said today.
The Labor Department said new applications for unemployment insurance in the week that ended last Saturday totaled 349,000, down from 351,000 a week earlier and 361,000 in the week that ended on March 6. 
 The four-week moving average of new jobless claims totaled 359,250 during the period ended March 20, down from 359,750 a week earlier and the lowest since 353,250 were filed for the period ended March 6.

HEADLINE: Second Chance on Environment

SERIES: What Price Cleanup? -- Last of five articles.

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
Four laws that help form the foundation of United States environmental policy are up for renewal in the next two years, and leading environmental advocates in Congress say they intend to use the opportunity to begin redefining how the nation safeguards its air, land and water.
The Clean Water Act, the Endangered Species Act, the Superfund law for cleaning up toxic wastes and the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act for disposing of hazardous chemicals all are under Congressional review. Calls for change from lawmakers focus on their desire for more rigorous science and better analyses of the costs and benefits. Several leading members said that too often Congress has moved from panic to panic and not developed a uniform approach to consider risks. 
 "Costs are out of sight," and the benefits from many recent environmental programs are not apparent, said Representative Mike Synar, the Oklahoma Democrat who is chairman of a House subcommittee on the environment. Now, he added, "we have a chance to end the quilt-patch form of environmental lawmaking."
Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, the ranking Republican on the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works, said current policies had already controlled 90 percent of the pollution. "But now there is increasing recognition of the costs," he said. "It will cost twice as much or three times as much to get the last little percent. Do we want to do that?"
Others in Congress, notably Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, see it as their job to make sure that cost savings do not compromise safety.
Several members of Congress said that one lesson of environmental policy-making in the 1980's was that acting on the basis of being safe rather than sorry had unintended consequences. Not the least of them has been many costly rules that are not producing measurable improvements in public health or the environment.
There is a higher premium on preventing such mistakes in the 1990's, and not only because of scarce financial resources. With even larger global environmental problems becoming apparent from climate change to deforestation, the nation could make even bigger mistakes if it acts aggressively without a measured, careful analysis of the consequences.
 
4 Laws as One Program
 This week, Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who heads the Committee on Environment and Public Works, began a series of hearings to develop a comprehensive and effective environmental program.
Mr. Baucus's effort is the first time a Congressional committee has attempted to consider four separate laws as related parts of a unified program of environmental protection. In an interview, he said that it was too early to make specific recommendations about amending the laws, but he also said that all would undergo some changes.
Senator Baucus and Representative Synar said their work was guided by two main questions.
First, what should lawmakers and regulators do after they discover a new environmental problem that seems dangerous -- but before careful scientific analysis has shown the degree of risk? Many environmentalists say waiting for more data might mean that the Government reacts only after people have begun dying.
Second, what should be done about regulations enacted over the last 15 years that set inordinately strict standards for toxic compounds in air, water or the ground? Most were based on rodent studies now perceived to be flawed, and even scientists who conducted the studies say that as many as two-thirds of the compounds deemed carcinogenic would present no danger to humans.
William K. Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency in the Bush Administration, said one problem was the air of crisis that surrounded every new environmental concern.
 
'Cost Considerations'
 "It is far past time when we become mature enough as a nation to address an environmental issue, mobilize to support it, and do so without acting in an emergency atmosphere," he said. "Not everything is a crisis that has to be corrected tomorrow. And we need to make clear that cost considerations are relevant to any remedy. Cities just aren't going to keep spending more on cleaning up toxic dumps, for instance, than they are on their schools."
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, has introduced a bill that would require the Government to amass much stronger scientific proof and convene expert panels to consider a new environmental rule before it is issued.
Environmentalists call that thinking a recipe for disaster.
"As a scientist, we always hope to have more research to answer complex questions," said Dr. Adam Finkel of Resources for the Future, an environmental research group in Washington. "But in 1993 we don't have the scientific basis for rejecting the current approach, which says we should be prudent when faced with uncertainty."
Many experts also assert that, just as damage from forest fires is reversible, so too is damage from many pollutants. At the same time, the National Cancer Institute and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta say that even after a generation of study, there is no confirmed evidence that pollutants are causing epidemics of cancer, birth defects or other chronic diseases.
The cancer institute says about 500,000 people die from cancer each year. Some institute officials estimate that between 1 and 3 percent of those deaths resulted from environmental pollutants. That would be between 5,000 and 15,000 people. Other scientists say that exposure to the panoply of chemicals in the environment causes other affects in people, among them infertility and nervous system disorders.
Experts urging the most conservative course say environmental poisons may be causing as many as 15 percent of all cancer. The higher number takes into account research indicating that farm and factory workers exposed to high levels of toxic substances are dying at higher than normal rates from certain types of cancers.
Senator Moynihan believes research like this can be improved and put to better use.
"We're entirely capable of moving on to a more productive period of environmental protection that is based on clear factual assessments of what produces risks to human health and the environment," he said.
If the Government decides to undo existing regulations it faces years of work, following much the same process of hearings and notification periods that led to the rules.
"Once something is decided as being a threat, it is very hard to recognize that new information suggests that it's not," said Carol M. Browner, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.
Whatever new approach Congress or the Clinton Administration takes in the next two years, leading lawmakers say they want to be careful not to weaken a number of regulations that are widely believed to provide valuable protections for public health. High on that list are the landmark environmental laws passed in the 1970's like the Clean Water Act and the laws establishing protection for public lands.
But environmental experts say many other programs do not offer clear benefits. With this in mind, Mr. Synar and other lawmakers have begun talking about some principles they hope to use as they consider the four major laws that are up for renewal:
*Require the Government to consider the cost of a regulation before it is issued. Several environmental statutes, including the 1972 Clean Water Act, prohibit the Government from taking costs into account.
*Increase spending on problems now regarded as more important, like protecting endangered plants and animals, and reducing financing for less dangerous problems, like cleaning up toxic waste sites.
*Give businesses and cities more flexibility to decide how to comply with environmental standards, ending the expensive and rigid approach demanded under most laws.
Even as they work toward these goals, the lawmakers said they were fully aware that 15 years from now that it was likely that Congress would look back and see that other kinds of mistakes had been made. But at least, they said, in the 1990's the United States would have begun to take more methodical steps based on better science to solve environmental problems.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
The Series: A Recap of the Articles

 The first article in this series, which appeared on Sunday, reported that leading scientists, economists and Government officials had reached the dismaying conclusion that much of America's environmental program had gone seriously awry. They said the nation's environmental policy had been allowed to evolve in reaction to popular panics rather than in response to sound scientific analyses.
The article on Monday described how Congress banned the practice of dumping sewage in the sea after trash, industrial waste and worse washed ashore on the East Coast in 1988.
Tuesday's article described the serious doubts being raised about the validity of rat and mouse studies, long the Government's most important tool for identifying environmental hazards and setting priorities for Federal regulation. Chemicals often have different effects in animals and humans.
Wednesday's article described how a movement born in Columbus, Ohio, prompted the National League of Cities to call for an update of environmental laws.

HEADLINE: China Finds Way to Slay Dragon of Inflation

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 25

 BODY:
One of the biggest headaches for China's leaders as this year began was an overheating economy, which threatened to ignite inflation. They fretted about it, fought about it and warned the public about it.
Now, in a demonstration of the power of positive thinking, the problem has disappeared. 
 It is not that anything happened to the economy. Rather, an 88-year-old retiree, a grandfather with no training in economics and no formal position these days, reportedly told associates that the economy was fine.
Since the old man's name is Deng Xiaoping, and he happens to be China's unofficial emperor, everyone decided that he had a point.
Leaders stopped warning about "overheating" and began urging the public to "seize the opportunity" and pick up the economic pace. The central bank announced that it would pursue an easy monetary policy. The expression "guo ri," or overheating, virtually vanished from the official press.
The episode illustrates how China functions these days, and some economists believe it also underscores the risks of basing policy decisions on the whims of emperors. For even if China's officials have all got the message, the economy has not.
"It's clearly overheating," a foreign economist in Beijing said. "Look at the way prices are going up, look at the way investment is soaring, look at the shortages and bottlenecks.
"For a dozen years, China has been following a boom-bust cycle, and now we're headed down the same road. I can see the bust coming."
But some other economists are much more optimistic. And even some of the overheating scenarios -- such as rising inflation that eventually forces a yearlong "recession" in which the economy grows by only 4 percent or so -- would be a dream come true for the United States or Europe.
The real problem is political rather than economic: How will the public react to rising prices? The last bout of inflation helped provoke the Tiananmen demonstrations in 1989.
Already people are grumbling about rising prices and about new programs for raising medical costs and housing prices to rational levels. Economists say price liberalization is a great idea, but workers are unconvinced.
Official statistics show that by the end of February, price levels in major cities stood 15.3 percent higher than a year ago. China does not disclose monthly changes in inflation, but the statistics it does release suggest that inflation is now probably running at an annual rate of more than 20 percent in major cities, and gaining momentum.
Concern about overheating is perhaps inevitable considering that China is experiencing a spectacular boom, resulting in 12.8 percent growth in gross domestic product last year. Most economists believe that this is too fast a clip to be sustained for more than a couple of years.
"The Government officials I talk to are all worried about the economy overheating," an Asian diplomat in Beijing said. "It's not a certainty, but it's a concern."
The economic boom is partly a result of a wave of construction of office buildings, homes, hotels and highways. In the first two months of 1993, state-owned companies increased investment in fixed assets by 64 percent over the same period last year.
The boom is also fueled by loose credit from local bank branches that the central Government has found it difficult to control. The money supply, including cash and checking accounts, rose 37 percent last year.
A survey of 114 Chinese economists, widely reported in the Chinese press in January, found that by a two-to-one margin they believed that the economy "is beginning to grow too quickly and may lead to inflation." The official newspapers in December and January printed front-page editorials against overheating, and the leadership signaled that it planned to slow the pace.
Prime Minister Li Peng and other officials who had tried to restrain the economy apparently gave up when they heard Mr. Deng say in December and January that a bit of overheating was nothing to worry about. Mr. Li recently called for "better and faster economic development."

HEADLINE: Bosnian Muslims Join Croats in Accepting Peace Pact

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 25

 BODY:
The President of Bosnia's Muslim-dominated Government agreed today to a plan to end the year-old war that has torn apart his country, and international mediators said later that the world must prepare to take tougher action against the Serbs, whose leadership in Bosnia still refuses to make peace.
After a day of last-minute bargaining and delays, President Alija Izetbegovic approved a map dividing Bosnia and Herzegovina into 10 near-autonomous provinces and an amended plan for governing the country while a new constitution is drawn up. 
 The Bosnian Croats have also accepted the plan, which was drawn up by a United Nations-European Community mediation team and includes elaborate provisions for a cease-fire, the disengagement of forces and deployment of a United Nations peacekeeping force up to 50,000 strong.
 
Recalcitrant Serb
 The leader of Bosnia's Serbian nationalists, Radovan Karadzic, refused to sign either the map or the government plan. In the course of the last few days, he has made clear that he does not share the the fundamental aim of the mediators, Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen: ending the war on terms that preserve Bosnia as a unified country.
Dr. Karadzic said it was "unacceptable for Serbs to be subjected to pressure" and called today's action "a victory for the Croatian and Muslim coalition."
President Izetbegovic said he had only accepted the plan with a number of conditions, including an end to Serbian "aggression."
He also said the Clinton Administration had undertaken to do "everything in its power" to lift the arms embargo imposed on Bosnia and the rest of the old Yugoslav federation if the Serbs continue to attack. The embargo has made it difficult for the Government to upgrade its arsenal to match the well-stocked Serbs.
But in Washington, Administration officials said only that they were considering support for an end to the embargo against the Government.
 
Meeting Mediators' Goals
 The outcome of this latest round of talks was substantially what Mr. Vance and Lord Owen sought when they moved the negotiations from Geneva to New York last month in the hope that the Security Council would press the Muslims into an agreement with the Croats, leaving the Serb nationalists isolated.
The mediators hope that this isolation will increase the pressure on the Bosnian Serbs and their patrons in Serbia to accept the peace plan. But critics have noted that Yugoslavia, which now includes only Serbia and Montenegro, has weathered increasing isolation, including a United Nations trade embargo, with no slackening of support for the Serbs in Bosnia.
In an interview today, Dr. Karadzic said he doubted that his people would ever accept the Vance-Owen plan.
"There is no chance they will accept the map," he said. "Anyway I will tell them about the worst possibilities of sanctions and pressures. Then you will find 12 million Serbs are ready to be opposed to the whole world."
He said Slobodan Milosevic, president of the Serbian republic in Yugoslavia, was unlikely to pressure him to accept the plan; neither does he think Russia will press him to sign, he said, adding that he plans to visit Moscow next month.
 
Commitment to Convoys
 Dr. Karadzic also said his first act on returning to his headquarters at Pale, outside Sarajevo, would be "to insure that all humanitarian convoys get through our lines" in eastern Bosnia and to Sarajevo.
At a news conference after the signing, the mediators said they would ask the Security Council to back the plan and to impose tough new economic sanctions on the rump Yugoslav federation and on the Serbian-controlled areas of Bosnia if Dr. Karadzic does not sign as well.
Calling it "a mistake to imagine negotiations can continue without limit," Lord Owen said, "the highest priority is to demonstrate sanctions will be applied more toughly."
"If there is no readiness to come around to this peace agreement, the international community will have to take some further action, and it will be tough action," he said. "Hard choices must be made."
Lord Owen, who represents the European Community, said he hoped the Security Council would now be prepared "to back its words with actions and bring a range of pressures to bear" on the Serbian leadership.
But Lord Owen came down against lifting the arms embargo on Bosnia, saying the danger was that Russia would supply the Serbs with arms and the war would intensify. And he called for sanctions to be relaxed gradually as and if the Serbs carry out the peace plan. "You can't have a stick without a carrot," he said.
 
'Major Step Forward'
 Mr. Vance, representing the United Nations, called today's signing "a major step forward" and said that while Dr. Karadzic had not signed, he had indicated the intention to stay in touch with the mediators and was returning home to consult his supporters and "reflect."
Lord Owen said he thought the Security Council should give Dr. Karadzic about a week to consult his colleagues and give a final yes or no answer on the package.
Tonight the Security Council issued a statement welcoming the agreement and calling on the Serbian side to sign as well and cease its "ethnic cleansing" and "obstruction of humanitarian assistance."
The Council said it "stands ready to take the steps required to bring about a peace settlement."
 
New Sanctions Proposed
 The United States, Britain and France have already prepared a list of sanctions that would further reduce Yugoslavia's contacts by banning shipment of goods across its territory and seizing more of its overseas assets.
They are also currently assisting Yugoslavia's neighbors and European Community countries in tightening the existing trade embargo, which was imposed last year after the Council decided Serbia's government was helping the Serbs in Bosnia to set up an independent state and drive out other ethnic groups.
But the international situation has changed in recent days in ways that promise to make the Vance-Owen strategy more difficult to achieve.
The power struggle in Moscow has already forced President Clinton to give a higher priority to helping President Boris N. Yeltsin than to advancing the Bosnian peace plans.
This became clear Wednesday when the United States agreed to postpone a Security Council decision to enforce the flight ban over Bosnia because Mr. Yeltsin feared that any such anti-Serb move would strengthen the hand of his enemies at home.
It may thus be difficult for Russia to give its full support to tough new sanctions against Serbia as long as Mr. Yeltsin's position is being seriously challenged by opponents who seem prepared to use Russia's traditional ties to the Serbs as a weapon in the domestic political contest.
 
Concession on Sarajevo
 In order to win President Izetbegovic's support, Mr. Vance and Lord Owen agreed to small changes in the proposed provincial boundaries and in the arrangements for an interim government; these changes seem to make the package even more unacceptable to the Serbs.
The mediators slightly enlarged the province surrounding Sarajevo, insuring that it would have a Muslim majority. And they agreed that while all three ethnic factions would share power equally in governing the capital city, the government of the rest of the Sarajevo province would be in Muslim hands.
Dr. Karadzic has anyway hardened his position on both the map and the future government arrangements, demanding extensive new lands in eastern Bosnia and saying there should be no central government at all until a new constitution is agreed upon. This would leave the Serbian provinces as states within a state.
Some Yugoslavia experts at the United Nations fear that the Serbian reaction to today's agreement between Croats and Muslims will be to open a new offensive, taking advantage of the difficulty that Russia faces in taking action against them while President Yeltsin's position is threatened.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Job Plan Sounding Less Monumental

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
In his economic message to a joint session of Congress last month, President Clinton described a soaring effort "to create jobs and guarantee a strong recovery," to rebuild the nation's decaying foundation, feed and house the unfortunate and give jobs to half-a-million unemployed.
But as the Senate began a raucous debate today on Mr. Clinton's proposal to inject $16.3 billion as an emergency stimulus for the economy, the effort was in peril of becoming something considerably more mundane: a political football, fumbled by the White House and pounced on by Republicans and dissidents in the President's party. 
 Not that the stimulus proposal -- the minuscule tail-end of Mr. Clinton's five-year, $8 trillion budget package -- was in danger of being defeated or even seriously altered. Despite stormy speeches and filibuster threats, the Senate's 57 Democrats seemed likely to pass and send it to the White House next week, just as the House did last week.
The prospect that it may prove an embarrassment, on the other hand, was more palpable. As the economy has revived, the White House has been increasingly pressed to show that its emergency legislation addresses an emergency, that its stimulus will actually stimulate, that its unemployed will gain many permanent jobs or that the red ink it creates as part of a deficit-reduction package is a political plus.
 
Republicans Zero In
 The Republicans zeroed in this week on disclosures that the stimulus includes proposals to inventory fish, build grandstands for canoe races and make films on Acadian culture.
The package's delicate position was underscored today, when Senate debate was quickly stalled by a filibuster, not by Republicans, but by two unhappy Democrats, Senators David L. Boren of Oklahoma and John B. Breaux of Louisiana.
The two fiscal conservatives want to put off spending about half of the stimulus money until Congress locks Mr. Clinton's broader deficit-cutting plan into law, probably this summer. They decided to revolt, sending the Senate into gridlock, when the President's point man on the bill, Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, denied them and the bill's other enemies any such opportunity.
Using the Senate's Gordian rules, he arranged debate so that critics could not amend the stimulus package without first voting against it -- something most Democrats, whose fates are lashed to Mr. Clinton's, are loath to do, even symbolically.
Mr. Byrd needs 60 votes to break the filibuster, but was not certain he had them. Senators Boren and Breaux also need 60 votes, to break any Republican filibuster should they be allowed to offer their amendment, but were not sure they had them either. So the three faced off for more than six hours, daring each other to try something, until everyone finally got tired and went home.
Mr. Boren said that he and Mr. Breaux would suspend their filibuster, at least temporarily, but he was not certain what would happen next.
 
Minimal Results Expected
 On its face, this is much ado about almost nothing. While Mr. Clinton this week called the stimulus bill an essential bridge from economic doldrums to recovery, most economists now agree that it will accomplish little. Of the $16.3 billion allotted, $10 billion to $12.7 billion would enter the economy this fiscal year. Nor would a great many of the jobs it would create be permanent.
Even many Democrats who believe that an economic jolt is no longer needed support the stimulus plan because it would spend on traditional Democratic causes. Mr. Clinton would pour another $556 million into the Head Start program; $300 million more into childhood immunizations; $14 million more into housing for the very poorest rural people; $1 billion into summer jobs for poor youths, and $4 billion in extended unemployment benefits.
But Republican critics have scored by highlighting some proposals that elicit less sympathy. There would be $2 billion to make up a shortfall in a college student loan fund, which would educate students but stimulate the production of few new jobs, and $6 million would be spent on programs to recycle escaping methane from coal mines, landfills and farm-animal dung.
 
Some Strange Programs
 One measure that has been killed would have subsidized loans for casinos on Indian reservations. Among still-extant proposals, the Interior Department would spend $1.4 million to make line drawings of 28 historic buildings, $75,000 to prepare atlases of freshwater fish in three states. And the Forest Service would spend $800,000 to build grandstands and the like for the canoeing course for the 1996 Summer Olympics.
At his news conference this week, Mr. Clinton, who has been stung by the attacks, said those ideas were not officially his Administration's ideas, but arose when critical lawmakers asked Clinton aides for lists of "every absurd thing you could possibly spend the money on." But that is incorrect. The proposals were official submissions, usually offered by Cabinet secretaries or senior aides.
One that has remained is a proposal by the Army Corps of Engineers to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars for automatic piezometers -- devices that gauge the pressure inside dams -- to replace models that now must be read manually.
The proposal prompted what may have been the best line of the long debate over the stimulus, offered by Representative John T. Myers, Republican of Indiana.
"Automating to create jobs -- that's a dichotomy in itself, isn't it?" he said. "That is government work for you. Highly labor-intensive automation. O.K."

HEADLINE: Sacramento Portrait;
Well Liked Even by California Rivals, Latest Brown Is Now Early Favorite

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif.

 BODY:
There was a made-for-television moment here one recent morning that most politicians could only dream of.
With a baby on each hip and the cameras rolling, Kathleen Brown, Treasurer of California, went to the bank to buy bonds for her twin grandchildren and remind voters that politics is her family business. 
 A few hours later and a few blocks away, there was a dry-as-dust hearing of a State Senate subcommittee on indebtedness and financing.
And Kathleen Brown was there too, without cameras or cuddly props, testifying about how California can regain its luster with Wall Street.
 
Favorite of the Pros
 Slick politician and sober administrator. These are the polarities of Ms. Brown's days, a year and a half before statewide elections but with Democrat officeholders ready to anoint her the next governor, as they did her father and brother before her.
Some recent numbers explain the party professionals' heady rush to declare a winner even before there are any declared candidates:
Ms. Brown has already raised more than $2 million, a stunning sum at this stage of the game. In recent polls, she is running well ahead of Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, and in front of the Insurance Commissioner, John Garamendi, her most likely primary opponent. And six of 10 registered voters say they are disinclined to re-elect Mr. Wilson.
These numbers may thrill the party faithful, but in Ms. Brown's camp they spell worry about being the front-runner in a race not yet begun.
 
Focus on Today
 "I have lived long enough on this earth as a Brown to know that rising expectations can only lead to lower expectations," said Ms. Brown, who is 47 years old. "So I'm falling back on what my mother taught me, which is to focus on what I'm doing now: To borrow low and invest high."
How long can Ms. Brown fly high without offering concrete proposals to fix the mess this state is in?
At the subcommittee hearing, one Republican state Senator, Robert Beverly, pressed her hard but without success. With spiraling costs and shrinking revenues -- a result of immigration, recession and assorted expensive disasters -- would she balance the budget with higher taxes or lower spending?
"All options should be considered," Ms. Brown murmured.
 
A Stand or a Pose?
 Such haziness will not be tolerated indefinitely, Dan Schnur, a top aide to Governor Wilson, predicted. Posters of Mr. Wilson wearing Mickey Mouse ears now adorn lamp posts in Sacramento. But the wounded Governor could be an unintended beneficiary if President Clinton succeeds in righting the economy.
Mr. Schnur has already created a line for television describing what he sees as Ms. Brown's reluctance to take substantive positions on difficult issues: "Some people take a stand. Kathleen strikes a pose."
But she strikes it with panache, as she did at the Wells Fargo Bank branch, where she bought $250 in bonds for each of her grandchildren.
As Ms. Brown checked the shoulder of her fuchsia suit for drool, 11-month-old Katherine Brown Armstrong teethed on a bond application and her twin, Brendan Arthur, pretended to yak on the telephone.
 
Easy Questions First
 The first question by the assembled local reporters -- "What year will the twins be eligible to run for governor?" -- was a real softball, and Ms. Brown laughed with everyone else.
Later, she basked in the success of this staged moment as she made her way to one of several Capitol meetings about California's bleak economic picture, its bad credit rating and its cash crisis, which for the second year will leave coffers empty before the end of the fiscal year.
"Weren't they adorable?" she asked. "Now I understand why my father was so shameless about interjecting his children and his grandchildren."
Ms. Brown is the third member of the clan to aspire to California's highest office. Her father, Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, was governor from 1959 to 1967 and was considered the master builder, leaving a legacy of highways, aqueducts and schools. Her brother, Edmund G. Brown Jr., served from 1975 to 1983. Jerry Brown was considered a kind of mad genius, ahead of his time in terms of environmental regulation. Ms. Brown is said, by admirers and critics alike, to embody the best of both, with her brother's brains and her father's charm.
 
Cookie Jars and Budgets
 Politician Brown gave way to Treasurer Brown at the hearing of the Senate subcommittee, which was looking for ways to avoid repeating last summer's budget embarrassment. Using everyday analogies about empty cookie jars, Ms. Brown urged the same remedies she had proposed during last year's 63-day budget stalemate, when the state paid its bills with i.o.u.'s: realistic economic forecasts and a timely budget.
In state budget wars, the Treasurer's office is more a pulpit than a position of real authority. Still, some Wall Street analysts say that Ms. Brown's plain-spoken advice to the Governor and Legislature gave wide public attention to the often-ignored relationship between unbalanced budgets and high borrowing costs.
Ms. Brown said she sees herself as "spokesperson for the state's economic well-being." Apologizing for her immodesty, she compared herself to Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Chairman, "who is looked to with respect because of his independence and breadth of knowledge."
 
Looking to Wall Street
 Ms. Brown's primary duty is to be California's banker, managing a $22 billion investment portfolio, overseeing the sale of state bonds and representing California before the credit-rating agencies.
Along with New York City, California is one of top two issuers in the government bond market. And Ms. Brown seems to get good marks on Wall Street, where a half-dozen experts referred to her as informed, articulate and cooperative.
"Everybody says positive things for quotes because she gives out a lot of business," said Austin V. Koenen, a managing director of public finance at Morgan, Stanley & Company, who handles no California deals. But even if that were not the case, he said, "I don't think there's much negative."
Ms. Brown is widely credited with reducing a big backlog of voter-approved but unsold bonds for schools, prisons and other public works projects, thus stimulating job creation in a time of unemployment.
 
Another Governor's Opinion
 In her first bid for statewide office, against Tom Hayes in 1990, Ms. Brown was elected Treasurer by fewer than 300,000 votes. Her earlier public service had been modest -- sitting on the Los Angeles boards of education and public works, with a hiatus as a bond lawyer for the firm of O'Melveny & Myers.
In hoping to use the Treasurer's post as a springboard to higher office, Ms. Brown is following the path of Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas.
In a telephone interview, Governor Richards said, "It's an office that shows you have financial skills, which is something the public is looking for these days in an elected official."
Because municipal finance remains a relatively arcane subject, Ms. Brown is less vulnerable to public second-guessing than is Mr. Garamendi. As Insurance Commissioner, he is responsible for turning a voter initiative for reduced automobile insurance rates into a workable program, but the popular measure is bottled up in the courts.
 
'Everyone Has an Opinion'
 Bruce Cain, the associate director of the Institute for Governmental Studies at the University of California at Berkeley, said public cynicism over the insurance measure would make Mr. Garamendi "an easy target" at election time.
Ms. Brown compares that sort of scrutiny to her experience on the Board of Education. "Everyone has an opinion about how the schools should run, how teachers should teach and how Johnny should learn," she said. "Yes, the Treasurer's job is less understood."
As she talks, Ms. Brown is loping, without pocketbook or attache case, across the Capitol grounds, eating her daily frozen yogurt and enjoying the camelias of early spring. There is a naturalness to her, a willingness to come to work with her hair still damp from the shower, that contradicts her studied political polish.
Bernice Brown, Ms. Brown's 84-year-old mother, says that "everyone likes Kathy" because she does things like write thank-you notes and send gifts. She recently delivered a teddy bear to Assembly Speaker Willie Brown, another possible opponent in the Democratic primary, upon the birth of his first grandchild.
 
Liked Even by Rivals
 Mrs. Brown seems to be right about her daughter's likability, and Republicans are almost apologetic about their affection for her.
"She has a nice way about her, and I happen to like her," said Steven A. Merksamer, a Republican strategist and chief of staff to former Gov. George Deukmejian.
Clearly, Ms. Brown both loves and excels at press-the-flesh campaigning, which she has done for her father, brother or herself for as long as she can remember. Last year, when she tepidly supported Jerry's quixotic run for the Presidency, she said she did not have time to campaign for him, given the duties of her job. Instead, she toured the far corners of the state in support of Congressional and state legislative candidates.
There, she collected political i.o.u.'s and nurtured memories of a lifetime on the rubber-chicken circuit.
"There's no substitute for being in Bakersfield, at the Dorothy Donahue Dinner, when they give the Just Because You're You Award," she said. "It's one of my most favorite things in the world. There's a connectedness. It makes me feel with my roots and with the people of California."

HEADLINE: Guilty Plea By Baxter On Boycott

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 25

 BODY:
Baxter International Inc., the world's largest medical supplies company, agreed today to the stiffest punishments the Government has ever meted out to an American business for cooperating with Arab countries in their longstanding economic boycott of Israel.
But experts say the outcome of the three-year investigation may only serve to underscore how difficult it has been to enforce the Federal laws that forbid American companies to honor economic boycotts that the United States does not sanction. 
 Baxter, the first company to face criminal charges of violating the anti-boycott law, pleaded guilty to one violation. It will pay the maximum $500,000 fine. The Government and Baxter also said that the company and two subsidiaries would pay nearly $6 million in penalties and accept a two-year ban on new exports to Syria and Saudia Arabia to settle related civil complaints filed by the Commerce Department.
 
Trying to Get Off a List
 Baxter admitted to the Commerce Department that it had violated provisions of the law that would prohibit it from providing the Arab nations with details of its business dealings with Israel and of its charitable contributions there. Baxter violated the laws in an effort to get off an Arab blacklist that had limited its business opportunities in the Middle East. The company first learned in 1975 that it had been placed on the blacklist; in 1989, it was told it had been removed.
Baxter also announced today that it had settled three shareholder lawsuits contending that its activities had hurt the value of its stock.
The criminal settlement was by far the toughest imposed on an American company since the passage in 1977 of the first law forbidding cooperation with the boycott. In the largest case prior to Baxter's, Safeway Stores Inc. paid just under $1 million in 1988 but did not admit any wrongdoing. A total of 30 cases were settled last year for about $2.1 million.
 
The Government's View
 "Those who choose profits over adherence to American law must now recognize the commitment of the Departments of Justice and Commerce to enforce the statute," said Joan Bainbridge Safford, the Acting United States Attorney here. That commitment had been questioned by a number of critics during the Reagan and Bush Administrations."
Despite the ground broken by the three-year investigation, the power of the statute to punish companies remains limited. Baxter said that it would set aside $7.5 million in the current quarter to cover its financial liabilities in the matter but that it expected no material impact on this year's earnings. Baxter earned $436 million on sales of $8.47 billion in 1992.
"Other companies will take note of this because of the size, but it shows that bad publicity is still the Government's major weapon," said Joseph Kamalick, publisher of the Boycott Law Bulletin, a Houston newsletter.
Baxter said today that it had never intentionally violated the laws. It stressed that despite its guilty pleas, the Commerce Department did not formally find that it had violated the laws. Baxter officials say that the lack of such a finding will allow it to continue to do business in New York City and New York State, both of which forbid public institutions to do business with companies found to have violated these laws.
The stock market shrugged off the news. Baxter's shares ended at $29.50, down 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. "The odds are that investors are right in thinking it won't have any impact," said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, who follows the company for Sanford C. Bernstein.
Jewish groups said they were pleased with the announcements today. Henry Siegman, executive director of the American Jewish Congress in Washington, said the penalties were a sign that the Clinton Administration intended to pursue enforcement of the law. He also praised Baxter for stating that it opposed the boycott and for stressing its ongoing business ties to Israel.
 
Dealings With Israel
 Baxter, which is based in Deerfield, Ill., said it was "particularly pleased that the Government's investigation did not find that Baxter had refused to do business with Israel, as some have alleged." It said that its sales to Israel last year, at $6 million, were almost double those to any other Middle East nation.
"We think it is in the best interest of the company, our employees, and Israel to get these matters behind us," said Geoffrey Fenton, a company spokesman, when asked why the company had abandoned its stand that it had not violated the laws.
The civil and criminal investigations of Baxter grew out of reports in the late 1980's and in 1990 that the company had closed a manufacturing plant in Israel, had illegally provided information via the Syrian Army to the Arab League, a Damascus-based organization that coordinates the boycott, and had offered discounted products amounting to bribes to various Arab nations in an effort to get off the league's blacklist of companies that do business with Israel.
The league has urged members not to trade with companies on the list as a way of putting pressure on multinational companies to collaborate with the Arab boycott of Israel.
The criminal charge stemmed from a letter written Feb. 25, 1988, by G. Marshall Abbey, the company's general counsel, to the Syrian Army Supply Department. That letter provided Syria with numerous items of information it had requested about Baxter's activities in Israel. Syria had requested the information in response to an earlier letter from the company asking that Baxter be removed from the blacklist.
As part of the settlements, Mr. Abbey agreed to pay the Commerce Department $100,100.
The Justice Department said the evidence did not prove the more serious charges against the company that had been leveled by critics. For example, the critics had said that Baxter sold its profitable manufacturing plant in Ashdod, Israel, in 1988 as part of its efforts to get off the blacklist; Baxter said the plant was sold because it had poor growth prospects. Nor was there substantial evidence, the Justice Department said, that Baxter had paid bribes to Arab officials to get taken off the list.
 
Funneling Money
 The settlement papers, however, paint a picture of a company that repeatedly violated the law by knowingly furnishing information -- actions that Baxter's outside lawyers had warned might be violations -- and by failing to report Syrian requests for information.
The documents outline discussions by company employees about how to funnel "fees" and "penalty" money to Arab officials whom it expected to help get it off the blacklist. In one letter, Mr. Abbey stated that he was risking violating the law.
In one case, a Baxter employee negotiated a plan to provide $3 million of Baxter products to a Syrian company for $1 million as a way of getting $2 million into the hands of Syrians expected to be helpful.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 15.94 for Its First Gain of the Week

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Investors returned to blue-chip issues yesterday as the political crisis in Russia appeared to cool, igniting a fairly strong and broad-based advance after three losing sessions.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 15.94 points to end at 3,461.32, thanks to a rebound in several Dow components including Westinghouse, United Technologies and Eastman Kodak. 
 In Russia, President Boris N. Yeltsin's main rival, the speaker of the Parliament, Ruslan Khasbulatov, retreated yesterday from a demand for Mr. Yeltsin's removal, but the confrontation between the Congress of Deputies and Mr. Yeltsin remains.
 
'Source of Anxiety'
 The Russian crisis 'is a sword of Damocles hanging over the market,' said Harry W. Laubscher, senior vice president-market analyst at Tucker Anthony Inc. in New York City. 'It's going to be a continuing source of anxiety, but for now investors are going to look at basic economic issues and trends here at home."
The Dow dropped several points in the last half-hour of trading as several computerized sell programs went into effect and some traders sought to take short-term profits "in case something happens overnight" in Russia, Mr. Laubscher said.
Dennis E. Jarrett, chief market analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company, noted that despite the generally positive market, investors seemed to be quite cautious in their stock choices. 'It's a situation-by-situation kind of day," he said.
Eugene E. Peroni, director of technical research at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia, said that recent trading had been in a fairly narrow range and that he expected much wider swings in the next few sessions and certainly within the next two weeks.
 
A Drop in Volume
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 251.5 million shares, down from 274.9 million on Wednesday. Advances led declines 1,149 to 741.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks rose 1.42 points, to 248.33. The average share gained 20 cents.
 Investors appeared to be searching for bargains, especially in the battered pharmaceutical group. Merck, whose stock plunged Wednesday after announcing 1993 earnings would be at the low end of analysts' projections, was up 3/4, to 35 1/2. Abbot Laboratories rose 3/8, to 24 3/8, and Upjohn rose 5/8, to 28 3/4.
Westinghouse led the Big Board's most-active list; the company said there was no news that would account for the heavier-than-normal trading of 7.4 million shares. Westinghouse rose 1, to 15 3/8.
Analysts noted that several companies that make up the Dow Jones industrial average were up 1 point or more, including Texaco and J. P. Morgan. The arithmetic of the Dow means that a 1 point rise in a stock tends to raise the overall average 2 points, analysts said.
In Big Board trading, Cabletron Systems climbed 4 7/8, to 87 5/8, after the maker of computer software and hardware systems reported record quarterly earnings and sales.
Shares of the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, rose 1, to 43 5/8, despite a vote in the Senate backing President Clinton's proposal for the Government to make direct loans to students.
 Philip Morris fell 1 1/8, to 61 1/2. Morgan Stanley was said to have cut its estimates and growth rate on the company.
 Shares of Getty Petroleum rose 2, to 12 1/8, after the operator of gasoline stations said its profit doubled in the latest quarter.
Shares of Charles Schwab jumped 2 3/4, to 36 3/8, on composite volume of 291,600 shares. The brokerage firm, coming off record earnings in 1992, raised its quarterly dividend 25 percent and declared a 3-for-2 stock split.
In Nasdaq trading, Oracle Systems rose 1 1/8, to 36 7/8; Cisco Systems climbed 3 1/2, to 45; Adaptec was up 4 1/8, to 26, and Intel rose 1 1/8, to 115 3/8.
 The Nasdaq composite index outperformed the Dow index, as technology shares rose sharply. It ended up 6.65 points, at 681.01.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 2.80, to 450.87. The American Stock Exchange index was up 0.84, to 419.12.

HEADLINE: 2 New Business Districts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
New York City officials yesterday created two new business improvement districts, including one on Fifth Avenue. Mayor David N. Dinkins signed two bills giving businesses the right to raise money among themselves to complement city services like cleaning streets and increasing security. One bill designated the area along Fifth Avenue from 46th to 61st Streets and includes properties on 57th Street from the Avenue of the Americas to Madison Avenue. The other in Queens, the Woodhaven Business Improvement District, covers Jamaica Avenue from Eldert Lane to 100th Street.

HEADLINE: Caracas Journal;
New in the Seat of Power: A Two-Fisted Radical

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela

 BODY:
Black in a land dominated by Latins, a political outsider who founded his own underground party, Aristobulo Izturiz Almeida is the kind of visitor who could rattle the crystal chandeliers of Caracas's ornate city hall.
Only a few months ago, Mr. Izturiz got into a fistfight with bank guards in an attempt to block the sale of part of Venezuela's state telephone company to an American-led consortium. 
 But in January the 46-year-old militant unionist came in from the streets. Today, in his new office, elegant with gold leaf and stained glass, Mr. Izturiz gives orders as the Mayor of Caracas.
"The established parties are deteriorating," Mr. Izturiz said to explain his upset victory last December on the ticket of his now legal party, Radical Cause. "They are losing credibility. I have absolute confidence that we will win the presidency next December."
 
Faring Well in the Polls
 The same popular revolt that made Mr. Izturiz the Mayor of Venezuela's most populous city is making Andres Velasquez, the Radical Cause candidate, the fastest rising contender in public opinion polls before the December presidential election. Campaigning on a clean government slate, Mr. Velasquez, a state governor, now places second in surveys after Rafael Caldera, a 77-year-old former President, who is losing appeal.
The voter revolt follows a year that saw more than 1,400 street protests and two violent coup attempts against the Government of Carlos Andres Perez.
[The Supreme Court agreed in mid-March to review a petition by Attorney General Ramon Escovar Salom to try Mr. Perez on charges of embezzling $17 million.]
Bitter over economic austerity and unpunished corruption, voters in December delivered Mr. Perez's governing Democratic Action party its worst electoral setback in its 51-year history. Opposition control of state governorships increased from one-half to two-thirds. And in South America's oldest democracy, only half of the electorate voted.
With the presidential race channeling political pressure into half a dozen campaigns, most people interviewed here predicted that Mr. Perez would survive his final year in office.
"I am sure that CAP will finish his presidential term," said Alberto Mansueti, the executive director of a political research foundation, referring to the President by his initials. "But I am not so sure his successor will."
 
Constant Rumors of a Coup
 The year is off to a rocky start for Venezuela, the second largest foreign supplier of oil to the United States after Saudi Arabia.
In February, army troops occupied two state capitals where riots broke out after candidates of the governing party rejected fraud charges and claimed victories. The Supreme Court is to rule on the validity of the elections in those two states, Barinas and Sucre.
Of about 3,000 soldiers and civilians arrested after the two coup attempts all were released except 125, who were tried and convicted by an emergency tribunal. [In mid-March the Supreme Court threw out the convictions.]
Reflecting military unrest, 60 soldiers rebelled in January, briefly seizing the commander of Venezuela's military police as a hostage. In Caracas newspapers, rumors of coup attempts are routine.
"A lot of officers are asking themselves, 'Why am I supporting this situation?' " Francisco Efrain Visconti, a Venezuelan Air Force general who led a coup attempt in November, said in a recent interview in Lima, Peru, where he lives in exile. "If measures aren't taken, there will be a civilian explosion."
 
Military Problem 'Latent'
 Demonstrating a shared rejection of Venezuela's status quo, a Radical Cause congressman traveled to Lima to hold a joint news conference with the exiled rebel.
"The military problem is latent," Mr. Izturiz warned here. "It's like heart disease -- the heart attack could come at any moment."
The rebel soldiers and the Radical Cause civilians share economic views that are nationalist and statist and deep anger over corruption.
"The political and economic ruling classes are submitting to the schemes of foreign financial institutions, above all North American, and to the tyranny of the International Monetary Fund," General Visconti wrote in a recent essay about his "civilian-military movement."
"There is no human being in the country that does not feel beaten down by the effects of the brutal economic policy imposed by the I.M.F.," he wrote.
The general neglected to mention that Venezuela's oil sales, the country's primary source of income, dropped by 20 percent in dollar terms over the last three years. In another essay by the coup plotters, they call for reversing Mr. Perez's free-market policies and restoring controls on imports and on foreign exchange.
Anger over the economy fuels much of the protest here.
On paper, 1992 was another banner year for Venezuela. The country attracted $2 billion in new foreign investment and recorded economic growth of 7.3 percent.
 
Spreading the Wealth
 But deflating these numbers, 71 percent of Venezuelans responding to a poll in January said the economy worsened in 1992. Most investment and growth is in the capital-intensive oil industry, which creates relatively few new jobs.
The feeling is widespread that Mr. Perez's free-market policies violate deeply held beliefs that Venezuela's large state economy exists to spread the oil wealth.
"Wealth is not something that has to be produced, but something simply given," concludes a recent survey of public attitudes by the Fundacion Libertas, a free-market group here. "In the popular mind, work and wealth have nothing to do with each other. Individual wealth is seen as the result of proximity to the distribution process, not of proximity to the production process."
In this environment, Mr. Izturiz has no regrets over his quixotic, bare-knuckled attempt to block the sale of the state telephone company to a foreign consortium lead by GTE.
"Hotels, banks and sugar plantations can be privatized," he said. "But basic and strategic industries, like oil and telephones, should remain in the hands of the state."

GRAPHIC: Bitter over economic austerity and unpunished corruption, voters in Venezuela are rejecting the status quo. In Caracas, the Mayor's office is now filled by Aristobulo Izturiz Almeida, a militant unionist. A painting of Simon Bolivar, the revolutionary leader, also occupies a place. (Associated Press for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Senate Approves First Step In President's Budget Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
Voting along party lines, the Senate today approved a five-year budget outline that is almost identical to what President Clinton proposed last month and what the House passed last week.
In a telephone conversation with Senate leaders after the vote, Mr. Clinton called it a remarkable achievement, and said, "Finally we've done something to break the gridlock." 
 Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, also basked in the victory. "The American people made a choice last November," he said on the Senate floor. "I think the American people want change, and this Senate has taken a step toward giving it to them."
But while the vote was doubtless a victory for the new Administration and the Democratic majority in Congress, the measure, which is called a budget resolution, is no more than a skeleton. The first step in the Congressional budget process, it merely establishes how much money will be spent and how much revenue will be raised each year.
The meat and the muscle -- which taxes will be raised and cut, and how much money will be spent on each Government program -- will be determined by subsequent legislation.
 
'The Hard Part Starts'
 "Now the hard part starts," said Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader. "We start shooting with real bullets from now on."
The Senate approved the measure by 54 to 45. Only two Democrats, Bob Krueger of Texas and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, voted against it. Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii was absent. All 43 Republicans voted "no."
After the vote, the Senate turned at once to Mr. Clinton's plan to spend an additional $16 billion over two years to stimulate the economy and create jobs. The debate will last for days, and any number of amendments may be adopted. But in the end, Congress will probably approve the stimulus plan without substantial change.
The budget resolution is supposed to shrink the Federal deficit by a total of slightly more than $500 billion over five years. On an annual basis, the deficit, now about $300 billion, would be cut to below $200 billion in the fiscal year 1997, the last of Mr. Clinton's term.
The deficit reduction would be slightly greater than what the House approved. The differences between the House and Senate measures will be worked out in a conference committee, probably next week. Congressional leaders hope to pass the final version before the recess for Easter and Passover begins on April 2.
 
Change of Course
 More important than the details of the resolutions, the debate in the Senate and the one in the House last week showed conclusively that the Government is on a different course from the one followed for the last 12 years. Taxes will be raised. The military budget will be cut. More money will spent for a host of programs that languished with Republicans in the White House.
Much of the six days of debate in the Senate was spent on extraneous issues or political hot potatoes like an increase in taxes on some Social Security benefits. But the underlying issue, this change of course, was never far below the surface.
Senator Mitchell framed it in the floor debate on Wednesday night, when the Senate was discussing an alternative Republican budget that included no tax increase and would have allowed more spending for the military and much less for domestic programs than the Democrats favor.
"So the issue is very simple here," he said. "If you like the status quo, if you like the economic policies of the past four years, if you do not think there ought to be any change in this country's policies, if you want to keep going the way we have been going in the last years, piling up this impossibly high debt and telling the American people there are not any problems and we can do this all in a very easy way -- why, if you believe that, then you vote for this substitute amendment.
"But if you think this country ought to change the course it is on, if you think this country ought to have a different economic policy, if you think this country ought to have a policy that looks to the future, not the past, if you think that President Clinton ought to have a chance, just a chance, to get started in office, then you ought to defeat this substitute amendment and pass this budget resolution."
 
Angle of Attack
 Senator Dole, who has probably invested more political capital over the last decade than any other politician in the cause of shrinking the budget deficit, did not really take issue with Mr. Mitchell's view that the debate was over two divergent philosophies. He just said, over and over, that he thought Democrats were attacking the problem from the wrong angle, raising taxes rather than making deep cuts in spending.
"I think this is a big mistake we have just made," he said after the vote this afternoon. "We've got a pretty good recovery under way. We don't want to stifle it."
Sometimes Senate debates build to a peak as the final vote approaches. Not today.
The 50 hours allotted for the debate ended Wednesday evening with at least two dozen amendments still pending. So on Wednesday night and for almost three hours this morning, the Senate took up amendments every 10 minutes, almost all of them offered by Republicans, and killed them on party-line votes with no debate whatsoever, without even a description of what they entailed.
For the Republican Senators, it was a chance to cast votes that would look good on the record and to force the Democrats to cast votes that might be used against them in the next election.
For instance, Senator Dirk Kempthorne of Idaho proposed cutting financing for Congress by 25 percent. His colleague from Idaho, Larry E. Craig, proposed excluding hydroelectric power from the energy tax.
Even if amendments like those had been adopted, they would not have had the force of law, since the sole purpose of a budget resolution is to set only broad outlines, not details. But they could have proved useful in campaign commercials.
The final vote was taken without even a word summing up the six days of debate.
