HEADLINE: Fed Chief's Loan Hopes For Small Businesses

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, expressed optimism today that lending to small business would soon increase as banks were willing to take more risks.
Testifying before the House Committee on Small Business, Mr. Greenspan was not ready to declare the credit crunch over, however, saying, "I find reasons for optimism but not complacency." 
 The Fed chairman said that there has been a modest increase in business loans this winter and that the recent improvement in economic growth could soon lead to a further pickup in lending.
He said that because bank earnings and their capital basis were up, "banks are patently in a strong position to meet" the expected increase in demand for loans.
"Our surveys and other information indicate that banks' attitudes toward loans and risk taking are improving," he said.
 
Banks' Progress Praised
 Mr. Greenspan said the banking industry as a whole has made "remarkable progress" in working through its "severe portfolio problems" during a period of weak economic growth.
He noted that banks had written off $125 billion in bad loans over the last five years, causing many of them to adopt stricter lending standards and creating a credit squeeze.
The Fed chief praised President Clinton's announcement on March 10 easing regulations on bank lending. These measures would reduce the amount of paperwork required for many loans, make it easier to grant loans based on a borrower's character, and ease requirements on assessing real estate used as collateral in small loans.
As he often has before, Mr. Greenspan said legislation in recent years has gone too far in regulating banks, adding that the laws had discouraged lending by increasing paperwork and raising costs.
 
'A Chilling Effect'
 "Each new proposed piece of detailed banking legislation has to be evaluated in advance," he said, "to determine what the impacts are likely to be on the health, vigor and competitiveness of the banking system."
Mr. Greenspan complained that these laws had "resulted in a drumbeat" of requirements.
"Such micro-management," he said, "has a chilling effect on bank lending attitudes, imparting a high degree of management uncertainty while the implementing rules are developed, debated and adopted."
The Fed chairman said many examiners had become overzealous in their regulation after they were criticized for being too lax in the 1980's. Another factor discouraging lending, he said, is that commercial real estate remained weak, so that banks often do not feel confident that they know what the collateral of their loans is worth.
He said that until the amount of real estate transactions picked up, bankers would not feel confident about the value of property used to secure existing or new loans. This, he said, has colored business confidence in general, adding, "I am still concerned that a real estate market that has not found its feet is retarding the availability of small-business credit."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Auction Again Fails to Lift Bonds

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
For the second consecutive day, the Treasury held a successful auction that did not give the market a lift. The result was that the price of the 30-year bond slumped 13/32 yesterday and the yield rose to 6.85 percent, not too far from the 6.89 percent top of its three-week trading range.
"Customers are beginning to feel that the bull market has run out of steam," said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief financial economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd. "They are a little more yield-sensitive because they are developing a trading-range mentality." 
 This trading-range mentality is likely to continue until at least next Friday, when the Labor Department issues the employment report for March. If the jobs data indicate that economic growth is solid, yields could jump over 7 percent. But if the data are weak, yields could move toward new lows.
The decline in long Treasury securities, including the 10-year note, came on the day that the Senate approved President Clinton's budget outline, which includes the promise of major deficit reduction over the next five years.
 
Investors Becoming Leery?
 But while the promise of this deficit reduction has contributed to the rally that pushed the yield on the 30-year bond to a 16-year low of 6.72 percent on March 8, Mr. Ricchiuto suggested that some investors were becoming a little more leery of the promise now.
He said that the revision of budget estimates by the Congressional Budget Office, which cut the size of Mr. Clinton's promised deficit reduction, and the bidding war that followed in Congress for more spending cuts, has made some investors wonder what really will be accomplished.
Yesterday's approval also reminded investors and traders alike that the budget resolution that was approved was only an outline and promise of what is to be done. The actual votes on tax increases and spending cuts still have to be cast.
The initial reaction to the Treasury's successful auction of $11 billion in five-year notes was positive. The prices of bonds and notes, which had declined in the morning and the early afternoon, bounced up enough to erase all or some of their losses. But then the prices began to fall again.
"The initial reaction was fairly good," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates. "But when they delved into the numbers and realized that it was a dealer-dominated auction, that tempered the price auction," he said.
Mr. McCarthy noted that most of the auction was bought by dealers from New York and that it also appeared that only a few dealers got a large part of the five-year notes sold.
 
May Cut Prices
 Because dealers -- as opposed to institutional investors -- bought most of the notes, there will be a period when dealers move the notes to customers. And this kind of supply bulge can weigh on prices because dealers do not like to get caught with too much supply in a sluggish market and they may cut prices.
The five-year notes were awarded at a single yield of 5.19 percent. The coupon on the notes, which mature in March 1998, is 5.125 percent. By the end of trading, the yield had inched up to 5.21 percent, which may already reflect the effort of dealers trying to pass them on to customers by lowering the price, which moves in the opposite direction of the yield.
 
New York Issue
 The prices of tax-exempt bonds declined about 1/4 to 3/8 point yesterday as the flood of new issues continued in response to low interest rates. About $1.3 billion of new bonds were sold, according to Bloomberg Business News.
The New York Local Government Assistance Corporation, which was established in 1990 to help finance local government operations, moved yesterday to take advantage of the lower interest rates and save some money. It priced $352.8 million of refunding revenue bonds that will be used to pay off older, higher-interest- rate bonds.
The refunding revenue bonds were initially priced through Morgan Stanley & Company to yield a maximum 5.95 percent for a bond due in 2021, with serial bond yields ranging from 4.55 percent in 1999 to 5.65 percent in 2008. Another long maturity was priced to yield 5.92 percent for an issue due in 2016.
Underwriters, who said the bonds were rated A+ by Fitch Investors Service, are expecting a single-A rating by Moody's and Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: Unit Says Budget Balanced, but It Faults Dinkins

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
The state agency that monitors New York City's fiscal health said yesterday that the city would achieve its 13th consecutive balanced budget this year, but it warned that the Dinkins administration was not doing enough to solve long-term problems and faced a grimly rising fever line of multibillion-dollar deficits over the next four years.
In an evaluation of a budget plan issued by the city in January, the state's Financial Control Board said City Hall had balanced a $30.3 billion budget for the 1993 fiscal year ending next June 30 with $245 million left over from 1992 and $675 million in savings devices that will not be available in the 1994 to 1997 fiscal years. 
 Despite an improving economy, the board said, prospects for closing future budget gaps are bleak. Spending is higher and growing faster, and revenues are lower and growing more slowly than last year, it said. By freezing taxes, raising wages and easing targets for cutting its work force, it said, the city missed chances to cut projected deficits ranging from $2.1 billion in 1994 to $4.2 billion in 1997.
"The critical problems causing persistent billion-dollar gaps remain largely unaddressed or unabated by this financial plan," the board said in a 79-page report. "Indeed, the gaps to be closed over the next four years are larger than they were in the financial plan one year ago."
 
City Officials Disagree
 Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel and the city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, said the report had focused excessively on projections years off and subject to so many changes -- in the economy and in state and Federal aid, for example -- that they were hard to predict. They said the Dinkins administration, despite the recession, had balanced its budgets and hoped to continue doing so.
Mr. Steisel said the state could help by relieving the city of "crushing" Medicaid expenses, as promised, a point that he said the report had failed to emphasize. He also said tax increases and cuts in services might be needed, but they could be avoided with adequate state and Federal aid. "We remain committed to long-term structural stability," Mr. Steisel said.
Mr. Michael called the report "unrealistic" and "simplistic" in projecting future budget problems, and added: "We have shown an ability to deal with each and every one of those problems and there is no reason to question our resolve or ability to deal with them in the future."
The criticisms of the control board, which was created during the city's fiscal crisis in the 1970's and has the power to take over city finances in an emergency, are hardly new. The board has said repeatedly in recent years that the city has not done enough to secure long-term fiscal stability.
The core problem is that revenues, held down by a poor economy, are not keeping pace with expenses, and the gap -- worsened by rising costs in welfare, education, hospitals and other unavoidable areas -- continues to widen in projections for future years.
By not cutting its work force of 211,000 more sharply, by stretching its debt further into the future, by using a previous year's surplus for current expenses, by relying on many spending cuts that are good for only one year and do not achieve permanent savings, the city has not provided long-term solutions to its fiscal problems, the board said.
"In the past year, the city's problems have steadily gotten larger," Allen J. Proctor, the board's executive director, said in an interview. "Every action has been focused on balancing this year's budget, but the city has not made any inroads in dealing with these larger problems."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Concerns Over the Standoff in Russia

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended higher yesterday against most leading foreign currencies except the yen. Traders bought the Japanese currency to take advantage of a plunge the previous day.
Activity was thin on the eve of important new developments in Russia's power standoff and was broadly influenced by heavy cross-selling of German marks for yen. 
 The mark selling gave the dollar enough momentum to advance against the German currency into a new key trading range.
 
Gold Gains
 Gold rose in world markets. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery closed at $332.70 an ounce, up 20 cents. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $332.50 an ounce, up 30 cents from late Wednesday.
Financial markets were waiting for today's session of the Russian Congress to consider ousting President Boris N. Yeltsin for his decision to call an April referendum to determine who rules Russia. The Congress opposes the referendum.
Some traders were buying dollars ahead of the weekend, not wanting to get caught short amid the Russian volatility. Traders were also uncertain of whether Germany would press ahead with another interest rate cut, which would help the dollar by hurting the value of mark-denominated investments.
The "vote in Russia is keeping people not wanting to go home short dollars," Earl Johnson, vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, said. Traders said the uncertainty helped the dollar trade above 1.6400 marks, higher than its recent trading range of 1.6250 to 1.6380 marks.
In European trading, the dollar ended at 1.6425 German marks, up from 1.6279. At 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.6420 marks, up from 1.6375 marks late Wednesday.
The dollar rose overseas against the yen, but fell in New York. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 117.15 yen, up 1.22 yen from Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 117.35 yen. In New York at 4 P.M. the dollar was quoted at 117.30 yen, down from late Wednesday's 117.65 yen.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.4735, from $1.4825 late Wednesday. Later in New York it fetched $1.4750, less than late Wednesday's $1.4770.
Other late dollar rate in New York, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.5205 Swiss francs, up from 1.5155; 5.5835 French francs, up from 5.5685; 1,603.00 Italian lire, up from 1,596.00, and $1.2442 (Canadian), up from $1.2430 (Canadian).
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's levels, were: 1.6425 marks, up from 1.6279; 1.5225 Swiss francs, up from 1.5085; 5.5830 French francs, up from 5.5425; 1.8455 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8310; 1,603.00 lire, up from 1,592.50, and $1.2439 (Canadian), down from $1.2445 (Canadian).

HEADLINE: TVWeekend;
3 African Leaders and David Frost

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
South Africa's three pre-eminent political figures are honored tonight by the attentions of David Frost. You may not learn much that is new from the encounters, but it is an opportunity to catch their election-year styles, along with the style of the recently dubbed Sir David himself.
Mr. Frost is most businesslike in his opening conversation with the Zulu chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, leader of the Inkatha Freedom Party, whose members have been involved in bloody encounters with supporters of Nelson Mandela and his African National Congress. The longtime rivals blame each another for their failure of communication. Mr. Frost, like an imperial emissary to feuding tribesmen, advises, "The sooner the two of you get together, the better." 
 One issue has to do with arrangements for the South African economy. In this election season, Mr. Mandela says that his organization has always advocated free enterprise, that it has moved away from its advocacy of nationalization of certain industries and that its Communist Party allies will be only a tiny minority of its election list.
President F. W. de Klerk uses most of his time to deliver a stump speech on his desire for consensus, unity, stability, peace and economic growth, from which neither Mr. Buthelezi nor Mr. Mandela dissents.
Like other interviewers faced with the estimable Mr. Mandela, who is given the most time tonight, Mr. Frost adopts a Barbara Walters mode: "And when was there a moment when you decided this was going to be your whole life, fighting for a free South Africa?"
Mr. Mandela reminisces, fairly interestingly, about his years of imprisonment and says he would be willing to serve in any capacity under an elected Government. "What a very interesting and generous offer," Mr. Frost allows, and ends the talk by assuring Mr. Mandela that his wish to be remembered as a "man who has done his duty on earth" will be granted. Being knighted evidently confers powers over history.
 
'The Un-Americans'
 A&E, tonight at 8
The unedifying history of America's crackdown on Communists and so-called security risks is told tonight from the point of view of some of the scores of people who were jailed and the thousands who lost their jobs between the late 1940's and the early 60's. Some say they were victims of mistaken identity or political vendettas; the admitted Communists say they were idealists who were guilty, at worst, of being stupid about Stalin. Admire them or not, very few had committed anything resembling a crime.
As an early reference to "vigilantes and victims" suggests, the two-hour treatment is in accord with a rote leftist mythology that portrays Communists as radicals with a human face and leaves out the many anti-Communist liberals and conservatives who fought the rampages of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the House Committee on Un-American Activities. Nonetheless, the newsreels of the time are reminders of the poisonous spirit that infected the land.
The cruel crookedness of it all is personified in a concluding interview with Harvey J. Matusow, an admitted con artist who made a career first as an ex-Communist informer and then as an exposer of the informer racket and finally as a stand-up comedian.
 
'Here's Looking at You, Warner Brothers'
 TNT, tomorrow at 8 P.M.
This two-hour celebration of the studio that Jack, Harry, Sam and Albert Warner built tells little about movie making in what is accurately enough known as Hollywood's golden age, but anyone with a weakness for icons in action should get their money's worth. The puffy anecdotal narration by Clint Eastwood, Barbra Streisand and others serves mainly to link star turns, from Rin-Tin-Tin's to Robert Redford's.
Sure, you've seen most of these big moments from the big years of the big studio before (although John Barrymore as Captain Ahab was new to me), but so what? There's Edward G. Robinson expiring with the line "Mother of mercy, is this the end of Rico?" and Paul Muni fading into a black night with "I steal." There's Bugs Bunny slipping out of tight scrapes and Errol Flynn ("All right, my hearties, follow me!") battling out of them. There's Ruby Keeler in Busby Berkeley mosaics. There's James Cagney pushing women around and Bette Davis kicking men around. There's Humphrey Bogart turning tough toward Mary Astor, going soft over Ingrid Bergman and being provoked by Lauren Bacall. And, as they say, much more.
You can also see or tape several of the scenes in context this weekend, as TNT will be showing, mostly in the early morning hours, "The Jazz Singer," "The Sea Hawk," "The Public Enemy," "I Am a Fugitive From a Chain Gang," "The Big Sleep," "Key Largo," "Destination Tokyo" and "Now, Voyager," in which, yes, Paul Henreid lights that cigarette for Bette Davis.

HEADLINE: Art in Review

BYLINE: By CHARLES HAGEN

 BODY:

 'In Transit'
 New Museum of Contemporary Art
 583 Broadway (near Prince Street)
 SoHo
 Through April 11
"In Transit" is a show whose reach far exceeds its grasp. With works by a host of artists -- among them Mildred Howard, Larry Rogers, Helen Levitt, Krzysztof Wodizcko, Glenn Ligon and Aki Fujiyoshi -- addressing what the museum calls "the involuntary movement of human beings and objects through different urban spaces" and the changing nature of cities, the exhibition should be far more interesting than it is. 
 A blitz of works in a variety of media, including installations, audio and videotapes, photographs and sculptural objects, have been assembled here; approximately half were commissioned especially for the occasion, but few of the works provide much insight into the show's sociological theme.
Camilo Jose Vergara's muddy color photographs of buildings in poor neighborhoods in the United States, for example, say little new about the nature of contemporary cities. Martha Rosler takes on a worthy subject: pollution and toxic waste in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. But her installation is weighted down with seven bulky government reports, and has all the visual interest of a display about the advantages of flossing.
Some of the art is just jejune. Lois Nesbitt presents maps of New York City that record, among other things, subways she has never ridden and places in the city she has never been; these include almost everything outside of Manhattan.
Among the few highlights of the show are Margaret Morton's Piranesi-like black-and-white photographs of the cavernous railroad tunnels under Riverside Park, where homeless people gather, and Santu Mofokeng's quietly expressive photographs of life in Soweto, South Africa. But Mr. Mofokeng's pictures are shown with minimal captions, and as a result provide little specific information about their subjects.
As organized by France Morin, the New Museum's chief curator, with the help of Kostas Gounis, an anthropologist, and Dr. John Jeffries, a political economist, "In Transit" is a muddled stew of confused intentions, political posturing and mediocre art.

HEADLINE: Marines Can't Defer Aircraft Replacement

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Guide for Pentagon Budget Cuts" (editorial, March 9) offers suggestions drawn from a Congressional Budget Office report and supplies another of your own, which is, as we say in Texas, a mile wide and an inch deep. The case you present, without substantiation, is to defer buying the V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft for at least a decade to save $1 billion now. The saving would be a false one. 
 The Marines need a medium-lift replacement not 10 years from now, but now. The V-22 is that replacement. The CH-46 helicopters that are in use have passed their useful life. The number of passengers allowed to be carried on them has been reduced, and the distance they are allowed to fly has been limited, all in the interest of safety. They are great helicopters, but they are old and worn out.
Keeping the CH-46's in the inventory for 10 more years without replacement would not save the $1 billion that has been designated for the V-22 because the funds would have to be spent elsewhere to help shore up the medium-lift resources of the Marines. Upgrading the CH-46's or replacing them with other helicopters will cost nearly as much as the V-22 and in addition not provide any increase in capability.
The V-22 is the proved cost-effective solution to the medium-lift requirement and for more than two dozen other joint services specialized missions. Tilt-rotors have considerable potential for civil applications, too, including flying commuter passengers from vertiports, rather than congested airports, increasing the capacity of airports at no cost.
Continuing the V-22 is a sound military and economic decision. Postponing it will cancel it. Nothing will be saved, and another significant American technological advancement will be lost.
 
TERRY ARNOLD
Manager, Tiltrotor Communications
Bell Helicopter Textron Inc.
Fort Worth, March 10, 1993

HEADLINE: What Nicaraguan Land Claims Mean

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your correspondent in Managua again champions the "oppressed" upper classes of Nicaragua in a March 6 news article concerning the efforts to regain ownership of a house by a woman wealthy enough to have sat out the revolution in Miami. 
 The article contends that 5,000 to 6,000 people seeking the return of their property tell "an impassioned tale of frustration and injustice in pursuit of what each regards as legally his or hers." No source is provided for this number. Your correspondent raises no question about the legitimacy of these claims, many by people who gained wealth and economic power during the years of the dictator Anastasio Somoza Debayle, who ruled Nicaragua as a private fiefdom for his family and cronies.
The article ignores the widely supported determination not to give property back to people associated with the Somoza dictatorship.
Your correspondent states that President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro promised all returning exiles the return of confiscated properties. The platform on which she was elected made no such promise, stating compensation would be made to owners of unjustly confiscated property.
The platform did promise that the peasants, or campesinos, would not lose land given them under land reform, a promise your correspondent is not likely to investigate as hundreds of poor campesinos, homeowners and renters are evicted from their homes and land.
President Chamorro has established a process to return land or compensate property owners with full due process. Against this process lies the intense and constant demand for land throughout the country, especially in the countryside, where Mrs. Chamorro promised demobilized Sandinista army soldiers, as well as contras laying down their arms, land and the means to work that land. Such promises have not been fulfilled.
These demands for land and for compensation for confiscated properties come at a time of extreme economic strife in Nicaragua, exacerbated by the Bush Administration's and now President Clinton's continued withholding of economic aid to Nicaragua.
 
JIM BURCHELL
Madison, N.J., March 10, 1993
The writer is an organizer for Quest for Peace, which ships humanitarian aid to Nicaragua.

HEADLINE: SPEAKER IN RUSSIA NOW VOICING DOUBT ON YELTSIN OUSTER

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 25

 BODY:
The leader of Russia's Legislature indicated on the eve of a session of the Congress of People's Deputies that he would try to head off a vote on ousting President Boris N. Yeltsin.
His statement reinforced speculation that the deputies lacked the two-thirds majority needed to vote the President out of office. But as the deputies converged on Moscow from around Russia and both sides issued their final appeals, it was evident that this would be the most contentious and fateful session of the Congress in the three years since it was elected. 
 Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, the 50-year-old Parliament Speaker, who has guided the Congress through a steadily growing power struggle with the President, declared in comments to reporters and later in a nationwide television address that he was opposed to the direct ouster of Mr. Yeltsin.
"To tell you frankly, I am not a supporter of impeachment," he told reporters. "Impeachment is the most extreme measure. I don't think that among all possible measures we should immediately talk about the most extreme one."
 
Hostility Remains
 Speaking later on national television, Mr. Khasbulatov (pronounced khahz-boo-LAH-tawff) left no doubt that his hostility to Mr. Yeltsin remained as before. He roundly criticized Mr. Yeltsin for his reforms, for purportedly trying to monopolize power, for an economic program "totally subordinated to Western influence." But he did not directly accuse the president of violating the constitution, and he said, "We didn't summon the Congress to fire anyone." Earlier, he had set the wheels in motion for the vote that could lead to the ouster of Mr. Yeltsin.
Mr. Yeltsin, appearing on television about a half hour later, struck hard and straight. Evidently sensing that the tide of battle was flowing his way, the President criticized his antagonists both in the Legislature and the Constitutional Court, accusing the former of plotting his overthrow and the latter of "political prejudice."
Sitting sternly in front of the white, blue and red Russian flag, he warned: "Remember: if the Congress adopts historically incorrect decisions, it will plunge the people into an abyss of confrontation."
 
A Different Meaning
 Many deputies were dubious that the Congress could muster the 689 votes needed to oust the President. Under Russian law, "impeachment" is not the legislative indictment understood in the United States Constitution, but a final decision to fire the President.
Russians have adopted the word "impeachment" into their language as a noun. A common expression is "golovat impichment," which means to vote impeachment.
But the People's Deputies have given ample evidence in their last eight convocations that they act in unforeseeable ways. Until the first round of procedural ballots in the Grand Palace of the Kremlin on Friday, there was no way to gauge whether Mr. Yeltsin's actions since they last met two weeks ago had intimidated or further incited the majority.
"It will be a very difficult Congress," Mr. Khasbulatov conceded.
From all sides, calls for compromise intensified, often including a call for new elections. The most dramatic came from the Patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Church, Aleksei II, who declared in a televised statement that failure to find a political settlement could lead to bloodshed or civil war.
Similar calls came, among others, from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former Soviet President, and the Council of Independent Trade Unions.
Mr. Khasbulatov, too, reiterated his call for simultaneous elections for the Legislature and the President, either next fall or in the spring of 1994. Mr. Yeltsin has also talked of new elections, though he has said presidential elections should follow parliamentary elections by a year, since the Congress was elected a year before him: they in March 1990 and he and Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi in June 1991.
In his most recent proposals, however, Mr. Yeltsin has talked only of elections to a new bicameral Parliament with newly defined authority -- not to another 1,000-member Congress with virtually unlimited legislative powers.
Mr. Yeltsin was also probably wary of any deals with the Congress unless he could receive ironclad guarantees that the legislators would not betray him again. Last time he made an agreement with them, in December, the Congress and the Constitutional Court turned around and reneged, forcing the President into the current showdown.
 
Announcement, and Reaction
 It began last Saturday, when Mr. Yeltsin made a dramatic announcement on television calling for a vote of confidence April 25 and vastly expanded powers under a "special rule" until then. The Constitutional Court declared the measures unconstitutional and the sitting Legislature summoned a full Congress to consider ouster.
But when Mr. Yeltsin finally published the decrees on Wednesday, they turned out to have none of the measures to which the Court objected. That left the Court's chairman, Valery D. Zorkin, and Mr. Khasbulatov in an acutely uncomfortable position -- just as Mr. Yeltsin and his tacticians probably intended.
Mr. Yeltsin hammered away at the rush to judgment in his televised address. "The Constitutional Court was in such a hurry to make a decision that it did not even want to wait for the documents that I talked about to be published," he said.
Mr. Khasbulatov acknowledged in his address that the actual decree was less offensive than Mr. Yeltsin's public appeal. But he angrily dismissed this as a transparent maneuver. "We are not in kindergarten," he said.
Mr. Zorkin made no comments.
 
Met with Vice President
 But the Vice President, another prominent actor in the conflict, met with Mr. Yeltsin. Mr. Rutskoi, who would succeed Mr. Yeltsin if he were deposed, refused to support the President's measures last Saturday.
As events swirled toward a climax, the suspense was tangible. Whether the Congress voted to oust, or a compromise was found, it was clear that Russia was headed for more upheavals, struggles and tribulations.
All across Moscow and the country, scenarios were played out and people anxiously pondered where each might lead. There were reports that Mr. Yeltsin would address the Congress.
Mr. Yeltsin's chief tactician, Sergei M. Shakhrai, Deputy Chairman of the Council of Ministers, told reporters that the Congress would probably start by sorting out the vague constitutional articles dealing with ouster and succession and that Mr. Khasbulatov would next try to head off an actual vote on ouster. Most likely, he would try to set new presidential and parliamentary elections and to cancel the vote of confidence proposed by Mr. Yeltsin.
Mr. Shakhrai also said some deputies might try to dismiss the leaders of all three branches of Government.
The greatest danger was that the Congress would vote to oust Mr. Yeltsin. He has already declared that he would not step down and that the threat of violence would become real.
But even if the Congress stopped short of ousting him, there was no telling how Mr. Yeltsin would overcome resistance to his April 25 ballot or where he would find the means to finance it. And there was no telling how its results would be used, since the Congress would not recognize them.
The question was whether enough common ground remained for a compromise after the bitter recriminations of recent weeks and months.
Mr. Khasbulatov spoke repeatedly of compromise, but the condition he set in his televised address was effectively for the President to renounce his latest measures publicly.
"If there is a willingness by the President to cooperate, if he recognizes that he pushed erroneous decisions, if he works cooperatively with the Congress, I believe we can find a way out," he said.
"I will try. I will do everything that depends on me, but you know that in such complex situations the chairman is not all-powerful. If the President ties to help smooth the situation and not to aggravate it, we might reach for a serious agreement, based on which people might find new hope."
 
Broad Defense
 In general, Mr. Khasbulatov's televised statements went well beyond the immediate issues and amounted to a broad defense of what he has tried to do as chairman.
He argued that he had always defended democracy, that he always supported economic reform and was only against the economic "shock therapy" tried by Mr. Yeltsin's Government. He spoke for the first time in public of his ethnic background as a Chechen. The predominantly Muslim area of Chechnya has declared independence from Russia.
Mr. Khasbulatov said there was always "dirty propaganda" over the fact that he was not Russian, "though I must say I always thought and said that in our conditions of multinational politics we need a clear pro-Russian policy." He added, "I do this not because I am pro-Russian, but because if the Russian people feel free and secure in their own fatherland, that is the best guarantee for all ethnic minorities."
Mr. Khasbulatov's chatty performance, presented in the form of an interview with a friendly reporter, was in sharp contrast to Mr. Yeltsin's tough, terse statement.
"There are forces in the Supreme Soviet that are seeking any reason to increase confrontation," he said. "It can be said with certainty today: one of the scenarios of overthrowing the President is under way."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 29, 1993, Monday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Friday about the political crisis in Moscow misstated the Russian expression for "to vote impeachment." It is "golosovat impichment."

HEADLINE: Ending Its Secrecy, White House Lists Health-Care Panel

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
After much criticism of the secrecy surrounding the work of his health policy team, President Clinton today abandoned his effort to conceal the names of more than 500 people who are developing his proposal to guarantee health insurance coverage for all Americans.
With the names of many of those people having already circulated around Washington, the White House acknowledged that its effort to keep the identities secret had failed, and it reluctantly issued a listing of all 511 staff members of the health-care task force. [The list appears on page 8.] 
 "Most of that list has been circulating around town for weeks," said Michael D. Bromberg, executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems, which represents 1,400 hospitals.
 
Secrecy Led to Errors
 Of the 511 people listed by the White House, 412 are described as full-time employees of the Government. Eighty-two are described as special, or temporary, employees. And 17 are described as consultants.
More than 130 of those described as full-time Government employees work for members of Congress or for Congressional committees.
In the past, Robert O. Boorstin, a spokesman for the Task Force on National Health Care Reform, had said the White House would not identify people working for the panel out of concern that they would be pestered by lobbyists or journalists.
But today White House spokesmen said they were making the list public now because some of the unofficial lists published or otherwise circulated had been incomplete or inaccurate.
Before today, Health Care Reform Week, published by the United Communications Group, and Health Care Policy Report, published weekly by the Bureau of National Affairs, had listed the names of many people working for the task force, which is headed by Hillary Rodham Clinton.
But White House officials said they were particularly upset when the names of 528 people supposedly working for the panel were published on the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday. The Journal tweaked the Administration by inviting "amateur Kremlinologists" to provide information on those whom the newspaper listed.
 
'The Truth Will Out'
 On March 18, Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, a Republican from upstate New York, issued a similar unofficial list, which was then published in the Congressional Record. "This country has learned, over two centuries, that a free and unfettered exchange in public is the best medicine for any of our nation's problems," Mr. Solomon said last week. "And in the end, as the First Lady will soon learn, the truth will out."
President Clinton created the task force on Jan. 25, five days after he took office. The 12-member panel, which includes six Cabinet Secretaries, is responsible for helping him develop a plan to control health costs and to guarantee health insurance coverage for all Americans.
But most of the work is being done by staff members, the people who were identified today. The task force itself will hold its first meeting, a public hearing at George Washington University here, on Monday. Mr. Clinton has said he will submit his proposals to Congress by May 3.
The most prominent name on the list issued today is that of Ira C. Magaziner, senior adviser to the President for policy development. He is coordinating the work of the task force.
The list includes the names of many longtime employees of the Department of Health and Human Services, like Joseph Antos, Kathleen A. Buto, Barbara Gagel and James Lubitz; people who worked on Mr. Clinton's campaign team, like Judith Feder and Atul Gawande; six people identified as working for Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources, and six who work for Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health.
In February, the Association of American Physicians and Surgeons sued the Government in an effort to get meetings of the task force opened to the public. Kent Masterson Brown, a lawyer for the association, said tonight that he was pleased that the names of the staff members had been released.
 
Organization Remains Mystery
 But the list does not show the organization of the task force, which has more than 30 "working groups." It does not indicate who is working on which issues, and the identification of outside experts hired by the White House is often incomplete.
For example, Paul Starr is listed as being affiliated with the Department of Health and Human Services. The White House gives no indication that he is, in fact, a professor of sociology at Princeton University.
Nor does the White House disclose that Mr. Starr is in charge of a panel studying one of the most volatile issues, "short-term cost controls," which may include Federal limits on doctors' fees, hospital charges, drug prices and insurance premiums.
 
Tired of Inaccuracies
 Mr. Boorstin, the spokesman for the task force, said: "In conjunction with the public meeting of the task force, we decided to release the list. Frankly, we were tired of seeing so many inaccurate lists published in so many normally reputable places.
"The reason we originally did not release this list had nothing to do with some grand Soviet-style conspiracy," Mr. Boorstin said. "Rather, we were trying to be kind and fair to people who gave up three months of their lives to help devise health-care policy. We didn't want to subject them to the assault of lobbyists, special interests and the enthusiastic Washington press corps."
Mr. Bromberg, often described as the dean of health-care lobbyists in Washington, said: "The staff of the task force has been listening to us. But they ought to be talking to more people in the real world who have to deliver health care. Those 500 have been pretty sheltered. They are doing a good job in terms of identifying options for the President. But very few of these people ever have to treat a patient or insure one or deliver care."

HEADLINE: U.S. Asks I.M.F. to Increase Aid To Russia and to Ease Conditions

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, working to assemble a new aid package to help President Boris N. Yeltsin, has proposed that the International Monetary Fund greatly increase its assistance to Russia.
The Administration has also suggested that the I.M.F. ease some restrictions that blocked the delivery of much of the Western aid promised last year. 
 Under a proposal that has been submitted to other Western nations, the Administration would have the monetary fund increase aid to $13.5 billion a year, Western officials said today, compared to just $1 billion out of the $8.5 billion in aid it was expected to provide a year ago.
The total amount of aid proposed last year for Russia by the fund, the United States and the six other major industrial democracies was $24 billion. Of that sum, only about $15 billion was delivered, mostly in the form of credits for Russian imports.
The main reason for the shortfall was Russia's failure to make all the economic reforms sought by Western bankers.
For example, the International Monetary Fund put together a $6 billion fund for Russia to help stabilize the value of the ruble. The fund was never used because Russia never took sufficient steps to curb inflation, a prerequisite for maintaining the value of the ruble against other currencies.
The Russian failure was critical because without a stable ruble, investment and trade are extremely difficult to carry out.
 
Split Over Curbing Inflation
 Despite the hopes of the Clinton Administration, it is not clear that Russia could do much better this year, even with less restrictive conditions on the aid. As the turmoil of the last week demonstrated, the Government is badly split over steps to curb inflation, which is now raging at about 25 percent a month.
In the past year, Western bankers and economists have tried and failed many times to work out a program in Russia to curtail inflation by reining in the money supply. But Russia has been slow because of fears that higher interest rates and other anti-inflationary steps would throw people out of work and lead to big increases in prices of food and other goods.
Popular anxiety about rising prices and unemployment fueled the conservative opposition to talk of removing President Yeltsin this week.
Part of the Administration's new proposal, apparently timed to bring action in time for President Clinton's meeting with President Yeltsin in Vancouver on April 3-4, was made Wednesday in a letter to the so-called Group of Seven industrial nations.
The proposal was for the International Monetary Fund to be the main source of loans to finance imports, a fund to stabilize the ruble, and perhaps credits to help rebuild industry.
 
G-7 Support Thought Likely
 Western officials said they thought the seven nations would embrace most if not all parts of the proposal.
A significant part of the Administration's proposal is to expand the I.M.F.'s role in providing aid. In the $24 billion package assembled last year, the fund played a leading role, but much of the aid was promised as direct loans from individual countries to Russia.
If the monetary fund expands its role, then Western governments might then expand their own direct assistance, bringing the total to $30 billion this year.
"We are committed to doing everything we possibly can to keep alive democracy and reform in Russia," President Clinton said today after meeting for the first time with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany. "We believe it is in the immediate interests and the long-term interests of all of our people."
 
I.M.F. Seen as Best Source
 American officials have been deeply disappointed with the West's failure to provide much of the $24 billion in aid it promised Russia last year.
The letter makes clear that the Administration sees the Washington-based International Monetary Fund as the best source to tap for additional aid at a time when the United States and other Western nations are strapped by recession and budget deficits.
One senior official said the Administration wants the monetary fund to act "more creatively" in helping Russia. For example, the Administration's letter suggests that the I.M.F. make between $1.8 and $3 billion available under an emergency fund that provides credit to countries that suffer an unexpected shortfall of export revenues.
The Administration's push for the International Monetary Fund to provide more aid comes at a time when the Administration is eager to show in a highly visible way that the West is helping Russia in its traumatic transition to a market economy and Mr. Yeltsin in his confrontation with the Russian Parliament.
Administration officials said they were also considering a fund to make loans available to Russian entrepreneurs, a technical aid package to help the beleaguered oil industry, and loan guarantees to help finance homes for demobilized Russian troops. They were also urging somewhat easier terms to reschedule Russia's $80 billion in foreign debt to provide about $15 billion in relief on interest and principal.
Mr. Clinton, who said after the meeting with Mr. Kohl that the "personal chemistry" between the two leaders was "quite good," added, "We also believe that the rest of the G-7 countries must cooperate with us and with each other to vigorously produce a program of support for Russia."
At their joint news conference, Mr. Kohl said, "Both of us are aware that any type of setback would be much more expensive than any type of assistance we are discussing."
In words of implicit praise for President Clinton, Mr. Kohl added that "under the leadership of the Americans and the American president" the two leaders wanted to send a message that the West would do its utmost to "see to it that Russia and the other successor states to the Soviet Union stand a chance to walk on their own path towards freedom."
Germany has provided more aid to Russia than any other nation, but because it is saddled by a recession and with the huge costs of unification, it has become hesitant to continue carrying such a large portion of the load.
Today in Tokyo, the Japanese Government, easing resistance to providing substantial aid to Russia, announced that it would serve as host of a meeting of the Group of Seven's finance and foreign ministers on April 14 and 15 to discuss an aid package for Russia.
The Administration's lettersaid aid from the monetary fund should be contingent on Russia's reining in its runaway money supply growth and taking other reforms. Some officials said in private, however, that the Administration was urging the monetary fund to be somewhat less strict in demanding that Moscow make stringent reforms in exchange for aid.

HEADLINE: I.B.M.'s New Leader;
Task of Turning Around I.B.M. Is Given to an Industry Outsider

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
I.B.M. officially named Louis V. Gerstner Jr. as its chairman and chief executive yesterday, after a two-month search that led the troubled computer giant's board to conclude that it needs a risk-taking business strategist, like Mr. Gerstner, not a seasoned technology expert.
By placing its uncertain future and corporate America's biggest challenge in the hands of Mr. Gerstner, the chairman of RJR Nabisco Holdings and a computer industry outsider, I.B.M. has defined its course: to accelerate the evolution of a corporate empire into a loose confederation of more nimble, entrepreneurial businesses. 
 Whether Mr. Gerstner, 51, a former consultant at McKinsey & Company and a one-time president of the American Express Company, is the right person to revive the International Business Machines Corporation has been widely debated in the computer industry. [Page 45.]
 
 
Industry's Suggestions
 But even some of the company's longtime critics concede that I.B.M. is a unique corporation, with $60 billion in annual revenues, and that perhaps its chief executive should not be a person steeped in some niche of computer technology.
James E. Burke, the retired chairman of Johnson & Johnson who led the I.B.M. board's search, said he spoke to 75 computer industry executives, only a few of whom were candidates for the job. Though a veteran I.B.M. board member, he says he found those talks most enlightening.
"What I didn't understand as much as I should have, and what I.B.M. didn't understand enough, was the rate of change in this industry," Mr. Burke said yesterday in an interview. "I don't think any of us understood the impact of that, and how much smaller, entrepreneurial companies can exploit that rapid pace of change. They move quickly, and they love to take risk. And I see those qualities in Lou."
For his part, Mr. Gerstner said he would spend his first few months on the job talking to I.B.M. managers and workers, scrutinizing each of the company's businesses before taking action. And he sought to dampen expectations that there would soon be a sharp reversal of I.B.M.'s fortunes.
"This is not going to be a short-term fix," he said at a morning news conference in Manhattan. "This is going to take time."
The announcement that Mr. Gerstner would succeed John F. Akers as I.B.M.'s chairman and chief executive was not a surprise. It has been known since January that Mr. Akers is being eased out, and the two-month hunt for a new chief was the most avidly watched talent search in the history of American business. It was apparent for a week that Mr. Gerstner was the front-runner.
He has had ample time to ponder the challenge awaiting him at I.B.M. The company is but the most striking example of a crisis facing many old-line American corporations, as household names from General Motors to Sears are forced to cut jobs and streamline operations to try to keep up with leaner, more efficient rivals, from Toyota to Wal-Mart.
"I.B.M., like many other American companies, has found that the markets and the technology have shifted so fast that its old models of doing business no longer work," said James Champy, a management consultant in Cambridge, Mass., and co-author of a new book, "Re-engineering the Corporation," which examines how big companies can be more efficient.
 Under Mr. Akers, I.B.M. did try to remake itself. The company cut its work force from 406,000 in 1986 to 300,000 by the end of last year, and its business units were given more freedom from corporate headquarters.
But the company has not moved fast enough to get ahead of the quicksilver pace of technological change in the computer industry, which is the main reason it reported a loss of nearly $5 billion last year. I.B.M. has been hit particularly hard by a shift from multimillion-dollar mainframe computers, I.B.M.'s mainstay business, toward smaller desktop machines that run on microprocessors.
Mr. Burke, the I.B.M. director, said that one trait he admired in Mr. Gerstner was his belief in decentralized management, with those closest to customers making more decisions.
For a couple of years, sales of I.B.M.'s software and services have grown rapidly even as sales of its equipment have slipped. A comment made by Mr. Gerstner at the news conference suggested that he might try to hasten the shift to software and services, like consulting corporate customers on how to link computers and software most efficiently.
The historic search for a new chief executive -- the first from outside the I.B.M. ranks in the company's 79-year history -- was conducted by the seven members of the board's search team, led by Mr. Burke. It began in late January, Mr. Burke said, with "a handful" of candidates, including Mr. Gerstner, that was informally put together by the search team.
 
 
Code Name: 'Abel'
 With the help of two executive recruiters, Heidrick & Struggles and Spencer Stuart, a more comprehensive list of 125 people worldwide was assembled. But the board mainly focused on its short initial list.
In an effort to insure secrecy, the candidates were given code names, and Mr. Gerstner's was "Abel." "Lou Gerstner was the first person I talked to," Mr. Burke explained.
When Mr. Burke first talked with him, shortly after the search was announced in late January, Mr. Gerstner said his first reaction was negative. "I said, 'That's not for me; I'm happy where I am," Mr. Gerstner recalled in an interview, referring to his post at RJR Nabisco, the tobacco-and-food conglomerate.
But Mr. Burke persisted, and Mr. Gerstner reconsidered. "Jim Burke began to convince me that his was more than an extraordinary challenge, which does turn me on," Mr. Gerstner said. "He began to convince me that it was important to the country and the economy that I.B.M. be restored to the force that it once was."
Mr. Burke said that once Mr. Gerstner began discussing the job in those broader terms, "we figured we had him."
Mr. Burke sought to deflect the impression that others in the computer industry had turned down the job. Several well-known executives, including John Sculley, the chief executive of Apple Computer Inc., and George M. C. Fisher, the chairman of Motorola Inc., had issued public statements saying they did not want the I.B.M. job.
But Mr. Burke said that Mr. Gerstner was the only person to whom the board made a formal offer. Still, as one executive recruiter noted, the etiquette of top-level corporate job searches tends to be that a formal offer is not made unless the candidate has strongly indicated acceptance.
The terms of Mr. Gerstner's I.B.M. pay package have not been disclosed, but should be made known within a few days. He walks away from a multimillion-dollar yearly compensation package at RJR Nabisco.
Investors showed little reaction to the expected announcement, driving I.B.M. shares up 87.5 cents each yesterday, to $51.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Casino Backers Raise the Ante In Connecticut

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 26

 BODY:
As a debate over casino gambling intensifies in the Connecticut Legislature, casino operators have begun one of the most sophisticated and expensive efforts ever undertaken in this state to win friends and influence the people who count.
Mirage Resorts, which has offered to build two casinos, in Bridgeport and Hartford, spent more than $92,000 last month alone on lobbying, public relations fees, expenses and entertainment, the largest one-month lobbying tab in recent history, if not ever, according to the State Ethics Commission.
 
An Advertising Barrage
 That does not count the $382,000 the company committed for what it called an initial television advertising barrage (by Hal Riney, the high-priced and mellow-voiced creator of ads for Gallo Wines and of Ronald Reagan's "Morning in America" campaign) or the even subtler efforts and arguments that are harder to categorize. 
 "It's intense stuff," said Representative William R. Dyson, a nine-term Democrat from New Haven who said he had not "officially taken a position" on the bill.
"I can't think of anything that's been anywhere near this level," he said.
Opponents and supporters alike say that every new jolt of bad news about the state's troubled economy, like the partial closing of the Navy's submarine base in Groton, announced earlier this month, bolsters the case for casinos.
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who says that a further expansion of gambling would cause social harm, has not succeeded in stifling the proposal. He signed a $100 million-a-year profit-sharing deal in January with the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, operators of the state's only existing casino, which had seemed to derail casino developers. The deal made the tribe's payments contingent on the Indians' keeping their monopoly on gambling. But now even some of Mr. Weicker's supporters say that by agreeing to such a deal, he may have undermined his right to object to an expansion of gambling on grounds of social principle.
Stephen A. Wynn, the president and chairman of Mirage Resorts, has also raised the ante. He told the State Legislature last month that his company would guarantee a minimum of $140 million in tax revenues for two casinos.
 
Talking About Jobs
 Around the state, discussion on the issue is pervasive and basic, centering on jobs and economic development.
Many Hartford residents awoke this morning, for example, to hear a radio talk-show host broadcasting live from the Mirage in Las Vegas, enthusiastically interviewing casino workers about their jobs. The trip was paid for by the Mirage.
On Saturday, the company will hold a Jobs Information Fair in Bridgeport, Connecticut's largest and poorest city, to tell people about casino jobs that do not yet exist. The idea, a company spokesman said, is to "get people excited" and encourage them to press local legislators.
The casino bill, which cleared a major hurdle on Thursday when the Legislature's Public Safety Committee approved it by a 21-to-4 vote, is still considered a long shot to become law this year. The bill would require the approval of three other committees, and Mr. Weicker has promised to veto the bill if it reaches his desk. Overriding a veto would take a two-thirds majority in both the House and Senate.
 
Urban Democrats Lead Drive
 Democrats in and around Bridgeport and Hartford are leading the drive for the casinos, while suburban Republicans have formed the core of the opposition. Legislators from southeastern Connecticut, whose constituents' jobs at the Indians' casino in Ledyard could be endangered by competition, are largely united against the proposal, leaving other lawmakers in both parties to be picked off, one by one. Supporters of the rights of labor, for instance, are being wooed with the argument that state labor laws are not enforceable on Indian lands, but would be in a state-regulated casino.
"They're hammering away and they're scoring some points," said Representative Thomas S. Luby, a Democrat from Meriden and the majority leader in the House of Representatives. Mr. Luby described himself as skeptical about the potential of gambling to provide long-term economic growth, especially if casinos sprout up elsewhere around the region. However, Mr. Luby said, "I don't think anyone at this point can predict the result."
Mr. Luby believes that residents, especially the unemployed, are listening hard. The television ad, with its simple language about jobs and Connecticut's future, makes the casino sound almost incidental.
"You walk into a luncheonette today and you'll see people turning to you and saying, 'What about those 23,000 jobs?' " he said.
 
Going to the Job Fair
 Orlando Rivera, a 24-year-old Bridgeport maintenance worker with a wife and two children and no job since he was laid off four months ago, said today he would be going to the Mirage job fair, if only to keep up his hopes.
"I want a new job," he said. "And if it takes a casino to get one, then I'm all for a casino coming to Bridgeport."
The job fair will feature 38 Mirage employees, ranging from cooks to croupiers, who were flown to Connecticut on Thursday. Mark Rivers, a spokesman for Mirage, said that two of the employees were former Connecticut residents who would be able to tell the sad, but no doubt ultimately uplifting story of how they could not find work in their home state because of the bad economy, and so went west to work for the Mirage.

 BODY:

I.B.M.'s New Leader

HEADLINE: U.S. Calls On Japan to Set Trade Goals

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration asked Japan today to set specific figures for how much in foreign goods and services it plans to buy as part of a fiscal stimulus package.
Continuing its aggressive approach to trade policy, the Administration also asked Japan to outline the steps it intends to take to carry out a pledge to increase purchases of American automobile parts. 
 The requests were presented by the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, during a meeting with Trade Minister Yoshiro Mori of Japan and came on the heels of remarks by President Clinton that American companies have only a "remote" chance of cracking Japan's market.
 
Fiscal Package for Japan
 Washington has called on Tokyo to give Japan's sagging economy a budgetary lift by increasing Government spending and cutting taxes. Japan is working on such a fiscal package.
Mr. Kantor's office said that in his talks he "pointed out the importance of including a specific allocation for purchases of foreign goods and services by the Japanese Government" in the package.
"Kantor stressed that U.S.-Japan bilateral agreements and understandings require immediate action by Japan to insure full implementation," the trade representative's office said after the two officials met for an hour.
Mr. Kantor told Mr. Mori that the United States expected Japan's automobile industry to fulfill the pledges it made in January to buy more American auto parts.
 
Pledge on U.S. Auto Parts
 "This includes the pledge to increase purchases of American auto parts by Japanese auto manufacturers in the United States and Japan to $19 billion by 1994 and to increase local content of production in the United States from 50 percent to 70 percent by 1994," Mr. Kantor's office said.
Mr. Kantor presented Mr. Mori with a letter that asked for the "steps Japan intends to take to meet its pledge." The letter was from Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown as well as from Mr. Kantor.
Mr. Kantor did note that Japan had lived up to its agreement to increase its purchases of foreign computer chips to 20 percent of the Japanese market.
But he made clear that further progress was needed during the life of the current agreement, which expires in mid-1996.
Mr. Kantor and Mr. Mori agreed on the importance of bringing the Uruguay round of international trade talks to a successful conclusion, according to Mr. Kantor's office. But Mr. Kantor told Mr. Mori that he expected Tokyo to "be fully prepared to contribute actively to all aspects of the negotiations."

HEADLINE: Of 3 Arkansas Pals and a Raccoon Roast

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
One of the most important friendships in Washington today is the quiet alliance of three former Arkansas Governors who all ended up working on Pennsylvania Avenue: President Clinton, Senator David Pryor and Senator Dale Bumpers.
Theirs is a unique bond. It was forged on the rubber-chitterlings circuit of Arkansas politics, it survived their once reckless pursuit of a roasted raccoon and it thrives today with Mr. Bumpers and Mr. Pryor serving as Mr. Clinton's eyes and ears on the Senate floor. That is, when the three Democrats are not in the White House living room tuning in Arkansas basketball games via the President's satellite dish. 
 But first, the raccoon story. As Senator Bumpers, the official raconteur of the Bill, David and Dale club, tells it, every year Democrats in Gillett, Ark., put on a raccoon supper that is compulsory for Arkansas politicians. But in January 1988, Arkansas was buried in a blizzard on Coon Supper day.
 
What's a Little Snow?
 "Bill called me and said: 'Are you going to the Coon Supper?' " Senator Bumpers recalled. "I said, 'Gosh, Bill, I don't think we can land.' He said, 'Well, I talked to the county judge and he says the road graders are out there scraping the snow off the runway so we can get in.' "
Senator Pryor looked at the weather and bowed out, but Senator Bumpers and Governor Clinton took off. On the way, as Mr. Clinton regaled Mr. Bumpers with stories, the runway iced up, and when their small plane landed, it skidded and spun into a cow pasture.
"I swear, I don't think Bill ever quit telling that story he was in the middle of when we finally came to a halt. I said: 'Bill, get that door open. Let's get out of here.' And he just casually found the door. He was in no hurry whatever. He finally opened the door and we jumped out of that plane and we took off running through the snow to get away from it. I'm sure we hadn't gone 30 feet, and good ol' Bill says to me, 'Boy, I bet we don't ever lose a vote down here again.' "
Some people never change.
But that, of course, is why Senator Bumpers loves telling the story -- because the shared memories of a thousand dinners and a thousand small Arkansas towns is the glue that cements this friendship.
Since the early 1970's, Mr. Clinton, Mr. Bumpers and Mr. Pryor have taken turns helping one another run their state, warning one another of land mines, supporting one another's campaigns and generally serving as a mutual aid society. With the arrival of Mr. Clinton in the White House, they have taken their alliance to Washington, where, with little notice, the two Senators are now among the President's closest advisers.
When Mr. Clinton wants the inside dope on a representative or senator, he simply calls for "Dale 'n' David," which is usually pronounced as one word around the White House.
"I don't know if the President calls Bumpers and Pryor every day, but someone here does," said Skip Rutherford, an informal White House adviser who like so many in the intertwined world of Arkansas politics is a Bumpers confidant, a Clinton family friend and a former Pryor aide. "There is between the three of them what the operators would call an open line."
When the President is looking for some company he can relax with, he dials up his two Razorback buddies from the Hill, and when Mr. Clinton gave his first nationally televised address from the Oval Office last month, two days before his economic message to Congress, he asked only these two friends down to the White House to keep him company.
 
Senators to Lean On
 The routine started during the New Hampshire primaries, when Mr. Clinton, unnerved by charges of draft dodging and marital infidelity, imported the Senators for moral support. "I did notice this about Bill Clinton in New Hampshire," recalled Senator Pryor. "I think if he could look out into an audience and spot someone he knew, or spot someone especially from Arkansas, I think it kind of inspired him, kind of relaxed him."
Besides policy advice, Mr. Clinton has also gleaned some of his best down-home Arkansasisms from his two friends, including these favorites: "He's squealin' like a pig stuck under a gate"; "If you don't want to run with the big dogs, stay on the porch"; and, "You gotta throw the corn where the hogs can get to it," a Bumpers saying often used in reference to making aid more easily available to the Russians.
In a way, all three men owe their political careers to a liberal Republican, Winthrop Rockefeller, the man who knocked off Gov. Orval Faubus, the archconservative segregationist who ruled Arkansas from 1954 to 1966. In the Arkansas New Testament, Rockefeller begat Bumpers (Governor from 1971 to 1975), Bumpers begat Pryor (Governor from 1975 to 1979) and Pryor begat Clinton (Governor from 1979 to 1981 and from 1983 to 1992).
 
Turnabout in Arkansas
 "Arkansas felt ashamed over the demagoguery and international ridicule that Faubus brought, and so it turned to some of the most liberal governors and senators you will find anywhere outside of Massachusetts," said John R. Brummett, a columnist for the Arkansas Times.
What is unusual is that three ambitious politicians, who shared so many of the same values, aspirations and fund-raisers, managed not only to stay out of each other's way but also to become fast friends. From 1974 on they often appeared together at rallies around the state, but each one was always running for a different job. Thomas F. McLarty 3d, President Clinton's childhood friend whom they all call Mack and who is now White House chief of staff, was the chairman of the Arkansas Democratic Party for some of that time, describing himself "as kind of the Ed McMahon of that traveling minstrel show."
Senators Pryor and Bumpers were clearly always glad they could keep one job ahead of young Bill -- until now. "The first time I met Bill Clinton was at a function in Russell, Ark., in 1974 and he was running against John Paul Hammerschmidt for the House," Senator Bumpers recalled. "I had heard about this young law professor but I was not prepared for him to be as articulate and attractive as he was. I was a Governor running for the Senate, and you know, I looked at him and made a quick calculation: If this guy is elected to the House of Representatives, six years from now he is probably going to come after me. Absolutely! I had no relish for that."
 
Different Relationships
 The relationships among them, while openly affectionate, nevertheless have shades of difference. The 58-year-old Senator Pryor has more of an avuncular relationship with the President, friends say, while Senator Bumpers, though 67 years old, is in many ways more like Mr. Clinton -- Presidential aspirant and policy aficionado with a razor tongue -- and their relationship has just a spice of sibling competitiveness. They still tell the story in Little Rock about a political roast of Mr. Clinton in 1982, when Mr. Bumpers roasted him just a little too well done.
Turning to Mr. Clinton on the dais, Senator Bumpers said: "You'll understand if Bill is not at his best at tonight. He was working all day on his income taxes, but he couldn't send them in because when he came to the line for the signature of head of household he couldn't find Hillary."
Senator Bumpers, who is also very close with Mrs. Clinton, now winces at the memory of that evening, saying: "That did cause some grief. I felt terrible about that."
 
Barometers of Congress
 But the roasting skewers have been put away, and now Senators Bumpers and Pryor serve as the President's personal barometers on Capitol Hill, much as former Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada did for Ronald Reagan. While this has certainly enhanced their status among fellow lawmakers, it has also earned them the extra headache of colleagues' trying to get to the President through them.
Neither Senator will talk about his conversations with the President. The closest they come is Senator Pryor's explanation: "We try to help him with the politics of the Senate, the institution itself, some of the personalities he is dealing with. Sometimes he'll ask, 'What's this guy going to ask me when he comes to White House at 3:30 P.M.? How should I respond? What makes him tick? What's he like? What's he want?' That sort of thing is a role that Dale and I probably play."
Mr. Clinton has also incorporated Senator Bumpers's proposals for helping small businesses with tax credits into his economic plan, and it was Senator Pryor's long-time campaign to control prescription drug costs that helped inspire Mr. Clinton's own assault on the pharmaceutical industry last month.
But while both Senators relish having one of their long-playing trio in the Oval Office, both have been around politics, and Bill Clinton, too long to exaggerate their roles.
"He probably calls us to be nice as much as anything," said Senator Bumpers, "because he got a long way without either one of us."

The third now resides at the White House. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. 9)

HEADLINE: A Drawback to Serb Sanctions: They Don't Work

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 26

 BODY:
As the United States and its Western allies assess the possibility of tightening sanctions against Serbia in an effort to bring peace to Bosnia, they are confronted by a troubling paradox: The diplomatic measures taken up to now have ended up strengthening the Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic, and entrenching most Serbs in a dogged commitment to the war.
The signing on Thursday by Alija Izetbegovic, the leader of the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government, of a proposed international peace plan has left the Serbs as the only Bosnian faction that has not accepted it. President Clinton has spoken of toughening trade sanctions against the Serbs, or lifting an arms embargo on the Bosnian Government forces, as a means to bring Serbian compliance. 
 But almost a year after the start of the Bosnian war and nine months after the imposition of a virtual trade embargo on the Serbian-dominated federal Yugoslavia, there is scant evidence that sanctions have brought any of the desired results.
With inflation now running above 250 percent a month, unemployment affecting a third of the population, the economy in ruins and young lives being lost daily in the war, the elements would appear to exist for a surge of Serbian protest against Mr. Milosevic.
 
Few Opponents to War
 Yet Zarko Korac, a psychology professor at Belgrade University, who is helping to organize a demonstration against the war on April 3, the first anniversary of its outbreak, believes it would be an achievement if the march drew more than 500 people.
"The number one obsession of people is that they see a plot against the nation to annihilate it," Mr. Korac said. "Sanctions work for the Government because they help feed the notion that the world is unjustly inimical to the Serbs and that only a tough leader like Mr. Milosevic can resist."
Vuk Draskovic, the leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, the main opposition party in Belgrade, added: "I'm absolutely against the sanctions because Mr. Milosevic has benefited from them. They're his big excuse for all the problems here."
Criticism of the United Nations sanctions, and of the notion of tightening them, is almost universal here, even among those who detest the Milosevic Government. The main effect of cutting Serbia's economic ties to the world, opposition leaders say, has been to awaken an old Balkan instinct -- pride in a defiant struggle for survival.
It was not supposed to turn out this way. Under the scenario sketched by Western officials shortly after the United Nations sanctions were imposed last June, popular discontent was supposed to reach its apex during the tough winter months, eventually swelling to the point where Mr. Milosevic was either defeated in elections last December or driven from power by a tide of protest.
Mr. Milosevic's departure, according to this outline, would in turn unlock the door to peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina because his quiet financial, logistical and ideological support for the Serbian nationalists in Bosnia has been crucial to their prosecution of the war.
But winter has given way to an unseasonably warm spring, and there is scarcely a whimper of protest to be heard among the cafes whose tables are already spilling onto the sidewalks of Belgrade.
People grumble about the lack of gasoline or the shortage of medicine in hospitals, but they seem to make no connection between the shortages, the weakening economy and the Government. The opposition parties are hopelessly divided. Mr. Milosevic has been comfortably re-elected and a brooding fatalism has set in.
"The Government feeds itself on war and sanctions," said Ljubomir Madzar, an economist who supports the opposition Democratic Party. "Indeed, there is a possibility that the Government could be seriously weakened if sanctions were partly lifted."
United States diplomats in Belgrade concede that sanctions may have backfired. "Mr. Milosevic is now more firmly in the saddle than he has been for a long time, and he is there partly because he can always blame the outside world to distract attention from his own failures," one said.
But few policy options appear to remain. By consensus, the most effective moment for a Western military intervention in Bosnia passed several months ago because the division of the republic along ethnic lines favored by the Serbs is now so advanced as to appear irreversible.
All that is left for the United States, it seems, is lukewarm support for the peace plan devised by the mediation team of Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen, although Western officials here are skeptical about the Serbian forces in Bosnia respecting the plan's ethnic divisions and central government.
In part, the failure of Western diplomatic measures to bring the desired results appears to reflect a misreading of the complex psychology of Serbia, forged over a long history of heroic defiance and terrible slaughter.
"The agenda here is nationalism," said Vesna Pesic, a leader of the small Civic Alliance opposition group.
This nationalism gained explosive force because the trauma of the brutal civil war fought in Yugoslavia during and after World War II was never resolved in the peaceful postwar decades of Titoism, the nonaligned brand of Communism led by Marshal Tito that sought to forge a homogenous Yugoslavia out of the diverse ethnicity of the Balkans.
"After the war there was oblivion," said Bojan Jovanovic, an anthropologist at Belgrade University. "Nobody ever brought the balance sheet."
All that was repressed has now emerged. To the Serbs, thousands of whom were killed in Croatia and Bosnia during World War II by the puppet Croatian fascist regime, the threats posed by Yugoslavia's breakup apparently raised specters real enough to rally support for renewed nationalist fervor.
This support has been sustained because many Serbs -- even moderate opposition figures -- believe that international recognition of the independence of Croatia and Bosnia failed to take account of the position of the roughly 600,000 Serbs living in Croatia and the 1.4 million in Bosnia who were left to fend for themselves against hostile new governments in Croatia and Bosnia.
"The political structure of this country now needs a war," said Mr. Korac, the psychologist. "It generates support. And that frightens me because Mr. Milosevic is intelligent, ruthless and immensely destructive."
Mrs. Pesic, the opposition leader, added: "Nobody knows how to get out of this. We feel trapped. What's going to happen? Nothing. Disaster."
 
 
Balkan Update
Belgrade, Yugoslavia
Gen. Ratko Mladic, the commander of the Serbian forces in Bosnia, agreed yesterday with the leaders of the Muslim and Croatian forces on a cease-fire to take effect tomorrow. The agreement was announced by Lieut. Gen. Philippe Morillon, the commander of United Nations forces in Bosnia. General Mladic said the cease-fire would take hold along the armies' current front lines.
 
 
Sarajevo, Bosnia
An 18-inch snowfall put a damper on the shelling of Sarajevo by Serbian forces. The snow also worsened the plight of Muslims trapped in the town of Srebrenica in eastern Bosnia.
 
 
Washington
Seeming to play down earlier comments that he might consider lifting the embargo on sending arms to the Bosnian Government, President Clinton said that for now he intended to rely on economic sanctions and diplomatic pressure to get the Serbs to accept a peace accord.
