HEADLINE: Growth Rate in Late '92 Surged to a 5-Year High

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
Strong consumer spending helped fuel the fastest economic growth in five years in late 1992, the Government reported today, but analysts said the economy had since slowed, partly because of sluggish hiring.
The Commerce Department said the gross domestic product -- the total output of goods and services -- grew at a 4.7 percent annual rate from October through December, a pace that economists said confirmed that the economic recovery was well in place. 
 For the year, the economy grew 2.1 percent, the best annual performance since 1989, when it expanded 2.5 percent. The economy had contracted 1.2 percent in 1991.
 
Predictions Aren't Robust
 But analysts predicted the G.D.P. would grow only about 3 percent this year.
"Economic growth is definitely slowing from what I call a fairly strong pace in the final quarter of last year," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist with the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York, agreed. "Recent data suggest that growth during the first quarter is decelerating sharply," she said.
During the seven quarters since the end of the recession in March 1991, output has grown only about 4 percent -- half the 7.9 percent average for the corresponding period of other recent recoveries.
The revised 4.7 percent fourth-quarter growth rate was slightly less than the department's 4.8 percent estimate last month. The economy expanded at a 3.4 percent rate in the third quarter of 1992; 1.5 percent in the second and 2.9 percent in the first.
The department said a measure of inflation tied to the G.D.P. rose a revised 3.4 percent during the fourth quarter, up from 2.1 percent in the third quarter and even faster than the 2.9 percent estimate last month. For the year, the inflation rate was 2.9 percent, down from 4 percent in 1991.
The department also said that after-tax corporate profits shot up 9.2 percent in the final three months of 1992, to $242.6 billion. It was the biggest jump since a 10.8 percent gain in the first quarter. For the year, corporate profits were up 10 percent.
The slight downward revision in the fourth-quarter G.D.P. was attributed to fewer exports and less Government spending than had been previously estimated. Those reductions were partly offset by the heavy year-end consumer spending.

HEADLINE: Clinton, Planning Forest Conference, Hopes to Free Logjam in Northwest

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., March 26

 BODY:
When President Clinton sits down next week with the warring factions in the Pacific Northwest timber dispute, he will be trying to do something more than save a piece of original America larger than Massachusetts.
The April 2 forest summit conference here will be the Administration's biggest and perhaps most difficult attempt to make good on campaign assertions that it is possible to protect a rare natural resource without putting a lot of people out of work. Voters in the Northwest, even in the timber counties, rejected Republican arguments last fall that the cost of environmentalism was too high. Now, the victors are expected to deliver. 
 The White House is bringing an enormous show of Presidential power to the issue. Mr. Clinton will be accompanied at the forest conference by Vice President Al Gore and at least four Cabinet members, and will be joined by the Governors of California, Oregon and Washington.
During the campaign Mr. Clinton visited timber towns and preached tolerance. But now he has the painful task of finding a solution to a conflict that bedeviled the two previous Republican Administrations and crippled the daily operations of the United States Forest Service.
 
Watershed Repair Plan
 One proposal under consideration by the White House, and favored by some Congressional leaders, is to put thousands of people to work restoring the land hit hardest by logging. The intent is to repair watersheds and streams that nurture salmon, one of the forests' most valuable species.
The timber industry wants trees, not new jobs in the woods, and is pressing for some relief from environmental restrictions that have virtually shut down logging in national forests west of the Cascade Range. But many people in the industry believe the battle has already been lost.
What started nearly a decade ago as an effort to save the spotted owl, a species facing extinction in the ancient, heavily logged forests of coastal Washington, Oregon and Northern California, has grown into a national campaign to save the forests for their own sake. Laws intended to protect fish and wildlife have been used, with great success, to curb the Government's timber program in the Northwest.
For nearly two years, as various government agencies fought among themselves, the courts have essentially been in charge of the forests. They have banned logging on millions of acres until the Federal Government provides a plan to assure that its timber sales are not violating the law.
 
Different Legal Positions
 This gridlock in the forests makes Congressional paralysis seem like sweet harmony by comparison. "One of the problems has been that the United States itself has taken different positions," the President said at a White House news conference on Tuesday. "So the first thing I hope to do is to be able to at least adopt a uniform legal position."
Last week a scientific panel put together by the Forest Service in response to a court order said that "there is simply no free lunch" in the Government's effort to save old-growth forests. More than 600 plant and animal species -- everything from salmon and spotted owls to a cancer-fighting drug that comes from the bark of yew trees -- are dependent on the health of America's temperate rain forest. Logging is causing the ecosystem to unravel, the scientists said.
But more than 30,000 workers who make their living cutting those trees stand to lose their jobs if the restrictions continue, according to the Government's projections.
The large timber companies that own their own land are having profitable years, while small sawmills that depend on Federal timber are running out of wood. The mills have been able to keep job losses to a minimum thus far because they are cutting a backlog of timber that was sold to them before the court injunctions.
As the courts have repeatedly ruled for environmentalists, it has become highly unlikely that the Government will ever go back to full-scale timber harvesting. Instead, the one-day forest conference has focused on how to take care of displaced workers and how to end the legal quagmire.
Mr. Clinton predicts pain for both sides. Whatever solution is worked out "will probably make everybody mad," the President said Tuesday, adding, "But I will try to be fair to the people whose livelihoods depend on this, and fair to the environment that we are all obligated to maintain."
Under the proposal to restore salmon streams, much of the money from the Forest Service budget that has been used for the timber program would be used to hire people in rural communities to plant new trees, fix trails and repair or remove roads that are depositing sediment in nearby streams. The payoff, proponents of the plan say, are healthy forests that will attract fishermen, hunters and hikers.
It would also fit in with Mr. Clinton's campaign promises. In Oregon last September he said, "If national policy puts you out of work, national policy ought to put you back in a job."
Some people in the timber industry seem ready to make a change. "We need to retrain people," said Mike Draper, executive secretary of the Western Council of Industrial Workers, a timber workers' union. "It's the obligation of government, because they are the ones who set these communities up to begin with."
A second major proposal, being advanced by the timber industry, is to allow a considerable amount of logging in the old-growth forests but to change the way it is done. Clear-cutting, in which an entire swath of trees is leveled, cleared and burned, would end. Trees would be selectively cut, or thinned. By going easier on the land, proponents say, fewer species would be harmed.
Environmentalists had hoped to have the national forests east of the Cascade Range, including the vast Colville National Forest in the eastern Washington district of Representative Thomas S. Foley, the House Speaker, be part of the summit conference agenda. But the White House, perhaps in a nod to Mr. Foley's general support of the timber interests, has taken eastern forests off the table.
Because of the climate, forests west of the Cascades are thick and rich in fish and wildlife; the eastern slopes are arid and not as heavily timbered.
The disappointment for the timber industry is that the Endangered Species Act, the legal tool that has been most effective in opposition to logging, is not up for change -- at least not now, said Katie McGinty, the President's chief environmental policy adviser.
 
Banner Year for Giants
 While loggers and sawmill workers dependent on Federal timber are suffering the most as a result of the the forest gridlock, the timber industry is having a banner year over all -- in part because lumber prices are higher now than any time since the late 1970's.
Last year more lumber from private timber tracts in the Northwest was exported than was cut from all of the region's 19 national forests. Environmentalists say there would be no timber crisis if the big companies did not send so much of their lumber overseas.
"We should stop the unconscionable colonial practice of selling off our precious raw materials," said Tim Hermach, head of the Native Forest Council, a nonprofit environmental group based in Eugene, Ore.
Mr. Hermach and other environmental leaders have urged Mr. Clinton to issue an executive order to tax or temporarily halt exports, diverting private timber to American sawmills.
The national forests contribute only 13 percent of the nation's domestic timber supply. Of that, only a fraction comes from the ancient forests. By the Forest Service's estimate, there are about six million acres of these virgin forests left, about half of which are protected in wilderness areas or parks.
The fight is over what to do with the other three million acres of publicly owned old-growth forests. Until a few years ago, more than 60,000 acres a year were being clear-cut.
The White House has been trying to play down expectations for the forest conference, saying it will be the starting point for a resolution of the issue. Congressional leaders are hoping to present a legislative package by June 1, according to Representative Norm Dicks, Democrat of Washington.
In announcing the forest conference earlier this month, Mr. Clinton joked that his summit conference with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, scheduled to be held a day later in Vancouver, British Columbia, would be easy compared to the meeting in Portland. He was only half-kidding.

Mr. Babbitt is touring the Pacific Northwest in preparation for a forest conference on April 2 that will be attended by President Clinton. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Integration Is Issue of Language and Geography

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
The growth of Hartford's Puerto Rican population and the need to provide bilingual education for its children may be the ultimate complications in a landmark desegregation lawsuit that seeks to link the city's schools with suburban ones.
Almost half of Hartford's 25,400 schoolchildren are Puerto Rican, and in some elementary schools almost half the pupils sit in bilingual classes, where they are taught mathematics, science and other subjects in Spanish while they learn English. 
 So integration here is no longer a matter of black and white. Just as Puerto Ricans are reshaping Connecticut's capital city, where they are expected to become the largest ethnic group this decade, the special needs of their children are remaking its schools. And if integration is to come, they do not want it to come at the expense of bilingual education.
"That's one of the areas that worries me in this case," said Raul Montanez-Pitre, the principal of Hooker School, a Hartford elementary school where nearly half the classes are bilingual. "How do you integrate children with limited English proficiency, who are being segregated linguistically because of sound pedagogical reasons, without jeopardizing the integrity of the program?"
For many suburbs, however, bilingual education would add an entirely new dimension to desegregation. It would introduce into their schools the seeming contradiction of classrooms that are intentionally segregated, by language. And it would require them to deal with the sensitive questions of culture and identity that Puerto Ricans carry with them from birth.
Puerto Ricans are not like earlier immigrants. They are already American citizens, Americans born into a centuries-old Spanish-speaking culture. They are propelled here by poverty at home, but the way home remains open to them. For many, holding on to two languages is vital for reconciling their dual identity.
"When you try to fool around with the language, you start fooling with the culture," said Juan Fuentes, a photographer who has documented the lives of Puerto Ricans here since the 1960's, when most came to work in shade-tobacco fields. "If you lose the culture, you lose everything."
 
Ciencia en Espanol, Writing in English
 The lawsuit known as Sheff v. O'Neill charges that the concentration of poor black and Puerto Rican children in Hartford schools denies them the educational opportunity available to suburban children.
A visit to Hooker School provides a glimpse of the linguistic balancing act entailed in bilingual education.
Hooker looks like any 1950's elementary school from Sherbrooke Avenue, where small houses face it. But a battered housing project is nearby, and visitors must buzz the office to be admitted through the locked front doors. Seventeen of the 38 classrooms are in portable buildings. Seventy percent of the pupils are Puerto Rican. Nearly 400 are assigned to bilingual classes.
In the integration lawsuit, in which testimony was concluded last month, the state blamed poverty for the poor academic performance of the city's children, and poverty is most extreme among Puerto Ricans. Three of four qualify for free or reduced-price lunches.
Reminders of poverty are constant in Maria Collazo's fourth-grade classroom at Hooker School, starting with the breakfast placed on each desk.
In the fourth grade, bilingual teachers begin to teach academic subjects in English, but science is still taught in Spanish. Ms. Collazo goes over the food groups as her pupils eat muffins and drink juice and milk. She has written on the blackboard: "proteinar," "hidratos carbone," "grasas" and "vitaminas."
She reminds the children to cover their workbooks, hand-me-downs from previous years. "Your mothers will be receiving their checks next week and they will be going shopping," she says. "Ask them to save the bags for covering your books."
The children have written stories, in English, with a common plot: A woman builds a robot to do her work, and that robot builds a second one to do his work.
One boy imagined that the second robot was female, and that she built another male. "And then the first robot got jealous," he wrote. "And then the first robot said, 'You got a problem?' Then they started fighting. Then they blew up and the female robot stayed alone."
There is a Spanish lesson. One theory behind bilingual instruction is that children must know the language spoken at home before tackling English. But many Puerto Rican children, especially those born on the mainland, grow up learning fractured Spanish at home.
The children wave their hands wildly so Ms. Collazo will call on them. Doing math problems, those who finish early help others. Her best pupils, she says, will move into mainstream classes taught in English next year. More will move over in sixth grade, or seventh, or eighth.
"It depends a lot on the home," she said. Timing is also a factor. One girl just arrived from Puerto Rico and speaks no English.
The class moves on to language arts, in English. The subject is tall tales. They are learning about exaggeration.
 
<Transitions Difficult For the Immigrants
 The desegregation suit testimony, which was completed in February, sometimes reinforced stereotypes: All Puerto Ricans are poor. Few speak English. Children born here learn neither English nor Spanish. The difficult transition that all immigrants must make is not being made.
Puerto Ricans in Hartford are indeed poor. They first came from the island's rural poor, recruited by tobacco growers in the 1960's and 70's; 30 percent unemployment continues to drive north those who are least successful at home.
Some adults do not speak English; many are newly arrived. And studies suggest that Hispanic people across the country take an extra generation to make the transition to English, in part because the migration keeps Spanish alive in their neighborhoods.
So there is immediately a conflict of logic and identity when these citizens encounter the expectation that greets nearly all immigrants to the mainland: that to become Americans, they must give up their native language.
"The message is, 'You need to give this up to be part of my society,' " said William M. Ortiz, executive director of the San Juan Center, a social-service agency. "And I say, Why? I speak Spanish and English. I own my home. My children are doing well in school."
Puerto Ricans are also part of the first great wave of immigration that many Americans have experienced. In the 1980's it produced a backlash led by the movement to make English the country's official language.
Sitting in a German restaurant in West Hartford one day, Hernan Lafontaine, Hartford's former Superintendent of Schools, addressed a waitress in German. Turning to his lunch partner, he said, "If people hear me speak German, they will look at me and say, "Look at that cultured man.' "
Mr. Lafontaine, now a professor of education at Southern Connecticut State University, repeated himself in Spanish and added, with a shrug, "If I say the same thing in Spanish, they will say, 'Look at that Puerto Rican.' "
 
Schools' Goals Or Parents' Goals?
 The stated purpose of bilingual instruction is to move children from their native language into English. This transition is eased by instructing them in their native language while they learn English.
If all goes well, children who enter school speaking only Spanish will sit in English-only classes in four to seven years, in the same grade as if they had spoken English all their lives.
That is the theory, but the results are disputed.
Supporters of bilingual education see an opportunity to create magnet schools where English-speaking children learn Spanish and Spanish-speaking children learn English. Failing that, they want to preserve separate bilingual classrooms.
If bilingual classes are moved to suburban schools, they want to insure that they are fully integrated into the buildings, not isolated in basement rooms or distant wings and neglected by unsympathetic principals.
"All the research, and common sense, tells us that the principal is one of the keys to making the program work or not work in a school," said Peter Roos, a lawyer with Multicultural Education Training and Advocacy, a public-interest law firm in San Francisco.
"If you set up a program in the suburbs where you have a principal who has never dealt with these issues and might, quite frankly, be hostile to bilingual education, you can be in trouble."
By contrast, critics say there are good reasons to question bilingual education. Its real value to its supporters, they say, is that it teaches their children their native language. But that stands in the way of its educational goal, the acquisition of English.
"There's no scientific research that says it is more effective," said Prof. Christine Rossell of Boston University, who has testified on bilingual education in several desegregation cases. Studies, she said, show that at best, children taught in their native language do no worse than those taught in English. "The worst outcome," she said, "is that they do a lot worse."
Supporters say bilingual education's results are disappointing because few districts have committed the resources to do it right.
It is also unclear whether Puerto Rican parents want to take a chance on integration. In a survey conducted for the Sheff trial, 45 percent said they would move or resort to private schools if their children were reassigned by a desegregation plan.
The question arises, said Sandra DelValle, a lawyer with the Puerto Rican Defense and Educational Fund in New York, because desegregation cases have largely been defined by blacks.
Puerto Ricans, she said, "haven't been educated on what desegregation means."
"It's a matter of educating the Latino community generally on the fact that a good school may have to be traveled to," she said.
Within Hartford's Puerto Rican neighborhoods, many people say most parents want their own schools improved.

HEADLINE: Fed Neutral in February

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers decided in February to maintain an evenhanded monetary policy and remain equally prepared to raise or lower interest rates as necessary, according to minutes released today.
The Federal Open Market Committee voted 12 to 0 on Feb. 3 in favor of a directive that "did not include a presumption about the likely direction of any adjustment" to interest rates. 
 For most of 1992, policy makers leaned toward lower interest rates in an effort to propel the tenuous economic recovery. In December, the committee noted signs of more vigorous growth and shifted to a neutral stance on interest rates, maintaining it in February.
The Federal Reserve generally seeks to maintain economic growth without adding to inflation. It lowers interest rates to encourage borrowing and spur growth. It raises rates to dampen economic demand and price increases.
In the latest minutes, committee members were split on inflation prospects. Most said "inflation remained quite subdued," the minutes said. But, it added, "A few referred to the recent firming in some commodity prices and the consensus among private forecasters that inflation could drift higher over the next few years." One committee member, who was not named, recommended considering higher rates.

HEADLINE: I.B.M.'S NEW LEADER;
Negative Trends Dampen IBM Japan's Profit

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 26

 BODY:
In a sign that it can no longer escape the problems afflicting its parent company, IBM Japan said today that its net income tumbled 45 percent in 1992, its third consecutive decline. Pretax earnings, hurt by a special restructuring charge, plunged 90 percent.
The Japanese subsidiary, which accounts for about a sixth of the revenues of the International Business Machines Corporation, has long been one of the company's biggest money makers. Even now, it is not suffering the losses and sweeping employment cutbacks that I.B.M. is experiencing in the United States and Europe. 
 Still, the moves by customers to small computers and industry-standard software that have hurt I.B.M.'s mainframe business in the United States are starting to occur here as well. Those trends, plus the Japanese recession, have deflated the profits of all computer companies here.
 At a news conference today, Kakutaro Kitashiro, the president of IBM Japan, said the company's sales of computer hardware fell sharply last year. That was offset, however, by double-digit growth in software and services, which now account for nearly 50 percent of revenues.
IBM Japan recorded net income in 1992 of 31.21 billion yen, or about $267 million at an exchange rate of 117 yen to the dollar. That compares with 56.48 billion yen in 1991, or $483 million at the same exchange rate, and is 70 percent below the 1989 level.
The net income figures were bolstered by a change in the method of accounting for income tax. Pretax earnings, which have fallen every year since 1988, plunged 90 percent, to 10.56 billion yen, or about $90 million.
The pretax earnings were hurt by a special charge of 16.21 billion yen, or roughly $140 million, which covered a voluntary retirement program and other restructuring measures. Not counting the special charge, pretax profit, which is called ordinary income, was down 74 percent.
Revenue fell 1.4 percent, to 1.255 trillion yen, or about $10.7 billion, the second consecutive decline.
Sales of mainframe computers, the core of the company's business, fell by double digits, although sales of the largest machines were strong. Sales of minicomputers and personal computers also fell more than 10 percent. But sales of work stations doubled, when measured in yen, and rose 50 percent in terms of units, company officials said.
IBM Japan has been undergoing a restructuring that mirrors its parent's, but is less drastic. It has created some autonomous subsidiaries and is trying to reduce its work force by voluntary retirements.
It even has a new chief executive, although he is an insider, not an outsider like Louis V. Gerstner Jr., who was named I.B.M.'s chief executive today. Mr. Kitashiro, who was named president last year with a mandate to shake things up, also gained the title of chief executive today.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls in Light Day; Russia Termed a Big Worry

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell broadly in light trading yesterday, heavily influenced by technical and speculative pressures, traders said.
Traders were hesistant about making major moves despite a sharp rise in the yield on the Treasury's long bond to 6.94 percent. 
 Ordinarily, the dollar might rise on such news, since higher interest rates make dollar-denominated investments more attractive. But with the political situation in Russia still uncertain, dollar bulls remained recalcitrant about changing their positions ahead of the weekend.
 
'Something May Erupt'
 "The main thing in the market's mind is something may erupt in Russia, though nothing now seems to be," said Lisa Pazer, a currency analyst at MMS International.
Gold slipped in New York after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery closed at $332.40 a troy ounce, off 30 cents. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $332.25 an ounce, up 25 cents from late Thursday.
The dollar fell about 1 pfennig against the German mark in European trading amid rumors of a Far East central bank selling a large amount of dollars for marks. In addition, a report of sustained high inflation in Germany dimmed hopes for a significant cut in German interest rates.
In late trading in Europe, the dollar was quoted at 1.6305 German marks, down from 1.6425. Later, in New York, the dollar closed at 1.6335 marks, down from 1.6420.
The Japanese yen, meanwhile, gained for a second day against the dollar, bouncing back from its plunge on Wednesday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 116.76 yen, down 0.39 yen from Thursday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 116.35 yen and, in New York, the dollar closed at 116.50 yen, down from 117.30 late Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.4905, from $1.4735 late Thursday. A pound traded at $1.4875 in late New York activity, more than $1.4750 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.5130 Swiss francs, down from 1.5205; 1,597.00 Italian lire, down from 1,601.00, and 1.2444 Canadian dollars, up from 1.24415.

HEADLINE: First, Bring Troops Home From Europe

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Unfortunately, "A Guide for Pentagon Budget Cuts" (editorial, March 9), a seemingly comprehensive list of suggestions following a Congressional Budget Office report, does not cover a most glaring expense in the defense budget. That is the astronomical cost of stationing 110,000 American service people and their dependents in Europe.
Although the numbers have been considerably reduced and we no longer pump as many billions of dollars a year into the German economy, we still donate huge amounts to Germany, which still has, despite all the difficulties attendant on absorbing the former East Germany, one of the leading economies in the world. 
 How can anyone talk about closing bases in the United States, cutting the deficit or reducing the military in any but the usual slipshod, criminally bureaucratic manner, or most ridiculous of all, of raising taxes, when billions of United States dollars continue to flow into Germany?
How can you condone the closing of bases in the United States when the American taxpayer is helping support a European economy by maintaining American troops there?
I must have been mistaken when I thought the reason the United States had troops stationed in Europe was to offset the threat of invasion by the Soviet Union. But if I, like many millions of Americans, believe that this was true, then what is the reason for the continued stationing of United States troops there?
I thought I read that the Soviet Union had collapsed. If so, then it must follow that the threat that caused the stationing of United States troops in Europe for some 50 years must have collapsed also. Why are they still there? And scheduled to be there through 1995?
Before any of our bases in the United States are closed, before any downsizing of the Armed Forces takes place, I believe that these troops should be brought back home -- now.
 
FRANK M. GALLO
Cornwall-on-Hudson, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
The Pride and the Pain Of a Man Burned by Racism

BYLINE: By D. J. R. BRUCKNER

 BODY:
Matt Robinson's project in his new play, "The Confessions of Stepin Fetchit," is to recover history and provoke reflection. Judging from the audience reaction during a discussion period after each performance, he succeeds; some people appear really exasperated.
Mr. Robinson, a veteran writer and producer of "Sesame Street" and "The Cosby Show," is shrewd and economical in his one-act presentation of Lincoln Perry, the creator of the shiftless black comic character of 1930's films who was at first enormously popular and later, under assault from civil rights advocates, reviled. Mr. Robinson knew Perry in the last 20 years of his life, and he lets Perry tell his own story, bringing out amid a lot of laughter the intelligence, pride and sense of injury that gave the best Stepin Fetchit movie scenes their bite. 
 Portraying a gifted performer is a tough assignment for an actor. Here Roscoe Orman -- familiar to everyone who's been a child in the last two decades as Gordon in "Sesame Street" -- brings it off in style. Starting out with a hilarious typical Stepin Fetchit scene and going on to recall Perry's career, and his fate as a rejected symbol of shame, Mr. Orman presents a man who grows larger and more troubling by the minute.
He is all the more convincing because his Perry is so obviously smart, and cunning in the ways of Hollywood, but also a wounded man who is sometimes arrogant, annoyingly superior to other blacks as well as to whites and alienated, in the end, from almost everyone. In gesture even more than in words he conveys an enormous amount of information about the life and the soul of Lincoln Perry in 75 minutes.
And for anyone who has seen enough of the Stepin Fetchit films to be captivated or mystified by what critics in the 1930's called the impression of chained lightning in his feet, Mr. Orman will conjure up warm smiles as he demonstrates the corn lickin' Lulu and knock-kneed Sally dance steps Perry learned from his father, and gives instructions on how to do Stepin Fetchit's shuffles: "Side, back and forward." Finally, having taunted the audience with, "You can't kill Stepin Fetchit; you might shoot part of yourself," he does a nifty line of steps into the wings, a shadowy silhouette on a dark stage in front of a glowing reproduction of the Hollywood sign in the hills above the film capital.
 
The Confessions of Stepin Fetchit
By Matt Robinson; directed by Bill Lathan; scenery by Kert Lundell; costumes by Judy Dearing; lighting by Shirley Prendergast; sound by Robert LaPierre; movement consultant, Hank Smith; production stage manager, Jacqui Casto. Presented by the American Place Theater, Wynn Handman, director; Dara Hershman, general manager. At 111 West 46th Street, Manhattan.

WITH: Roscoe Orman.

HEADLINE: A Business That Repairs Equipment Damaged in Disasters

BYLINE: By TOM TOOLEN

DATELINE: Totowa

 BODY:
In a society that often discards items too quickly, the Relectronic Service Corporation of Totowa is something of a rarity. It repairs, cleans and restores, electronic and other equipment that was scheduled for the scrap heap after being damaged in fires, floods or other disasters.
 Max Klepp, president of Relectronic since its founding 12 years ago, says the amount of resources being thrown away in today's technological world is a "disgrace." 
 "Often, all the equipment needs is a good cleaning," he said.
 Mr. Klepp, 56, said restoring instead of replacing equipment saves companies millions of dollars and returns them to normal much faster than if they had to wait for new equipment.
 Old habits die hard, he said. "The largest man-made structure in the world is a dump on Staten Island," he said.
 
A Changing Attitude
 With tough economic times, the throwaway attitude is changing, however. Restoring rather than replacing has gained favor with the insurance industry.
 "Rescuing equipment is a whole new ball game," said Dean Brown, general adjuster of Industrial Risk Insurance of St. Louis. "We can now rely on this new breed of disaster troubleshooter, such as Relectronic, to send in teams with the mission of restoring even the most high-tech equipment. This means dramatic savings in otherwise catastrophic insurance losses."
 Relectronic entered the American market 11 years ago. "First we need to make sure we do no harm," said Wilhelm Tondok, managing director of Relectronic, the service corporation's parent company, based in Munich, who was visiting the Totowa plant. "And if the cleanup cost is more than 50 percent of the replacement value, we say replace it."
 Mr. Klepp added: "We can make only one mistake, and that is to say we can clean it up when we can't. Therefore we prefer to err on the side of caution."
 
Sent to Disaster Areas
 Relectronic sends teams to disaster areas, and the work is often dangerous. "We had to use helicopters to get to a factory in Guatemala after the dam broke and the entire factory was under water," Mr. Klepp said. "And we were constantly working under terrifically adverse conditions in the flooding in the midwest, when 400 factories were under water."
 Relectronic is a division of Siemens, the German electronics giant. Its United States and Canada operation had sales totaling $9 million in the 1993 calendar year, up from $5 million in 1992.
 "Unfortunately for some people, the disaster business is growing." Mr. Klepp said.
 Mr. Klepp is a former vice president at Siemens. A native of Austria, he holds a master's degree in electrical engineering from the University of Vienna and an M.B.A. in business from Fairleigh Dickinson University. His wife, Helga, is the company's customer service manager.
 Relectronic has five offices in the United States and Canada, and there are offices in 14 other countries. The employees log thousands of miles a year flying to trouble spots around the globe. Everyone was called in to help the American branches during the Midwest Floods last summer.
 "We were working around the clock in two shifts, and everyone was putting in 20-hour days," Mr. Klepp said.
 The teams of workers were sent immediately to the Midwest to decontaminate and restore thousands of pieces of equipment and computer systems in factories, hospitals and telephone substations. Relectronic worked for more than 400 businesses that were hit by the flooding.
 "Our guys did not come back fat," Mr. Klepp said, pointing out that they were working in temperatures that soared to 120 degrees in some cases.
 In one factory, many of the highly sophisticated computer-controlled machines in the Midwest floods were caked in eight inches of mud. The machines had to be hoisted to higher ground so they could dry out. Mr. Klepp said; then they were decontaminated before they could be restored to their original state.
 Mr. Klepp said his company uses biodegradable water-based chemicals to clean the equipment. "Of course we have to comply with all environmental laws," he said.
 "Our motto," he added, "is to never make a situation worse."
 Relectronic has about 100 employees in Totowa at the North American headquarters, and at branch offices in California, Illinois, Georgia, Florida and Ontario, Canada.
 One of the most dramatic of the company's rescues was in Austria when a technician had to climb a mountain to restore an electronic Alphine weather station whose parts had become corroded by the atmospheric humidity. It helped that the technician was also a mountain climber, Mr. Klepp said.
 Gil Little Bear of Riverdale in the Bronx is in charge of quality control for the company and has flown hundreds of thousands of miles in his 12 years with Relectronic. He said one of his most dangerous trips was the two months he spent in Papus, New Guinea, in 1987, when a fire knocked out a telephone relay center that served many countries on the Pacific Rim, including parts of Australia, Fiji, Somoa and the Solomon Islands.
 "Many nations' communications were affected,and that put extra pressure on our team to get the system back working," Mr. Little Bear said. "It was a big job because we were operating in a very primitive jungle area."
 Mr. Little Bear was one of a team of five Americans, four Germans and several Australians. It took two months to decontaminated and restore the system.
 Getting companies back online and getting people back to their jobs gives Mr. Klepp a tremendous amount of satisfaction, he said. "We really feel we are doing a good deed," he said.

HEADLINE: A Yank in Yokohama

BYLINE: By Alida Becker; Alida Becker is an editor of The Book Review.

 BODY:

JAPAN THROUGH AMERICAN EYES
The Journal of Francis Hall,
Kanagawa and Yokohama, 1859-1866.
Edited by F. G. Notehelfer.
Illustrated. 652 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
Princeton University Press. $49.50. 
 "OF all the countries in which to win the reputation of a prophet, I would pronounce Japan the most difficult."
Francis Hall -- teacher, bookseller, entrepreneur, world traveler, journalist, philanthropist and amateur botanist -- was modest (and wise) enough not to claim to be a pundit. Which may be why this genial and relentlessly inquisitive man, who founded the leading American trading house in 19th-century Japan and enlightened his countrymen with on-the-spot reporting for Horace Greeley's New York Tribune, is now largely unknown.
It's easy to imagine, then, how surprised F. G. Notehelfer, a professor of history at the University of California, Los Angeles, must have been when he first leafed through Francis Hall's journal. In family hands until World War II, it had been acquired by a California book dealer and then by the Cleveland Public Library, which pursued the possibility of publication. Mr. Notehelfer, called in to advise, quickly determined that "a rather extraordinary discovery" had been made.
The Japan that Francis Hall encountered when he set off in 1859 with some missionary friends was, as Mr. Notehelfer reminds us in his graceful introduction, entering "one of the most turbulent and confusing decades" in its existence. In fact, "Japan Through American Eyes" is a portrait of a society on the brink of revolution, a feudal world reluctantly opening its doors -- but only a crack.
Hall arrived in Kanagawa, near Yokohama, just a year after a few highly restricted treaty ports were designated for foreign residence and trading. We know now that the teetering government of the shogun, the fractious provincial aristocracy and the long-enfeebled imperial court were already locked in a struggle that would result in the Meiji Restoration, a movement that set Japan on the road to modernization. But all Hall knew was what he could see and hear for himself: the news and rumors passed along by servants and acquaintances, the scenes that unfolded before him as he wandered through the countryside. Occasionally he was able to make a brief visit to other trading ports -- or, rarer still, to Edo, the capital city. More often, though, he recorded the daily life of the growing towns of Kanagawa and Yokohama.
Scholars may pore over Hall's journal for its revelations about a pivotal historical period, but for the rest of us the attraction lies in Hall himself. He was the sort of man who wryly noted, on starting out for a walk, the oddity of putting a revolver in one pocket and a copy of Tennyson in the other. He was equally comfortable telling rollicking tales of an expedition to a volcano, conducting a flirtation with a young woman in a graveyard and politely coping with the "indefatigable" attentions of a Government spy.
Despite his detailed notes on politics and economics, his eager cataloguing of the intricacies of Japan's social and cultural life, Hall had a decidedly whimsical streak. During one afternoon jaunt, he introduced an elderly Japanese invalid to the pleasures of a "brandy sting" ("When she had finished it she politely asked for 'just a little more' "), and he was an admirer not only of the excellent Japanese oysters but of the amenities of Buddhist temples, whose quarters he used as lodgings and whose wells he borrowed, on at least one occasion, to cool his champagne.
Better still, the discerning eye he turned on the Japanese ("They had kindness," he observed of the social status accorded to Japanese women, "but not respect") could just as easily be diverted toward his fellow foreigners. He remarked, for example, that the reactions to news of an arson plot against the foreign settlement went "according to nationality. The Dutch are decidedly timorous and full of absurd rumors, the French suspicious but inclined to be defiant, the English disturbed and apprehensive and practicing a caution that smacks of fear . . . the American laughing at the alarm and incredulous of any real danger, showing not a little of his native recklessness."
Hall's early journal entries are the most vivid, packed with enthusiastic accounts of his discoveries. But Mr. Notehelfer has filled out the later years, when business demanded more of Hall's time, with absorbing passages from his newspaper reporting. Whether writing privately or publicly, Francis Hall was always alert to clues about the "hidden nation" whose people charmed, puzzled and sometimes alarmed him. The only times he seems unreliable are the days when the journal simply notes, "Nothing transpires of interest."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2194 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Modernism and Morality In the South Bronx

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
Come 1998, a gleaming new police academy building will streak through the center of the South Bronx like a marathon runner dashing toward the ribbon. The academy's architects have designed a modern athletic thoroughbred of a building. With a sleek, translucent facade of steel and glass, curving as it rounds the bend at East 153d Street just off the Grand Concourse, the design looks every inch a champion, and indeed it is one. Last December, the design won a competition for the most important new public building to go forward during the Dinkins administration.
A lot is riding on this project. With a budget of $230 million, the Police Academy is an important civic symbol, a sign that even in hard times, New York can build major public works. Now housed in crowded quarters on East 20th Street in Manhattan, the academy will be relocated to the South Bronx in an effort to erase the borough's image as a metaphor for urban decline. Not least, at a time when law and order promises to become a major issue in the approaching mayoral campaign, this project offers a conspicuous show of support for the city's law enforcement officers. It also offers an opportunity of overpowering importance: a chance to rethink the critical place of law enforcement in American cities today. This is what lifts the project out of the realm of local news and into a national spotlight. 
 For some, the building represents a change in course for architecture. Earlier last year, the city's competition to design the Whitehall Ferry Terminal was won by a post-modern entry by Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates with Frederic Schwartz. By contrast, the Police Academy competition (in which Venturi, Scott Brown was also an entrant) was won by an aggressively modernist design by Ellerbe Becket and Michael Fieldman & Partners. Some interpret this contrast as a sign of a modernist revival.
More likely, the contrast signifies a crisis of faith in the supremacy of architectural esthetics. Underlying the crisis is the belief that architecture ought to do more than it has done in recent years to ameliorate social conditions. But how? How far can buildings make up for society's shortcomings? The Police Academy is a case study in the dysfunctional relationship between esthetic means and social ends. It illustrates the fallacy in thinking that modernist images can revive modernism's utopian mission.
Government officials and architects are not the only ones now reckoning with the place of law enforcement in the cities. As a result of the Rodney King beating and its politically charged aftermath, Americans have never been more aware of the tensions between the public and the police. The King trials will not resolve those tensions, because the beating did not create them. They will persist so long as society expects the police to compensate for its own failure to reframe the social contract. If police behavior is sometimes warped, the public's expectations of law enforcement are also warped. Police are supposed to maintain civil order within a society that has retreated from the moral order once embedded in the public realm.
As those who have followed the trials have witnessed, law enforcement is more than a profession. It is a culture. And a police academy is where that culture is transmitted. Here cadets are trained not just in firearms, arrest procedures and other technical skills but also in the codes of a fellowship: its bonds of solidarity, ideals of heroism and sacrifice, the unstable mix of service and distrust that binds the police to the public, or fails to.
The city's decision to organize a design competition -- in effect, to honor architecture along with the men and women in blue -- gave due recognition to the importance of this project. And the Ellerbe Becket/Fieldman scheme was visually the strongest of the seven finalists. In model form, it is a beautiful piece of architectural sculpture, at once muscular and lyrical, formally assertive but not visually overbearing, its airy translucence a deliberate attempt to avoid a fortresslike impression. With its taut, horizontally stretched skin of steel and glass, the design recalls the work of Erich Mendelsohn, the pioneer modernist who imbued static forms with the quality of dynamic motion.
In this, as in much of his recent work, Peter Pran, Ellerbe Becket's principal designer, is also heavily indebted to Zaha Hadid and to the Russian modernists who have long inspired her. It is delicious to contemplate that in five years' time the capital city of capitalism will be policed by officers trained inside a building that harks back to the Soviet avant-garde.
The shape of the building, and the configuration of the outdoor campus it partly frames, make the best of an awkward site, an irregularly shaped eight-and-a-half-acre parcel that is bordered on the south by an elevated roadway and on the east by commuter rail tracks. Two buildings are enfolded within the academy's broad horizontal sweep. Administration offices are housed in the curved, eight-story tower at the western end, while classrooms are in the wing that stretches 400 feet to the northeast. A library, an auditorium and other public spaces are set at the juncture of the two wings.
The design's elegance derives partly from its tiny footprint. By stacking the functions vertically, the architects were able to shape a block that is linear, not blocklike. At its western edge, the facade rises to a sharp, glittering peak and pulls partly away from the building envelope, as if it were doing stretching exercises before a morning run.
Outdoor athletic areas, in fact, take up the greater share of the campus. Set within the building's curving frame are a running track, basketball courts and two muster decks, platforms where cadets assemble each morning. One of the decks, protected by a sweeping metal canopy, is designed for use in foul weather. On sunny days, the southeastern orientation will take advantage of the maximum solar exposure.
Although the Police Academy will not open its doors for another five years, it has already begun to play an educational role. The design has become a focus for discussions on the contributions the academy could make to the South Bronx. A group of pro-bono architects and planners called Bronx Center has provided the catalyst for these discussions. Initiated by Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx, and chaired by Richard A. Kahan, a former president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, the group has come up with some excellent ideas. They include creating new housing, so recruits can live in the neighborhood while they study there, and hiring local construction firms to benefit the community economically as well as architecturally.
Their most exciting proposal is to create a high school that would focus on criminal justice studies, a kind of High School of the Performing Arts for the Commishes of tomorrow. Mr. Kahan envisions a place where recruits would serve as student mentors, helping to bridge the frightening gap between police and public. Naturally, it would have made more sense to hold these discussions before the design competition. Fortunately, the Police Department and the Board of Education have been receptive to the Bronx Center proposals, even though they would reorganize the Police Academy's public spaces and, quite likely, change the building's design.
There's something else at stake in this building, at least for Mr. Pran: nothing less than the very soul of his profession. In a preface to a recent monograph of his work, he depicts contemporary architecture as a Manichaean struggle between the forces of light and darkness. "The main opposition today," he writes, "is between the new authentic modern architecture and the regressive post-modern (unhistoric) historicism." Evidently seeing himself as architecture's answer to 911, Mr. Pran supplies a list of other architects who he thinks fall into line on the correct side of the struggle. It reads like a roll call on his personal muster deck, a line-'em-up inspection of the good guys willing to fight the undesirable post-modern elements that have ruined the old modern neighborhood.
Mr. Pran's buildings may well be progressive, but his thinking is out of date. The post-modern bandwagon passed by some time ago. The movement's most ardent promoters, such as Charles Jencks and Philip Johnson, were among the first to leap off it. And few architects today are eager to crank up another bandwagon. For them, and for much of the public also, phrases like "the new modernism" have the same hollow, promotional ring that turned post-modernism into such a nightmare.
Still, Mr. Pran's anxieties about the state of architecture are widely shared. Many architects today would like to regain the moral authority of the modern movement. They yearn for the solidarity of purpose that once united architects in the cause of building a better world. But what are the means by which those goals can be achieved today?
For Mr. Pran, the means is architectural form. He thinks that "the tremendous heritage of early modern architecture" can be revived by evoking its formal vocabulary. But the Police Academy tells a different story. What edges this project into the utopian dimension of early modernism is the potential of the building program to reduce the tensions between the public and police. While the architects partly developed this potential, the Bronx Center has pushed the hardest to make it happen. And any number of formal vocabularies could be used to accommodate their goals.
Mr. Pran writes that "architecture is about giving people the opportunity to live better lives." That is a fine piece of rhetoric, and so is the Police Academy design. But the moral value of this building depends on how far it can be pushed out of the realm of high-flown rhetoric and into the turbulent South Bronx. This marathon champion of a building could easily be an alien presence, streaking through the neighborhood without looking around.
It is understandable that architects now have such an inflated idea of the moral power of forms. Forms are virtually all they have to work with. In a way, architects are in a position precisely analogous to that of the police. They are expected to provide order and cohesion in an environment that has become fragmented. They are asked to create symbols of a public realm that scarcely exists unless volunteers are willing to provide it.
It is tempting, in fact, to interpret the Police Academy's thin, warped facade as an emblem of this condition. The warp mirrors our warped expectations. The facade is handsome. But it can no more restore modernism's moral order than a fluted column can restore a world of classical harmony.
IF THIS IS A TIME OF CHANGE FOR architecture, it need not be the time for architects to lock-step into another dreary stylistic movement, or to promote themselves by trashing the work of the preceding era. Thus it is regrettable that Mr. Pran singles out for attack the "anti-modern" work of Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown. Mr. Venturi and Ms. Scott Brown did indeed open up paths that some of their followers took in retrogressive directions. But there is nothing anti-modern about their work. In fact, it is hyper-modern. It recognizes that the glass tower and the golden arches are both products of modernity. Painfully aware of the wholesale discrediting of the past that occurred in the heyday of the modern movement, Mr. Venturi and Ms. Scott Brown have no desire to repeat it by throwing out the glass tower.
Nothing could be more "unhistoric" than to fantasize that post-modernism did not happen, or to deny that its best examples shared the creative ideals that Mr. Pran rightly advocates. It is also blatantly unhistorical to equate modernism solely with the pioneering work of Walter Gropius, Le Corbusier and Mies van der Rohe. If architects want to ground their work more fully in modern history, they must remember what came after the pioneers: the exhausted state of modernism in the 1960's, when Mr. Venturi and Ms. Scott Brown developed their ideas.
By then, modern invention had been reduced to dogma and modern morality to a club for keeping people in line. Modern architects had become creatures of corporate culture but fancied themselves artistic iconoclasts. Does anyone really want to live through that again?
Though different in style, the Police Academy raises precisely the same dilemma that surfaced with the ferry terminal project for Staten Island last year. Admiration for the design must be tempered by the fear that "world class" architecture has become an acceptable way to camouflage poverty-class planning. With the ferry terminal, the city's welcome support for architecture had to be measured against a transportation system that is coming apart at the seams.
With the Police Academy, the dilemma is even more acute. The design's strengths must be weighed against the ravaged condition of schools, housing and entire inner-city neighborhoods where law and order has become a desperate substitute for public life.

HEADLINE: HOW JACK KEMP LOST THE WAR ON POVERTY

 BODY:
Jason DeParle's article on Jack Kemp's ill-fated war on poverty twice describes the former Budget Director Dick Darman as mocking the idea of "empowerment" as a left-wing idea from the 60's ("How Jack Kemp Lost the War on Poverty," Feb. 28). This reflects the state of Darman's regrettable ignorance. The word "empowerment" first appeared in a brilliant 1967 book entitled "Black Power and Urban Unrest," by a distinguished scholar and churchman, Dr. Nathan Wright Jr. Dr. Wright, who had recently been chairman of the National Conference on Black Power, eloquently introduced the idea of empowerment to the Senate Subcommittee on Housing and Urban Affairs on July 27, 1967.
Far from being a 1960's leftist, Dr. Wright was a lifelong registered Republican. His testimony was in support of a bill sponsored by all the Republican senators to help lower-income people become homeowners. He was featured in a cover story in this magazine in 1968 as a black Republican likely to be influential during the Nixon years. (Alas, his wise voice was largely ignored.) 
 Empowerment is a profoundly Republican idea, and Jack Kemp and Jim Pinkerton built on a solid Republican foundation in advocating it. The Republican party is now out of power, in no small measure because of the myopic arrogance of Darman, whose attachment to the party came only from his ambition, not from commitment to any principle.
 
JOHN MCLAUGHRY
Kirby, Vt.

HEADLINE: Refinancings Balloon as the Rates Slide

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
A WAVE of refinancings and new mortgage applications have swamped lenders in recent weeks as interest rates have slid to record lows.
"It's pandemonium," said Ellen Feldschreiber, a partner with the Manhattan Mortgage Company. "We have people who are refinancing who refinanced last year, and even six months ago." 
 The national average interest rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages fell slightly, to 7.55 percent for the week ended March 26, according to preliminary figures from HSH Associates in Butler, N.J., which surveys 2,000 lenders nationwide each week.
The average interest rate had been 7.65 percent at the end of the previous week, but it stood at 7.52 percent for the week ending March 12 and 7.51 percent, the lowest rate since May 1973, for the week ended March 5.
The up-twice, down-once pattern follows 17 consecutive weeks of falling average rates for 30-year fixed mortgages, going back to the week ended Nov. 13, 1992, when the average rate was 8.54 percent.
"The biggest part of the interest rate rally may be gone," said Keith T. Gumbinger, an analyst with HSH Associates. "The probability of rates decreasing is less that it is for interest rates increasing."
Declines in interest rates can save borrowers significant sums. At 7.51 percent, the monthly principal and interest payment is $699.89 on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage of $100,000. For a similar loan at 8.54 percent the payment is $771.75 a month.
Mr. Gumbinger attributed the vacillation of mortgage rates in March to the rising demand for new mortgages and refinancings. According to the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington, refinancing activity reached a record level for the week ended March 12, the most recent week for which data were available. Overall, loan application volume -- for refinancing and new mortgages -- was 11 percent higher than the previous week and 113 percent higher than for the same week in 1992.
More importantly, though, Mr. Gumbinger cited fears of inflation. Consumer prices climbed a moderate 0.30 percentage point last month but "core" inflation rose a more troubling 0.50 percentage point for the second straight month. Many analysts considered the results, combined with a recent jump in producer prices, evidence of rising inflation.
Mr. Gumbinger said that the overall decline in mortgage rates since November had been fueled by a decline in yields in the bond market. Interest rates on 30-year Treasury bonds, which are commonly known as long bonds, fell to 6.72 percent on March 8, the lowest point recorded since the Treasury began selling them in 1977.
The falling yields are attributed to traders' and investors' belief that inflation will remain low; that Congress and the White House will reduce the deficit and that the tax increases the Clinton Administration has called for will slow economic growth and lessen the threat of rising inflation.
Should it appear that significent deficit reductions are not forthcoming, or if inflation heats up, then bond yields are likely to rise, followed by higher mortgage rates.
"The market is kind of politicized right now," Mr. Gumbinger said.
Mortgage interest rates actually began falling in the mid-80's, with zigs and zags along the way since then. They peaked in Oct. 1981 at 18.19 percent for fixed-rate loans and 17.54 percent for adjustable-rate mortgages.
As it was last summer, during the last decline in mortgage interest rates, much of the activity involves refinancing. According to the Mortgage Bankers Association, 62.1 percent of all applications for the week ended March 12 were for refinancings.
"Last year homeowners freed up about $16 million in lower debt service due to refinancings and adjustments made to their adjustable-rate mortgages," said Warren Lasko, executive vice president of the association. "We expect similar savings this year."
Refinancing can be a complicated and cumbersome project for many homeowners. In fact, many of the old rules that used to dictate when and how to refinance have changed. In the past, when homes were generally increasing in value, a "2-2-2" formula usually determined whether it made financial sense to refinance. The numbers meant that if borrowers had been in their home at least two years, intended to stay at least two more and refinanced at a rate at least two points lower than their current mortgage rate, refinancing was practical.
TODAY, though, guidelines are more flexible and depend on individual circumstances. Homeowners who qualify for refinancing should calculate how much they will pay in closing costs, fees and points -- a point is 1 percent of the amount borrowed. (Generally, closing costs for refinancing a share loan on a co-op will be less than for a mortgage on a condominium or home.)
Then they should figure how much their monthly mortgage payments will drop and how long it will take before their monthly savings cover the refinancing costs.
Many buyers and those now refinancing, particularly those nearing retirement, are also choosing 15-year mortgages instead of the more traditional 30-year loans. The impetus for a shorter mortgage is to reduce the amount of interest paid out over the life of the loan or, among older borrowers, to pay off the mortgage before retirement.
They are also choosing fixed-rate over adjustable-rate loans. Only about 11 percent of the new mortgage and refinancing activity today consists of adjustable-rate loans.
Borrowers, however, should take a close look at adjustable-rate mortgages, which seem riskier, especially considering the rising interest rates of the 80's. They may be missing out on the savings they could achieve if interest rates stay low. Indeed, homeowners who took out adjustable-rate mortgages in the 80's have watched their monthly payments drop significantly in the last year. And should adjustable rates rise, even to levels higher than today's fixed rates, the savings in the earlier years of the adjustable loan may still keep borrowers ahead.
Adjustable-rate mortgages also tend to be the most beneficial to borrowers who plan to sell their homes in three to five years; homeowners stay in their homes an average of only seven years nowadays.
As for risk, annual and lifetime caps will protect today's adjustable-loan borrowers from sudden high increases.
Average national adjustable rates have fallen to an all-time low of 4.75 percent for the week ending March 26. On Nov. 13, 1992, when the downturn in interest rates began, the rate was 5.33 percent.
Qualifying for refinancing can be difficult, particularly if the home has declined in value, as many have in the last five years, or if the homeowner has encountered credit problems or a decline in household income.
Ms. Feldschreiber added, though, that that many of the new buyers and refinancings were at the high end, where qualifiying problems are less likely to be encountered. She also said that home appraisals, a necessary step in any refinancing, have been higher in the past few weeks.
"It's only been very recently that we have been noticing this,' she said.
