HEADLINE: TV Industry Scrambles for Studio Space

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
UNTIL January, you could get to Sesame Street by way of Ninth Avenue in Manhattan. Come July, however, Sesame Street will be found intersecting 34th Avenue in Astoria, Queens.
Having outgrown Unitel Video's Studio 55, at Ninth Avenue and 55th Street, the Children's Television Workshop, which produces "Sesame Street," started searching in 1991 for new space in Manhattan. They needed at least 12,000 square feet, said Marjorie Kalins, the group vice president of production, and clearance of 23 feet to the lights, since the sets must be high enough off the floor to allow the Muppet puppeteers to work standing up. 
 Such space "was absolutely not available," said David Micciulla, vice president and general manager of Unitel, which runs eight studios in Manhattan. "It's not even that it's booked. It doesn't exist."
After a fruitless year and a half, the producers concluded there was no choice but to take "Sesame Street" across the East River to Kaufman Astoria Studios. In 1994, however, "Sesame Street" plans to move again, to the Manhattan Industrial Center on the Chelsea waterfront, where new soundstages will have been built specially for the show.
"Sesame Street" was not alone in its search. Ms. Kalins said that she and a representative of Procter & Gamble were "tripping over one another" as they visited locations. Procter & Gamble produces three soap operas -- "As the World Turns," "Guiding Light" and "Another World" -- in studios on the East and West Sides, and in Brooklyn. For years, it has been trying to find an alternative in New York, while keeping an eye on Los Angeles.
For David Letterman, CBS examined 15 theaters on and off Broadway -- including the Ambassador, Belasco, Cort, Helen Hayes -- before settling on the Ed Sullivan Theater at Broadway and 53d Street, a neo-Gothic landmark that needs millions of dollars of renovation work.
The "Sesame Street," Procter & Gamble and CBS odysseys underscore what many believe to be a critical problem for the television industry in New York City: the lack of large, technically advanced studios, particularly in Manhattan, where performers are more likely to live or stay, audiences to congregate and suppliers to be located.
"I think we need additional state-of-the-art television facilities," said Richard Brick, director of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting. "I'm of what we call the 'Field of Dreams' philosophy, to quote a recent movie. If you build them, they will come."
Patrick Pleven, the assistant director for broadcasting, said, "Just as we have convention centers, maybe the city should think about having broadcast centers."
ECONOMICALLY, the stakes are high. For example, the Procter & Gamble shows together employ at least 450 people on any given day and about 700 in a week, full- and part-time. The shows generate more than $100 million a year in salaries, rentals, materials and transportation.
"I want work," Mr. Brick said. "I want jobs. I want the economic benefits of more production. If that means creating Manhattan facilities, I'm very much for it."
A key problem is that studios function best horizontally, with broad expanses of space at street level and support services such as the scenery shop as close as possible. But given the cost of land in Manhattan, the premium is on vertical construction. Studios can be reached only through loading docks and freight elevators. And the scenery shops may be far away, where the rent is cheaper.
"The physical asset of a studio doesn't produce enough money to warrant its being in Manhattan," said George S. Kaufman, the developer of Kaufman Astoria Studios.
Mr. Kaufman and his associates believe that producers need look no farther than Queens and they resent the "Manhattan or bust" mentality with which they compete.
"It's not facilities that New York needs -- it needs business," said Hal G. Rosenbluth, senior executive vice president and chief operating officer at Kaufman Astoria. "Facilities are not going to generate business. They make up too small a percentage of the budget. Their impact is so small."
And to the argument that Kaufman Astoria has film stages, not proper television studios, Mr. Rosenbluth pointed out that "The Cosby Show," "Here and Now" and "The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd" were produced there. And the Lifetime Television cable network has two studios in the complex.
One of the biggest questions in the industry is what Procter & Gamble will do. Ann Jenemann Smith, a spokeswoman at the company's Cincinnati headquarters, said it would keep producing in New York as long as it could stay competitive and control costs.
That may be difficult. "Production requirements have grown increasingly more demanding and sophisticated," she said. "The studios in New York City continue to be very limited in space and operating configurations. Comparing them to the state-of-the-art facilities in Los Angeles, New York studios are smaller, less flexible and they're more expensive to manage."
Eight years ago, Mayor Edward I. Koch announced that Procter & Gamble and Arol Buntzman, a developer, would rebuild the abandoned Washburn Wire Company plant on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, from 116th to 119th Streets, as the new home for the three soap operas. Within a year, however, plagued by delays and cost overruns, the East Harlem project collapsed.
NOTHING else has materialized since then. "The issue becomes one of money," said Philip Dixson, who represents Procter & Gamble in New York as the vice president and managing director of daytime program services at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.
"We exist in 13-week and 26-week cycles," Mr. Dixson said. "You can't take that to the bank and get financing. Nobody in today's market can afford to build these things on spec, in the hope that one of these shows will make a commitment."
He rephrased the "Field of Dreams" tagline: "If you build it, I might come."
Ms. Kalins noted that the economics of studio development were such that "it can't be driven unless you have a dedicated client for that space that can provide some guarantee of the percentage of the amortization."
"Sesame Street" came close to being the anchor tenant of the proposed Silver Screen Studios, which are to be created in the five-block-long headhouse of the Chelsea Piers on the Hudson River, between 17th and 22d Streets. The piers themselves would be used as a sports center, including two ice-skating rinks, an indoor track and gymnastics area and an outdoor golf driving range.
The project would be undertaken by Chelsea Piers Management, owned by Roland W. Betts, Tom A. Bernstein and David A. Tewksbury, which would lease the state-owned piers for 10 years.
When Mr. Betts's team was selected last June by the Transportation Department, he said construction might begin in January 1993. But the project has been delayed.
In November, the Hudson River Park Conservancy, a subsidiary of the state Urban Development Corporation, "saw the need to insure that an environmental assessment be done prior to such a major undertaking on West Side waterfront," said its president, Tom Fox. The decision followed by two months a lawsuit against the larger Hudson River Park project by four civic groups on environmental grounds.
"We were all set until the state required an environmental impact statement before they executed the lease," Mr. Betts said. The delay derailed the "Sesame Street" deal, as the show has to begin taping in August 1993.
"Film and television producers want to be here," Mr. Betts said. "Their question to us is, 'When is the E.I.S. going to be finished?' " He said that he still believed the $50 million project could begin this summer.
Another proposal in circulation calls for rehabilitating the New York Coliseum as an international broadcast center, under a 10-year lease, until the site is redeveloped by Boston Properties. The partners in this enterprise are Dick Maitland and Steve Israel.
On March 14, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the Coliseum through the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, requested "expressions of interest" from operators who would lease the Coliseum. It cautioned in that document that the property was under contract for sale and that it would seek a lease term "consistent with the future development of the site."
Procter & Gamble had "some serious interest" in the Coliseum proposal, Mr. Dixson said. But he said the site had "a lot of encumbrances, politically and legally, and I'm not sure those can be dealt with in a way that would allow a producer like myself to go in there and operate economically."
Next year, "Sesame Street" plans to occupy the 10th floor of the Manhattan Industrial Center, on 10th Avenue, between 15th and 16th Streets. That space would be leased and rebuilt by M.T.I., an independent studio operator, and sublet to Children's Television Workshop. The workshop's other show, "Ghostwriter," would remain at M.T.I. Television City, Park Avenue and 106th Street.
Earlier this month, Mayor David N. Dinkins and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced $49.7 million in benefits to help CBS rebuild its Broadcast Center at 524 West 57th Street and also to renovate the Ed Sullivan Theater for Mr. Letterman.
The Broadcast Center is a four-building complex between 10th and 11th Avenues, where some 3,200 people work, in and around seven studios. On a recent morning, crews in Studio 41, used by "As the World Turns," were setting up Lucinda's office, a solarium, the McKechnie living room and a grand jury anteroom. In a corridor outside, dozens of people were lined up to get into Studio 45, where the Joan Rivers show was about to begin. Next door, in Studio 44, Harry Smith and Paula Zahn were finishing the "CBS This Morning" broadcast.
AT the heart of this operation is the "routing switcher," an installation that links all the technical equipment -- cameras, control consoles, satellites, transmitters, videotape machines. The existing "switcher" dates to the 1960's. As it grew less reliable, CBS had to decide how and where to replace it. "Unlike a soap-opera studio or a newsroom, those computers can be anyplace," said Edward Grebow, senior vice president for operations and administration.
"We traveled to Westchester, New Jersey and farther afield," he said. "We never wanted to leave New York but we'd be doing our stockholders a disservice if we didn't consider other options." These included the Queens West project in Hunters Point.
CBS was persuaded to stay in place through $31 million in sales-tax waivers on purchases of machinery and equipment, $12.2 million in electric power and $6.5 million in real-estate tax credits. Title to the Broadcast Center will formally be transferred to the city's Industrial Development Agency, which will permit certain tax savings. A similar arrangement was used six years ago when NBC modernized its studios at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.
Capital Cities/ABC has taken a different tack. It plans two new studios, Nos. 25 and 26, on the northwest corner of West End Avenue and 64th Street, adjoining Studios 23 and 24.
STUDIO 26 would have 15,000 square feet, with room for an audience, and might be used for a game show, talk show or situation comedy. "All My Children" would move to Studio 25 from Studio 23, which would be taken by "One Life to Live." That would open Studio 17, at 56 West 66th Street, for news or entertainment use, freeing space elsewhere for the creation of other new shows.
ABC has calculated that 300 new jobs would be created and 170 existing jobs would be retained. Also, because all the scenery for the soap operas and the new entertainment show would be built and stored on site, 122 truck trips a day would be eliminated.
To help offset the estimated $100 million cost, ABC would sell part of its site to a developer who would build an apartment complex in an L-shape around Studio 25.
"We do have to justify this project in-house," said Bruce E. Phillips, vice president for design and development at Capital Cities/ ABC. "Our building costs are higher here than in Los Angeles. We have to come up with an edge, to make this facility competitive."
"This studio will get built," said Richard E. Hockman, vice president for real estate and construction. "What the city process will determine is whether it gets built in New York or Los Angeles."
Originally, the network proposed three towers with 937 units. Objecting to the high density, among other things, Community Board 7 opposed the plan by a vote of 28 to 5. Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan also recommended disapproval.
ABC has since eliminated one of the three towers and reduced the number of units to about 500, all the while protesting that it is unfairly being made to pay the political price for local opposition to the nearby Manhattan West and Riverside South projects.
The matter is now before the City Planning Commission, which is to vote on Wednesday.
ABC seems to share the "Field of Dreams" philosophy. "We believe that if studio space is available, the need will materialize down the road," Mr. Phillips said.
This appears to be a particularly ripe moment for New York, given the proliferation of talk shows, which demand an unending supply of the interesting guests and lively audiences that the city can offer.
On one single block -- 57th Street, between 10th and 11th Avenues -- four talk shows are taped: Joan Rivers and Geraldo Rivera at the CBS Broadcast Center, Sally Jesse Raphael and Rush Limbaugh at Unitel Video.
THE old "Sesame Street" home, Studio 55, was snapped up by the Jane Whitney show, which has moved from Boston. That began a new round of musical chairs because two other talk shows had their eyes on Studio 55, said Bill Vassar of Unitel.
And Bill Cosby is to return in the 1994 fall season with a one-hour light comedy that will be produced in New York, along the lines of "Murder, She Wrote" or "Columbo," an NBC spokesman said.
Meanwhile, other opportunities slip away.
"We are frequently being asked by shows for space that we don't have room for," Mr. Grebow said. "If we had the room, we could do more, because there are a lot of shows shooting in very substandard spaces."
Stephen Burrow, executive director of the New York local of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, said New York had lost game shows as well as a situation comedy, "in part for lack of adequate studio space."
The Borough President's office has begun analyzing how many additional studios might be needed. "It's very much in the city's interest to entertain proposals for studio construction," Ms. Messinger said. "On the other hand, we have to be careful not to mindlessly allow a lot of different proponents of creating studio space to get into an expensive competition for a finite number of films and commercials and programs, because that's a very expensive glut to create."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

CHINESE SCHOLARS UNITE
Scholars from the People's Republic of China and from Taiwan will discuss their differences and their future in a day and evening conference at Yale on Saturday. The event is open to the public for a fee of $20 and free to students. 
 The morning session will cover Chinese culture, past and present; literature and media development in Taiwan and the mainland, and the future of Chinese ethical thought, science and technology and institutional reform.
From 1:45 to 5 P.M. the topics will include the future of trade between the mainland and Taiwan; investment possibilities and economic cooperation; political relations and democratization and legal conflicts and the implications for the United States.
Jonathan Spence, professor of history at Yale, will deliver a keynote address at 7:30 P.M., after which there will be a table discussion until 10 P.M.
Among the speakers scheduled throughout the day are Howard Lamar, Acting President of Yale; Chen Yih-young , president of the National Open University of Taiwan; Tu Wei-ming, professor of Chinese culture at Harvard; Duan Ruichun, visiting professor from Beijing University; Chang Xiuze, professor of economics at Nankai University in Tianjin; Hsu Tzong-li, professor of law at the National Taiwan University in Taipei, and other faculty members specializing in Asian studies from American, Taiwanese and Chinese mainland universities.
Some presentations will be in English, others will be in Chinese. Lunch and dinner are available in nearby restaurants, or on campus with special tickets. Registration will be at 8:30 A.M. in Sheffield-Sterling-Strathcona Hall at Prospect and Grove Streets. For more information call 230-9685.
 
MAKING MATZOH
 Most people are familiar with the Old Testament story about how the Jews, escaping from Egypt, baked a kind of bread called matzoh by setting unleavened dough out on rocks in the broiling sun until it was cooked.
At Passover, the Jewish holiday commemorating the Exodus each spring, food markets carry a variety of packaged matzoh, and now, thanks to Beth Israel Synagogue, 40 King Street in Norwalk, anyone can learn how to bake it at home.
Today at 9:30 and again at 10:30 A.M. matzoh-baking workshops will be held in which participants will make the dough, roll it out, bake it and take it home. The event will end with a film on the production of matzoh. All ages, from children to the elderly, are welcome. Admission is $3 to cover the cost of materials. Call 866-0534 for more information.
 
GRANDPARENT STORIES
 Grandparents will be invited to make half-hour videotaped readings of stories or chapters of books to send to their grandchildren in a program that starts Thursday at the Farmington Library. "So many families live far from the grandparents; we found this fills a need," said Lucille O'Connor, who directs the program.
While some grandparents do make such tapings at home, "We find that older people are not fond of fiddling with electronic equipment," Ms. O'Connell said. Besides, the library has a large selection of new books covering the grandparent-grandchild relationship.
The tapes will be played back for the reader and an occasional re-taping may be made if the first one is not satisfactory. Grandparents should bring a blank tape or they may purchase one at the library.
Appointments must be made by calling 673-6791.
 
SCHWEITZER LECTURER
 Jane Goodall, the naturalist who gained worldwide recognition for her work with primates in Tanzania, will deliver the first International Albert Schweitzer Lecture at Yale on Friday at 4 P.M. in Battell Chapel. Her subject will be "Chimpanzees: Living Bridge Between Man and Beast" and admission is free.
The lecture series was established by the International Schweitzer Institute for the Humanities and the Whitney Humanities Center at Yale. Three lectures will be presented each year featuring international figures speaking on topics of concern to Dr. Schweitzer during his lifetime: social justice, medicine and health, human and animal rights, the environment, nuclear disarmament and world peace.
Ms. Goodall will speak a second time on Saturday at 4 P.M. in Hamden, where the Schweitzer Institute's new center is to open at 515 Sherman Avenue on the campus of Quinnipiac College. Her talk, titled "Some Lessons From Our Nearest Relatives," will be presented in Alumni Hall and admission is free.
 
PILOBOLUS WORKSHOPS
 The Pilobolus Dance Theater will hold two two-day workshops at the Mattatuck Museum in Waterbury. Classes from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday will be held, one for those who have had little or no experience in dance movement, and another one for those who are somewhat experienced.
Teaching will focus on improvisational movement for the inexperienced, and on choreography and performance for the more advanced students. Each workshop is limited to 30 people; the instructors will be the artistic directors of Pilobolus.
Drawing from their own interests and experiences, participants will collaborate on creating new dances that they will perform informally on Sunday at 4 P.M. for a public audience.
To register for a fee of $40 for either of the two-day workshops, or to obtain more information, call 868-0538. There will be no charge for those attending the 4 P.M. performance.
Pilobolus will perform next Sunday at 8 P.M. at Central Naugatuck Valley Higher Education Center. Tickets are $15, or $10 for students and the elderly. Call 575-8039 for reservations.
 
SOUNDS CUCKOO
 "Imitazione del Cuccu" for violin and continuo by Walther, "The Cuckoo and the Nightingale" by Handel and "Le Rappel des Oiseaux" by Couperin hint at the genre of music to be performed on Saturday at 8 P.M. in the First Congregational Church of Darien.
It consists of concerti and other works that imitate the sounds of cats, dogs, cuckoos, nightingales, hens and goldfinches, among other wild and domesticated creatures.
Musicians of the Old Post Road, who created the program, perform on authentic period instruments. They include Michael Bahmann, harpsichordist; Suzanne Stumpf, flutist; Dana Maiben and Julie McKenzie, violinists; Anne Black, violist, and Daniel Ryan, cellist.
The church is at 14 Brookside Road and admission will be $10, or $5 for students and the elderly.
 
MALL FOR MALL
 England's restored 18th- and 19th-century shops and shopping arcades are the subject of a talk to be given today at 2 P.M. by Lorella Brocklesby, a professor of architecture and cultural historian from London who is currently an adjunct professor of humanities at New York University. The program will be at the Yale Center for British Art, 1080 Chapel Street in New Haven and admission is $5.
Burlington Arcade and its top-hatted beadles, Covent Garden, The Colonnades in Bath, and elegantly restored Georgian and Victorian arcades in Stanford and York are among the venues to be discussed and compared with the ubiquitous American mall.

HEADLINE: Hartford Whalers' Goal: To Become Connecticut's Team, or Else

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
SINCE moving to Hartford during the 1974-75 season, officials of the Hartford Whalers hockey club have made it a point to stress that the Whalers are the only major league sports team in Connecticut. And in recent years, as attendance has steadily declined, some club officials have said that although the Whalers carry a Hartford geographical designation, they are, in effect, "Connecticut's team" and worthy of fan support throughout the state.
In truth, hockey fans in most of the state have shown little or no allegiance to the Whalers. Fans in Fairfield and New Haven Counties, for example, tend to root for the New York Rangers, while most hockey fans in the eastern part of the state follow the Boston Bruins. 
 Indeed, even Rick Francis, the Whalers' vice president for marketing and sales, concedes that the vast majority of the team's fans are from within a 25-mile radius of Hartford, which includes the Springfield, Mass. area, and that most of them live in the Farmington Valley.
Now, with the team in dire financial straits and amid reports that the Whalers may move out of state, the Whaler hierarchy is trying to lure fans from throughout Connecticut. "We're a Connecticut team, and we'd like to get more people from Fairfield County and other parts of the state to our games," Richard Gordon, principal owner of the Whalers, said in a recent interview. "And since we are a regional team, we're considering changing our name to the Connecticut Whalers."
 
Breaking the New York Habit
 Mr. Gordon said that the team was faced with a situation where in Fairfield County, for example, a lot of people were more oriented toward New York. "We want to try to attract them and make them aware of the fact that you can drive to the Hartford Civic Center from most parts of Fairfield County quicker than you can drive to Madison Square Garden," he said. "And our prices are a lot cheaper."
The top price for a New York Rangers' game is $39, compared with $27 for a Whalers' game. Parking fees near Madison Square Garden are as high as $20, compared with $4 and $5 at the Hartford Civic Center.
Through 40 home games of this season, with 5 remaining, the Whalers have averaged 10,336 fans at the Civic Center, which seats 15,635 for hockey and has been the team's home since it opened in January 1975. That is the lowest average attendance for the team since it joined the National Hockey League in 1979 after five seasons in the old American Hockey Association, when they were known as the New England Whalers.
 
Millions in Losses
 By any name, the franchise, which has the smallest market of any American team in the N.H.L., is in trouble. Mr. Gordon said the club lost $4.5 million last season and would lose around $7 million this year. "The economy is killing us, what with all the closings and layoffs around Hartford," Mr. Gordon said. "And the team's performance hasn't helped."
Mr. Gordon, a real estate developer who has owned about 75 percent of the Whalers along with a corporate consortium since 1988, was alluding to the Whalers' record of 21 victories, 46 defeats and 5 ties, going into last night's game against Minnesota. That is the worst record in the N.H.L. apart from that of two expansion teams, the Ottawa Senators and the San Jose Sharks.
But the team's plight goes beyond its poor performance and low attendance. When some Whaler officials hinted that the club might have to leave Connecticut for greener financial pastures, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., himself a hockey fan, helped negotiate for the team a $4 million loan last October along with loan guarantees of up to $10 million. Under terms of the loan, the state retains the option for seven years to buy the team itself or arrange for a buyer from within Connecticut. The purchase price would be 90 percent of any offer the Whalers' ownership might get to move the team elsewhere.
 
New Lease a Key
 Seemingly, the key to keeping the Whalers in Hartford is a new lease with the city, which owns the Civic Center. Currently, the Whalers are playing at the Civic Center under a second extension of an old lease, which, in the words of Mr. Weicker, "stinks."
"I've put $23 million into a building that I don't own," Mr. Gordon said. "And unlike other N.H.L. teams, we don't receive any share of the concession or parking revenues. And we get only about half of the rinkboard advertising."
To make matters worse, Whaler games are rarely shown on television, so the club is deprived of television revenues, and its radio network has declined in the last few years from a high of a dozen stations to nine.
Despite all the problems, Mr. Gordon said he was committed to staying in Hartford. "I definitely want to stay, and my bet is that a satisfactory lease will be worked out so that we do stay," said Mr. Gordon, who attends most games, often with his friend, Ivan Lendl, the tennis player, a resident of Greenwich and member of the club's board of directors
 
Hartford Beleaguered by Blows
 This is hardly the best time for the Whalers to be asking for a better deal on their lease with the city. For one thing, the city-owned Civic Center most likely will wind up losing money during the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, for the first time since 1981. And for another, the city administration is confronted with serious budgetary problems. But faced with the prospect of losing the Whalers -- which would be the latest in a series of blows to Hartford's economy and image -- the city is expected to approve a lease that would be more beneficial to the team.
"Everything, including parking and concession revenues, is under review," said Rick Hornung, the executive assistant to Mayor Carrie Saxon Perry. "We have offered various combinations to Richard Gordon, but they have not been acceptable. But we are confident we can work out a deal."
Mr. Hornung said that the Whalers owed $1.5 million in back rent and that Mr. Gordon had asked for free rent under a new lease. At present, he said, the team's annual rent is $1.1 million.
He also conceded it was possible that a study commissioned by the state earlier this year might recommend that the state take over control of the Civic Center. "It's quite possible that the city might go along with such a suggestion," Mr. Hornung said.
 
Opposition to Name Change
 While the city of Hartford seems amenable to giving the Whalers a better deal on a lease, there apparently is strong opposition to a name change, at least in the Hartford area. A recent poll by The Hartford Courant showed that, by a margin of about 6 to 1, respondents favored retaining the Hartford designation.
"Just as Boston belongs to the name Boston Celtics, Hartford belongs to the name Hartford Whalers," Mayor Perry said. "The Celtics are not known as the Massachusetts Celtics, nor should the Whalers be known as the Connecticut Whalers." Mrs. Perry did not note that the National Football League team that plays in Foxboro, Mass., is known as the New England Patriots.
Mr. Hornung said that since Mr. Gordon proposed the name change recently, the Mayor's office has been inundated with calls of protest. "We've lost The Hartford Times, the Hartford National Bank and G. Fox, which is synonymous with Hartford," Mr. Hornung said. "We don't want to lose the name Hartford Whalers, too."
Despite persistent rumors in recent months that the Whalers are destined to leave he state, Mr. Gordon has never threatened to sell the team. But when asked if he were willing to continue losing millions of dollars each year, as he says he has been doing, he said: "No, I'm not. Who would?"
When the Whalers arrived in Hartford in 1975, they found themselves in a city with no hockey tradition, unlike New Haven which has had professional hockey for most of the last 57 years, although it is about to lose its minor league hockey franchise. But the Whalers have hardly helped establish a tradition: The team has won only one divisional title since joining the N.H.L. in 1979 and, over all, has enjoyed only three winning seasons during its 13 years in the N.H.L.
 
Sounds of Silence
 Not only are crowds at the Civic Center relatively small they are also unusually quiet as hockey crowds go, a factor that has drawn criticism from some players over the years, who have suggested that they would welcome more vocal support. Indeed, Mr. Francis, the vice president for marketing and sales, said that when the Boston Bruins, who are the Whalers' main rival, play at the Civic Center, about 5,000 of their fans are on hand to cheer them on. "Bruin fans make up about a third of the crowd, but at times, from the noise they make, you'd think they had more fans in the house than we did," Mr. Francis said.
Attendance at Whaler games has declined steadily since peaking at an average of 14,616 during the 1987-88 season, when the team won the Adams Division title but was then eliminated early in the Stanley Cup playoffs. As recently as the 1990-91 season, the Whalers averaged 12,621 fans. But last season, when at one stretch the team went 14 games without a victory, the Whalers averaged only 10,659. Ironically, they drew even fewer spectators during their playoff series against the Montreal Canadiens, usually a big hockey attraction even in Hartford. At one game against Montreal, only 5,602 people attended, while another playoff game drew fewer than 8,000 spectators.
With five home dates left on the regular-season schedule this season, the Whalers' attendance is bound to be the lowest since the team joined the N.H.L. in 1979. Season ticket sales have been declining every year, to a low of about 7,000 this season. "We've been losing between 1,000 and 2,000 season tickets a year," Mr. Francis said. "But we're only down by 500 this season."
 
Promotion Incentives
 The club has tried a variety of promotional devices in an effort to attract more fans. For instance, the Whalers offered blocks of $27 tickets to a number of Hartford area corporations for $13 and made the same top-price tickets available to season-ticket holders for $10. During the Christmas holidays, the club again offered tickets to college and high school students at half price. In addition, the Whalers have discounted tickets at varying times for veterans and union members. But attendance still has not picked up.
Leases for the plush sky boxes have also continued to decline. This season, for instance, only 31 of the sky boxes -- which range in price from $60,000 to $80,000, depending on the length of the lease -- have been leased.
"We've got to reach out and get more fans from throughout Connecticut, particularly downstate," Mr. Gordon said. "Hartford is not as far away as many people downstate think it is. And even though most of them read New York papers, they're from Connecticut, and I just hope they'll realize that we're Connecticut's hockey team."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: The Eltinge/Empire Theater;
A Film Restores a Bit of 42d Street -- in Faux Decay

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
ONLY Arnold Schwarzenegger could have done it. The hopeful have been waiting two, ten, even fifty years for the restoration of 42d Street theaters, without result.
But the star's new movie, "The Last Action Hero," has muscled the cheap plastic and crummy signs off the 1912 Empire Theater, at 236 West 42d Street. 
 Now the worn red granite base course, the aged, rusticated limestone, the elaborate weathered bronze doors and ticket booth have reappeared.
One little problem: It's all fake, and with a slight tap the "stone" rings out hollow. But this masterful display of the art director's skills is as close as anyone has yet come to bringing the theaters back.
The Empire was built by the producer Al Woods as the Eltinge Theater, named after Woods's money-making star Julian Eltinge. By Eltinge's own account, he played a woman in a Harvard production and soon left school for a career as a female impersonator. He was successful enough to perform at Windsor Castle for King Edward VII, who gave him a white bulldog.
In 1911 Woods staged "The Fascinating Widow," written specifically for Eltinge, at the Liberty Theater. It ran four years and made them both rich. The next year he built a theater just west of the Liberty.
It is not clear if Eltinge ever actually played there, but his name lent it luster: in 1912 he was earning $1,625 a week, more than President William Howard Taft's $1,442. He also developed his own magazine (with articles on how he applies makeup and why women should take up "the gentle art of boxing") and his own line of cold cream, whose buyers got a free photograph of him.
The building, designed by the theater specialist Thomas Lamb, has a giant square terra cotta facade with a great central bay, all covered with the customary garlands, cartouches and other details, some in polychrome. Compared to other theaters at the time, it marked a new level of composed, urban grandeur.
According to "Lost Broadway Theaters," by Nicholas Van Hoogstraten (Princeton Architectural Press, 1991), later stage productions at the Eltinge starred such actors as Laurence Olivier and Clark Gable. They were superseded in 1931 by burlesque and then movies.
Eltinge died in 1941 and in 1954 the theater was renamed the Empire. By then the theaters on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues had been in decline for several decades and there was wishful thinking of somehow returning them to their original cultured vitality.
In the 1960's a series of proposals called for widespread demolition on 42d Street. Nothing came of them.
In 1981 the New York State Urban Development Corporation announced a plan that called for preserving the theaters, but the project has been repeatedly delayed. In 1990 the Durst Organization announced the impending restoration of the Empire and others it then owned. That, too, did not happen, and eight darkened theaters on that block of 42d Street have continued their slide into decay.
But a month ago Columbia Pictures used 42d Street as a set for "The Last Action Hero." On most buildings the changes were minor -- marquees were relit, storefronts cleaned up -- and meant to produce the colorful, if tawdry, 42d Street of a few years ago, before the closings, says John Wright Stevens, the production's New York art director.
It is on the Empire that the changes are enough to reward a visit by the architectural pilgrim. Stevens and Eugenio Zanetti, the production designer for the film, could not salvage the original ground floor, which had been too mutilated, but spent about $80,000 to erect a new facade over it. It looks like solid stone and bronze but -- thonk! thonk! -- it is Hollywood hollow. The deception is so good it will leave anyone who thinks himself an expert agape with shock pleasure.
THE "granite" (made of stucco over plywood) is stained and has been made to look as though it is flaking off from a trash fire. The "limestone" (stucco on plywood) has been made to look cracked and chipped. The "bronze" (fiberglass) ticket booth and figured doors have convincing green corrosion stains.
The whole assemblage has just the right covering of studio-supplied dirt to make it fit in a legitimately dirty 42d Street; it looks a lot more real than the results of many big- budget restoration projects.
Stevens's constructions are being left in place indefinitely and he hopes they will "call attention to these theaters, to have them be recognized for what they were, and saved."
But hurry: The fiberglass is starting to peel, the plywood to swell, and a steady rain of snow-melt comes through the Empire's roof.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Eltinge (later the Empire) Theater at 236 West 42d Street in 1912. (Theater Collection, Museum of the City of New York)

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut;
Victorian Rehabs for Bridgeport's Needy

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
A HANDFUL of young Bridgeport developers are using a rarely employed Federal tax credit to help finance the rehabilitation of middle-class Victorian homes in the inner city. The resulting units are rented to subsidized low-income tenants.
The credit applies only to properties in historic districts. The work must be done according to specifications of the National Register of Historic Places, consisting largely of restoring the exteriors to their original condition. The owners get a credit of 20 percent of the cost of renovation on their Federal taxes if they do not live in the house themselves. They may, however, live in one unit of a two-family or multifamily building and still receive a reduced credit. 
 "During the early 1980's there were major historic rehabilitation projects throughout the state using the credit," said Linda Spencer, historian at the Connecticut Historical Commission in Hartford.
Developers had a strong incentive to restore the properties because real estate was booming and the credit was 25 percent. On Washington Street in South Norwalk, for example, dilapidated commercial buildings were redeveloped as condominiums, restaurants and boutiques by the Collins Development Corporation of Stamford.
"After the 1986 tax reform the program took a nose dive," said Ms. Spencer. "The credit was reduced and it was no longer available to property owners who made more than $150,000, cutting out important developers."
As the recession deepened, historic preservation dropped to a low priority and in Bridgeport "almost nothing happened between 1986 and 1991," said Charles Brilvitch, the city's Environmental Review Officer. "Until the late 80's every time a house sold it went for a higher price, until the last owner, unable to sell or rent profitably, abandoned it," he said.
He has been acting as adviser to developers who wish to apply for the credit, including Jonathan Rogers, 33, and Paul Edison, 30, former commercial brokers at Coldwell Banker in Manhattan.
"Four years ago we decided to look for rehabs," said Mr. Rogers. "Nothing else in the market was being done because of the economy, and we both had an interest in historic preservation." He had studied the subject while a student at the University of Vermont, and having grown up in Fairfield County he was familiar with Bridgeport and its depressed historic real estate.
They formed McDillon Inc., a contraction of their middle names, and to date they have rehabilitated 13 2- to 5-family homes in some of Bridgeport's worst and most crime ridden, albeit Historic District, neighborhoods. "We plan to continue for another 25 years," said Mr. Edison.
SAM PIERPONT, another 30-year-old developer, has done the same thing with 23 buildings in six years. "I'm living in a boarding house myself," he said, "but I love what I'm doing and I feel like I'm doing some good. In ten years if prices go up I can make money on sales and higher rents."
The three men have acquired a reputation locally and with the state's preservationists as quality developers who are meeting a need for low-income housing. "They are taking the same risks as any developer," said Laura Clark, director of the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation. "We can only encourage them, because our studies show that rehabs in inner cities reverberate and upgrade whole areas."
"We lend actively to the McDillon company," said Barry Rosa, a vice president in the residential mortgage division of People's Bank in Bridgeport. "Some of the housing where they work in the west and south ends is phenomenal-- five or six fireplaces with marble inlays, ceilings with plaster scrollwork that cannot be duplicated today. We support their effort to create affordable housing and we have always taken the position that rehabilitation is a sensible way to do it."
With one of the state's highest tax rates, at $67 per $1,000 assessment, the city has 5 local Historic Districts and 23 National Register Districts with 2,750 homes, hundreds of which are neglected and/or vacant.
In an effort to assist in the redevelopment of historic houses the city exempts them from the first year of taxes at the higher assessment resulting from rehabilitation. In addition, the new tax rate is phased in at 10 percent a year over a 10-year period.
The city also finances streetscaping on blocks where redevelopment is taking place. "Attractive housing is strategically important to new businesses coming into Bridgeport," said Michael Freimuth, Director of Planning and Economic Development.
The McDillon company recently completed a 2-family project at a 100-year-old home on Cottage Street. The block of houses was designed by the Palliser architectural firm of London, imported to Bridgeport by P.T. Barnum, the circus impresario and one-time Bridgeport mayor.
Dana Carter and her five children moved into one unit earlier this month. It has five bedrooms, a large kitchen, a living room and dining room separated by sliding pocket doors, a front and back yard. It rents for $900.
THE property, on a 50- by 100-foot lot, was purchased in foreclosure in 1992 "with $45,000 of our own money," Mr. Edison said. It had been sold for $120,000 in 1989. To finance the restoration McDillon received $28,000 from Neighborhood Housing Services, a local nonprofit agency, $84,600 from People's Bank, and $8,500 from a Community Block Grant. Taxes are currently $1,864 on an assessment of $27,496.
In sharp contrast is the story of Lydia and Dan Klyver, husband-and-wife developers from Southport who had the same idea but on a different and ultimately disastrous scale. Early in 1988 they paid $708,000 for a rundown, 24 room Victorian mansion on Park Avenue, a depressed Bridgeport neighborhood.
They spent an additional $400,000 converting it to six handsome condominiums that they were unable to sell after reducing the price from $142,000 to $100,000. "We rented all the units for $1,000 a month and still couldn't break even," said Mr. Klyver. Only half the units are rented at $700 a month and the Klyvers cannot meet mortgage payments.
"They should have known Park Avenue is not a $1,000 market," said Richard Ruggio, the city's Tax Assessment Engineer. And Mr. Rosa said, "One reason the bank supports the McDillon company is that their understanding of the relationship of cash flow to financing makes sense."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Design/Build;
Pros and Cons of an Under-One-Roof Architects Firm

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
DESIGN/BUILD. It's jargon for a one-stop-shopping approach to architectural services, one in which the same firm designs an office and then builds it.
The list of pros is long. When the architect and construction contractor work for the same firm, they can ram a project through in record time, ordering parts and furniture literally as fast as the designs come off the drawing board. Neither can waffle out of responsibility for a problem by blaming the other. And a designer and builder working together from the first are more likely to devise a realistic budget. 
 But the list of cons is even longer.The temptation to inflate construction budgets can be great without a bidding process. In-process overruns can run rampant without an independent architect riding herd on the project. There's no extra set of eyes to alert the client to design glitches. And more experienced builders never get a crack at the job.
Rocky Meli and John Borrelli, who formed Meli Borrelli Associates in 1991 as the city's first firm to operate solely on the design/build premise, concede that both lists look formidable. But as quickly as clients raise their questions, they tick off their answers.
Worried about cost overruns? They'll guarantee to bring the job in within budget, even if they have to absorb the added costs.
Anxious about inflation in the budget? Sure, the guaranteed maximum price is based on a worst-case scenario, but they work on a flat fee, not percentage of cost, so they say they have no incentive to ratchet the budget up.
And then they offer their coup de grace: Because the contractor and engineer are part of the original bidding process, they are basing their cost estimates on the actual job, not on an architect's best-guess based on similar jobs in the past.
"We can quantify what the tenant will need down to the last nail," said Mr. Meli, the team's construction expert. "We don't present drawings without numbers."
In a sense, the guarantees are a bit gimmicky. Meli Borrelli does post bonds, get letters of credit and provide other financial sureties. But construction mistakes or scheduling problems can run costs up by many millions of dollars, an amount that a tiny architectural firm run by a 34-year-old (Rocky) and a 37-year-old (John) would probably not have access to. A design/build firm has the same opportunity to make kickback arrangements with vendors as does any independent contractor. And clients do sometimes change their mind in mid-stream.
Moreover, Meli Borrelli doesn't come cheap. Where competition has driven architectural fees down to well below $3 a foot, Meli Borrelli usually charges $3.50.
Nonetheless, enough clients have gotten past any angst about high up-front costs and youngish architects to catapult Meli Borrelli to about 80 employees and $140 million in billings in less than two years.
"We operate with tight move-in deadlines, and design/build seemed the only way to meet them," said Tom A. Denis, a member of senior management at Credit Suisse, one of Meli Borrelli's first clients, for which the then-fledgling firm built 106,000 feet of office space at 12 East 49th Street.
Even traditional architects acknowledge design/build's speed.
"If you really need to be building things as they come off the drawing board, then design/ build makes sense," said Matthew Cusumano, a partner in SCR Design Organization, Manhattan architects.
At least one old-line architect has hitched his future to the concept. Last month, Sidney P. Gilbert sold SPGA Group, his 26-year old, 22-person architectural firm to Meli Borrelli.
"I have no question that design/build is the future of this industry," Mr. Gilbert said.
He may be right. With so little building going on, competition among architects for interior design jobs has grown fierce and any firm that offers a guarantee on price and scheduling has an edge.
This is particularly true these days because the staff-paring that has been endemic to most American corporations over the last decade has all but wiped out many corporate facilities departments. The few corporate real estate people who got to keep their jobs generally saw their responsibilities increased, leaving them little time to oversee design projects. With that kind of pressure, it helps when meetings with the architect do double duty as meetings with the builder.
"Having one point of contact is really worth a lot," said Mr. Denis of Credit Suisse.
SO is having a tutored engineering eye looking at designs, added Roger P. Smock, senior vice president of the National Bank 0f Canada, for which Meli Borrelli built two floors at 125 West 55th Street.
He notes how the wiring and setups for microwave transmission were designed in from the start. He points to the raised floor, covered by carpet squares that can be readily taken up, which let the bank hide the extensive computer wiring it uses yet easily reach it when it had to tinker with its systems.
"They even knew how many file cabinets we would need and where they should go," Mr. Smock said. And they brought the project in on time and at the agreed-on budget of $3.65 million.
Actually, neither Mr. Meli nor Mr. Borrelli were unknown quantities to Mr. Smock or Mr. Denis. They, with several other of the firm's clients, had worked with both men when they were employed by Karco-Davis, another New York interior design firm. In fact, several clients moved ongoing projects from Karco-Davis to the new company.
But others, including Alitalia and Burlington, are recent converts. And many tenant representatives are starting to recommend Meli Borrelli to their own clients.
"They give budgets that go to 30 pages, down to the ashtrays, and they give them quickly," said Maurice Solomon, vice chairman of Julien J. Studley.
Those detailed, concrete budgets are the real key to the design/build process. Like most design firms, Meli Borrelli starts a project by cataloging how many employees a client has, what type of office each needs and what sort of equipment, down to the last fax or copy machine, is needed.
At that point, the design/build process veers off on its own.
Meli Borrelli has copious computer programs that match vendor price lists, construction data and floor space requirements with the client's needs. For fees that range from $1,000 to $15,000, it will provide the tenant with data about exactly how much wall space, how many electrical outlets, how much mill work, what sort of cooling or electrical capacity is needed, and the like.
"That way, they don't waste time with inappropriate buildings," Mr. Borrelli said.
ONCE the client has a short list of buildings, a Meli Borrelli team -- an engineer, architect and construction expert -- checks each out and creates a separate budget for building acceptable space in each. It also flags potential glitches (for example, the floor plate in Building X would not allow for enough windowed offices).
The firm has built up formidable laurels, but none it can rest easily on yet. Even its staunchest client fans say they would continue to put future projects out to bid rather than just hand them to Meli Borrelli.
"Their track record says they bring projects in on budget and on time and my gut says they are trustworthy," said Lane Grijns, general manager of NMB Postbank Groep, for which Meli Borrelli designed and built more than 90,000 feet of office space at 135 East 57th Street. "But with these kinds of major expenditures I would start the process from scratch again anyway."
That isn't necessarily bad news for Meli Borrelli, though. Credit Suisse, too, has continued to put new projects out for bid. On one, 150,000 square feet of office space at One Liberty Plaza, it chose Janco Rasic Associates as the architects because they had more experience designing the particular "look" Credit Suisse wanted there. But, it hired Meli Borrelli as construction manager.
"We negotiated a guaranteed price with them, and they're responsible for bringing the project in on budget and on time," said Mr. Denis, who expects the project to be done in a few weeks. "In other words, I hired them to protect me."

HEADLINE: Piscataway Journal;
Election Battle Rages Over School Superintendent's Changes

BYLINE: By STEVEN HART

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY

 BODY:
NEXT month, voters all over the state will head for the polls to pass judgment on school budgets and cast ballots for board of education candidates. But in Piscataway, the vote will go beyond these standard issues to include what amounts to an unofficial referendum on one man -- the Superintendent of Schools, Dr. Philip Geiger -- and the changes he has brought about in this district of about 5,800 students.
With a total of nine candidates, only two of them incumbents, vying for four board seats -- an unusually high number, caused by the retirement of one member and the resignation of another -- both the pro- and anti-Geiger factions expect the campaign to be active and nasty. 
 "I don't think it's anything that is not known," said Eloise Samuels, who along with a fellow incumbent, Theodore Kornegay, expects determined opposition. "The teachers are running their slate, and it's obvious it's against Phil."
Marge Matthews, a township resident whose job as a school bus driver was affected when the board voted in January to assign transportation duties to a private company, said, "We will be going full force ahead to get rid of the board members who voted with Geiger."
It was the privatization of bus routes -- previously run by the district, with a third of the routes handled by the Barker Bus Company of Somerset County -- that galvanized the community, pitting bus drivers and their supporters, all residents, against a board itself composed of residents.
 
Parents' Choice Allowed
 Among the other changes wrought by Dr. Geiger are a new policy allowing parents to choose which elementary schools their children will attend and a "reading recovery" program offering one-on-one instruction to first graders in the lowest 20 percent of reading ability.
And he has undertaken an ambitious program to install 530 Apple Macintosh computers in each of the district's elementary school classrooms. By placing four computers in each classroom and giving the teacher a larger monitor, Dr. Geiger said, the district will be drawing on customized software and programs provided by the Educational Management Group of Phoenix, which has a six-year agreement costing Piscataway about $2.2 million.
Arriving in Piscataway two years ago, Dr. Geiger brought with him a master's degree from the Wharton School of Finance, a doctorate in education from Columbia University and a briefcase full of ideas like zero-based budgeting -- starting from scratch each year, making each program prove its worth all over again -- that were guaranteed to shake things up.
Citing research that makes the elementary school years most crucial to learning, Dr. Geiger talks of a nongraded approach that would blur the lines between grades. Rather than the current march from one grade level to the next, he wants to see an individualized approach reflecting each child's rate of intellectual growth.
He would even like to see the current grading system reduced to three marks: A, B and I for incomplete.
"When kids get C's, D's and F's, you give kids the privilege of failing," Dr. Geiger said. "You say he's fallen behind, but somehow he's going to magically make up for it next year. Our job is to educate kids, not sort them."
Ideas like those were why, according to the board members who voted on his appointment, Dr. Geiger was chosen to succeed a 12-year Superintendent, Dr. Burt Edelchick, who had come up from the ranks of Piscataway teachers.
Paula Van Riper, the current school board president, said: "The school district had been plodding along, sometimes doing things reactively rather than looking ahead. We knew full well, even during the discussions before hiring him, that there would be a lot of controversy and staff upheaval."
Dr. Geiger's record in that regard was clear. As Superintendent of Schools in Galloway, from 1978 to 1984, he drove his teaching staff hard and stirred animosity by privatizing school custodial services, a move the township has since rescinded. In Lexington, Mass., where he served as Superintendent of Schools before coming to Piscataway, he privatized school food services but gradually lost his supporters on the school committee.
Still, the Piscataway board could hardly have anticipated the uproar caused by Dr. Geiger's drive to privatize support services, a move meant to free up money for new programs by relieving the district of the tab for benefits and salaries awarded in kinder economic times.
A 1991 decision to turn school cafeteria services over to Service America Inc., a Pennsylvania-based company, saved the district about $480,000 this year while increasing student participation to 75 percent from 45 percent of the total student population, said the district's business administrator, Guy Vander Vliet.
The decision affected 55 part-time lunchroom workers, all of whom had been getting $8 to $15 an hour along with $8,000 in health benefits. The board required Service America to give them first pick of jobs, and Mr. Vander Vliet said about half of the old staff chose to stay on at lower salaries and reduced benefits.
The same provision was written into the transportation contract, which was awarded this year to Ryder Pupil Transportation Services, a division of the nationwide Ryder truck rental chain. The company will take over all routes in April, after students return from spring vacation.
Ryder also bought up the district's fleet of 70 buses and smaller vehicles for about $1.3 million, in addition to which the district will save about $1.5 million in operating costs along with salaries and budgets for 65 part-time drivers, Mr. Vander Vliet said.
 
Tumultuous Series of Hearings
 But the bus drivers, unlike the cafeteria workers, were represented by the Piscataway Township Education Association, which brought the community out in force to oppose privatization.
During a tumultuous series of hearings leading up to the privatization decision, signs warning "We'll remember you in April" were a common sight, Mrs. Van Riper said. There were also plenty of personal attacks, she added, on board members in general and Dr. Geiger in particular.
"It got pretty dirty," Mrs. Van Riper said. "Bus drivers would send letters home with children saying this and that will happen if you get an outside company driving your kids."
Dominic Ciardi, a board member who was elected on an anti-Geiger platform, said, "He's been accused of everything anybody can think of." Mr. Ciardi now calls himself one of Dr. Geiger's "greatest supporters."
Despite the controversy, Mrs. Van Riper said that "when the dust settles, even those bus drivers will understand." But Mrs. Matthews, who worked for 30 years as a bus driver, disagreed.
"No, I don't think the bus drivers will ever understand," she said Though she now says she is "very, very impressed" with Ryder, her bitterness toward Dr. Geiger and the school board remains.
"It will never, ever go back to the way it was," Mrs. Matthews said. "We had a rapport with the kids and the parents in town that was second to none. There are still parents in town I won't talk to because they didn't come out to support us."
Michele Martin, president of the 750-member Piscataway Township Education Association, called privatization "a short-term Band-Aid solution, and we're trying to educate the public about this."
As head of the association, Ms. Martin represents teachers, classroom aides, custodians and other employees.
"Where will the privatization end?" Ms. Martin said, noting that there is talk of privatizing custodial services. "The board could decide to privatize every one of the units, whether speech therapists or nurses."
Some of Dr. Geiger's harshest critics acknowledge the value of many of his ideas, but like Ms. Martin they question the speed of the changes. Ms. Martin advocated going slow and, in the case of policy changes like privatization, putting questions to the public in a referendum.
Opposition to Dr. Geiger and board incumbents is expected to come from Piscataway Residents for Excellence in Education, a citizens' group widely viewed as linked with the education association, which does not officially endorse candidates.
 
Dislike of Board's 'Attitude'
 Certainly there is no shortage of anti-Geiger sentiment in this year's field of board contenders.
"I'm not in Geiger's camp," said Frank Cicerale, a self-employed accountant. "There are a lot of things I don't like. I didn't like the attitude of the board -- I don't think they are listening to the people. I'm not happy."
Ed Eodice, who is an executive with Mack Trucks Inc. of Allentown, Pa., was finishing his second board term when Dr. Geiger was coming aboard. Voted out in 1991, Mr. Eodice is now making opposition to privatization one of the themes of his comeback campaign.
"With privatization, I think you lose control," Mr. Eodice said. "We had a good system, good, loyal and dedicated people driving the buses."
And if Mr. Eodice gets on the board this year, will he vote to renew Dr. Geiger's contract?
"I really don't know right now," he said.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

ON YOUR MARK
For the 24th year the combination Scarsdale 15K and 4-Mile Runs and the Abe Simon Memorial 15K Run will step off today at 1:30 P.M. from Scarsdale High School on Wayside Lane, weaving through Greenacres and Fox Meadow back to the school parking lot. 
 Participants in the Scarsdale runs are encouraged to cover the distance by walking, if that is their preference. All walkers will receive ribbons. Runners in seven age categories, varying from 14 and under to 60 and older, male and female, will receive trophies for first place and medals for second and third place in all races.
Runners in the memorial portion, named for Mr. Simon, an avid runner and founder of an older persons' running club, will follow the same 15-kilometer course, but they must enter in teams of five men whose minimum age is 50 and three women whose minimum age is 40.
Registration will take place at the high school from 10:30 A.M. to race time. The fee of $15, ($8 for young people through grade 12) covers the cost of refreshments. About 400 runners are expected. Each runner will receive a free T-shirt, and awards will be presented at the finish. Running times vary from last year's winning 15 minutes, 48 seconds to about an hour.
In case of bad weather, a cancellation announcement will be made by the Scarsdale Police Department over WFAS Radio.
 
GARDENING PRIMER
 Barring another blizzard, it's time to get that green thumb working, and the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx will devote next weekend to giving beginning gardeners some substantive inspiration.
From 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Saturday and Sunday, novices can acquire information covering soil preparation, plant selection, tools and techniques. They will also have an opportunity to view the rewards of good gardening by touring the 16 professionally prepared specialty gardens on the grounds.
Vegetable gardens that are not only edible but attractive will be one of the topics, and a complete list, with costs, of the most appropriate tools, hats, gloves, shoes and sunscreens will be discussed, along with ways to avoid an aching back.
Soil experts will recommend the best ways to incorporate organic material for aeration and drainage, and how to cultivate a continuously blooming array of flowers suitable for cutting. Basic garden design, free- flowing or geometric, the uses of herbs, and how to make compost of the remains of dead plants are other subjects to be covered.
The advice is available with the regular admission of $3, $2 for people 65 and older and students. Admission to the Enid Haupt Conservatory spring floral exhibition, titled "Glories of a Manor Garden," is an additional $3, $2 for students and the elderly. The number to call for directions or more information is (718) 817-8700.
 
IN PRAISE OF PIPES
 A special recital celebrating the installation of a new rank of festival- trumpet organ pipes at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills is scheduled for 4 P.M. today. The church is at 555 Bedford Road in North Tarrytown.
Dr. Norman O. Smith, organist and music director, will be joined by Heidi and Randall Wolfgang, oboists, in a program of works by Bach, Brahms, Saint-Saens, Widor and others.
The organ is one of the finest in the county, and the church's stained-glass windows by Marc Chagall and Henri Matisse are renowned worldwide and at their best in the afternoon sun. Admission will be $5 at the door.For more information, the number to call is 631-2069.
 
THE BEEKEEPER'S ART
 Anyone whose property contains pussy willows, red maples, linden trees, locust trees, tulip trees, goldenrod, clover or alfalfa has a natural habitat for beekeeping, although bees may be raised without them.
Theo Cherbuliez, a math teacher at the Hackley School in Tarrytown and a beekeeper since her teens, will present a program on "Getting Started in Beekeeping" today at 2 P.M. at the Greenburgh Nature Center on Dromore Road off Central Avenue. It is geared for adults and older children.
Ms. Charbuliez says that beekeeping is becoming a popular backyard activity because the bees do most of the work and the honey can be an extra source of income.
She will demonstrate how to work with various types of equipment and show a film on the seasonal activities associated with beekeeping. And she will discuss the economics of producing honey for sale, remedies for bee stings and how to keep the hive's occupants from annoying the neighbors.
Subsequent training sessions may be arranged with the nature center's beekeeper free of charge. Admission to the program will be $3. The number to call for more information is 723-3470.
 
OF DOLLS AND DANCERS

The Westchester Theater of Dance will present two performances of "Coppelia" at 1 and 4 P.M. today at the Mid-Westchester Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in Scarsdale. Set to the music of Delibes, the story concerns a doll maker, his doll, a young peasant girl and her beau. The production is designed for children of any age.
More than 20 dancers from the school's corps de ballet will perform along with soloists including Anna Weiss, Peter Nevin, Megan Carney and Christine Jackson. Featured in other works are three professional dancers. Mary Jane Houdina will perform an original jazz piece to music of Aretha Franklin; Ellen Kogan will dance in "Klezmerized" with a background of traditional Klezmer music, and there will be a number by Victoria Pasquale, a former Y student who is now a member of the American Ballet Theater.
Tickets are $10 at the door. The Y is at 999 Wilmot Road, and the phone number for more information is 472-3300.
 
RAGS AND 'RAGTIME'
 E. L. Doctorow, author of "Ragtime," will be honored at a benefit for Richard Kapp's Westchester-based Philharmonia Virtuosi on Thursday at 6:30 P.M. at the old Tappan Hill Restaurant, now called Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown.
Dinner and a raffle will be included in the $175 ticket price, but the main attraction will be a reading by Mr. Doctorow from "Ragtime," the locale of which is New Rochelle in the 20's. The reading will be accompanied by a live performance of Scott Joplin rags by the orchestra.
Raffle tickets alone cost $10, or three for $25, and the principal prize is a trans-Atlantic trip on the Queen Elizabeth 2 with a return flight on American Airlines.
Mr. Doctorow's books have been translated into 25 languages, and he has received many awards including the National Book Critics Circle Award, the National Book Award and the Pen-Faulkner Award. The restaurant, a former summer home of Mark Twain overlooking the Hudson River, is at 81 Highland Avenue. The phone numbers for reservations, raffle tickets or more information are 359-4220 or 693-5595.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Betting That the Fix Is In In Japan

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
TO believers in free markets, the idea that a government can manipulate a huge stock market is abhorrent. But this year the Japanese Government seems to have succeeded in doing just that.
With Japanese stocks spurting, foreign money managers are being forced to decide whether the rally is real. More and more are deciding they had better get on board, lest a recovery in the Japanese economy begin without them. The bulls note that Japan's money supply grew last month, for the first time since August, and believe that the long bear market, in which the Nikkei 225 average fell 63 percent from its peak at the end of 1989, is finally over. 
 If so, it comes at a convenient time for many Japanese companies, particularly banks with extensive stock holdings. The Japanese fiscal year ends Wednesday, and stock values on that date will determine just how sick many balance sheets appear to be when financial reports are released.
The Government's efforts to push up stocks have included pouring in Government-controlled retirement money to increase demand while blocking new stock offerings. Westerners reacted with scorn when the moves were announced, but that was before they worked. Now, foreign investors appear to be buying heavily, although some remain skeptical.
"It's against the whole history of the world to think that governments can arrest stock market collapses after huge bubbles," said one of the doubters, Barton Biggs, the director of global strategy at Morgan Stanley. "I don't believe they will get away with it."
For international money managers, being out of Japan when prices are rising and the yen is strong is a virtual guarantee of poor performance. That has led to what Mr. Biggs calls "panic buying," which he thinks could push prices up until late April or May.
It may also have played a role in Morgan Stanley's official recommendation to its clients, which came last week from David Roche, the firm's global strategist. Noting signs the recession is ending, he suggested buying a long list of Japanese stocks. Someone at Morgan Stanley is wrong.
In some ways, the rally in Tokyo is reminiscent of the August 1982 lift-off in New York, when share prices soared months before the recession ended and when few saw signs that the economy might improve. Bull markets, as the old saw goes, are built on a wall of worries. There is no shortage of such worries. Still, buyers now are betting that government manipulation will keep working. It does not look like a safe bet.
Last week's column pointed to a pending bond issue from one of Donald Trump's casinos as a sign that the junk bond market is growing very speculative. Now we hear that the bond, which has little in the way of collateral and will not pay cash interest for eight years, might be priced at 12 percent or lower, rather than the 15 percent we had heard. If so, speculation is greater than we thought.
