HEADLINE: Clinton Plan -- Small Businesses Smile

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FROM the way he talks, President Clinton wants to be Johnny Appleseed for the nation's small businesses. Sow a few tax credits here, sprinkle on some new incentives there and, presto, within a few months small businesses will grow from coast to coast, producing a cornucopia of new jobs.
Some of the President's seeds have already sprouted, as some businesses have rushed to take advantage of the proposed incentives even before Congress approves many of the plan's details -- as is widely expected. After four years of lackluster growth, they are eager to move ahead, caught in the surge of confidence brought by the plan. 
 Thanks to a proposed tax break for capital gains in small companies, Stephanie Harkness, who runs a plastics factory in Santa Cruz, Calif., says she has found it far easier to attract the investors she needs to expand. In a rapid response to the planned investment tax credit, Jim Hambuchen is already shopping for a $20,000 ditch-digger for his electrical contracting company in Arkansas, and John Clark, who owns a pizza factory in Chicago, has his eye on an $80,000 packaging machine. He would also benefit from promised incentives for inner-city businesses.
Of course, no one who sows ever sees 100 percent of the seeds germinate, and Mr. Clinton is no exception. Many small businesses view his proposed tax increases as a chill wind that is pushing them to protect what they have rather than put their energies into expanding. For example, Eamonn McGeady, president of a marine construction company in Baltimore, says the proposed energy tax and higher income taxes will hurt his bottom line, discouraging him from hiring more people.
Like thousands of others across the country, these four executives are already responding to the plan. Sketches of them, their goals and their businesses follow.
Mr. Clinton expects great things from small business -- usually defined as companies with fewer than 500 employees -- and his package pays special attention to it. With the giants of industry laying off workers, he sees small business as the engine of job growth -- and probably his best hope for achieving his goal of creating eight million jobs in four years. Indeed, small business employs 60 percent of the nation's 99 million private-sector workers.
 
The Goal: New Jobs
 "Small businesses have created virtually all of the new jobs in our country in the last 10 years," Mr. Clinton told the nation's mayors this month. "Their inability to create more jobs than larger employers have been shedding is the central cause of stagnant employment in America."
Not surprisingly, his economic package has a raft of provisions targeted at small businesses. For companies with sales of less than $5 million, the Clinton plan proposes a permanent investment tax credit at 7 percent for the first two years and 5 percent in subsequent years. For companies with less than $50 million in capital, it proposes halving capital-gains taxes on investments in those firms that are held for five years or more. As part of his plan to create "enterprise zones" -- hard-pressed areas where tax breaks are offered to encourage investment -- Mr. Clinton offers numerous employment and investment incentives for small businesses in the inner city.
Political handicappers say these provisions stand a good chance of sailing through Congress because they are not very expensive and have a huge constituency. Between 1981 and 1992, the number of small businesses rocketed to 21 million from 13 million. The proposals make conservatives smile because they touch all the right buttons: encouraging entrepreneurship, easing regulations and cutting capital-gains taxes. And they please liberals because they have a populist flavor and will help the folks on Main Street.
But whether the plan will be as big a success economically as politically is open to question. Owners of two dozen small businesses predicted in interviews that the plan would benefit them somewhat, but they did not expect it to produce the explosion of jobs the President envisions.
Their biggest hope is not even pinned to the plan's specifics. Rather, they are counting on the President's overall plan to increase business and consumer confidence and keep interest rates low, which would give the economy -- and small business -- a powerful boost.
"If we get the deficit cuts the President has called for, and if he shows some real leadership, the plan will have a bigger effect for us and for the economy than the dollars that would flow to us directly from the plan," said Frank Clayton, who runs an electrical supply company with eight employees in suburban Cleveland.
With small business as diverse as all America, the proposals would benefit some enterprises far more than others. The investment tax credit would give manufacturers a lot to cheer about, while many service-sector firms would watch the parade pass them by. Start-up businesses looking for investors to help them expand would no doubt benefit more than older concerns because of the cut in capital-gains taxes.
Inner-city businesses, in particular, would gain from proposals to set up enterprise zones, while rural firms might be hurt disproportionately by the proposed broad-based energy tax. And the increase in corporate and personal income taxes would slap the most successful entrepreneurs.
"We appreciate some of the things the President has held out for small business," said Jack Faris, president of the National Federation of Independent Business, which has 600,000 businesses as members. "But the basic problem is the plan takes more tax money and gives it to the Government. Higher taxes mean higher prices for products and less money in consumers' pockets, and that doesn't bode well for small business."
If President Clinton's overall package does run into turbulent waters, some of the small-business incentives may sink or be altered. Last week the Administration, responding to pressure from Silicon Valley firms, agreed to raise the ceiling on companies covered by the capital-gains tax break to $50 million in total capital from $25 million, but many companies want the ceiling raised even higher. And many lawmakers are hoping to tinker with the size of the investment tax credit.
Two developments that were not part of the President's economic package will heavily affect small business. Many welcomed the proposals the Administration introduced March 10 to ease the credit crunch by reducing the paperwork needed to make a loan, easing requirements on property appraisals and making it easier to make character loans. But many small businesses are frightened that President Clinton's health-care proposals will hit them hard, requiring them to provide medical coverage for employees or pay higher taxes to help finance the changes.
In many ways small business's feelings on health reform parallel its views on the economic package. "While we are uncomfortable with paying more taxes, it's fair to say that on the whole, we're willing to pay our fair share if the plan is fair," said John Galles, executive vice president of National Small Business United, with 65,000 members.
Despite some gripes with the Clinton plan, it has made small-business men and women stand a bit taller because it puts so much faith in them.
"We're most enthused that this President has come out of the chute saying, 'Small business is the way out of the economic throes of this country, and I'm going to do everything possible to alleviate the burden on small business,' " said Bennie Thayer, chairman of the National Association of the Self-Employed, which has 320,000 members. "We call him the Small Business President."
 
Stephanie Harkness
Perfect Timing For an Investment
 Stephanie Harkness, a former high school principal, sounds almost surprised that her molded-plastics business has done so well since she set it up four years ago in Santa Cruz, south of San Francisco.
She was convinced that her knack with people and her husband's technical expertise would make her dream work. Today, Pacific Plastics and Engineering has a spic-and-span factory, 26 employees and more than $2 million in annual sales, mostly of disposable medical devices and plastic parts used in electronic equipment.
For Ms. Harkness, President Clinton's economic plan could not have arrived at a better time -- the proposed tax breaks on capital gains have already made it far easier for her to pursue her plans to buy a neighboring company.
"The capital-gains plan makes it more attractive for our angels," she said, from a second-story office above her sprawling factory floor.
Ms. Harkness has her sight on a company that makes golf-course yardage markers. Pacific Plastics is already under contract to make many of the markers, and she predicts that it can rack up $14 million in profits in the next few years if she can sell the markers to 10 percent of the nation's golf courses.
"If we buy that firm, we would be able to expand, and we'd have to hire at least 10 or 15 more people," said Ms. Harkness, a 49-year-old native Californian. She had been concerned about finding the $1 million needed for the acquisition. Now, thanks to Mr. Clinton's plan, far more investors than she expected are knocking on her door.
"It's very attractive for them," she said. "They invest $100,000 to $300,000, hold their investment for five years, and not only do they share in the profits during that time, but they will be able to write off half their gains when they sell it," she said.
Ms. Harkness is also excited about another aspect of Mr. Clinton's plan: the proposed investment tax credit. She says it will encourage her company to buy four $100,000 injection molding machines over the next two years; she had planned to buy three.
She has one big complaint with the President's plan: the energy tax, which could raise her $60,000 annual energy bill by 5 to 10 percent. "It's not going to make it easier for us to compete globally," she said. Her company exports 10 percent of its production. "We run our equipment 24 hours a day, seven days a week."
Not one to rein in her enthusiasm, she clearly supports the President's plan, even though she voted for President Bush last November.
"I'm encouraged by the President's plan," she said. "The mood of the country has shifted, and as long as the plan is implemented, I think America will be a better place than it has been the last four years."
 
Eamonn McGeady
Hopes Scuttled By New Taxes
 With his tugboat captain's license and law school diploma hanging on the wall behind him and an excellent view of Baltimore's Curtis Bay before him, Eamonn McGeady, president of a marine construction company, would seem the picture of success. But his mood is less than buoyant.
Mr. McGeady, a 60-year-old Army veteran who voted for George Bush, sees President Clinton's economic plan as a big negative for small business. He angrily asserts that all the additional taxes will sabotage rather than spur entrepreneurship. In his view, the plan gives him little incentive to buy new tugboats or floating cranes or add to his work force of 58.
"On balance, a small business is going to have the Government's hand in its pocket to a greater extent than it does now," said Mr. McGeady, whose company builds and maintains piers, bulkheads, bridges and underwater pipelines and cables. "Most of us find that objectionable."
For him, the villain of the piece is not the rise in corporate income taxes to 36 percent from 34 percent, but the even bigger jump in personal income taxes on upper-income people. The President wants to raise the top tax rate for families with taxable income of more than $140,000 to 36 percent and put a surtax on incomes of more than $250,000, raising the effective tax rate to 39.6 percent.
Like many small businesses with a handful of owners, Mr. McGeady's company qualifies as an S corporation -- named for the subchapter of the Internal Revenue Code that authorizes it. That means its earnings flow directly to the owners and are subject to personal income taxes, not to corporate income taxes.
Mr. McGeady points out that some years his top effective tax rate would be raised -- to 36 percent from 31 percent. In a really profitable year, it might soar to 39.6 percent.
"If you're a small business with a taxable income at that level, that will be devastating," said Mr. McGeady, who succeeded his father at the company's helm 30 years ago. "It all seems like a very Machiavellian scheme to get the Government's hands on the economic engine of the nation, and that's small business."
With the economy picking up, he said, his company, Martin G. Imbach Inc., could soon surpass the boom year it had two years ago, when it earned $550,000 on $9.25 million in sales. These profits are divvied up among him and his two brothers -- the company's sole shareholders -- and represent the capital needed to buy new equipment.
The tax increases, he said, would more than offset the main incentive the Clinton plan offers him, the investment tax credit. He has repeatedly written to President Clinton, urging him to make more spending cuts instead of increasing taxes.
"Right now I need to hire four or five additional people," he said. "But at the moment I'm hesitating because I assume that employees in general will cost more as a result of all these things -- including the possibility of higher health care taxes." Still, he has one big hope from the program: that some of the increased infrastructure spending will come his way.
 
John Clark
Defying the Odds In the Inner City
 Running a factory in a South Chicago neighborhood where many people are afraid to walk at night is not for the faint of heart. Insurance costs are steep and finding well-trained workers is not easy. And energy costs in Chicago are higher than for many competitors in other parts of the country.
Defying the odds, John Clark, the 50-year-old president of Reggio's Pizza, has in 20 years built a successful business that produces more than one million frozen pizzas a year. Although he describes himself as a conservative, Mr. Clark backs President Clinton's plan not only because it offers many goodies for inner-city companies but also because he believes it will strengthen the economy and cut the budget deficit.
The President's plan includes special investment incentives and employment tax credits for companies in 50 enterprise zones. The as-yet unspecified areas would presumably include the South Side.
"It would definitely make it less costly to do business here," Mr. Clark said. "When you're a small-business person, you have to take advantage of all these things because they can make the difference whether you remain a viable business."
Among the inducements for inner-city companies are special accelerated depreciation measures, writing off in one year the first $75,000 of an investment, and a 25 percent tax credit on the first $15,000 in wages paid to workers who live in the enterprise zone. The goal is to cut double-digit unemployment in inner-city neighborhoods.
"If you have two people equally qualified, one with the tax credit and one without, you don't have to be a genius to figure out which one I'm going to hire," he said.
For Mr. Clark, who has 86 workers and high employee turnover, these measures could add more than $50,000 to his bottom line. Although many economic studies argue that enterprise zones do little to turn around urban areas, Mr. Clark is confident that the new incentives will help South Chicago businesses expand and hire new workers.
He feels a personal frustration over one aspect of the plan -- the investment tax credit. During the last two years, he made the biggest investment of his life, buying a 30-year-old Seven-Up factory and installing $1 million worth of equipment, including an automatic sauce and sausage depositor.
He curses his luck that the 7 percent tax credit was not in place for those investments. Nonetheless, he hopes to use it this year for an $80,000 packaging machine.
In contrast to many of his small-business colleagues, Mr. Clark hardly seems to mind that the Clinton plan includes several tax increases, because he is confident that the plan will give the economy a lift.
"When Reagan took office in 1980 the Federal debt was $1 trillion, and when Bush handed over the reins it was $4 trillion," he said. "That wasn't working, and we have to try something else.
"As long as I feel that the tax burden is distributed as fairly as possible, I don't have a real problem with paying it," he added. "I'm an American citizen, and the Government has to be strong."
 
The Hambuchens
Mom and Pop, Ready to Grow
 GiGi Hambuchen is finally starting to admit it: her eight-year-old I.B.M. 286 desktop computer is too slow to meet the demands of her cluttered lighting-fixture shop in Conway, Ark., 30 miles north of Little Rock.
Her husband, Jim, who runs an electrical contracting firm from a crowded office in the rear, has started to think it is time to replace his clumsy ditch-digging machine dating from 1974. If ever a small business was ripe for President Clinton's proposed investment tax credit, it could be the Hambuchens' mom-and-pop operation.
"I've been thinking of buying some new vans and some new equipment, so the credit will be very helpful to me," said Mr. Hambuchen, who does wiring for new homes and electrical repair work.
He has begun snooping around for a $20,000 ditch digger, as well as a $2,000 jackhammer, and Mrs. Hambuchen has become a lot more receptive to salesmen's pitches for more powerful computers.
The 7 percent credit proposed on equipment purchases might even persuade Mr. Hambuchen to add a seventh van to his fleet, which would enable him to add two workers to his force of 14. The business, founded by his father in 1946, already owns six vans, but he is embarrassed to admit his newest van is five years old.
"If we could get this economy going, and if we could get some of these tax benefits through, I think I'd really buy some new equipment," he said, almost amazed at hearing himself sound like a big spender.
The Hambuchens, who voted for Mr. Clinton last November, say that as Governor he worked hard to make businesses feel welcome in Arkansas. "Our business has been growing slowly but surely," said Mr. Hambuchen, who noted that a decade ago he had six employees. "Clinton has helped us along. He's helped the state; he's brought in a lot of new businesses."
The past few months, his business has been going like gangbusters, thanks to a boom in home-building resulting from the lower interest rates brought about, at least in part, by Mr. Clinton's deficit-cutting package. Mr. Hambuchen's easygoing manner and eagerness to chat up acquaintances certainly helped his efforts to win new business.
"I see things opening up," he said. "I think Clinton's going to get the economy running. But he's going to have to move pretty quick because people could run out of patience after what's happened the last few years."
He has one bone to pick with the President: the energy tax. "That will affect us very much," he said. "All these vans get only about 10 miles to the gallon."
But one thing he doesn't mind is raising taxes on the rich. "I'm not in the $180,000 bracket," he said.
Mr. Clinton's economic plan has been Topic A in the lighting-fixture shop recently. While there has been grumbling about tax increases, Mrs. Hambuchen said, the plan has received generally favorable reviews.
"Whether or not people voted for him," she said, "they say they are ready to do their part to get rid of the deficit so long as he really does something about getting it down."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 28, 1993

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1413 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/March 21-26

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
I.B.M. Forsakes Techies for a Cookie King 

It was the biggest talent search ever in American business, made doubly difficult because some prime candidates took one look at the job and wanted none of it. I.B.M., a giant beyond imagination, had taken an unimaginably giant fall, and there's no telling when, or if, anyone can pick up all the pieces. Among the industry heavyweights who removed themselves from contention were John Sculley of Apple and George Fisher of Motorola. So in the end I.B.M. made what would seem an unlikely choice to succeed John F. Akers, a choice from far beyond the computer industry: Louis V. Gerstner Jr. of RJR Nabisco. True, he is one of America's most respected executives, and is said to be an extraordinarily quick study. But it's an awful long way from mastering cookies to mastering computers. And one of I.B.M.'s tasks is clear: it has not been able to keep up as the focus of technology shifted from multimillion-dollar mainframes to smaller machines. But then again, perhaps I.B.M. has plenty of technology lying around and what it needs is business savvy -- maybe such an unlikely choice could prove to be the right path. "What I.B.M. needs is a business architect, not a technology wizard," one industry expert said.
 
Baxter Had the Wrong Friends
 
It's hard enough to sort out enemies and friends in the Mideast. That goes double when you try to reach into that powderkeg and come up with a neat set of standards for American business. Are our friends' enemies our enemies? Can they be friends if they treat our friends as enemies? Get out the computer flow charts. The 1977 law that bars American companies from cooperating with the Arab boycott of Israel has been a nightmare to enforce. But maybe Baxter International went too far. Last week, in the stiffest punishment ever meted out under the law, Baxter agreed to pay a $500,000 fine and other penalties. Baxter admitted that it violated the law by providing Arab nations with details of its dealings with Israel.
 
POST SLAYS OWNER (Almost)
 
It happens so often: one day something deeply offends the public sensibility, the next it is the answer to every prayer. Rupert Murdoch, roundly blasted for the flamboyance he imposed on The New York Post, was forced to sell the paper five years ago because he also owned a local television station. But such niceties melted away in an instant last week when he stepped forward and, even though he lost $150 million the last time out, offered to buy the paper back. Gov. Mario Cuomo and others quickly sought to sidestep the cross-ownership rule. The reason was clear: The Post has turned into a sad, surreal circus -- with the editor, Pete Hamill, setting up shop in a diner and saying all his paychecks have bounced. But this gets tricky: From whom does Mr. Murdoch buy the paper? Abe Hirschfeld owns it, sort of, though his bizarre stunts may at last be over. The bankruptcy court owns it, sort of. In a truer sense, though, perhaps it's the city that owns it now.
 
Q. Who Owns The New York Post?
 
A.
 Peter Kalikow
 Abe Hirschfeld
 Rupert Murdoch
 Pete Hamill
 Steven Hoffenberg
 Bankruptcy court
 All of the above
 None of the above
 
Answers available next week (maybe)
 
A Marriage Made at Microsoft
 
All work and no play has made William Gates a rich man. (No, "rich man" doesn't do it: if he had forests, rivers and a flag, he'd be a rich country.) And so fabled is the killer business instinct of Microsoft's chairman that some software competitors have wished that Mr. Gates would get married, have children, soften up -- and then perhaps ease up on his rivals. Well, that theory will be put to a test. Mr. Gates, 37, plans to marry Melinda French, 28, a Microsoft executive.
 
Chrysler's Back: Look at Its Pay
 
Even with all the uproar over executive pay, when times are good companies often go all out to reward top managers. Chrysler came back from yet another brink last year, with its new models a hit and its stock selling for about four times what it was 18 months ago, and Lee Iacocca was not forgotten. His 1992 pay was four times what he got in 1991 -- $12.2 million in salary and other compensation. But he's retired now -- not that he wanted to let that chairman's title go -- so he'll have to get by as a $500,000-a-year Chrysler consultant. His successor, Robert Eaton, didn't do badly either: $7.4 million in total pay in 1992.
 
Merck to Clinton: What Profits?
 
In the pantheon of Clinton villains, drug prices rank high. A prime White House target is what it sees as drug makers' fat profits. Merck's answer: We're not doing that well, so ease up. Merck said last week that its profit growth was slowing, and drug stocks were punished. It was in large part a political message: Merck's chairman, P. Roy Vagelos, said the industry "certainly does not need price controls" -- and he dramatized the woes by saying he and his top executives would take a 10 percent pay cut.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Daimler Plays by U.S. Rules
 
Naturally, the New York Stock Exchange wants to list big foreign companies. Otherwise it risks losing its status as a financial hub. But when Daimler-Benz knocked, the S.E.C. jumped in, demanding certain disclosures. German companies, it seems, can set up secret reserves, stuffing cash into the mattress in fat years and pulling it out to prop up profits in lean ones. But the S.E.C. said that wouldn't do for a Big Board company: how would an investor know what was going on? The S.E.C. apparently won the day, for Daimler said last week that it expected to be listed -- and it is likely to provide most of the required information.
 
Beers Across the Border
 
As the beer industry goes global, everything is changing: taste, economics, trade laws. A few weeks ago Miller introduced something revolutionary, a beer with strong taste. And last week Anheuser-Busch paid nearly half a billion dollars for 18 percent of Grupo Modelo, the Mexican brewer that makes Corona and other brands -- the type of deal expected under the North American Free Trade Agreement. Where will it all lead? Will beefy football fans soon be bellying up for a pint of lukewarm Guinness? Or will "lite" beer take over the world?
 
Sony One-Note? No Way!
 
There's no disputing it: To get to the top, you've got to eat, sleep and breathe business -- especially in Japan, land of the endless workday. So how is it that Norio Ogha, Sony's president, is also such an accomplished musician that he will soon conduct at Avery Fisher Hall? Well, he eats and breathes Sony; he just doesn't sleep. Trained as a musician, he at first worked for Sony by day and sang opera by night -- until he fell asleep waiting to sing his part in "The Marriage of Figaro." Now, to pursue his passion for conducting, he studies scores from 2:30 till 5 each morning. But clearly, the work ethic weighs heavily. "That way it's on my time," he explains, "not Sony's time."
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
A Predator's Ball, Up-Tempo
 
Some pairings are naturals: when they happen, there's a blinding flash of light and you wonder why it took so long. Laurel and Hardy. Rodgers and Hammerstein. Now, Michael Jackson and Michael Milken. Just count the similarities: first name, fame, bankrolls, life style, hairdo . . . . Mr. Milken has secured the backing of Mr. Jackson to form an interactive educational television network, but whether Mr. Jackson's backing will be financial or creative remains unclear, and no deal has been reached. But Mr. Milken, just out of Government custody and now required to work 1,800 hours of community service in each of the next three years, said his philanthropic foundations would start the educational network with Mr. Jackson's help.
 
If It Quacks Like a Truck . . .
 
When there's pent-up anger, it pokes out in odd places: a husband and wife battle about teacups when all of life is the true topic. And so with Bill Clinton's spat with Japan. Yes, he's irate about the lopsided trade, about what he calls a closed Japanese market, but his fury last week focused on mini-vans. He said he wanted to levy tariffs as if they were trucks, not cars, and Japan shot back that he'd have a battle on his hands if he did. Here's a simple solution: Peek inside a mini-van and see if it's full of people or plumbing supplies. Then decide if it's a car or a truck.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Exploring The Murky World of Drug Prices

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
LAST week an advisory panel of the Food and Drug Administration recommended approval of Tacrine, the first drug to treat Alzheimer's disease, and health economists are quaking to see how much it will cost patients. Although the drug produces slight or no benefit in most patients, Warner-Lambert has indicated that its price was likely to be well over $1,000 a year. And since there is no other treatment for Alzheimer's and Warner-Lambert has the sole right to produce it, patients or their insurers are expected to pay.
Now that the Clinton Administration has chastised the pharmaceutical industry for excessive prices and profits, health economists have found themselves wondering how to settle on a fair drug price. At the heart of the debate is the inherent tension between patients who feel entitled to medicines at an affordable price and drug manufacturers whose first allegiance is, after all, to their shareholders and who will sell drugs for as much as they can. 
"These companies are not charities -- they are charging what the market will allow them to charge," said Sam Peltzman, a professor of economics at the University of Chicago. He notes that under current law, drug companies are granted monopolies to sell new drugs at any price they wish for over 10 years, so "of course they are going to try to maximize their profits," he said.
Drug companies have generally refused to explain how they price individual drugs, but cite high research and development costs as well as the saving new drugs offer in explaining their charges. "Drugs save the health care system money," said Jeffrey Warren, a spokesman for the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association. "They are cheaper than alternative therapies. They avoid hospitalization and surgery, and keep people out of nursing homes."
Following this logic, the manufacturers have argued that a dose of a drug to treat the lungs of premature infants is worth the hundreds of dollars that it costs, since the treatment decreases the children's need for even more costly intensive care.
 
The Ethics of Price-Gouging
 But others disagree. "If someone who finds a pill that would save babies from some dreadful fate says, 'I'm charging an outrageous amount but it's worth it,' I would say that's morally corrupt," said Dr. Paul Meier of Columbia University, who is a frequent consultant to the Food and Drug Administration. "There's a limit to how much we should play the market."
Even avid defenders of free markets admit that current market forces have not worked well to keep drug prices reasonable. "A fair price normally gets set in a market where there are many well informed buyers and many sellers and no subsidies or taxes or patents to distort it," said Dr. Alan Garber, a medical doctor and economist at Stanford University. "In health care none of these conditions exist."
Dr. Meier uses his own experience to prove how the market has failed. For many years he has suffered from dandruff, that he now controls with a prescription shampoo for which he pays $3 through a drug plan; the real price of the shampoo has recently risen to $25. "If it were my $25, I would be back to some other remedy," he said. "But I have no incentive to take the cheaper drug and my doctor has no incentive to prescribe it."
Critics of the industry say there are many methods that the Government or insurers could use to determine if a drug price was fair. Dr. Peter Arno, a health economist at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, suggests that drug prices could be set by comparing the price of a new drug to others that perform the same function or to the drug's price in other nations.
For new classes of drugs, Dr. Arno said, prices could be set to cover the cost of drug development "plus a reasonable rate of return." Such "cost-plus" pricing has been used to established reasonable rates in many regulated industries and to reimburse defense contractors.
 
Secret Costs of Production
 But drug manufacturers have avidly guarded their production costs as proprietary information. And even if they were revealed, Dr. Peltzman says, that strategy would not work well in the pharmaceutical world. "If you tie the price of the drug to the cost of developing just that product, you miss the essence of pharmaceutical development, where nine out of ten products fail," he said. Some economists have suggested that a company's total research costs could be factored into setting the price of its successful product, but Professor Peltzman said: "If we say we're are going to pay for all the losers, that encourages waste in the system and mediocre research."
Instead, he and others think the answer lies in reinvigorating market forces that have lain dormant while drugs prices have risen: companies must face more competition, and those who purchase pharmaceuticals must become conscious of price.
Professor Pelzman suggests that patent protection could be cut to five years. Although a company might decide to charge very high prices for the first few years of a drug's life, competition from other quarters would quickly bring down the price, he said.
Dr. Garber said the strategy of managed competition, in which all patients become members of large health maintenance organizations could also hold down drug prices if the groups bargained with drug manufacturers to get the best price for their customers. In the last two weeks the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association has endorsed this approach as preferable to outright price control, Mr. Warren said, understanding that "it will probably result in more competitive prices."
Unfortunately when a company has a monopoly on a drug, there is currently little room for bargaining, and virtually all the drugs costing hundreds of dollars a dose are still under patent. "When there is a unique drug, we face some really tough choices," Dr. Garber said. "It's much easier when you're talking about a drug with 14 close substitutes."
Dr. Garber believes that insurers and health maintenance organizations would have to be able to refuse to pay for treatments that they deemed too costly; otherwise, "any company with a unique product can say the sky's the limit, and we can't afford that." He added that Canada and Australia already tell manufacturers that they won't purchase certain products unless they are priced reasonably.
To draw these lines in the sand, Dr. Garber predicts, health economists will have to become better at determining a drug's cost effectiveness. "Payers are going to have to be able to say there's a price that just not worth it," he said.

HEADLINE: Those Who Pay Health Costs Think About Drawing Lines

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
THEY don't like the word even in Oregon, the state that thrust it into the news. "I certainly don't use the term rationing unless someone forces me to," says Jean I. Thorne, director of Oregon's Medicaid program, which this month received Federal permission for a plan in which poor people will not be covered for low-priority treatments while basic health benefits are extended to everyone.
Americans are worried about health costs, which now soak up 14 percent of the gross national product, surveys show, and want the Government to do something about them. But one thing Americans emphatically do not want, these same surveys find, is rationing of medical care. The idea that someone might be denied, say, an organ transplant that might save his life just because it costs so much is abhorrent. 
 Nor is it part of American medical tradition. "Twenty years ago, when making ward rounds with my students, I'd say that we'll go on trying the next test or treatment and the next one until there is no hope of helping the patient," said Dr. William B. Schwartz of the University of Southern California. That approach -- do anything that might help whatever the cost -- still prevails today, though it often does not benefit the uninsured. It is implicit in laws that, for example, require the Government to license new drugs that promise the slightest benefit, without regard for their sometimes astronomical prices.
"If we want to continue to teach that philosophy, it's going to be incredibly costly," said Dr. Schwartz, who has for years argued that rationing is inevitable if the country wants health spending to level off. "That is a societal decision."
But do not expect any politician, this year or next, to use the dreaded word in the debate over health costs. Instead, watch for the phrase "cost-effective," and read the fine print telling how it will be applied. In those two words lie the seeds of wrenching change.
Already, medical researchers are trying to reduce ineffective or harmful procedures by developing guidelines on, for example, which patients will benefit from operations like coronary bypass. Insurers, through "managed care," have also tried to weed out procedures and hospital days that are not medically necessary.
Pruning out inappropriate care is only sensible -- but it is not rationing. Refusing to pay for something, not because it is ineffective but because its costs greatly outweigh potential benefits, would be the great departure.
Not every expert agrees that rationing is needed in the forseeable future, even if the country adopts a ceiling on spending. After studying the results of many procedures, including coronary bypass, angioplasty, hysterectomy and gall bladder operations, Dr. Robert Brook and his colleagues at the Rand Corporation concluded that one-quarter to one-third of all medical care in the country is either inappropriate or carries risks that equal potential benefits. "We have to get rid of all that before we talk about rationing," Dr. Brook said. "We have at least 10 years before we have to think about rationing."
Another optimist is Dr. Paul Ellwood, a physician and health economist in Jackson Hole, Wyo., and a father of the "managed competition" model favored by President Clinton and his task force, which is expected to issue recommendations in early May for restructuring the health care system. "The health system has overshot," said Dr. Ellwood. "It's doing more with patients than will benefit them."
 
Cutting Waste
 Under managed competition, most doctors and hospitals would join prepaid plans like health maintenance organizations that would compete for the business of large consumer groups. By rewarding doctors for prudent care and publicizing comparative medical results, he said, the approach should help "move medical care back to where most things that are done to patients actually improve their health." By drastically reducing waste, he said, "we can avoid or at least delay rationing."
Dr. Schwartz counters with harsh mathematics. The inescapable truth, he said, is the relentless upward trend in medical costs, compounded annually and driven mainly by new technology and the aging of the population. He is all for stopping useless care, but once those savings are achieved, then the upward trend resumes, scarcely dented. "Maybe for five years real costs increase by 4.5 percent instead of 6 percent," he said. "That's wonderful, but then you're back to the full trend of 6 percent."
While some advances, like vaccines, cut medical costs, many more add to them, Dr. Schwartz said. Many wonder drugs control rather than cure disease: AZT is not just expensive in itself, but in keeping AIDS patients alive encourages extra treament at huge expense for infections and anemia.
Other advances bring incremental gains for a high price. An example: Injected contrast mediums, used in diagnostic imaging about 10 million times a year. The commonly used medium is inexpensive but causes death in a tiny percentage of those cases, about 300 fatalities a year. A new, safer medium being adopted, Dr. Schwartz said, will save those 300 lives at a cost of $1 billion a year.
 
Hope for a Price
 This month, a Federal advisory panel, prohibited by law from considering cost, recommended licensing of Tacrine, a drug that may lead to modest improvements in cognition for one in five Alzheimer's patients who take it. But there is no way to identify those who will benefit or to easily measure the benefits, so many of the country's four million Alzheimer's patients may take it, and Medicare and private insurers will pay. Costs for the drug and required monitoring of side effects may be several billion dollars a year.
Dr. Schwartz says medical resources must somehow be directed to where they give the best returns. He cited the use of $1,000 magnetic resonance imaging scans for patients with head injuries. High priority would go to patients in a stupor or confused state suggesting a 50-50 chance of a life-threatening but treatable blood clot. The cost would be $2,000 per life saved.
But in patients who merely complain of a few bad headaches and some dizziness -- many of whom today are receiving scans just in case -- the chance of finding a dangerous, treatable condition like a clot may be one in 2,000, Dr. Schwartz said, which means the expenditure of $2 million for each life saved.
"As a physician I hate this idea, but we can't afford to spend $2 million per case," Dr. Schwartz said. "When that one fatal case is missed there will be pain and misery. It's a social trade-off. We lost that 1 in 2,000, but what about environmental pollution, or education?"
If the day of reckoning does come, how should rationing be done? Uwe Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University, said there are basically two approaches.
One is the "civics textbook" approach, in which government makes open and formally stated choices. The second is to "muddle through elegantly," decentralizing rationing with "ad hoc decisions in the trenches." The latter approach may not satisfy the civics books, he said, but it may be the more realistic route.
Oregon's plan of "prioritization," as officials there prefer to call it, which has involved exhaustive public hearings and creation of a formal ranking of diseases and treatments, is the epitome of approach No. 1. Its evolution also suggests that Dr. Reinhardt may be right about the difficulty. As finally approved, the plan hardly deserves to be called rationing; almost all the excluded treatments involve self-limiting conditions, cosmetic procedures and therapy of unproven value. By drawing the cutoff so low, the state has been able to gain wide support and Federal approval, but it expects to save only about 3 percent of its Medicaid costs over time, Ms. Thorne said.
Oregon officials "did not get into serious consideration of cost-effectiveness," she said; they lacked data and "did not want to be in the position of attaching dollars to a person's life." A few things clearly of slight benefit and extreme cost, like aggressive care for advanced, terminal cancer patients, were ranked near the bottom. But expensive organ transplants of proven value will be paid for. Some of the hardest decisions with huge financial impact -- when to put critically ill patients into intensive care and on artificial life support -- were largely left where they are now, in the hands of doctors and patients.
In what could become a forum for overtly balancing costs and benefits, advocates of managed competition call for a national board that would set guidelines for appropriate care, based on research. But for now at least, such guidelines should not bar beneficial care, Dr. Ellwood said. "I'd like to delay that as long as we possibly can."
Dr. Reinhardt doubts, in any case, that a public body could ever articulate and enforce such explosive trade-offs. 'Do you think there is a political body strong enough to say we are not going to do hip replacement surgery on a 90-year-old man or woman?"
The messier, more realistic way to ration, he said, involves capping the funds available for care, and limiting expensive investments like M.R.I. machines and intensive-care beds. Doctors would have to make new judgments, sometimes subconsciously, in seeking to provide the best care in a setting of limited resources. If there was a waiting list for the M.R.I., the patient with mere headaches would be given reassurance rather than a referral for a scan. If the intensive care unit was overflowing, the cancer patient with few weeks to live anyway would not receive cardiac resuscitation.
Something like this already happens in Canada and Europe, where costly equipment is more restricted. How deeply the rationing would cut into care would be determined by the level of spending, which is higher by far in the United States than in any other country.
In the United States, no one envisions a system that would prevent wealthier individuals from buying extra care with their own money, even if insurers refused to pay.
Dr. Reinhardt's invisible rationing would work best if doctors and patients were in H.M.O.'s, which must work within annual budgets, he said. In fee-for-service medicine, perversely, doctor and hospital both make more money by keeping a doomed patient alive an extra week or two.
"No physician in America would ever say that money even vaguely affected his decisions," Dr. Reinhardt said. "They may never even admit it to themselves."
But eliminating perverse incentives and forcing medicine to operate within clear limits would make a difference, he is sure. "They'll tell the family, 'Look, this just doesn't make sense.' "

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In Aid to Yeltsin, Damage Control for the West

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WEIGHED down by sagging economies and bulging budget deficits, the Western industrial nations have lost some of their ardor about lavishing billions of dollars in aid on Russia. Eager to cut their deficits and put their domestic houses in order, officials from many countries are not exactly doing cartwheels at the prospect of providing Russia with the $30 billion to $40 billion in aid that many experts say Moscow needs this year. The sums being talked about are considerably more than last year's $24 billion aid package.
Though such amounts are large, they could be modest compared to the price that the West would pay if Russia's President Boris N. Yeltsin were ousted and replaced by a hostile, ultra-nationalist regime. Such a government would probably not seek to start a new cold war with the West, but its focus might be on taking back parts or all of some other former Soviet republics, especially areas with large Russian populations. And that alone would be a formula for renewed nuclear threats and renewed tensions with the world's industrialized democracies. 
 A right-wing Russia intent on rebuilding its empire not only might put an end to the cuts in defense spending here and in Western Europe, but might cause Pentagon spending to climb again. "I think we would rethink a lot of the cuts," said Richard Ericson, director of the Harriman Institute, a center at Columbia University that specializes in Russian studies. "And," he added, "we might reconsider putting resources into the Strategic Defense Inititiative," the proposed anti-missile system pushed by President Ronald Reagan
Thanks largely to the end of the cold war, the Clinton Administration has proposed cutting the Pentagon's budget by $88 billion more over four years than President George Bush had proposed. If a reversal in Russia caused the Administration to cancel those cuts, the expense would dwarf the $700 million the Administration plans to spend this year to help Russia. That sum will actually help finance several billion dollars worth of aid, because much of the assistance will take the form of publicly insured export credits..
In short, many Western officials see aid to Mr. Yeltsin as an expensive investment but a wise one, that could help prevent the economically and psychologically costly resumption of a cold war.
Little wonder then that Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said on Friday, after meeting with President Clinton, "Both of us are aware that any type of setback" in Russia "would be more expensive than any type of assistance we are discussing."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
California Environmentalists Cut a Deal, Hope for the Best

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
FOR years environmentalists have fought to save endangered animals and plants with almost religious fervor, waging a war against the forces of nature, developers and governments in which compromise was scorned but victory usually elusive. Now they have begun to make pacts with the devil, and many of them are not sure it will work.
The latest Faustian pact came Thursday when major environmental leaders stepped onto a podium in Washington and shook hands with their devil, the big land developers of Southern California, the folks who -- if they could -- would turn almost every last acre of scrub between Los Angeles and the Mexican border into manicured tracts of fake Spanish-style suburban homes. The matchmaker was Bruce Babbitt, the new Interior Secretary, a former Governor of Arizona and a respected environmentalist himself but a politician who knows the value of compromise. 
 The instrument of this particular pact was a small songbird, the scrub-dwelling California gnatcatcher, a potential spoiler for the developers. As Southern California's voracious human population has swelled to more than 15 million, the gnatcatcher's numbers have dwindled to fewer than 3,000 mating pairs. To environmentalists, the pact represented a means of stopping further development; to the developers it merited no special protection, given how many jobs were at stake and that the gnatcatcher has plenty of cousins in Mexico's Baja California.
But both sides, recognizing political and economic realities, put aside some of their convictions and agreed to enter into a California state-sponsored program, called the Natural Communities Conservation Planning Program, whereby developers and local government would set up a dozen preserves meant to save not only the gnatcatcher, but also its full ecosystem, which is host to 30 or 40 other sensitive species. The catch: the developers get to bulldoze the rest of the coastal sage scrub habitat.
The agreement came just a week before President Clinton's planned journey to Oregon to broker another bitter environmental dispute, over the old-growth forests of the Pacific Northwest. But those forests, and the endangered northern spotted owl that inhabits them, are so far gone that a gnatcatcher-like compromise is not considered a model for saving timber jobs. Rather, the President is considering public works jobs for unemployed loggers and shifting the industry to forests farther east.
But backers of the gnatcatcher compromise used words like "innovative," "milestone" and "unprecedented." In fact, it was only the latest, albeit most ambitious, plan of its type. Known as habitat conservation plans, they have been used in several parts of the country as a means of heading off species-by-species conflicts over endangered plants and animals while allowing a measure of development -- particularly in fast-growing urban areas of the West.
Such plans were originally authorized by amendments to the Federal Endangered Species Act in 1982, and the first was used to save two rare butterflies on San Bruno Mountain, just south of San Francisco. But the pace of activity has picked up markedly over the last few years, in desert areas of California under attack by the metastasis of Los Angeles, in San Diego County, in the Las Vegas area, in central Texas near Austin and in Brevard County, Fla.
 
Most in California
 There are about 60 plans in various stages, mostly in California, taxing the Fish and Wildlife Service's administrative capacity, according to Michael J. Bean, chairman of wildlife programs for the Environmental Defense Fund in Washington. They have come under increasing scrutiny as the Endangered Species Act comes up for renewal in Congress this year amid pressures to find some way to ease its putative dampening effect on jobs and development. Some environmentalists have favored them because they offer the potential of more conservation bang for the buck than the old way: setting aside entire habitats that could preserve several species at once.
But so far it is hard to pronounce major successes. The butterflies on San Bruno Mountain are thriving, but there is much conflict over other plans, particularly over defining the boundaries and rules for development in protected areas of Riverside County, where the Stephens kangaroo rat is endangered.
There are high hopes for the Texas plan, known as the Balcones Canyon Land Conservation Plan, which would set aside up to 29,160 acres of limestone ridges and caves west of Austin, where two songbirds -- the black-capped vireo and the golden-cheeked warbler -- have been listed as endangered. Last August, voters approved a $22 million bond measure to acquire land. If the Fish and Wildlife Service approves, developers would get the green light to develop similar terrain in the area.
 
'A Lot of Reservations'
 "I have a lot of reservations about these plans," said Pamela P. Eaton of the Wilderness Society in Washington. "We have not seen any that are particularly good so far. In many cases that they are starting too late and the flexibility to make these trade-offs with developers are very limited."
The hope here at least is that there is room in the gnatcatcher case for the devil to get his due. It all depends on the details of the preservation plan offered by a special panel appointed by the California Resources Agency due next week. That agency is claiming much of the credit for the new plan, but the same agency two years ago refused to designate the gnatcatcher as endangered under state law; it was only the threat of Federal action that brought the developers to the table with the environmentalists. On Thursday, Secretary Babbitt declared it "threatened" rather than the more serious "endangered," giving the flexibility for the compromise plan.
In concept at least, the gnatcatcher habitat conservation plan is broader and geographically wider than any other such plan in the country, and differs markedly in that it will allow developers to proceed under special interim guidelines while the preserve boundary lines are drawn. "It's all in the follow-through," said John McCaull, California legislative director for the National Audubon Society. Said Ann Notthoff, senior planner with the Natural Resources Defense Council in San Francisco, whose petition for endangered status forced the new compromise: "It's not a foregone conclusion that the developers are not going to get their way."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Environmentalists and developers of Southern California agreed last week to set aside enough crucial land to sustain the scrub-dwelling California gnatcatcher, below, whose habitat includes prime real estate along what is left of the coastal sage scrub, above. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times; Coalition for Habitat Conservation)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); MEXICO (92%);

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
For a Moment, a Senate Majority of Clintonites

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT was only one pace in a long journey. But the Senate's approval on Thursday of the general outline of the Clinton economic program, just 36 days after the President proposed it, left no question that the Government is on its new course.
Taxes are going to rise. The military faces deep spending cuts. And Washington is prepared to spend more in areas that were allowed to languish in the Republican years, areas like education, civilian research and public works projects. 
 Approval of the plan by the House of Representatives the week before last was a nice coup for the President. But the House Democrats started with advantages. They have a large majority, well-disciplined ranks and rules that permit the party leaders to ride roughshod over Republicans and dissidents.
Approval in the Senate, on the other hand, was a milestone. There is hardly a headier lot anywhere than Democratic Senators. Each has an agenda. Many, no doubt, think they and not Bill Clinton should be President. Yet, when the final vote was taken, all but three of the 57 -- all except Bob Krueger of Texas and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, who voted "no," and Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, who was absent -- voted with the President, while all 43 Republicans were against him. Even Lyndon B. Johnson in his heyday did not enjoy such unity in his party.
Mr. Clinton was jubilant. "Finally," he told Senate leaders in a telephone conversation after the vote, "we've done something to break the gridlock."
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, was also elated at the way his troops held ranks, but he cautioned them that "the hard part lies ahead."
The measure the Senators approved, called a budget resolution, is only the first step in the Congressional budget process. It sets overall figures for Government spending and revenues. Over five years, the resolution would raise taxes by a total of about $300 billion and reduce Government spending by about $200 billion. On an annual basis, it would bring the Federal deficit, now about $300 billion, below $200 billion by the fiscal year 1997, the last of Mr. Clinton's term.
But budget resolutions do not make the nitty-gritty determinations about which taxes will be raised and which cut, or about how much money will be spent on which Government programs. The Democrats' discipline will be harder to maintain when the lawmakers have to vote for real, as they did last week in a test vote, on such politically touchy aspects of the Clinton program as his proposal to require middle-income retirees to pay higher taxes on their Social Security benefits.
As a matter of fact, just after the budget vote, when Mr. Clinton's proposal to spend an additional $16 billion over the next two years to stimulate the economy and create jobs came up, the Democratic senators started squabbling.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Center of Gravity Moves West in Canada

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
CANADA'S West Coast has always been an anomaly, an enclave on the other side of the mountains with its own special customs and manners, a place ignored by the rest of the country and seeming to prefer it that way.
Its distance -- three time zones from Ottawa -- and its often eccentric leaders fostered the notion that British Columbia was not to be taken seriously. John Smith, the province's premier from 1872 to 1874, changed his name to Amor de Cosmos because it "tells what I love most: order, beauty, the world, the universe." 
 Now British Columbia -- the size of California, Oregon and Washington combined but with only 3 million people or one-tenth their population -- is shaking off its long insularity and could even become the tail that wags the rest of Canada.
Psychologically, the distance from Ottawa could be dramatically shortened if, as polls suggest, Avril Phaedra Campbell, who adopted the nickname Kim as a 12-year-old Vancouver student, is chosen to become Canada's first woman Prime Minister and its first born and bred on the West Coast.
The cello-playing Defense Minister is the odds-on favorite to succeed Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, who announced last month that he is stepping down in June after eight years in power marked by unpopular economic policies. If confirmed as leader of the Progressive Conservative party at a convention in June, Ms. Campbell, who last week announced her candidacy for the post, would complete Mr. Mulroney's term as Prime Minister and have to call elections before December.
Although the country yet knows little about her ideas for running the Government, she is the new political face from the baby-boomer generation that many Canadians are apparently seeking for their leader. At 46, she is the same age as President Clinton. Last week she told an Ottawa daily that she once smoked marijuana when she was a university student "and I inhaled the smoke." Like Mr. Mulroney, she speaks French. She also speaks Russian.
Her campaign for Tory delegates could stumble before the June party convention, or she could blow the national election. But for now, an Angus Reid/Southam News poll has found that with her leading the party, the Tories would vault to an 18-point lead over the currently front-running Liberals led by Jean Chretien, 59.
Yet even before Ms. Campbell's stock began to rise, British Columbia was doffing some of its Lotusland stereotypes and becoming more assertive on the national scene.
Thanks to its links with the Pacific Rim, its balmy temperatures and a constant influx of new residents from both Asia and the rest of Canada, British Columbia has become the fastest growing of the provinces, both in population and economic output. Last year, as Canada worked to climb out of a long national recession, economic activity spurted 2.4 percent in British Columbia, against less than 1 percent in the nine other provinces and two territories. This largely reflected B.C.'s expanding research and information industries and its rising trade with Asia, which buys more than a third of the province's exports.
The industrial mix is similar to California's. The difference is that British Columbia doesn't have a big defense industry. Defense cutbacks have ravaged California, and thousands are leaving for jobs elsewhere, just the reverse of what's happening up the coast.
B.C. still produces less than Ontario or Quebec, the two biggest provinces, which have heavy manufacturing bases and two-thirds of Canada's 27 million people. But the province's increasing economic clout has inevitably given it a stronger voice.
Vancouver, a snow-capped jewel on the Pacific that is closer to Asia than any other major city in North America, has 1.5 million people, a third of whom are immigrants. Twenty percent of the immigrants are either from China or Hong Kong.
The city, which ranks third in population in Canada after Toronto and Montreal, had its coming out seven years ago when Expo 86 drew 21 million visitors. Next weekend it is scheduled to play host to the summit conference of President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
 
'A Leader, Not a Follower'
 "Historically we were at the back end of the country, where the railroad stopped," said Michael A. Goldberg, dean of commerce and business administration at the University of British Columbia. "Now we're in the middle of the global economy, the same distance from Tokyo as from London. Because the kind of economy that is emerging is so different from what we have enjoyed up to now, we see ourselves as a leader, not a follower."
In the referendum defeat of a proposed constitutional overhaul last year, British Columbia was already playing a leadership role. It was loud on the "no" side, and its commentators, like the Vancouver talk radio host Rafe Mair, helped sway votes in the rest of the country.
The proposed overhaul, known as the Charlottetown Agreement, sought to provide guarantees to Quebec to keep it from bolting from the Canadian federation. British Columbians, who paradoxically share with Quebecers a sense of alienation, declared Quebec's price too high and voted 2-to-1 against the changes, the biggest margin for the "no" side in any province or territory.
Quebecers voted no as well, saying the agreement did not go far enough to meet their autonomy demands.
What especially angered British Columbians was a commitment that Quebec, now representing a quarter of the country's population, would always have a 25 percent vote in Parliament, meaning that British Columbia, as the fastest-growing province, would be shortchanged.
Lorne Seitz, the senior representative of the British Columbia government in Ottawa, said the referendum showed "the feeling that the interests and vision of people on the Western seaboard aren't adequately recognized." With Kim Campbell as Prime Minister, he added, B.C. may begin to be seen as "not just as one of eight other provinces, but on the level and status of Ontario and Quebec in the Canadian federation."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Those High-Tech Jobs Can Cross the Border, Too

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
IN theory, it is an attractive proposition. Mexico, with its low wages, would lure away only the low-skilled, easy-to-do jobs. The complicated, skilled work, requiring more training and education, would remain in the United States, at higher pay. The rub is that Mexicans are quickly learning to do the high-skilled, complicated jobs. Contrary to expectations, those are also being exported.
That is a painful revelation for Americans. South Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Spain, Singapore and Thailand have all demonstrated how rapidly a nation bent on industrialization can master complicated tasks that once seemed reserved for Japan, Germany or the United States. Oceans and tariffs had shielded Americans from the full force of this trend. But now Mexico, just down the highway, is struggling to industrialize. And the North American Free Trade Agreement is about to dismantle what is left of the barriers that protected American jobs. 
 "Ultimately, we will adjust to this transfer of jobs abroad, just as we adjusted to the migration of our farm population to the cities," said Frank Levy, labor economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "But while it is going on, you have to be concerned for the social peace of the country."
The Clinton Administration is just beginning to acknowledge that its principal measure for preserving jobs -- a $37.8 billion outlay over four years for schooling and for endless on-the-job training -- might not be sufficient.
True, American workers gaining skills from education and training will qualify as machinists, mechanics, computer experts, repair people and electricians -- the elite of the manufacturing work force. But over the past decade, the Mexican Government has greatly expanded the education and training of its young people for these same tasks. And when it comes to on-the-job training in Mexico, American companies setting up shop there are finding that it is far less costly than in the United States. The trainees earn only $1 or $2 an hour, a fraction of the wage for a beginner in a factory in the United States and far below the average American manufacturing wage of $11 an hour.
"What we can train here, they can train there for much less money," said Richard Freeman, a Harvard labor economist.
 
A Loss of 8 Million Jobs?

Acknowledging the Mexican competition, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich argued that, quite apart from training, the United States offsets the Mexican job lure in other ways. A growing economy will create a continuing demand for skilled American workers at good wages, he said. What's more, there are advantages for companies remaining at home, among them the extra sales that come from being close to customers and the savings that result from operating in the United States, with its many suppliers and its far better communications and transportation infrastructure than Mexico's.
"History suggests that the number of high-paying jobs increases as the economy expands," Mr. Reich said in a recent interview. "The real question is the dislocations over the short term, and that blow will be softened by the advantages offered by our superior infrastructure and being close to customers."
No one knows how many American jobs could slip away to Mexico as it becomes an ever larger manufacturing center for the United States market. But a conservative estimate offered by labor economists -- a "ballpark figure," as Mr. Levy put it -- is that 7 million to 8 million jobs, or 7 percent of the American work force, are in danger.
These are factory jobs, among the best paid in America. They are held mostly by non-college graduates, but also by some college-educated engineers. They range from the engineers and highly skilled machinists down through maintenance people and computer programmers to assembly line operators. Already, nearly 600,000 jobs have disappeared to Mexico, most of them at the low-skill end of this spectrum.
 
The Challenge of Innovation
 But the maquiladoras, the assembly plants that employ these workers, are slowly becoming automated and much more like standard American factories. More important, state-of-the-art factories are blossoming in Mexico: a Nissan car factory, a Ford engine plant, an A.T. &T. plastic molding operation, an automated Mexican paper mill.
This evolution is hardly a new phenomenon, but in the 1960's and 1970's it proceeded more slowly. Corporations in industrial nations would locate well-established, relatively low-skilled technologies in developing countries -- raw steel production, for example -- but would hesitate to transfer the more difficult technologies and skills involved in manufacturing, say, a transmission or a car engine. "You were not sure these countries were up to such tasks, but now you know they are," Mr. Levy said.
Certainly Mexico is. Harley Shaiken, a labor economist at the University of California at San Diego, asserts that the Japanese could duplicate in Mexico today "the technology and skills at every Japanese factory that was located in the United States over the past decade."
The work force for such factories is lining up in Mexico. More than 145,000 people are being graduated annually from that country's expanding network of publicly funded universities, technical institutes and secondary schools dedicated to preparing young people for skilled jobs.
"They are people who are overqualified for the jobs they now can get," said Hector Nunez Martinez, director of Chihuahua's Institute of Technology, which trains engineers, technicians and the Mexican equivalent of M.B.A.'s. "The supply of skilled workers is still greater than the demand for their skills," he said.
Whatever their skills, they fall short on one very major point. Mexican universities are not research institutes. That is still the preserve of the United States and the other advanced industrial countries. America's researchers and scientists are not yet an endangered species. Similarly, the factories in Mexico -- whether they are Mexican owned or foreign owned -- are not innovators. The machinery and the technologies employed there were first developed in the United States or Europe or Japan. A General Motors Saturn plant, with its innovative techniques, would not be placed first in Mexico, although someday soon such a plant might be copied there.
"We do well if we keep innovating," said Paul Osterman, an expert in job training at M.I.T.'s Sloane School of Management. "Mexico is clearly going to take some jobs away, and we have to come up with a strategy to create new ones."
Innovation is one solution. Upgrading jobs in the huge service sector is another. Retailing, after all, is a captive industry. New Yorkers or Midwesterners might buy products made in Mexico, but they won't shop for them there. But how do you upgrade an auto salesman? "I do not know," Mr. Freeman said. "We have not really thought about this issue."

HEADLINE: LETTER EXPLAINED MOTIVE IN BOMBING, OFFICIALS NOW SAY

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Law-enforcement officials said yesterday that the suspects in the World Trade Center bombing mailed a letter around the time of the attack claiming responsibility and attributing the action to deep resentment against United States policy in the Middle East.
The officials said they had determined late last week that the letter from a group calling itself the Liberation Army Fifth Battalion was authentic and that it provided the first insight into what might have prompted the attack.
 
A Warning
 The letter, mailed to The New York Times and turned over to the authorities, warned of additional actions against American civilian and military targets, including what they described as "Nuclear targets." Such attacks, they said, would be forthcoming unless the United States met a series of demands, including an end to diplomatic relations with Israel and an end to interfering "with any of the Middle East countries interior affairs." 
 The claims and threats were contained in a letter that described deep resentment over United States policies in the Middle East and said that Americans themselves were responsible.
 
'People Must Know'
 "The American people must know, that their civilians who got killed are not better than those who are getting killed by the American weapons and support," said the letter, which was written in occasionally faulty English.
"The American people are responsible for the actions of their government and they must question all of the crimes that their government is committing against other people," it continued. "Or they -- Americans -- will be the targets of our operations that could diminish them."
The letter was delivered to The Times four days after the bombing of the World Trade Center. It was turned over to the New York City Police Department's Chief of Detectives, Joseph R. Borrelli, who immediately passed it on to a Federal and city task force that is investigating the terrorist attack. The task force was meeting in Mr. Borrelli's office when he received the letter.
 
Found to Be 'Authentic'
 Investigators determined that the letter was "authentic" and that it had been prepared by one of the five men now in custody, law-enforcement officials said yesterday. But the officials declined to say precisely how the determination had been made, saying that it could compromise the investigation. They also would not say which of the suspects is believed to have written the document.
The investigators could have reached their conclusions through analysis of the handwritten return address on the envelope, a comparison of the printed text with typewriters or computer printers found in searches of suspects' homes or from comments made by one or more of the suspects. Copies of the letter might also have been found during the searches. A senior investigator said that none of the five arrested suspects had provided information about the others in the group.
"There is no question that the letter was prepared by a member of this cell," a senior investigator said, referring to the five suspects.
The evidence tying the suspect to the letter is "incontrovertible and it's not speculation," the investigator said. "It's the kind of evidence admissible in court."
Another New York City newspaper, which was not identified by investigators, apparently also received a letter from the group.
In the one-page letter, the group said the bombing of the lower Manhattan complex was a response to "the American political, economical and military support to Israel the state of terrorism and to the rest of the dictator countries in the region."
The letter, with a garbled return address in Arabic, demanded that the United States stop "all military, economical and political aids to Israel"; that it end diplomatic relations with Israel, and that it refrain from interference "with any of the Middle East countries interior affairs."
The Feb. 26 bombing, which killed 6 people and injured more than 1,000, has been investigated round the clock by hundreds of Federal and local investigators. Last week, Egyptian authorities turned over to United States officials Mahmud Abohalima, 33, whom investigators have portrayed as a prime suspect in the case.
Government officials in Washington said they had not previously heard of the Liberation Army Fifth Battalion. A private database maintained by the Rand Corporation, a business research group in Santa Monica, Calif., showed no previous indication of the group nor that a group by that name had ever claimed responsibility for a terrorist attack.
In the month since the bombing, the authorities have been able to follow an almost amateur's trail of clues -- telephone calls, a joint bank account, common addresses -- to arrest a small circle of five Middle Eastern immigrants, who all profess their innocence. A sixth suspect is still being sought. But while investigators believe they have found the core group of the conspiracy, until now they had not found any suggestion of the group's thinking or anything tying it directly to Middle Eastern politics.
 
Anger Is Shown
 The letter from the Fifth Battalion Liberation Army, however, clearly links the bombing of the World Trade Center to anger over the United States' support of Israel. Setting out the group's rationale for the explosion, the letter argued that "the terrorism that Israel practices (Which is supported by America) must be faced by a similar one."
It said United States citizens should question the "crimes" their Government is committing against others.
The letter said that the Liberation Army has "more than 150 suicidal soldiers ready to go ahead." It warned that if the group's demands were not met, it "will continue to execute our missions against military and civilian targets" in the United States and abroad. It specifically mentioned "some potential Nuclear targets."
The document also warned the United States to stop supporting secular Arab nations in the Middle East, which it described as "the rest of the dictator countries in the region."
It was unclear whether the writer of the letter was responding to any specific events in Israel or other Middle East countries, or any particular policies. But the overall thrust of the document indicated deep concern over the economic and military aid that the United States provides to Israel and its longstanding role as Israel's sponsor.
The United States also provides almost an equal amount of annual aid to Egypt, whose secular authorities are opposed vehemently by fundamentalist Islamic groups with which the bombing suspects have been associated.
 
Similar Roots
 Two of the suspects arrested and charged in connection with the bombing, Mohammed A. Salameh, 25, and Nidal A. Ayyad, also 25, came from Palestinian families displaced during the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. Mr. Salameh often spoke so passionately and angrily about Israeli policies and the fate of Palestine that a roommate asked him to move from their Jersey City apartment. The roommate, Ashraf Moneeb, said that to force Mr. Salameh to move he falsely told him he was getting married and needed the room.
Another suspect, Bilall Alkaisi, 27, left several addresses with United States immigration officials, claiming to be either from Lebanon or Jordan. The fourth suspect, Mr. Abohalima, was born in a mill town outside Alexandria, Egypt, and the fifth, Ibrahim A. Elgabrowny, 42, was born in Port Said, Egypt. All have said they are innocent of the bombing.
Many of the suspects were also fervent supporters of El Sayyid A. Nosair, who was tried for the assassination of Rabbi Meir Kahane, whose anti-Arab stance was so extreme that his Kach party was banned in Israel as racist. They showed up at Mr. Nosair's trial and have visited him at Attica state prison. Mr. Nosair was acquitted of the murder, but he is serving a maximum of 22 years on assault and weapons-possession convictions stemming from a second shooting just outside the midtown hotel where Mr. Kahane was slain.
