HEADLINE: U.N. Is Developing Control Center to Coordinate Growing Peacekeeping Role

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 27

 BODY:
In a windowless office on the 30th floor of United Nations headquarters here, with maps of Somalia and Mogadishu taped on the walls, an Egyptian major, a Zimbabwean major and a Pakistani captain watch television and wait for the telephone or the fax machine to ring.
They are part of a seven-officer team that keeps in touch with the American-led force in Somalia. But they are also the embryo of the new command and control center the United Nations plans to create here over the next few months to keep headquarters linked day and night with all its peacekeeping operations around the world. 
 There are now 60,000 peacekeepers in the field at an annual cost of some $2.8 billion, carrying out 13 operations stretching from El Salvador to Angola to the former Yugoslavia to Cambodia. And with the Security Council voting Friday to start the largest operation yet, in Somalia, and another huge assignment, in Bosnia, on the horizon, the United Nations is engaged in a sweeping overhaul of how it runs these efforts. The goal is a 24-hour-a-day "war room" and access to intelligence and troops from United Nations members.
The overhaul, long sought by the United States, began several months ago while Marrack Goulding, a former British diplomat, was in charge of peacekeeping. It is gathering pace under his former deputy, Kofi Annan, a 55-year-old Ghanaian who took over the top peacekeeping job at the start of the month. Mr. Goulding now looks after the United Nations' peacemaking efforts in Europe, Asia and the Americas.
 
No More 'Gifted Amateurism'
 "Our operations are now so large and complex that we are redesigning the whole department," said Mr. Annan. "The days of gifted amateurism are over."
In the past, the United Nations has run peacekeeping operations on a shoestring budget, using a handful of officials, most of whom have no military experience. Communications have frequently been poor and intelligence about conditions on the ground sketchy at best.
Now, four major changes are under way:
*The peacekeeping department is being reorganized and given a permanent planning unit to prepare operations.
*The United Nations is negotiating troop standby agreements with countries willing to provide units on short notice for peacekeeping duties. Mr. Annan hopes such commitments will enable him to put an advance guard on the ground within 24 hours of a Security Council decision to start a new operation, and to cut the force build-up time from the current three-to-four months to two months or less.
*An operations center with secure voice and data communication with all the peacekeeping operations around the world is being set up. "The days will soon be over when force commanders ring me up at home during the weekend for instructions and find the phone is busy," Mr. Annan said.
*The United Nations and its field commanders are making arrangements to receive military and political intelligence from the United States and other countries willing to share it. "We have to be careful because the big powers only give us what they want us to know," Mr. Annan said. "But in difficult places like Somalia and Bosnia we need all the intelligence we can gather."
As the United States prepares to hand over the Somalia operation to a United Nations force, it is planning to sell the organization an intelligence system that receives American satellite photos and political analysis. United Nations commanders in Bosnia are also expected to get intelligence from the United States and its allies.
 
The Most Ambitious Efforts
 The changes come at a time when Mr. Annan is preparing to launch the two most ambitious peacekeeping efforts the United Nations has ever attempted: dispatching some 30,000 soldiers and civilians to replace the American-led force in Somalia, and, if a peace agreement is reached in Bosnia, sending 50,000 or more NATO troops there to insure that the warring factions stick to the settlement.
Both operations would break new ground for the United Nations. In Somalia, a United Nations Secretary General will be assuming direct command for the first time in the organization's history of a well-armed force empowered to use force if necessary to carry out relief operations. The Somali factions agreed tonight to disarm and form a transitional government for the country.
"This will be first time the United Nations has had command and control of an enforcement action under Chapter 7 " said Mr. Annan, referring to the portion of the United Nations Charter allowing the Security Council to impose its orders by force.
If the leadership of Bosnia's three warring factions sign a peace agreement, the United Nations will find itself commanding a second enforcement operation. For the peacekeeping army it plans to send there will also be ordered to use force against what Mr. Annan calls "pockets of local resistance and rogue elephant commanders" who refuse to abide by the peace settlement's terms.
While details are not settled, Mr. Annan thinks NATO's southern command probably will be asked to take overall control of United Nations military operations throughout the former Yugoslavia, with Gen. Philippe Morillon of France remaining in command of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Both would report to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and through him to the Security Council.
Both operations would thus differ from the Korean and Persian Gulf conflicts, when the United States was authorized to lead a coalition into war and made key decisions itself. They would also be more comprehensive than in the Congo operation in 1960, when peacekeepers were allowed to use force only to prevent civil war and remove mercenaries.
Mr. Annan's enthusiasm for improving the United Nations peacekeeping operations is no surprise. Only two years ago he proposed what he calls "a modest extension of the United Nations' peacekeeping role," suggesting that the Secretary General send specially trained units of unarmed soldiers from member nations to disaster areas such as Somalia to help distribute relief supplies.
But the idea of giving the United Nations a kind of humanitarian rapid intervention force was killed by Javier Perez de Cuellar, then the Secretary General, who feared governments would see the plan as an infringement of their sovereignty.
 
U.N. Role Is Changing Fast
 These days Mr. Annan, who has degrees in management from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and economics from the Institute des Hautes Etudes Internationales in Geneva, laughs softly when he remembers that initiative. "Just look where we've got to now," he said. "A force of heavily armed soldiers is keeping order and distributing food in Somalia, and another 25,000 armed soldiers are doing similar work in the former Yugoslavia. Who would have believed that two years ago?"
Since then, of course, the collapse of the Soviet Union has freed the Security Council to intervene in disputes around the world and also allowed it to become increasingly intrusive in its handling of civil wars and other disasters. No longer does a hostile Kremlin fearing Western influence invoke the inviolability of national sovereignty as a reason for stopping the Western powers from acting in troubled countries.
Mr. Annan believes the United Nations must become increasingly inventive in designing peacekeeping operations to meet the constantly changing needs of individual crises. "During the cold war days we developed a theology of peacekeeping which was perceived as very successful," he said. "But success breeds its own hubris. We need to expand the range of options so we can deal with new challenges."
The list of countries that may soon need some form of United Nations intervention is also lengthening. Mr. Annan sees two African countries, Rwanda and Liberia, as the most likely candidates for peacekeeping forces after Somalia and Bosnia.
But in a recent article in the journal Foreign Policy, Gerard B. Helman, a former American representative to the United Nations in Geneva, and Steven R. Ratner of the Council on Foreign Relations warned that the United Nations may soon find itself involved with such "failing states" as Ethiopia, Zaire and Georgia.
In addition to the larger changes under way to prepare for such missions, Mr. Annan is doubling his personal staff from 27 to over 50, and he envisions a permanent staff in the "war room" of over 100 officers. He is also considering asking Defense Ministries to send troops on peacekeeping missions as part of their regular training.
As the demand for peacekeeping has grown sharply, the Security Council seems more willing to mount forceful interventions. Mr. Annan sees the trend as reflecting a growing intolerance of despots, wars and disasters and impatience with the idea that national sovereignty is inviolable.
"The Security Council is moving towards greater interventionism because in many tragedies public opinion perceives a human imperative that transcends everything else," he said. "We are using more force because we are encountering more resistance."
 
More Willingness to Use Force
 In a lecture at Oxford University this month, Mr. Annan's predecessor, Under Secretary General Goulding, also noted that the Security Council seems increasingly willing to use force these days. He said one reason is that the Security Council now frequently finds itself dealing with "armed groups outside the control of recognized political authorities with whom the United Nations can conclude the necessary political and practical agreements." Somali warlords and rogue commanders in the Balkans are cases in point.
In Mr. Annan's view, the rising bill for peacekeeping creates a link between his work and Mr. Goulding's new responsibilities as a peacemaker, which involve sending mediators and fact-finding teams to trouble spots in a bid to resolve disputes before they lead to war. "Somalia will cost $1.5 billion a year, Bosnia about $3 billion," Mr. Annan said. That means the world's peacekeeping bill could double this year after increasing fourfold in the last three years. The answer, he said, must be more "preventative diplomacy" aimed at stopping potential conflicts before they erupt into violence.
Mr. Annan, married with three children, has spent his whole career with the United Nations, starting at the World Health Organization in Geneva and rising to head the Office of Program Planning, Budget and Finance in New York before becoming Mr. Goulding's deputy a year ago.
He is also chairman of the board of trustees of the United Nations International School in New York, a job he is having trouble giving up. When he tried to resign last year the trustees invited him to a dinner for a valedictory presentation. But the plaque they gave him thanked him for his work as chairman between 1987 and 1997, implying he has another four years to go.

HEADLINE: USAIR SUPERVISORS FALSIFIED REPAIRS

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
USAir said this week that company supervisors at two airports had falsified records to certify plane repairs when they were not made and that Federal officials were investigating mechanics' accusations of broader abuses.
The company said a USAir maintenance supervisor in Charlotte, N.C., allowed a jet to fly with a defective warning system because he wanted to save the airline money. The company suspended and demoted the employee and said the problem had been eliminated. 
 In Indianapolis, USAir said it had found a "small handful" of similar problems at its maintenance center. Those repairs, it said, involved equipment like water systems that did not affect flight safety.
The airline acknowledged the incidents when questioned by The Associated Press, but described the problem as "confined." Jim Lloyd, the airline's general counsel, said USAir had aggressively investigated all of its maintenance centers over the past six weeks and found no current problems beyond those in Indianapolis.
 
Anonymous Calls
 Mr. Lloyd said investigations by the airline and the Federal Aviation Administration were prompted by anonymous calls by USAir mechanics to the aviation agency.
The mechanics union staged a short, bitter strike against the airline last fall.
The F.A.A. forbidss an airline supervisor to sign off on repairs that are not complete, and instances of such violations are considered very rare, said an agency spokesman, Fred Farrar.
He confirmed that the agency was investigating accusations of maintenance violations in Indianapolis but declined to confirm any other investigations.
Three senior mechanics, who spoke on condition they not be identified, said aviation agency investigators had recently been at Indianapolis, Pittsburgh and Greensboro, N.C. The mechanics said maintenance violations had occurred in all three cities.
In Greensboro, they said, a foreman threatened to punish mechanics if they did not sign off on certain repairs that had not been performed. Mr. Lloyd denied the accusation, saying it was a case of angry mechanics making exaggerated complaints about a young and aggressive foreman.
 
'Cooperating Fully'
 In a statement released Wednesday, USAir said it was "cooperating fully" with the Federal investigation. "At USAir, safety is always the top priority, and the airline stands firmly behind the excellence of its maintenance operation," the statement said.
The mechanics asserted that the maintenance problems arose from middle managers' desire to help cut costs. The mechanics said they had no evidence that the activities were sanctioned by corporate headquarters.
Documents obtained by The Associated Press show that the Charlotte supervisor who was demoted told Federal inspectors that the company's desire to cut costs influenced his decision to let a jet fly with a defective warning system.
The supervisor, Everette B. Tate, said he allowed the Boeing 737 to fly with passengers from Charlotte to Jacksonville, N.C., on March 29, 1992, after mechanics failed to repair the jet's system that warns of danger of an engine stall.
USAir suspended Mr. Tate for 10 days without pay and transferred him permanently to the sheet metal shop. The chief pilot on the flight, William F. Higgs, was suspended for 30 days.
The company said it planned to discipline the two foremen in Indianapolis who signed for repairs that were not done or signed repair records that should have been signed by mechanics under them.
Battered by the weak economy and last summer's fare wars, USAir has lost more than $600 million since 1991. Last week, the Clinton Administration gave British Airways permission to invest $300 million in the company, America's sixth-largest airline.

HEADLINE: Pact to Return Aristide to Haiti Is Called Near

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 27

 BODY:
Backed by strong diplomatic pressure from Washington, United Nations negotiators are close to announcing a settlement of the Haitian crisis that would return the country's exiled President, diplomats familiar with the talks say.
Under the proposed accord a consensus Government would be announced in a few days, and the central power broker of the country since the coup in September 1991, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, would resign as commander of the army. The settlement calls for the return of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in six months. 
 United Nations diplomats are negotiating the choice of a new prime minister who would be a compromise figure between the populist President and members of the deeply conservative economic elite. "The choice of a prime minister is crucial, and they are trying to do it as quickly as possible," said a diplomat who is familiar with the discussions. The list of possibilities has been winnowed down to a handful of names.
Several diplomats familiar with the talks said they had been advanced by strong support from the Clinton Administration for the United Nations initiative and Washington's insistence on Father Aristide's quick return.
On a visit to Haiti last weekend, a special adviser to Mr. Clinton on Haitian affairs, Lawrence Pezzullo, was reported to have bluntly warned the Haitian military and the de facto civilian Government that they had to accept quickly an agreement on Father Aristide's return. Mr. Pezzullo was accompanied by Gen. Jack Sheehan of the Marines, who delivered much the same message in discussions with the Haitian high command. The insistence on rapid movement was repeated this week by Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who said that Washington "would accept no delay" in negotiations for Father Aristide's return.
To help secure broad support for a negotiated solution and insure social peace after a new Government has been set up, diplomats said, a two-day conference on aid to Haiti is scheduled to start on April 6 in Washington.
The Haitian economy, the poorest in the hemisphere, has been shattered by the effects of a hemispherewide economic embargo imposed shortly after the coup against Father Aristide.
Under the emerging settlement the United Nations would play a large role in ending a reign of terror by soldiers in the countryside and, later, preventing revenge attacks by Father Aristide's supporters. A United Nations mission that could grow to 500 people would also oversee the reconstruction of an impartial judiciary and the creation of a professional police force. In recent weeks, 140 human rights observers have been sent to Haiti by the United Nations and the Organization of American States.
Negotiations on the political future of the country resumed on Monday, when a special United Nations envoy to Haiti, Dante Caputo, arrived here. The talks had been stalled for months over the refusal of many in the political elite and military to concede anything more than recognition in principle to the deposed President, whom they insisted had to remain in exile indefinitely. Father Aristide had insisted that General Cedras be exiled or punished for presiding over the coup.
Although other diplomatic initiatives aimed at restoring democracy have appeared to be near success, only to fade, people close to the discussions say Washington's repeated hints of sharply increased pressure and Mr. Clinton's personal interest in the crisis have given the renewed effort much greater chances of success.
"The people here honestly thought that the past Administration was sending mixed signals on Haiti and was willing to wait until 1995 for new elections," a diplomat said here. "Pezzullo and the general told them this time that with Clinton it's serious, and they've been hearing the same message in a thousand other ways, too."
The sense of movement here was shared by Haitians, as well. "The support of the international community has never been so strong as now," an adviser to Father Aristide, Micha Gaillard, said. "We cannot let this opportunity pass."

HEADLINE: Congressional Memo;
No Perk Too Small to Be Overlooked by Rebellious Freshmen

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
It may not be Lexington and Concord or the siege of the Bastille. But on Tuesday, the freshman Democratic rebels in Congress will make their first frontal assault against perks and pork.
At stake is nothing less than the hundreds of free parking spaces at National Airport. 
 The House bank scandal and the growing perception that lawmakers were spoiled by privileges like subsidized meals and haircuts helped produce the largest Congressional turnover in modern times and the expectation of a revolution. In the past few weeks, the 64 Democratic House freshmen have been caucusing feverishly, trying to put together a package of changes they will propose for enactment by the whole House.
If the most rebellious backbenchers get their way, lobbyists, political action committees and dictatorial committee chairmen will be condemned to the dust bin of history.
 
Small Perks at Risk
 But because of divisions in the newcomers' ranks, and the resentment of their elders, little is likely to be swept away beyond such picayune perks as personal use of frequent flier mileage acquired on official trips.
"Reform is one thing," said Representative Jolene Unsoeld, a three-term Democrat from Washington state, "but that doesn't mean you have to take a machine gun and mow it all down."
One proposal on the table would reduce to $50 the $250 annual cap on gifts lawmakers can accept. Another would require stricter accounting on the expenses of lobbyists. And a third would replace the current House schedule, typically a three-day work week, with three five-day work weeks followed by a week off.
Senior members are not exactly trembling, but they are expressing concern. In a meeting with freshman leaders this week, Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington requested that if they must attack the privilege of House members to park at National Airport, they should remember that members of the Senate and Supreme Court get free spots, too.
"The sense was if you take us down, take them all down," said a freshman member who spoke on condition of anonymity.
 
Happy to Get Along
 Actually, most Democratic freshmen have been firing less threatening weaponry. Many fear they could divert momentum away from the Clinton economic program, and several are happy to get along and go along with the leadership.
"It's going to be difficult to reach consensus," said Luis V. Gutierrez of Illinois, a freshman Democrat calling for radical reform. "I will pray, I will keep my fingers crossed, but I will not hold my breath."
To this point, the Democrats have mostly left the heavy lifting to their 47 Republican freshman colleagues. The backbench Republicans have served as the vanguard to cut Congressional spending and extinguish four select committees that do not legislate. Within their party caucus, the Republicans managed to persuade their elders to accept their demand to set term limits for committee ranking members. In an effort to kill pork-barrel politics, they are calling on the House to abolish the Appropriations Committee.
On Thursday, the Republican freshmen held a news conference to demand that Attorney General Janet Reno revoke her request that the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, Jay Stephens, resign along with all other incumbent United States Attorneys. They were taking a cut at Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, who is under investigation by Mr. Stephens.
 
Wants to Clear Air
 "Most of us campaigned to clean up the barn," Representative Bill Baker, a Republican freshman from California, told reporters. "Let's clear the air around Congress."
The Democratic freshmen, many of them experienced in state or city government, generally speak of the institution with more respect. Still, some have also made waves. Representatives Gutierrez and Eric D. Fingerhut of Ohio introduced legislation to freeze member salaries next year, a proposal the leadership quickly embraced as their own and enacted.
Representative Carrie Meek of Florida, the daughter of sharecroppers, and a handful of other black women freshmen, have been raising eyebrows among their elders in the Congressional Black Caucus by meeting themselves to plan revitalizing the mostly moribund group.
 
'A Gardening Exercise'
 Representative Karen Shepherd of Utah, a co-chairwoman of the Democratic freshman task force that is drafting the package, compared her work to "a gardening exercise" of weeding out arcane procedures and wasteful perks. Her pet peeve is the way the House schedules its time, with the constant interruptions of committee hearings and meetings with staff and constituents by repetitive and essentially meaningless votes on procedures. "It's like a floating craps game," she said.
But Ms. Shepherd and other reformers are meeting heavy resistance within their own ranks. Minority members tend to defend the seniority system, as do members from heavily Democratic districts, because they feel they have a chance of becoming chairmen themselves someday. And while most women members are strong advocates for campaign finance reform, most want to protect Emily's List, an organization that helps finance the campaigns of women candidates from new restrictions on political action committees.
Like several minority members of the class, Representative Alcee L. Hastings, a freshman Florida Democrat, views the reform movement with suspicion. "Parking is not a perk," he said. "It's a necessity. I have six of the best minds in America crowded into a cubbyhole that is called an office, and America is led to believe that I'm up here living in the lap of luxury."
The class radicals are still pushing, but they are beginning to see that they are probably on the losing side of the revolution. Reflecting their growing frustration, a caucus meeting of a few of the rowdier freshmen last week deteriorated into talk of taking the law into their own hands: one suggested tearing up the brass railings from the chamber's grand staircases and replacing the marble floors with asbestos to poison royalists. (Conspirators would not reveal the name of the hothead.)

HEADLINE: Making the Easy Military Cuts

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
In unveiling its proposed military budget for 1994, the Pentagon has adopted a holding pattern.
The $263 billion spending request announced by Defense Secretary Les Aspin today did not cancel any major arms programs. Nor does it require any fundamental restructuring. Many spending cuts in the proposed budget have been achieved by accelerating reductions that the Bush Administration had planned for later years. 
 Mr. Aspin acknowledged as much today when he told reporters at a Pentagon briefing that the spending plan was "a holding budget" pending a comprehensive Administration review of military requirements.
"This is a cautious budget on the weapons side -- very cautious," said Mr. Aspin, who added that the Defense Department was essentially "treading water" on buying weapons and research and development.
 
What Direction Next?
 The main question is not so much how the 1994 budget will be received by Congress but where the Pentagon will go from here in refashioning the American military.
Clearly, the proposed 1994 budget is but a small down payment on much greater cuts to come. Even before the election, the Bush Administration was planning to reduce American military spending. The proposed 1994 budget cuts the 1993 spending authority by $10 billion, and the Clinton Administration is planning to cut an additional $88 billion from what the Bush Administration proposed in spending reductions from 1994 through fiscal 1997.
According to current Administration plans, the military budget would drop to $246 billion in 1997 from $273 billion in 1993. Those totals include Pentagon spending authority as well as Energy Department money for developing and handling nuclear weapons.
But though it is a given that the military will shrink, the Clinton Administration is just beginning to grapple with the issue of what it will look like after the reductions are made and what that will mean for the country's international military image.
 
Awaiting Full Review
 In his Pentagon briefing today, Mr. Aspin stressed that the Clinton Administration needed a chance to conduct a comprehensive survey of military needs, an assessment the Pentagon has called the "bottom up review."
The review, which is to be completed by late summer, will consider issues like duplication among the services.
A crucial issue to be settled, Mr. Aspin said today, is how many regional conflicts the United States military needs to be prepared to fight at the same time.
The possibility of simultaneous American military action in trouble spots around the world is not an abstract consideration: the regime of Saddam Hussein is a continual thorn in the side of Washington; there is a possibility of peacekeeping operations in Bosnia; American troops are still in Somalia, and North Korea has decided to withdraw from the nuclear nonproliferation treaty.
Mr. Aspin underscored this point today, noting that with the breakup of the Soviet Union, judgments about regional dangers are what "really shapes and sizes the defense budget."
 
Budget as Driving Force
 Mr. Aspin did not provide any clues today of how the issue might be resolved, saying it would reflect a political assessment by the Administration about trouble spots around the world.
But though the Pentagon has sought to portray the "bottom up review" as one that will be driven by an evaluation of threats around the world, it seems clear that it will also be circumscribed by the budgetary decisions already made.
When President Clinton decided in advance how much money should be cut from the military budget over the next four years, the number of regional wars the Administration thinks the United States military should be able to fight at once may simply be the number the White House decides it can afford to fight.
However the Administration resolves the question of regional conflicts, the review promises to be a contentious process for the military services.
According to the 1994 spending plan, the number of Navy carriers will drop from 14 to 12, but one carrier being eliminated was for training. The number of active Army divisions is to be cut to 12 from 14. The number of Air Force active and reserve fighter wings is to be reduced to 24 from 28.
 
Spending on Training
 But the budget proposal includes a high rate of spending for maintenance and training, including flying time for pilots and steaming time for ships at sea.
"What we are proposing now did not cause any real gnashing of teeth," a senior military official said. "The real fight will come when we try to decide what to do from 1995 to 1999."
By keeping weapon production lines open, the 1994 budget also cushions the economic impact of President Clinton's plan to shift resources from the military to domestic programs, if only for the time being.
Even with many important decisions on hold, the 1994 budget does signal some new points of departure.
The "Star Wars" program has been changed, downgrading space-based defense of the United States while stepping up systems to defend against missile strikes on airfields and troops overseas. And for the first time, a small amount of money has been earmarked for peacekeeping operations as well as efforts to restrain the spread of weapons of mass destruction.
Taking note of these programs, Mr. Aspin proudly proclaimed the 1994 budget "the first truly post-cold-war budget." But military officials and experts on Capitol Hill agree that the toughest decisions lie ahead.

HEADLINE: Mississippi Campaign Reflects the Rights Struggle

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VICKSBURG, Miss., March 26

 BODY:
The special election here next week to fill a vacant Congressional seat has attracted a bevy of Democratic candidates who seem to symbolize the stages and philosophies of three decades of black political evolution in Mississippi.
But three white candidates are also in the eight-way race, and they are emblematic of both the longstanding racial tension within the state's Democratic Party and of the vigorous Republican Party, which has wrested important elected offices away from the Democrats in the last decade. 
 The voting on Tuesday is to fill the seat that opened when Mike Espy was appointed Secretary of Agriculture. Mr. Espy had held the seat since 1986, when he became the first black member of Congress from Mississippi since Reconstruction.
Because so many threads of the state's recent political history are intertwined in this contest, it has become highly volatile, local analysts say, and there is even a possibility that one of the whites might end up representing the state's only Congressional district with a black majority.
 
Runoff Is Expected
 Leslie McLemore, a political scientist at Jackson State University, said it was unlikely that any candidate would win an outright majority. A runoff, if needed, will be held April 13, and Mr. McLemore said he expected it would pit a black Democrat against one of the white candidates. In neither election will the ballot give party labels.
"And because of the animosity generated by this campaign among many on the Democratic side," Mr. McLemore said, "I don't see those finishing lower being enthusiastic about throwing their support behind the black Democrat who does make the runoff."
Although 58 percent of the voting-age population is black, the district has a history of low black voter turnout, he said. That suggests the possibility that Mississippi, with a 35 percent black population over all, could end up with all five of its Representatives white.
The Second Congressional District hugs the Mississippi River and its fertile flood plain for more than 200 miles, encompassing all or part of 24 rural counties, where there is a contrast of wealth and poverty that seems frozen in time from the days when local plantations were worked by slaves and cotton was king. It is one of the poorest Congressional districts in the nation.
 
Time for Victory
 Mr. Espy's 1986 victory came after the Justice Department supervised the redrawing of the district lines and increased the number of black voters in the district, and after another black candidate had, in two unsuccessful runs, helped to build black registration and confidence. After Mr. Espy won, he began reaching out as much to the white landowners and agricultural businesses in the district as he did to the largely poor black majority.
At times he was accused of deserting his core of support, but others applauded him as a coalition builder and an example of the nonracial politics that was needed to improve the state's economy and unify the Democratic Party. While he rarely got more than 20 percent of the white vote in the district, that alone was a significant breakthrough, said Ed Cole, the state's Democratic chairman.
The race to succeed Mr. Espy has attracted, for one, his older brother, Mayor Henry Espy of Clarksdale, who is president of the National Conference of Black Mayors. He is unabashedly running as the brother of the Agriculture Secretary and as someone who has a pipeline to the White House. He campaigns with the same reassuring, coalition-building tones that his brother favored, but the main thrust of his campaign is his connections.
 
Washington Tools
 "A state Mississippi's size with just five Congressmen needs all of the clout it can get," said the 50-year-old Mr. Espy. "My motto is, 'He who has the tools, let him use them.' "
The race has also attracted some names identified with the state's civil rights past, when coalition-building among blacks and whites was rare. There is James H. Meredith, 59, who integrated the University of Mississippi in 1962 but who is not given much chance of winning. There is also Unita Blackwell, the 59-year-old Mayor of tiny Mayersville for 26 years, who is a veteran of civil rights and voting rights drives.
Although Ms. Blackwell is an inspirational figure who is well known nationally, she is not considered politically strong in the district. Still, she has financial backing from Emily's List, which aids female candidates nationally, and her commercials feature the voice of the actor James Earl Jones.
Also running is Bennie Thompson, a 44-year-old Hinds County Supervisor, who is associated with yet another era in the state's political evolution: the effort to consolidate black political power in the years after the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Mr. Thompson, a former Mayor of Bolton, helped organize the state's first association of black mayors and later its first association of black county supervisors. .
 
Past Battles Recalled
 Mr. Thompson has tapped into his background of organization and activism to win support among Democrats in the district, but some people, particularly whites, say his history has made him a reminder of bitter black versus white battles over the years.
"Bennie Thompson is confrontational," said Stephen Golding, a white Vicksburg businessman who held a fund-raising event one night this week for Henry Espy at one of the city's antebellum mansions. "Henry Espy is more of a moderate, more appealing."
The other black candidate is Brian H. Neely, a 32-year-old Democrat and lawyer from Greenville who has not run for elected office before.
Two white Democrats are running. One of them, Dr. Steve Richardson, a 52-year-old Grenada dentist, is broadcasting commercials that show him in his white smock, holding a clump of just-picked cotton and saying, "I want to be your cotton-picking Congressman." The other, State Representative David M. Halbrook, 65, is a 20-year veteran of the State Legislature from Belzoni.
Neither is considered a strong candidate, but their presence on the ballot could draw votes from the remaining white in the race, and the sole Republican, Hayes Dent, a 31-year-old aide to Gov. Kirk Fordice.
 
Unruly Democrats
 Mr. Dent won the right to represent his party in an elimination caucus.
But disputes arose at a similar Democratic caucus, with some of the contenders withdrawing their pledge to support the caucus selection, so that party's field was not narrowed.
Critics of Mr. Dent say he has little in his favor beyond being the sole Republican and the recipient of about $300,000 in contributions, money that might prove crucial in a contest that will turn on how many people vote. In that sense, Mr. Dent said, his main competition is Mr. Thompson, with his extensive contacts and organization.
Mr. Dent does not buy the argument that the Second District should be represented by a black. The real issue, he said, was getting people to work together, "and I don't think it matters whether you are black or white to do that."

HEADLINE: The Architecture of Those Called Homeless

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

 BODY:
Pepe Otero's place evolved slowly, as so many building projects do.
It began as a rudimentary shell made from skids, the wood platforms used for delivery of heavy goods that have become the makeshift building blocks of the street. Time passed. And in a grim symbol of the seeming permanence of his situation, Mr. Otero's shell grew. 
 Mr. Otero's quarters, in one of Manhattan's poorest neighborhoods, represents a kind of architecture of the dispossessed in New York City. Tucked into the city's most forlorn corners and tenuously echoing a remembered idea of home, these illegal structures are inadequate, but increasingly elaborate, self-made alternatives to the city's shelter system.
For thousands of people living on the streets, such fragile dwellings, now being chronicled in museum exhibitions, are a last-ditch effort to carve out a precious, brittle piece of privacy on inhospitable urban turf.
 
A Shadow of a Home
 Like those of his dozen or so neighbors on a formerly vacant lot on the Lower East Side, Mr. Otero's shell has taken on the illusion of home. White bedposts and perforated orange bread crates form an entrance gate; plexiglass and refrigerator shelving set into diamond-shaped frames form windows. Mr. Otero, who is admired locally for his handiwork, has even built a marquesina, or portico, over the front walk.
"I had plenty of time," Mr. Otero, 67, explained recently, sitting in a small room filled with the smell of kerosene that he was burning against the cold. "I had to live someplace."
No one knows their numbers, which fluctuate with the thermometer, night by night and day by day. But in cities across the country, the growing ranks of homeless people and the overburdening of shelter systems have resulted in an increasing number of street builders like Mr. Otero.
They are among New York City's most vulnerable citizens. The weather this winter has been particularly grueling for those trying to build precarious dwellings in the city's shadow places: beneath highways, on piers, amid garbage in vacant lots.
The resemblances to home are superficial, bitterly so. Mr. Otero is living in conditions commonly associated with third-world countries. He has no plumbing or heating. He bathes in a pail of water hauled from a nearby fire hydrant and heated over a gas burner. His toilet is a white plastic bucket lined with a garbage bag, tucked inconspicuously into a corner and emptied twice a day.
 
The Metaphors
'The Architecture Of Despair'
 Margaret Morton, a New York photographer and an associate professor at the Cooper Union School of Art who has spent three and a half years documenting these structures, including Mr. Otero's, said they represented "the architecture of despair." To her, they reflect "the profound need to create a sense of home, no matter how extreme the circumstances."
Advocates for the homeless say the numbers of such shanties are growing nationally, a physical reflection, like the Hoovervilles of the 1930's, of an intractable social problem.
Mary Brosnahan, the executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless in New York City, said that of the 90,000 people her organization estimates to be homeless in the city, about 15,000 have rigged makeshift structures for themselves.
The street builders of New York City, she said, are fiercely independent and overwhelmingly male. "They are the ones who have a working knowledge of building," she said. "They are also familiar with the laws of the street and can protect their areas from predators."
To John Michael Vlach, the chairman of the American studies department at George Washington University, such bleak icons of domesticity have come to make up a "landscape of the powerless." But he said the transformation of anonymous, often harrowing urban spaces into personal ones, with no resources and against all odds, was a form of self-empowerment that went beyond basic survival.
"People make spaces to maintain their sanity," he said, "no matter where they are."
 
The Building Process
Found Objects, Fond Memories
 "This is not a house," said Thomas Davis, who lives under the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive along the East River in a plywood frame insulated with cardboard, to which he has meticulously added a mailbox, a roped-off deck, a fish-shaped wind gauge and -- most notably -- wheels.
"It's a refuge from the elements," he said. "A shack. A box."
Creating a street structure is "a survival situation," Mr. Davis said, adding, "You improvise."
One day, he said, he was taking apart automobile parts when he noticed the radiator fan and thought, "Maybe I could use this for something." Mr. Davis remembered a whirligig he had seen as a child in a springtime flower bed. "The wings would be moving," he recalled.
The sight of blimps floating above the East River and people fishing in summertime gave him the idea of building a "flying fish in the wind."
To the uninitiated, who often view them from moving vehicles, structures like Mr. Davis's don't look like living quarters. "They are looked on as a dump spot, an eyesore," Douglas Anderson, 32, said one frigid morning, as embers from the skids he was burning for warmth in an oil drum turned to ash in the wind. "But if you saw this place up close, you would see it's a home, with a personal touch."
 
Repelling Rain and Rats
 It took him more than two months and "nails, hammers and manpower" to put up his structure, a plywood frame with a pitched roof covered by a tarp "so the rain runs right off." The bottom is lined with scavenged Formica panels, prized by street builders because they repel rats and water. He arranged an outdoor sitting area out of weatherworn office chairs found in trash bins, tacking a faded Oriental rug to the wall behind them.
"You should try to think you're living indoors as much as you can," he said. "If you've got to live out here, you want it to be comfortable, to do the best you can. If you wander around thinking, 'My God, I'm homeless,' you're finished."
Maria Foscarinis, the director of the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty in Washington, said the structures were growing in number as homelessness increased nationally. "Homeless people are relying on their own resourcefulness to address a problem that is not being adequately addressed by society," she said. "These are measures intended to be temporary that are now becoming permanent."
 
The Chroniclers
What Academics And Cameras See
 A palpable yearning for permanence pervades both the structures and Ms. Morton's photographs of them, which are the subject of exhibitions at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in Manhattan and the NAME Gallery in Chicago, as well as "Transitory Gardens," a book that Ms. Morton wrote with Diana Balmori, a landscape historian; it is to be published this year by Yale University Press.
Ms. Morton noted that the structures, which their builders often refer to as "my place," tend to change seasonally and are continually being improved, sometimes to reflect the homelands of those who live in them.
Mr. Otero, for example, came to New York from Puerto Rico to seek employment as a typesetter and wound up with a job fixing lamps. Unable to make ends meet, he gave up his rented room and moved to Tompkins Square Park in early 1990, preferring his own shelter to one with a squalid shared bathroom.
That summer, Mr. Otero began building his structure in a nearby settlement that is known by its occupants as "Bushville," erecting an umbrella for shade and adding an open porch with a turquoise-and-white striped canopy. In November of the next year, he enclosed the porch. Last spring, he began extending the roof. His construction ideas come "from here," he said, pointing to his head.
Over time, encampments like Bushville, with its public walkways lined with skids and touches of ornament, form "unknown cities within the city," in the words of Richard Sennett, a professor of humanities at New York University. "The foundation of self-respect in our society is not having cash, but a place to live," he said, adding that the structures "are inexpressibly sad symbols of the way society has abandoned them."
 
The Government View
There's No Code For Wiring Shacks
 A piece of plywood tacked with cardboard, or a frayed strip of carpet placed outside to define a front yard, is homelessness made visible. "This isn't housing," said Marsha Martin, the director of the Mayor's Office on Homelessness and Single Room Occupancy Housing Services. "There is no standard to evaluate a Sterno can in a cardboard box."
Michael Kharfen, head of the Mayor's Community Assistance Unit, said many street builders represented the "hard-core homeless population" of New York City. Many are drug or alcohol abusers, he added. The city's concern over the encampments, the target of periodic removals, or "sweeps," has focused on health and safety issues, he said, particularly the use of kerosene and other flammable materials to generate heat.
The encampments typically exist on marginal property on the periphery of the urban mainstream. Ms. Martin pointed out that in a legal sense, the structures are not buildings and are thus not monitored by the City Building Department. If a safety or health or sanitation concern arises, or if threatening conduct occurs in the street, the city will consider intervention case by case, she said.
Since Ms. Morton began photographing the structures, five of her subjects have died. One, Yi Poi Lee, was killed. Mr. Lee, who lived in a hut bound together by yellow cloth tied in knots -- no nails were used -- died last spring when arsonists set fire to "The Hill," an encampment at the foot of the Manhattan Bridge in Chinatown. So he would not be buried in Potter's Field, Ms. Morton and a colleague organized the funeral.
 
The Quest for a Haven
Ever So Humble, But It's Private
 Security is a big concern among street builders. A reason commonly cited by homeless people for rejecting the city's shelter system is a lack of security. Settlements like Mr. Otero's, ad hoc though they be, are arranged to foster security, often with a "day watchman" standing guard.
But the big reason people build may be more compelling. However fragile, the presence of four walls "affords them the same security and sense of privacy that our homes afford us," Ms. Brosnahan said.
"It's a place to cook, a place where friends can visit and lovers can stay overnight," she said. "It is a rejection of the institution of the shelters, where your soul is checked at the door."
She added that the structures held a message for those planning future housing for the homeless. "At the bare minimum," she said, "we're talking about a small, secure room with a door that locks."
 
The Worldwide Problem
 Amos Rapoport, a professor of architecture at the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee, said "spontaneous settlements" built by homeless people, like Bushville in New York and the Mud Flats in Miami, suggest the "no-tech" shanty settlements throughout the third world: the hillside favelas of Rio de Janeiro, the villas miserias of Argentina, the barrios clandestinos of Colombia, the gecekondus of Ankara, Turkey, and the bamboo riverside huts near the mouth of the Ganges in Dhaka, Bangladesh.
Such settlements, whose hallmarks are often bits of flattened cardboard and corrugated metal roofs weighed down by rocks, have resulted largely from the rural displacement and rapid urbanization that followed World War II, he said.
Among all displaced builders, "the sense of control is important," he said, adding: "Even if conditions are worse than a city shelter, they have still made choices regarding their environment."
 
The Implacable Weather
 In the northeaster in December, Mr. Anderson was trapped inside his structure and had to break through a wall to escape flooding. Most of his belongings were swept away. He briefly went to a shelter, but, he said, "I didn't feel comfortable with it: too many different personalities."
He said with some pride that the northeaster had not destroyed the structure itself, unlike "those houses in New Jersey" that appeared on the news. Still, nature's wrath took a toll. "If you could have seen this place before that, you would have liked what you saw," he said. "There were no cracks. All this wood was meshed together. It was looking real good."
Mr. Anderson said he grew up in East New York, Brooklyn. The house he lived in as a young child burned down. The things he remembers most about it are the long kitchen table, where the family could be together, and the fact that to enter, "you stuck a key in the door."
He is now unemployed, and he vacated the $120-a-week room he had rented with money from a temporary job, because of "the overhead."
 
Across a Street, Out of Reach
 He is realistic about his present living situation. "That," he said, pointing to a brick apartment building across the street, "is definitely better than this. Everyone should have some decent roof overhead. We're all entitled to that."
He sometimes thinks about what a real house would be like. "At night, you'd see the stars," he said, "and during the day, the light would just flood the room."
But he feels good about the structure he built, which he considers a "launch point."
"Everything we needed, we solved," he said of the community that he and his neighbors have built and that Ms. Morton has recorded. He is proud of Mr. Davis and his flying fish. "We call his place Little House on the Prairie," Mr. Anderson said. "He's so good you can't walk past his place without saying, 'Wow!' "
"You know something?" he continued, pressed about his own dwelling. "It took character to build that. A lot of feeling went into it. Building it shaped my attitude. You realize you can do things for yourself. People who build for themselves have an interest in themselves. As long as you don't forget, you're not forgotten."
Mr. Anderson knows what a home is. "A home," he said, "is the idea of who you are."

HEADLINE: Heavy Turnout in Bridgeport for a Casino's 'Job Fair'

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, March 27

 BODY:
Hundreds of unemployed workers flocked to an all-day "job fair" in Connecticut's largest and poorest city today to find out about a campaign by Mirage Resorts, which is trying to gain support to build casinos in Bridgeport and Hartford.
More than 1,000 people entered the Cardinal Sheehan Center on Main Street within the first hour, and more than 5,000 were expected by the end of the day. 
 Two large television screens were set up at the fair, with public relations videos depicting the success of Mirage in Las Vegas and describing how it might work here. Forty Mirage employees walked around with buttons that read, "Ask Me About Jobs and We Will Help Train You."
Most job-seekers appeared to leave the event today strongly supporting the construction of casinos and said they would be asking their legislators to push for approval. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has opposed further expansion of gambling in the state and has promised to veto any bill approved by the Legislature because he believes it would cause social harm.
But those at the job fair said the Governor should reconsider. "Is he going to give me a job?" asked Kenneth Pellicci, a 44-year-old unemployed construction worker from Trumbull with a wife and three children. "If not then I think he should look at this again. I think this is a fantastic idea, it's the first time in months that I have any hope there may be a job for me."
Mr. Pellicci said he hasn't had any luck finding a permanent job since the Bridgeport construction company where he worked for 10 years went out of business two years ago.
Denne Epps, a 38-year-old mother of three, said she's been on welfare for more than 10 years and went to the job fair because she was desperate. "I need a job real bad," she said, "but there's no jobs in Bridgeport at all. I think this could be good for a lot of people like me who have been out of work a long time."
Luis Gomez, a 36-year-old Bridgeport restaurant worker, said he went to the job fair because he has been without a job for six months and that has taken a big toll on his wife and three children.
What Mirage is promising to do is create 22,000 jobs in Connecticut by investing $350 million in what it calls urban entertainment centers, which would include casinos, hotels, restaurants, movie theaters, bowling alleys, skating rinks and convention centers.
"If you asked me about this six months ago I would have said it was doubtful we would ever be supporting this kind of proposal," said Paul S. Timpanelli, president and chief executive officer of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council, which represents more than 1,300 businesses.

HEADLINE: Pollution Costs Torment a Town Already Reeling

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: THOMASTON, Conn.

 BODY:
It is not enough that the old mills along the Naugatuck River here are fading, and that unemployment in this Litchfield County town stands at 14.1 percent, the highest in Connecticut.
No, amid hard times, a raft of environmental problems have come along. Sewerage. Landfills. Even the water supply. It sometimes feels as if Thomaston is wearing out. 
 "You just don't know how much more of this a town can take," said Michael D. Rybak, the town's lawyer. "And you're going to have these problems. The town is probably a minefield of environmental problems if you want to go drilling over every square foot of it."
For residents, the recession is the greatest concern, the one they cannot help thinking and worrying about. But the other problems, they know, all translate into money, and they wonder where the state agencies that enforce environmental laws think Thomaston will get the money.
"They're more worried about paying for it," Brian Dayton, co-owner of Red's Hardware, said of residents' concerns. "The state mandates all these things, and then it doesn't help the town out."
 
Waiting in Line for Help
 The First Selectman, Eugene McMahon, has asked the state for help, putting his town of 7,000 people, a slice of apple-pie America with an opera house dominating Main Street, in line for aid behind better-known distressed cities like Bridgeport.
But he knows how Thomaston is likely to get the money to fix its environmental problems: by borrowing. "I don't want the town living on plastic for the next 25 years, but I don't know any other way around it," he said.
Water is the common element here, fittingly enough for a mill town that owes its life to the river rushing through it. The clockmaker Seth Thomas built a factory on the banks of the Naugatuck in 1813, and over the years more mills and a growing town crowded into the narrow, pretty valley.
Almost everything essential to Thomaston could be found by the river: the old brass mills and the new tool-and-die shops that employed residents, and the town dump and sewage-treatment plant that cleaned up after them. For decades the Naugatuck was an industrial sewer.
 
Cleaning Up the River
 The state, enforcing the Clean Water Act, now insists that Thomaston and other towns upgrade their sewage-treatment plants. The goal: reopening the river to fishing and swimming. Thomaston's cost: $14 million, or $2,000 a person.
In 1983, also at the state's urging, Thomaston closed its landfill and took its garbage to state-approved ones in Beacon Falls and Naugatuck. A few years later the state closed those, saying they were polluting the river.
Now big corporations, including Uniroyal Chemical and B. F. Goodrich, are suing Thomaston and other towns to help them pay for the $70 million Superfund cleanup of the landfills.
Then last November, the Connecticut Water Company shut down its three wells in Thomaston. The wells, which serve most of the town, were threatened with contamination from gasoline, the company said. The source: fuel tanks at the town garage.
The water company said it planned to recover its costs, including $1,000 a day to buy replacement water, from the polluter. It estimated the potential cost at $2.5 million.
 
'All Coming Down on Us'
 "It just seems to be all coming down on us at once here," Mr. McMahon said.
Bad luck plays a part. Thomaston officials say the leaking gasoline came not from the town's tanks, but from earlier tanks owned by a fuel vendor. In other cases, they say the town is being penalized for following the state's rules. Thomaston did what the state told it to do about its landfill, and is now stuck in a Superfund lawsuit.
Town officials support cleaning up the Naugatuck River, but right next to their sewage-treatment plant is a hazardous-waste processing company, Envirite, that was brought to Thomaston by state officials.
Before Envirite shut down, its activities ensnared the town's plant in Federal regulations, polluted its land and cost it $429,000 in legal and consultant fees and other expenses.
Douglas Cutler, an under secretary in the State Office of Policy and Management, is arranging a meeting between officials from Thomaston and the state's Department of Environmental Protection.
 
'All These Other Things'
 A former first selectman, Mr. Cutler says he has never seen such an array of environmental problems facing a single small town. And then there are the town's economic problems. "Everyone knows about the Superfund case," he said, "but here they have all these other things."
Two factories closed last year, and Plume & Atwood, a mill founded by Seth Thomas in 1852, has laid off most of its workers.
"I remember when we first opened, that mill was going three shifts," said Cathy Russ, whose family has owned the Vi-Arms Restaurant on Main Street since 1963.
Now, she said, "You work in the bar, and every day someone will come in and say, 'Well, I just got laid off,' or 'I just closed my shop,' or 'I've got two more unemployment checks left.' It's so disheartening. They look and they look and there's nothing there."
Thomaston natives like Mr. McMahon vow that these hard times will pass as employers discover the attractions of a small town with skilled workers who hold to small-town virtues. They point to the old clock factory on South Main Street, nearly empty in the mid-1980's, now filled with small businesses from metal finishers to antiques shops.
 
Watching How Money Is Spent
 Meanwhile, every dollar counts, and in small towns the people whose property taxes provide those dollars can easily see how they are spent. Mr. Rybak regrets the legal fees -- the Superfund suit has cost $54,000 for lawyers so far, including $33,000 for a specialist in Washington -- but other things stir resentment, too.
In February, three students embarrassed Thomaston by breaking into the high school to steal a test. Besides the bad publicity, some residents resent having to spend $3,000 to repair and change the school's locks.
Teachers are also suspect. The state's mandates and binding-arbitration system have raised their salaries, making them an economic elite in blue-collar towns like Thomaston. Factory workers who might get two weeks of vacation, if they had a job, can't help matching the teachers' $50,000 salaries against the 180-day school year.
"There's a lot of stress," said Henry S. Osowiecki Jr., a building contractor whose work force stands at 6, down from 24 a few years ago. "Not only do we feel it," he said, "but we can see it, we read it, and now we can taste it."

HEADLINE: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WEST;
Chaney Looks Just Horrible, He Feels Worse, but Loves It

BYLINE: By TOM FRIEND, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 27

 BODY:
John Chaney's larynx is so overused, his voice is alternately hoarse and soprano. But not even the din of a large Kingdome crowd can drown him out.
Late Friday night against Vanderbilt here, the knot on Chaney's tie was loosened to midchest, the pants around his waist needed hitching or a tighter belt and his Temple Owls were skittishly ahead, 62-59, with 14.1 seconds left. 
 A Temple freshman center, Derrick Battie, had two free throws coming and, inconveniently, the power to alter Chaney's life. Chaney had two choices: hoarse or soprano.
"Of course I yelled at the kid before he took the shots," Chaney said later, with big eyes. "I was screaming at him, 'Time to grow up. Time to grow up.' "
 
Curtain Call for Cosby
 Battie's free throws dropped, Temple won by 67-59, and Chaney is now one victory from reaching his first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament Final Four. The same disheveled necktie he wore Friday night he will wear again Sunday for the West Regional Final against No. 1 seeded Michigan -- "Superstitious, buddy," he said -- and he will bring alumnus Bill Cosby again, too.
Chaney and Cosby are predictably the team's two role models. Chaney wakes up his players each morning for practice at 5 o'clock, ushers the underachieving ones to class, calls referees "the law" and is living proof that a one-time bow-tied, cafeteria bus boy -- whose Jacksonville, Fla., home would flood after only an hour of rain -- can amount to something. Cosby has an equivalent story, publicized 10 times over, though Cosby admiringly returns to North Philadelphia and relates it to the team personally.
Cosby insists that Owl players call him "Bill," and he flew in for Friday's game wearing an "Owl Club" blazer and cherry-colored alumni suspenders.
 
'A Boy's Man'
 "I went to that school," Cosby said late Friday night, "and we're more about Philadelphia than most schools there. We have people who are lower, middle economic, but not lower education or lower intelligence. We're on the subway train to take clases, and we have cab drivers taking classes. We have people who already have jobs at what they're getting their degrees in.
"And that John Chaney, he is a boy's man. For many of these kids, coming into college is a real shock to their system. They need a disciplinarian, and that's why John'll practice at 6 in the morning. The first thing they see is their father -- the boy's man."
If Chaney, now 60, likes you, he will chastise you. At today's news conference, he called two of his starters -- forward Aaron McKie and guard Rick Brunson -- "the worst defensive players I've ever had" to their faces. It was only a half-serious jab, but also meant to galvanize them subtly for Sunday.
Chaney has been destitute enough that he can relate to the plights of his players. His two premier scorers on this year's team, McKie and Eddie Jones, were Proposition 48 casualties: ineligible as freshman because they did not maintain 2.0 grade point averages and score 700 on their Scholastic Aptitude Tests. Each scrounged up loans to pay for their initial year of school, and Jones said today, "Aaron and I sat in the stands for their N.C.A.A. tournament game that year against Georgia Tech, and almost cried. We at least wanted to be on the bench."
 
Sometimes Under Scrutiny
 Chaney accepts Proposition 48 players for the sake of giving them an ample chance in life. On the down side, he is scrutinized for it, and often maligned -- as when senior center Frazier Johnson flunked off the team in January or when freshman William Cunningham was arrested for an alleged carjacking incident in October. He still plays while awaiting a May trial.
In that sense, this team's ascension is gratifying to Chaney. Temple, on Feb. 7, was lambasted at home by Wake Forest, 106-69, and its record was once a mundane 10-10. Chaney gives away his neckties after defeats -- one Philadelphia writer now owns five of them -- and the Owls' losing streak had Chaney running daily to the store to buy new, striped ones. Moreover, senior guard Vic Carstarphen was out with a broken leg, which meant Temple's top nine players were two juniors, Jones and McKie, sophomore Brunson and six freshmen.
But Chaney did not put restraints on his offense and who ordered up a hyper, matchup zone on defense. The Owls won 10 of their last 12 games, and Jones, who notched 26 points against Vanderbilt, is improved and unafraid of Michigan's sneering Chris Webber. "The two teams I wouldn't want to play is Princeton and Temple," Webber said, wary of Chaney's so-called "amoeba" defense.
Webber also said today the Wolverines -- who defeated Temple by 7 in last year's N.C.A.A. tournament first round -- "looked like a bunch of junior high school kids the other night" against George Washington. Michigan, unless it upgrades, might well be vulnerable Sunday.
"I gave my Temple guys a good line tonight," Cosby said Friday."I said, "A wolverine has to come out of a hole. But an owl sits in a tree waitin' for them.' They liked that."

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
A Test You're Apt to Flunk

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN

 BODY:
Here's a quiz for industrial policy buffs: Which of the following products and production processes discovered in the last 35 years produced the biggest economic gains?
A computer control system? An electronic device for using videotape? A new type of primary metal? A process for producing aromatic chemicals? A new stain remover? A household cleaning device? A new type of thread? 
 If you picked the high-tech innovations -- computers, electronics and science-intensive production processes -- you are fashionably wrong. The right answer, according to Prof. Edwin Mansfield of the University of Pennsylvania, is low-tech: new thread and stain removers. By driving down prices of consumer goods, these innovations raised living standards for millions of Americans.
Dr. Mansfield's research serves as a sober warning to industrial policy enthusiasts, including President Clinton. Who sitting in Washington circa 1960 would have had the foresight, and guts, to propose spending taxpayer money to discover a better thread for sewing kids' jeans?
Mr. Clinton is on safe ground when he proposes across-the-board subsidies for research and development. Studies by Dr. Mansfield and others show that such investments -- by raising workplace productivity -- often throw off big gains to society. The trickier question is whether Washington ought to target specific industries or projects.
At the core of industrial policy proposals is the idea that there are investments that produce huge benefits for society but aren't undertaken because they generate only meager profit for the private investor. This happens, for example, when investors discover a product that is easily imitated; the initial investor reaps little profit even though the product proves to be a smashing success with consumers. If the Government could predict these cases, it could provide subsidies -- tipping the entrepreneur toward undertaking the investment.
But, as Dr. Mansfield's research suggests, there's little reason to believe Washington will be able to make accurate predictions. The high-tech investments in computer control systems and machine tool production did well; but investments in mundane consumer products did much better -- raising annual output in the overall economy by as much as three times the size of the original investment.
Mr. Clinton's idea that jump-starting high-tech investments will reverse the productivity slowdown is unproven. But it need not be discarded. What if Washington created a small fund -- perhaps a few billion dollars a year -- from which would-be investors could seek help for promising projects too risky for them to undertake on their own?
Sure, much of the money would probably go for naught as Washington picked the wrong projects or the process became corrupted by politics. But there's also a chance that the policy could turn up the next-generation computer chip -- an intoxicating possibility. As long as the program is kept small, it will leave plenty of money in private capital markets to bring Americans most of the 21st-century thread and stain-free clothes they crave.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Japan, Or So It Seems

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
From the aggressiveness of businessmen here, you'd never guess that Japanese politicians and officials have few competitors in the art of being laid-back and hardly worrying about anything, or so it seems.
North Korea, no friend of Tokyo, is building a nuclear bomb. China, Japan's historical nemesis, is booming and will revolutionize Asia's strategic landscape. Russia, a major counterweight to Beijing, is imploding, adding to the specter of a future Chinese colossus. And the Clinton Administration is beating Tokyo over the head about reducing its trade surplus with the U.S. and donating billions in new aid to the Russians. 
 Big matters all, yet most Japanese leaders say that everything is just fine. To them, there's practically no foreign policy crisis that can't be fixed in 5 to 10 years of quiet diplomacy.
The Chinese, so the Japanese tell me, are now great guys and will take care of the North Korean nukes. Bill Clinton is a great guy and will be even greater after he learns about Japan's open markets and grows older. And "Mr. Gelb, you are a great columnist, famous for your knowledge and insight." They also revere my age compared with Mr. Clinton's.
I think the Japanese are great, too. And I tell them I'm planning on moving here to hear more about how much they like my column.
All my conversations with officials in Tokyo were off the record, so I can't share much more inside information.
But since the economy is not off the record, I can inform you that the Japanese are definitely not mellow on that subject. Japan Inc. is in a recession, and the Government is trying to pump-prime it with tax breaks and public works projects, so far without clear success.
If pump-priming peters out, the Japanese might actually do the unthinkable and reform their rotting, stalemated political system. Serious reform isn't likely in this don't-rock-the-boat land. But for the first time since Douglas MacArthur set Japan on the road to democracy, it is possible. The ruling Liberal Democratic Party must be worried about that, and about losing power, but its actions betray no panic. L.D.P. leaders seem to think that if they can get the economy back on track, all will be well.
This time, however, their calculations may be off, because the public is outraged at recent revelations of corruption. For one, the authorities raided the home of Shin Kanemaru, the L.D.P.'s Mr. Fix-It, and found $50 million in unreported cash and 250 pounds of gold bars. For another, public prosecutors just found that construction companies have been providing handsome bribes to L.D.P. bosses for years. To the amusement of Japanese wags, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa wasn't considered powerful enough to be on the "Special A" list of recipients.
Mr. Miyazawa is very much in the mold of L.D.P. prime ministers -- dubious about being able to change much of anything, a roller with the punches of life, philosophically passive.
This passivity is at the very core of Japanese foreign policy. They even have a word for it -- gaiatsu. It means "waiting for foreign pressure and using it to overcome domestic resistance to needed policies." Put another way, it's like dousing yourself with gasoline, tossing a match to a friend, and saying, "The devil made me do good."
Gaiatsu is no way for a great nation like this one to run a foreign policy. It absolves Japan of responsibility and hands it all to others, particularly America.
Japanese officials say they want a new "global partnership" with the U.S., and the Clinton Administration is eager to oblige. It will keep squeezing on economics, but will also support Tokyo's quest for permanent membership in the U.N. Security Council and, in the meantime, consult with Tokyo as if it were a full member.
No one knows the problems with gaiatsu better than the Japanese. They realize they got little credit for the $12 billion they contributed to the Persian Gulf war because it was pulled out of them. And they see the same reaction coming if they don't step forward on their own with aid to Russia.
Nobody likes being a nag. And Japan, a great power facing historic choices and challenges -- whether or not the Japanese acknowledge them to a foreigner -- shouldn't wait to be nagged. Or so it seems.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Workers Need Place in the Economic Sun Again;
The Company Store

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The prescription of Richard B. Freeman and Joel Rogers for saving the labor movement (Op-Ed, March 10) would wind up killing it. They advocate that Federal law banning company unions be modified to permit employers to set up so-called "employee participation committees," which would "not engage in traditional collective bargaining over wages, hours and benefits," but "would have enforceable rights to information and consultation with management over labor policies." 
 This program overlooks a simple truth, embodied for nearly 60 years in our Federal labor law, that worker participation without worker power neither protects workers nor serves the country's good.
In the 1920's, company unionism was a significant force for preventing the growth of real unionism. Advocates of the so-called American Plan encouraged employers to set up phony organizations that gave workers the illusion of having a union, but that remained under the control of the employer. When the great wave of unionization swept through American factories and offices in the 1930's, with few exceptions, company unions had to be destroyed to allow formation of real, independent unions. The 1935 National Labor Relations Act therefore outlawed company unions.
Since then, that law has too often been amended by Congress or reinterpreted by the Labor Board and the courts in a way that eliminates worker rights by curbing union power. But the law's ban on company unions is untouched. It is ironic for Mr. Freeman and Mr. Rogers to advocate "labor law reform" be carried out in one of the few areas that still meet the act's original promise, guaranteeing workers the right to have free and independent unions of their choice.
Much needs to be done to restore the law's great promise. The problems facing labor and the country are not what they were 60 years ago. But we should not be blind to history and its lessons. We need true worker participation in developing corporate America's labor policies, but real unions, with real power -- not schemes to give companies tax breaks for an illusion of worker participation.
 
LARRY CARY
New York, March 15, 1993
 
The writer, who practices labor law, is a former president of the New York Labor History Association.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 7; Column 5; Real Estate Desk
