HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:
Post-Bankruptcy Prospects 
Question: In 1990, we were forced to file for bankruptcy. Now we are finally back on our feet financially and would like to purchase a small home of our own. Can we get a mortgage? . . . Fernando Carrion, the Bronx.
Answer: Yes, but it won't be easy. According to Beryl Riley, a mortgage manager with Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, your best bet may be secondary lenders, such as Champion Mortgage, which may also charge you a higher rate. Mortgage brokers may also help you find a lender. Some banks, such as Chase Manhattan, will consider an application from someone with a bankruptcy on his credit report, but only if there is a full discharge of the bankruptcy and the borrower has established good or secured credit. Further, two years should have elapsed since the bankruptcy discharge, three years if there is a down payment of less than 20 percent. Also, it should be documented that extraordinary circumstances caused the bankruptcy, such as an extended illness that was not covered by health insurance, and that the event is not likely to occur again.
 
Escrow Accounts
Question: I recently refinanced my mortgage, a fixed rate on a private single-family residence. My bank, however, has refused to give me a current escrow analysis. Who regulates escrow accounts? Can I ask my bank for a complete escrow analysis more than once a year? . . . Randy Hunt, Locust Valley, L.I.
Answer: No. According to Clare E. Sykes, a spokeswoman for the New York State Department of Banking, escrow issues are governed by the Federal Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act, which describes how escrow accounts are done, including how often escrow analyses can be requested. She added that analyses must be given annually, but no more often unless the lender desires. If the loan is refinanced by the same lender, the same rule applies. If a new lender refinances, then a new analysis is made.
 
Security Deposit
Question: My security deposit for my apartment is in a savings account under the name of the owner. I have a letter from her bank verifying that this account is separate from the owner's other accounts. But who is entitled to the accumulated interest? Also, the owner lives on the West Coast and travels extensively. How can I make sure that my deposit will be returned? Can I not pay my last month's rent? . . . K.A. Hanson, Manhattan
Answer: Maybe. According to Michael Finder, a Manhattan lawyer, when a landlord takes a security deposit it must be placed in a trust account and segregated from other money. Technically, he added, the account also has to be in the tenant's name.
 He said that if the building had six or fewer units the owner did not have to pay interest. But if it has more than six units the tenant is entitled to the interest in the account, minus a 1 percent administration fee, which goes to the landlord. The interest can be accrued or paid annually; it's the landlord's choice. If the apartment is a New York rent-stabilized unit, the tenant can request that the interest be paid annually.
 Mr. Finder said that, in New York, landlords had to return a security deposit within a reasonable amount of time; no exact number of days is prescribed. And though not paying your last month's rent is a violation of your lease, it has also become an almost customary practice. The landlord then keeps your security deposit and, if necessary, pursues a legal action to recover any damages. "It is common to not pay the last month's rent to get a security deposit back," he said.
 Technically, Mr. Finder added, a landlord could sue for nonpayment of a last month's rent and the tenant would be responsible for the landlord's legal fees. This rarely occurs, though. And as for any possibility of eviction during the last month, it couldn't be accomplished within 30 days, at least not in New York, he said.
 Should you decide to pay your last month's rent, Mr. Finder recommended contacting your landlord before your lease expires and reminding them that you are expecting your deposit back. If you don't receive it within 30 pays, pursue legal action.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 28, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An answer in the The Q & A column on March 28 referred incorrectly to the choice of whether the interest on a tenant's security deposit is paid annually or is accrued. Generally the choice is the tenant's, not the landlord's.

HEADLINE: As Japanese as Burt Bacharach

BYLINE: By David Leavitt; David Leavitt's most recent book is a collection of stories, "A Place I've Never Been." His new novel, "While England Sleeps," will be published this fall.

 BODY:

THE ELEPHANT VANISHES
Stories.
By Haruki Murakami.
Translated by Alfred Birnbaum
and Jay Rubin.
327 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $21. 
 FEW cultures excite or upset the American imagination as tenaciously as Japan's. News of life on that leapfrog of islands streams relentlessly through our televisions and newspapers, alternately offending and enthralling us. What kind of country is this, we wonder, that can produce Noh drama and cram schools, zen gardens and Nintendo games? American writers can't seem to get enough of Japan, which has become for some -- Jay McInerney, Brad Leit hauser and John Burnham Schwartz among them -- a magnet for expatriate adventuring. For writers like Michael Crichton, on the other hand, Japan is a predator nation out to destroy the American way of business -- a convenient scapegoat in a melodrama of economic espionage.
The Japanese novelist Haruki Murakami provides a different point of view in "The Elephant Vanishes," his first collection of stories. (He is also the author of the novels "Hard-Boiled Wonderland and the End of the World" and "A Wild Sheep Chase.") These stories, ably translated by Jay Rubin and Alfred Birnbaum, show us Japan as it's experienced from the inside. What is exotic to foreigners -- oyster hot pot or pillows filled with buckwheat husks -- is here the stuff of ordinary life; but so are McDonald's, steak and Julio Iglesias. Indeed, Mr. Murakami's Japan is such an unquestioned hybrid of tradition and export that one has to read 11 pages into the first story before the most casual reference to a "Tokyoite" signals that we aren't in America. His narrators -- young, urban, downwardly mobile -- are as likely to eat spaghetti as soba noodles. They listen to Wagner and Herbie Hancock, but disdain "stupid Japanese rock music. Love songs sweet enough to rot your teeth." They read Len Deighton novels and "War and Peace," not Kobo Abe and "The Tale of Genji." Their universe is Japanese, but their cultural reference points are almost exclusively Western.
This is a Japan characterized by a peculiar spiritual torpor. Bizarre events take place regularly, but fail to generate much reaction or curiosity. In "The Wind-Up Bird and Tuesday's Women," for instance, a young man's search for a missing cat leads him into a closed-off alley that passes between the backyards of parallel houses, a path "neglected and untrafficked, like some abandoned canal." There he encounters a sunbathing teen-age girl who, like the alley itself, seems both of the ordinary world and strangely apart from it. But their rambling conversation is too lazy to be truly flirtatious.
Similarly, in "A Window," another young man, this one a writing teacher who works for a correspondence school, pays a visit to one of his pupils, a married woman in her early 30's. Their few hours together eating hamburger steak and listening to Burt Bacha rach linger for years in the narrator's memory. "The weather was lovely that day," he recalls, "and over the railings of the building's verandas hung a colorful assortment of sheets and futons drying in the sun. Every now and then came the slap of a bamboo whisk fluffing out a futon. I can bring the sound back even now. It was strangely devoid of any sense of distance." Again, nothing happens. The wife and the teacher are "like two would-be passengers who had missed the same train," linked not so much by a shared passion as a shared sense of absence.
Most of Mr. Murakami's stories have a fabulistic edge. "The Dancing Dwarf" takes place in one of those impressively efficient Japanese factories we're always hearing about, only in this case the factory manufactures elephants: "Assigned to the ear section that month, I worked in the building with the yellow ceiling and posts. My helmet and pants were also yellow. . . . The month before, I had been assigned to the green building, where I wore a green helmet and pants and made heads."
In "TV People," human mutants "reduced" by 20 or 30 percent -- "figures that look far away even close up" -- invade the narrator's home and office. "From the time the TV People come into the apartment to the moment they leave," he tells us, "I don't budge. . . . Not to excuse myself, but you have people right in front of you denying your very presence like that, then see if you don't doubt whether you actually exist."
And in the haunting title story, another elephant mysteriously disappears, along with its keeper, from the enclosure where it has been kept as a kind of mascot for a Tokyo suburb. Again, the solution to the mystery hinges on questions of perspective and proportion.
In fact, all the stories in "The Elephant Vanishes" take place in parallel worlds not so much remote from ordinary life as hidden within its surfaces: secret alleys that afford unexpected -- and unsettling -- views. Mysteries are offered that defy solution or analysis. Their purpose, rather, is to point out not only how much we don't know but how much we can't know. As a result, the tendency of certain people and situations to defy description -- to most writers a bane -- becomes for Mr. Murakami something to revel in.
In the story called "Sleep," for example, a young woman suddenly discovers that she no longer needs it. Awakened literally and figuratively, she observes that there is something strange about her husband's face, but finds herself at a loss to articulate the source of this strangeness. "Honestly," she observes, " 'strange' is about all that fits. . . . The one thing I could remember was that his face looked strange."
Likewise, in "The Second Bakery Attack" a young man discovers that his wife keeps a shotgun and ski masks in the car, even though "neither of us had ever skied. But she didn't explain and I didn't ask. Married life is weird, I felt." One recalls the maxim given by the correspondence-school writing teacher in "A Window," who says to his student: "Don't try so hard to be the penetrating observer. Writing is, after all, a makeshift thing."
Makeshift indeed. Yet even in the slipperiest of Mr. Murakami's stories, pinpoints of detail flash out: pull tabs from beer cans lying in an ashtray "like scales from a mermaid"; shotgun shells rustling "like buckwheat husks in an old-fashioned pillow"; melted ice working its way through a cocktail "like a tiny ocean current."
"After I gave up sleeping," the narrator of "Sleep" observes, "it occurred to me what a simple thing reality is, how easy it is to make it work. . . . Like running a simple machine. Once you learn to run it, it's just a matter of repetition." In this observation she reveals her kinship with the narrator of "The Elephant Vanishes," who continues, after the disappearance, "to sell refrigerators and toaster ovens and coffee makers in the pragmatic world, based on afterimages of memories I retain from that world." Yet he, like his sleepless contemporary, doesn't live there anymore.
It's as if a kind of social schism has taken hold in this culture so intent on efficiency and productivity, a schism between the visible street and the hidden alley that resists simple resolution. In Mr. Murakami's view, "people are looking for a kind of unity in this kit-chin we know as the world. Unity of design. Unity of color. Unity of function." The problem, as he notes in a story called "The Last Lawn of the Afternoon," is that "no matter how hard you try to put everything neatly into shape, the context wanders this way and that, until finally the context isn't even there anymore. You're left with this pile of kittens lolling all over one another."
No metaphor could suit more exactly these stories in which animals -- elephants, kangaroos, windup birds, even a tragically mistreated "little green monster" -- figure so crucially. These stories, like the kittens themselves, are "warm with life, hopelessly" -- and, I would add, wonderfully -- "unstable."

HEADLINE: Where 'Boys Will Be Boys,' And Adults Are Befuddled

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAKEWOOD, Calif., March 26

 BODY:
It was lunchtime at Lakewood High School and the big men on campus were strutting their stuff at the local Taco Bell.
Eric Richardson, a 17-year-old football star, swaggered in, a T-shirt reading "No Crybabies" stretched taut across his pectorals. 
 "I got the power! I got the finesse! I got everything!" Eric declaimed to no one in particular.
Eric and eight of his friends, members of a group called the Spur Posse, had spent the last few days in jail, accused of molesting and raping girls as young as 10.
 
A Heroes' Welcome
 Now all but one had been released, while investigations continued. And the boys returned to school this week to a heroes' welcome, their status enhanced and their scrapbooks thicker by several press clippings.
The tale of the Spur Posse in some ways sounds like an old story about bad boys and fast girls, about athletes who can do no wrong and the people who fawn over them. But it comes as codes of sexual conduct are colliding with boys-will-be-boys mores and as unemployment and broken marriages are troubling the still waters of this piece of suburbia southeast of Los Angeles.
Lakewood's Mayor, Marc Titel, said he hoped the town would use its notoriety as an occasion for introspection. But he said he was not optimistic, because the boys seem unrepentent, the parents lenient and the other students inclined to lionize the athletes and vilify their accusers.
 
'Real Problems'
 "We need to look at what kind of values we are communicating to our kids," said Mr. Titel, a father of seven. "We have some real problems here, and promiscuity is one of them. For too long, we've accepted that that's the way it is. Well, that kind of resignation sends a message to kids that nothing's wrong with it."
Eric Richardson and his friends say they have heard that message. "They pass out condoms, teach sex education and pregnancy-this and pregnancy-that," the boy said, after polishing off a Nacho Supreme and necking with his girlfriend in a booth at the Taco Bell. "But they don't teach us any rules."
The exploits of these boys, who are also implicated in nonsexual crimes here, have laid bare the underbelly of life in this suburb, where a tract-house development dwarfing Levittown was built among bean fields in the 1950's for workers in the fledgling aerospace industry.
This is a predominately white community of 73,500 where virtually every block has its own baseball diamond or gridiron, where the boys are athletes and girls cheerleaders from the age of 6 or 7 and where most fathers are part-time coaches and mothers are "team moms."
 
Shaken by Divorce and Debt
 But these days, the 50's suburb is plagued with 90's problems.
Many members of the Spur Posse, which counts 20 to 30 boys as members and is named for the San Antonio Spurs professional basketball team, come from families shaken by divorce or financial crisis. One boy's parents are divorced, people here say, but continue to live together because they cannot afford to move. Another comes from a family repeatedly evicted from their home. A third stares back blankly when asked what he has been doing since high school. "Partying," he mumbled. "Playing ball."
Several are also being investigated or have been arrested on charges of burglary, assault, intimidation of witnesses and other crimes. The sexual charges stemmed from a meeting at school, when the sheriff's department invited 22 families with boys in the Spur Posse to come and discuss what their children were up to. Only seven parents came. One of them said rapes had been committed.
When sexual-abuse investigators began looking into the matter, they discovered that one complaint had already been filed, by a girl whose father, a former police officer, discovered she had had an abortion. The girl told her father she had been forced to have sex with several boys. Other girls were interviewed, and six more told similar stories. None have been identified.
 
'We Didn't Do Nothing Wrong'
 Many of the boys have acknowledged having sex with scores of underage girls as part of a competition. But the girls were willing participants, the boys said, and were known throughout the school as "sluts."
"We didn't do nothing wrong 'cause it's not illegal to hook up," said Billy Shehan, 19, using the local slang for sexual intercourse, which he says he has had 66 times, making him the group's top scorer.
In fact, sexual intercourse with a minor is a felony, even if the girl consents. But it is rarely prosecuted and the Los Angeles District Attorney, upon releasing most of the boys, said it was a "social" issue "better left to churches, schools and parents."
A few of the Spurs' parents are downright boastful about their sons. Take Don Belman, a salesman, who graduated from Lakewood High in 1963, married a hometown girl and had three strapping boys, all star athletes. "Aren't they virile specimens?" Mr. Belman said the other night as he watched them skating noisily through the neighborhood.
One of Mr. Belman's sons, 20-year-old Dana, founded the Spur Posse. A member of the Lakewood Youth Hall of Fame, Dana is awaiting trial on unrelated charges of stealing guns, credit cards and jewelry and trying to run over several girls with a pickup truck.
Another son, 19-year-old Kris, is the oldest of those who were arrested on the sexual charges. Four of the eight boys set free from jail remain under investigation, although it could not be learned which ones. A ninth boy remains in custody, charged with lewd conduct with a minor.
 
A Spur Who's 'All Man'
 On the night of Kris's release, Mr. Belman said his son was "all man." The girls that Kris had sex with were "giving it away," Mr. Belman added. "There wouldn't be enough jails in America" if all boys were imprisoned for doing what his son was accused of, he said.
Other parents are more bewildered than boastful.
Joyce Shehan, for instance, said she was mortified that her son Billy, not among those arrested, bragged of leading the Spurs in conquests. "It was like somebody kicked me in the stomach when I saw his face talking on television," Mrs. Shehan said.
She said she told Billy, "No means no, no matter how far you've progressed." But Billy says he recalls no such conversation.
Mrs. Shehan, a secretary, added that she knew Billy was sexually active from the time he was 14 years old and stocked his room with "rubbers from the Price Club."
Now, she said, her confidence in her parenting skills is shaken. "What should I have done different?" she asked.
There are also gradations of opinion among the 4,000 students at Lakewood High.
A few students said they were troubled by the boys' behavior, but they would discuss it only anonymously because they feared retaliation or wanted to stay in favor with the in-crowd.
"They're like bullies," said a tiny 10th-grade girl, who was waiting her turn at cheerleading tryouts. "They say stuff like, 'Oh, come on, I'm in love.' They pretend to be real sweet and then they tell everybody afterward and give out her phone number. Sometimes a bunch of them even go and take turns."
But far more students defended the Spurs and said their accusers were promiscuous girls who got what they asked for.
"These girls were all willing; they even bragged about it," said an 11th grader wearing red and white hair ribbons and carrying tissue-paper pompoms. "I know one girl who did every Spur, and she was proud of it. I'm not saying the boys are perfect angels. They take advantage of girls and treat them like crap in the morning. But they didn't rape anyone."
 
'Not the Prettiest' Victims
 At the D & D Sporting Goods store near the high school, two members of the Spurs and one of their girlfriends speculated about the motivation of these so-called fast girls.
"They're not the prettiest, you know," said Matt Nielsen, 18, a recent graduate of Lakewood High. Matt's divorced mother works a double shift as part-owner of D & D and as the overnight cashier at the supermarket next door.
"So they take whatever they can get," added Athena Morales, Matt's girlfriend and one of the many Lakewood students who wore black wristbands this week to protest the arrests.
Matt's 15-year-old brother, Scotty, chimed in: "That's how they're trying to get popular, by doing my friends." Scotty added that his best buddy was still in jail and set to go on trial next week for lewd conduct with a minor. The girl might actually have been 10, Scotty asserted, but she claimed to be 15.
In tabulating their sexual exploits, the boys in the Spur Posse make reference to the uniform numbers of the sports stars who are their heroes: "I'm 44 now -- Reggie Jackson," or "I'm 50 -- David Robinson."
And Bill Shehan, Billy's father, said, "I don't see these kids acting much different from professional athletes, like when Wilt Chamberlain came out in his book and said he had 20,000 women."

HEADLINE: Consumers Finally Respond To High Credit Card Interest

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
After a decade of self-deception, Americans have finally begun to face the truth about how much interest they actually pay on their credit cards. And now, for the first time, many consumers are shopping for a card that will charge them a lower rate.
For years, many consumers were drawn to Mastercards and Visa cards issued by banks mainly on the basis of which one offered the highest credit limit. Studies show that the vast majority of card holders simply told themselves that they did not pay any interest, when two-thirds of them did. Thus they were undisturbed by interest rates that stubbornly remained around 19 percent even as other rates fell sharply.
 
 
'More Honest With Themselves'
 "People used to say to themselves, 'I may pay interest once in a while, but that's not really me because I'm going to pay it it all off next month,' " said Ruvan N. Cohen, director of card marketing at Citibank, the nation's largest bank and largest issuer of credit cards. "In the last year people began to be more honest with themselves. They admit they pay interest and have started to read the rate disclosure boxes. We have to respond to that." 
 And now the slide in credit card rates shows no signs of stopping. Citibank will announce today that it is lowering rates to 15.4 percent, from 19.8 percent, on nine million cards -- including "affinity cards" linked to merchants, like the widely held cards that offer frequent-flier miles from American Airlines.
Last year Citibank lowered the rate for another nine million regular and gold cards for customers with good credit records. After today's rate cut, 70 percent of Citibank's 27 million cards will have rates below 19.8 percent, the industry standard since 1981.
 
 
Low Rates to New Customers
 And for the first time, Citibank will offer the low rates to new customers. Last week, it mailed 30 million solicitations offering a 9.9 percent rate for six months to customers who transfer their debts from another bank.
The Norwest Corporation noticed in the middle of last year that many customers who were heavy borrowers were transferring balances to lower-rate cards. "It became clear that our customers had fundamentally changed," said Brian O'Hare, the head of credit cards for the Minneapolis-based bank. Last summer Norwest dropped its rate for most customers to 15 percent from 19.8 percent.
This change in psychology is largely because the economic downturn has forced many consumers to look more closely at their finances. "The recession has had a profound impact on people's idea of value," Mr. O'Hare of Norwest said. "People are choosing to spend less and save more."
Another factor was simply the publicity given to interest rates. In 1986, Congress voted to phase out the deductibility of consumer interest, and in 1991 the Senate passed a bill introduced by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, to cap interest rates for credit cards.
"Here were 30-second sound bites right from the halls of Congress, and lo and behold, 80 percent of the people know what their A.P.R. is," said Thomas Lynch, head of credit cards at Chase Manhattan Bank, referring to annual percentage rate. "Two years before only 30 percent did."
Immediately after Senator D'Amato introduced his bill, in fact, calls began to pick up at Bank Card Holders of America, a group that sells lists of credit cards with low rates. Last year the group sold 2,500 of the lists a week for $4, double the rate of the year before. "With rates for home mortgages and car loans dropping to 20-year lows, consumers were beginning to ask why they were paying almost 20 percent for a credit card," Gerri E. Detweiler, the group's director, said.
Just two years ago, 70 percent of the money owed on credit cards -- nearly $200 billion -- was at rates higher than 18 percent. Last year that portion fell to 44 percent, according to a new study conducted for the Congressional Budget Office by Ram Research. At the same time, the portion of credit card debt with rates of 16.5 percent or less increased to 38 percent from 7 percent.
 
 
Variable Rates
 Most banks have quietly shifted to variable rates -- usually about 9 percentage points above the prime rate -- so this savings may not last when the prime, now 6 percent, rises. Even though that rate is still far higher than the best deals available on credit cards, last year the lower variable rates saved consumers more than $2 billion on the more than $30 billion paid annually for credit card interest payments.
But while the banks are responding, they are not doing so cheerfully. When customers did not shop for interest rates, the profit margins on credit cards were as high as 4 percent of the amount lent, far higher than those on other bank products. In 1990, banks earned more than $4 billion from credit card lending, one-quarter of the profits of the entire banking system. Some of the largest banks might not have survived their losses from bad real-estate loans if they had not been buoyed by earnings from cards.
Now losses from bad credit card debt have risen just as annual fees and interest rates have fallen. As a result, credit card earnings fell to 2.5 percent of assets in 1990 and to 1.5 percent of assets today, according to Salomon Brothers.
Banks, of course, can still demand higher rates on credit cards than on other types of consumer loans, because consumers are willing to pay for the greater convenience that cards offer. Nonetheless, with industrial companies like A.T.& T. and General Motors sponsoring very successful new card programs -- and offering discounts on everything from phone calls to new cars -- many banks are finding that their best defense is to cut rates.
 
 
Discounts Produce Growth
 Indeed, most banks are seeing the fastest growth in their card business when they offer the most aggressive discounts. The Wachovia Corporation, which offers a rate as low as 8.9 percent (with a $39 fee), saw its charge card loans grow by 33 percent last year. And the Bank of New York, which offers a card with no fee and a rate of 11.9 percent, grew by 27 percent, Ram Research found.
The banks that have cut rates more aggressively, along with the new nonbank card issuers, have been taking market share from the traditional issuers, like Citibank, which actually lost customers last year.
As a defense, most large card issuers switched last year from fixed rates, generally 19.8 percent, to variable rates that now are about 15 percent for at least some of their cardholders. Rates for gold cards are generally a few points lower. Those that did not offer lower rates found they were in trouble. General Electric, for example, introduced a credit card with great fanfare last fall but had to eliminate the annual fee and lower the interest from 18.4 percent to as low as 14.9 percent after it did not catch on in the marketplace.
The average standard card was offered to new customers with a rate of 16.63 percent last fall, down two full percentage points from the year before, according to a study of direct mail offers by BAI Marketing Research.
Even Sears's Discover Card, which offers a cash rebate and no annual fee with a 19.8 percent rate, is under pressure. A survey last year by another firm, Brittain Associates, showed that 25 percent of Discover card holders felt the rate was too high. In January, Sears slashed its interest rate to 14.9 percent for customers who charge more than $1,000 a year.
While it hardly seems surprising that rates on charge cards should come down as most other interest rates have plunged, that was not the case in the 1980's. At that time, as the prime rate dropped below 8 percent from 16 percent, the rate charged on most credit card borrowings remained firmly wedged at nearly 20 percent.
"Consumer sensitivity to interest rates was virtually nonexistent," said Donald J. Auriemma, a credit card consultant. "They didn't know their annual percentage rate and they didn't care."
What consumers focused on was whether their cards had high credit lines, and then opted for those that had no annual fee, even when paying $20 a year up front could save hundreds of dollars a year in interest. "People don't focus on how much they are revolving and what the dollars and cents consequences will be," said Robert G. Skolnick, executive vice president of BAI.
It was not until last year that offers of cards with lower rates started to attract more customers than no-fee cards, Mr. Auriemma said.
Amid the increased scrutiny from consumers, banks have tried to appear as if they are offering lower rates than they they really are. Some banks, including Citibank, offer the new lower rate only on purchases made after a cut is announced. Existing balances are billed at the higher rate.
Others, like Discover and American Express's Optima card, give the best rate only to customers who charge more than a certain amount in a year.
And many issuers now will raise rates on customers who miss payments or exceed their credit limits. Bankers say this policy appeals to consumers as fair and helps bankers compensate for their higher-risk customers at a time when credit losses have soared.
 
 
Banks Offset Costs
 The fact that the banks themselves are paying much less for the money they borrow has largely offset the cost of reducing their charge rates. To get the money to make fixed-rate credit card loans, banks typically sell certificates of deposit or bonds with three-year to five-year maturities, the average life of a credit card loan. Since they moved to variable-rate credit cards, banks are now financing their charge card loans with shorter term deposits, which cost them three or four percentage points less.

SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1061 words

HEADLINE: Horror for Hollywood: Film Hits a Nerve With Its Grim View of Hometown

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 28

 BODY:
Over the years, Hollywood has offered many portraits of its home territory, from a paradise of turquoise pools to apocalyptic visions like "Blade Runner." More knowingly than most moviegoers, Angelenos could shrug off the distortions as just illusion.
But now a film has struck a nerve in Los Angeles. The city is in an uproar over the Warner Brothers hit "Falling Down," a tale of a laid-off military worker played by Michael Douglas, a middle-aged man who mentally snaps in a freeway jam, leaves his car and embarks on a violent journey through a hostile city, much of it graffiti-splattered and ethnically threatening. 
 Korean-Americans objected to being portrayed as gouging shopkeepers. Hispanic residents recoiled at Mexican-American youths as murderous thugs. Even unemployed military workers said the film could hurt their job hunts.
On another day, such a film might not have caused a ripple. But Southern California, once considered the bright future of America, is in the grip of its worst economic slump since the Depression and is collectively wondering if it has any future at all. Moreover, the film comes shortly before the anniversary of the rioting last spring and during the Federal trial of the four white police officers who beat Rodney G. King.
 
Good Reviews in the East
 "Falling Down" had generally good reviews in the East, but not here. The Los Angeles Times has published seven negative articles about it, including three on the front page of its entertainment section on March 15. Then came three commentaries last Monday including a spirited defense by Mr. Douglas's father, Kirk Douglas, who argued that critics had misinterpreted the movie as making a hero of the "prejudiced, middle-class nerd" portrayed by his son.
All seem to agree that the film is entertaining and riveting, but few agree on its social message. A Los Angeles Times columnist, Peter H. King, retraced Mr. Douglas's steps in the movie, walking from downtown to Venice Beach. He reported that despite some "moments," the trek was uneventful.
" 'Falling Down' is the Los Angeles of late-night news and boilerplate sociology," Mr. King complained. "A city of drive-bys and Hare Krishnas and 'Will Work for Food' signs, of absurd wealth and wretched poverty and little in between. In short, it is the new mythical L.A., which has supplanted the old mythical L.A. of endless summers."
A week later, Mr. King's colleague, Bob Baker, a veteran reporter of urban issues, warned against more of "this simple-minded sociology."
"Last spring's riots created a wave of Hollywood interest in exploiting Los Angeles as a pressure cooker of horrors," he wrote. "From now on, anything goes. You want urban insanity as a backdrop? Set your screenplay here. Any portrait of the city, no matter how grotesque or overstated, can be justified by a simple wave of the producer's hand toward the temporary insanity of the riots."
Mr. Baker suggested that it was the likes of the film's character who had brought in these urban problems, by voting in 1978 for the tax-limiting Proposition 13, which resulted in "horrid" public services, crime and gangs.
The film's director, Joel Schumacher, argued that the negative local reaction meant the film was all too true. "Obviously, this movie struck a nerve," Mr. Schumacher, who moved from New York in 1971, said in an interview. "When you hit a nerve, people will scream."
Mr. Schumacher pointed out that the film was written and almost completely filmed before the riots, and he said it was not meant to exploit the black-Korean tensions.
"This is not a movie that decided to single out L.A.," he said. "It could easily have been about Chicago or New York or Miami. My experience is when people protest too much you've hit the nail on the head. The problems that led to the riots exist in most major cities. Those problems have not been addressed.
" 'Falling Down' waved a red flag and said, 'Hey, we've got serious problems here.' Denial of that is not going to help. I know there are armies of hard-working law-abiding people in L.A., but that's not all.
"The whole point of the movie is that it may seem like an option to act out. Everybody is buying guns, and acting out by ordinary people seems to be the order of the day. I wanted to make a film by a man acting out."
Mr. Schumacher added that the Douglas character is the film's villain.
That was not how many Angelenos took it. At recent screenings, many in the audiences applauded when the crazed character played by Mr. Douglas beat up a Korean merchant for charging too much and then vandalized his store; when he shot a Mexican-American gang member; when he terrorized a fast-food restaurant after clerks refused to serve him breakfast a minute or two after the cut-off time.
As audience reactions suggest, the film did tap a reservoir of anger here, and perhaps no group is more concerned about that than the 200,000 Korean-Americans, who were frequent targets in last year's riots.
Korean groups say that since February eight Korean-American merchants in Los Angeles County have been shot, five fatally. A white man swinging a belt and shouting anti-Asian epithets was arrested March 13 for vandalizing a liquor store in suburban Anaheim. As in the film, the man left the shop without stealing.
 
A Desire for Balance
 Speaking of the movie, Robert Park, program director for the Korean Coalition, said, "I could not believe they were showing this." The film also fed stereotypes, he said.
Members of the coalition met with studio executives and Mr. Schumacher, about two weeks ago, and those who attended said the meeting was cordial and fruitful.
Asian-Americans are not seeking censorship but want balance, said Stewart Kwoh, executive director of the Asian Pacific American Legal Center here. "It showed only the negative side of life in L.A.," he went on.
At City Hall, Mayor Tom Bradley has not made an issue of the film. But Deputy Mayor Mark Fabiani has called the movie "effective" and "entertaining" and said it "did express the frustration of living in any major city, not just L.A."
Mr. Fabiani also found a political lesson, saying the Douglas character was probably a Reaganite who voted to cut taxes and public services.
"But the Mayor's view," he went on, "is that complaining only creates more of an audience for it."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Using 'Kids' to Push Fight on Poverty May Obscure the Issues, Critics Say

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
Fortified by Chinese takeout food and tapes of the Grateful Dead, a dozen young workers labored overtime last week in the basement of a Capitol Hill town house, packaging social need.
They filled 5,000 envelopes with a report that says the United States increasingly consigns its children to lives of violence, poverty and failure. They relayed background footage to a satellite and produced localized sound bites for television stations in every state. 
 If experience holds true, the effort to gain attention will succeed beyond what its publicist, Tony Podesta, calls his "wildest imagination": the report was featured in about 1,400 of the nation's 1,600 daily newspapers last year and prompted editorials with sympathetic headlines like "Suffer the Children."
Today's release of the report, Kids Count Data Book, an annual profile of American children by the Annie E. Casey Foundation and the Center for the Study of Social Policy, two not-for-profit groups, is an example of the many public campaigns now selling a vision of activist Government beneath the face of a child. The movement's thesis is that American children as a whole are imperiled and in need of special help, especially Federal help.
Or, in the advocates' vernacular, "kids" are "at risk," but more "investments" can produce "better outcomes." As an example, the advocates argue that money spent on the Head Start preschool program saves money that would later accrue from crime, educational failure or welfare.
But skeptics say the talk of "kids" is really an effort to promote antipoverty policies that would meet greater resistance if labeled as such. And though some advocates disagree, their critics argue that little can be done to eliminate the poverty of children without confronting the complex forces behind the poverty of adults. After all, most poor children come attached to poor families.
Calling on the country to care about its "kids," they say, can sentimentalize and obscure the underlying issues.
 
Report Paints Bleak Picture
 Whatever the ideological intent, the numbers put forth in the Kids Count report are disturbing to many people. The report says about one of every four American children lives in a single-parent family and about one in five lives in poverty. In surveying trends in 10 categories of child well-being since 1985, the report found conditions worsening in six of them.
And whatever the underlying agenda, "kids" are selling. The success of the report, a state-by-state statistical compendium, has produced imitators in 37 states. They, too, issue annual reports, breaking the data down to the local level.
In California, an advocacy group called Children Now has placed public service advertisements on network television and recruited Wall Street barons like George Roberts to its board. Among the group's slogans is "Children. They're the only future we've got."
In Washington, the nation's most prominent child advocacy group, the Children's Defense Fund, is enjoying unprecedented political influence. One of its former chairwomen, Donna E. Shalala, is the Secretary of Health and Human Services; another is Hillary Rodham Clinton.
 
Problems for Poor and Rich
 The leaders of most of these organizations deny they are engaging in a bait-and-switch marketing strategy that simply uses children to promote antipoverty policies. Social conditions are worsening for most American children, they say, not just poor ones.
Some of their examples are compelling. They note a common culture of violence in music and television, drops in academic achievement, increased sexual activity and the ever-widening breakup of the American family.
"The problems we worry about are not exclusively concentrated among the poor," said Douglas Nelson, executive director of the Annie E. Casey Foundation.
Like most child advocates, Mr. Nelson is quick to add that poor children do suffer such problems disproportionately.
In an interview last fall, Marian Wright Edelman, the president of the Children's Defense Fund, similarly argued that children of all economic classes face common problems like "crass materialism," "the proliferation of guns," and "polluted air and the ozone problem."
"I worry so much about my kids having so much -- too much," Ms. Edelman said. She added, however, that children living in blighted areas faced a "heck of a bigger struggle."
James Steyer, the founder of Children Now, goes even further in arguing that the problems facing children cut across class boundaries. "My friends who went to Exeter with me -- they're worried about their kids," he said. "They're not sure they're going to have health care for their kids."
While the advocacy groups promote a vision of activist Government, there are important nuances in the language they use. The Children's Defense Fund, for instance, emphasizes a confidence in what it calls proven Government solutions, like Head Start.
The Kids Count report, by contrast, stresses the need to "rethink many of the public efforts." It is careful to stress that recent increases in spending have brought little improvements in problems like teen-age pregnancy, violence and family breakup.
Still, the general call for an activist Government has prompted criticisms from conservatives, who call the children's movement a front for higher taxes and more social programs.
But some liberals also offer critiques, saying talk of "children" is an imprecise way of framing a social problem. Christopher Jencks, a sociologist at Northwestern University, says the movement's rhetoric "is problematic partly because it talks its way around the problem of poverty, and partly because it implies that you can separate the problems of kids from the problems of their parents."
While some programs, like Head Start, focus directly on children, an effective antipoverty program must confront the web of cultural and economic forces at work in the larger society.
 
Negatives Increase
 But Mr. Jencks calls his remarks quibbles with a movement that he basically admires for its ability to get the public thinking about policy questions. "On balance, I'm mildly for these folks," he said.
The Kids Count data on teen-age years was especially negative. Births to single mothers grew, as did the percentage of children not graduating from high school and the percentage dying violent deaths. The arrest rate for violent crimes (rape, homicide, robbery and aggravated assault) rose by 48 percent.
While some conservatives have accused child advocates of blaming Government rather than parents, the Kids Count report is careful to talk about family formation. A new statistical measurement, called a family risk index, paints a portentous view of the future by assessing the percentage of American families that begin under adverse circumstances, increasing the likelihood that their children will experience poverty or other problems.
The authors found that 45 percent of the children born into new families had one of three disadvantages: either their mother had not finished high school, was not married or was a teen-ager. The report said 24 percent of the new families had two of these disadvantages and 11 percent had all three.
In virtually every category, minorities fared worse.
 
Spending and Results
 The report is distributed by Podesta & Associates, a public relations firm based on Capitol Hill that specializes in work for not-for-profit groups. One of its founders, John Podesta, is now staff secretary to President Clinton.
Though the report is careful to note that higher spending does not always produce desired results, such distinctions often do not carry through to press accounts. "It is truly a matter of pay now or pay later," reported a Columbia, S.C., television station after last year's report. A station in Orlando, Fla., quoted advocates saying that for a decade, the country has "cut every important program" serving children.
A series of public service advertisements produced by Children Now carry a similar endorsement of more public spending. They feature stark pictures of children under arrest, passed out on bathroom floors and peering hopelessly through a chain-link fence. "When will we pay for our children's future?" one advertisement asks. "Now or later?"
Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, a research organization, notes that spending on many children's programs, including Head Start, has risen sharply in recent years.
"In a lot of dimensions, society isn't turning its back on kids -- it's spending more than ever," he said. "So this is a bogyman of this literature."

HEADLINE: U.S. Suspects Iran Is Helping Iraq To Evade Embargo on Oil Exports

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
United States intelligence agencies have expressed concern that Iran and Iraq may have struck a deal calling for Iran to buy oil from Iraq in violation of United Nations sanctions, senior Clinton Administration officials said today.
Such an agreement between the two Middle Eastern adversaries would undermine international efforts imposed after the Persian Gulf war to deprive Iraq of oil revenue, the officials said. They said they were worried that the two countries' common enmity toward the United States may have caused the them to set aside years of animosity, at least partly. 
 An estimated 300,000 Iranians died in the eight-year war with Iraq, which ended in 1988; total military and civilian casualties have been estimated at more than a million. But both nations have also shown some willingness to cooperate in combatting efforts by Western countries to isolate them.
 
Reports of Big Convoy
 The Administration officials said they had no direct evidence that an oil-buying agreement had been reached. But they said they were troubled by intelligence reports indicating that a convoy of dozens of tanker-trucks recently carried a large shipment of Iraqi oil to Iran.
A report of the delivery appeared today in The Washington Post. A senior Administration official confirmed today that last week, Washington complained to Iran about the oil delivery and was considering whether to raise the matter with the United Nations. Because the United States does not have diplomatic relations with Iran, the protest was relayed through Swiss intermediaries, another official said.
The Iraqi Government in Baghdad has been seeking secret markets for its oil ever since it was banned from selling it under the punitive sanctions imposed by the Security Council after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990.
Some Iraqi oil is already believed to have been shipped abroad through Jordan. But United States officials have long been concerned about more extensive shipments through Iran, and Government experts said today that Baghdad and Teheran may have begun to discuss such an arrangement as early as 1991. It is believed that Iran, itself a significant oil producer, would re-export any oil that it got from Iraq, and pass the revenues on to Iraq.
The experts declined to estimate how much Iraqi oil may have been shipped to Iran, and said it was impossible to know what motivated Teheran to break the sanctions. But they noted that Iran had shown itself willing to assist Iraq in thwarting the West, most notably in permitting Baghdad to move military aircraft to Iranian airstrips during the gulf war.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New York Magazine: Bucking Trends

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
On March 4, New York magazine was all set to run a cover story titled "All the Pretty Young Things" about the latest, coolest, "most divinely decadent," beautiful young people in New York. That afternoon, word came that an arrest was imminent in the World Trade Center bombing.
In the next 18 hours, a 3,000-word article on the bombing was written and edited, and a new cover delivered to the printer. By Saturday afternoon, right on schedule, more than 400,000 copies with "The Arab Connection" on the cover were on their way to subscribers and newsstands. 
 Edward Kosner, the editor and president, declared: "When Arabs blow up the World Trade Center, the trick is to use it, to be topical, to change the cover, to respond. You just have to be prepared to throw out something, to reschedule -- otherwise the magazine just becomes a monthly." A magazine also has to have the money and technology for such quick turnarounds.
 
Success in a Weak Economy
 It is this sense of urgency and responsiveness to the city's quirkiness that has kept the magazine vital when other city magazines have found themselves unable to weather the recession and its aftermath. Many, more vulnerable than most because of their heavy reliance on local retail advertising, have ceased publication. New York City, for example, has lost Manhattan,inc., 7 Days and New York Woman since 1990.
Even American Express Publishing has given up on city magazines. Three years ago, it intended to build a stable of regional publications. Not only did it abandon plans to expand, but in December it put its three city magazines up for sale. Two of those, Atlanta and D, which covers Dallas, are still on the block. L.A. Style was purchased by Buzz, a rival Los Angeles publication, which closed it.
New York, though, has been profitable for 12 years and intermittently before that, Mr. Kosner said. K-III Magazines which bought New York from Rupert Murdoch in 1991, has just substantially increased the editorial budget, he said, enabling him to hire some new people.
Its circulation of 437,866 is its highest since 1985. But advertising has been weaker the last three years, reflecting an industry-wide trend. This year through the March 23 issue, ad pages are down 8.5 percent .
 
How Relevant? How Local?
 Some critics think the magazine is less focused on New York than it once was, less of an insider's journal. Others say it has become a sort of habit, one of the obligatory weekly rituals.
"I think it's gone from a 'must read' to a 'must skim'," said Alexandra Penney, editor in chief of Self, a health and fitness magazine. "But an important part of the equation is that a lot of other magazines went from a 'must read' to a 'forget it.' "
Even the severest critics, though, praise Mr. Kosner for putting out a consistently readable publication.
"It's become like everyone's relative; it has insinuated itself in our lives," said Betsy Carter, new executive editor at Harper's Bazaar, who founded New York Woman. "It has kept up with New York and the neuroses of New York. It's one of those things that you may not remember reading -- but I just don't think of not reading it."
Tomorrow night, K-III will give a dinner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in honor of Mr. Kosner, a former editor of Newsweek who has led the magazine since 1980. It will be the first of several celebrations for the 25th anniversary of the magazine, which was founded as an independent publication in 1968 by Clay Felker. Mr. Felker was editor of New York when it was a Sunday supplement of The Herald Tribune and later of the short-lived World Journal Tribune, which ceased publication in 1967.
 
Wistful Beginnings
 The magazine's early days in a fourth-floor walk-up on East 32d Street are part of the city's journalism lore. Mr. Felker used his $7,500 severance pay to buy the title, then set out to raise more. George Hirsch, the publisher, ran sweepstakes that included lures like "Dinner with Mayor Lindsay (your house or his) to Tell Him How to Run the City."
"I loved the beginnings so," said Gloria Steinem, who describes herself as the sole "girl" on a team that included Tom Wolfe, Pete Hamill, Jimmy Breslin and the art directors Milton Glaser and Walter Bernard. "We sat around trying to think of the best name for the magazine," she said. "Tom Wolfe suggested 'New York Moon', and we had visions of trucks, even if empty, racing around the city and people crying, 'The moon is out!' "
Mr. Felker said: "I don't think that any magazine that changes editors will have the same vision. Magazines like The New Yorker, Esquire, Vanity Fair very much reflect the individual editor. I think Ed has done a very professional job, and it looks wonderful."
Mr. Kosner still depends on the Felker formula -- a mix of longer articles on trends, personalities and pop culture; detailed service pieces, like "Finding the Best Bank for Your Dollar," and short, attention-getting gossipy sections like Intelligencer, Fast Track and Best Bets. Critics are also part of the magazine's core.
 
Underground Gourmet Surfaces
 Mr. Kosner noted that in his 13 years as editor New York had gone through phases, requiring it to keep changing pace. During the 80's boom, it emphasized consumption. With the recession, the focus shifted to "how to survive" and service articles.
"You don't have to reinvent the magazine," Mr. Kosner said, "but rather use the array of possibilities and the cycle of issues that have always been part of the genetic code of the magazine. It's just a different emphasis at different periods."
Whatever the emphasis, a trademark remains strong writing, and the best writers are always in demand. Asked if New York paid writers well enough to keep its own stable of talent -- a well-publicized recent departure was that of the political columnist Joe Klein to Newsweek last summer -- Mr. Kosner said he paid competitively with magazines like Esquire.
For important pieces, he said, "we pay very, very well." He did not provide figures.
Joe Klein, he said, left for Newsweek because it has a national circulation of three million, compared with New York's 437,000-plus.
 
Somewhat Different Audiences
 Mr. Kosner shrugs off criticism that the magazine is now less focused on the city. He also rejects suggestions that The New Yorker is breathing down New York's neck.
"When I took over the magazine," Mr. Kosner said, "they had 4,000 ad pages and we had 1,800." In 1992, New York had 2,198 ad pages to The New Yorker's 2,018. The advertising bases, however, are not really comparable. New York has 72 percent of its circulation in the metropolitan area; The New Yorker's circulation is predominantly national.
"If we do what we are supposed to do, nothing can affect us," Mr. Kosner said. 'But if we falter, if we lose our way, if we start chasing every little trendlet, then we can put ourselves at risk."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
For the first time, consumers are shopping for credit cards that charge lower interest rates, and as a result, rates are continuing to drop. Citibank will announce today that it is lowering rates to 15.4 percent, from 19.8 percent, on nine million cards. [Page A1.]
Lawmakers in the House and the Senate are mapping out divergent paths toward the creation of a secondary market where small-business loans can be bought and sold. [D1.] 
 Machine tool orders rose sharply in February, in part because of strong export orders. [D2.]
The Clinton Administration is considering, as part of its health-care plan, a proposal to dismantle the Medicaid program and integrate low-income people into the same health-care networks that would serve more affluent people. [A1.] A sweeping plan to change New York's health-care system was perhaps most significant for what it did not say. News analysis. [B1.]
 
Companies
Lexmark may offer a valuable lesson for I.B.M.'s new chief. Since it was spun off two years ago, Lexmark has made the kind of changes in management, marketing and corporate culture that experts say the lumbering giant must now make itself. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Clinging to Thin Hope In Debris of Hurricane

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla., March 28

 BODY:
At first glance, it appears that Hurricane Andrew demolished the house just yesterday. Wooden roof beams are still exposed, windows have not been replaced and huge piles of debris clutter the driveway.
But it has been seven months since the storm hit, and George Vargas, a 37-year-old butcher, has spent nearly every day supervising the painfully slow reconstruction of the home he shares with his wife, Amy, and their 6-year-old daughter, Isabel. He can afford the time because the storm also destroyed Homestead Meat Market, the business he and his father, now 65, operated for more than 20 years. 
 "Until I finish this house, I am not going to do anything else," said Mr. Vargas, whose wife is now supporting the family as a bank teller. "The business is gone, and it's not coming back, because my father just can't imagine starting all over again at his age."
For Mr. Vargas and the other residents of his block on 152nd Court, these may be even worse times than the days immediately after the hurricane. Through the late summer and fall, they were buoyed by the presence of the military and by national concern about their plight.
 
Hope Fades With Time
 But that interest has receded, and they say they feel isolated and tired -- even more so since the Clinton Administration announced plans to close Homestead Air Force Base, the town's economic bedrock until it was destroyed by the hurricane. In the days just after the storm, President George Bush promised to rebuild the base.
Having survived the winds and rain, they now find that Federal and county agencies, insurance companies and contractors often provide as many obstacles as help. What is worse, they can see no quick solutions or end to the upheaval, and no one can tell them when they might expect to resume normal lives.
"Andrew came and went in a few hours," said Margarita Rodriguez, Mr. Vargas's neighbor. "But living with the damage the storm did, and trying to recover from it, is something that just goes on and on and on."
 
No Inspiration in a Dump
 Since last August, Mrs. Rodriguez, her husband, Ricardo, her son, Ricky, and his wife have been living in a small rented apartment 40 minutes from their home. To save money, she has acted as her own contractor. Every day after work, she stops by to see what progress the construction crew has made, or to urge them to speed up their work, or to complain to the county that their trucks still have not hauled away the foul-smelling mounds of debris that have become home to assorted vermin.
"Since the hurricane, the most depressing thing has been to see all the debris piling up," said Mrs. Rodriguez, who grew up in Queens and moved to Homestead hoping to find a calmer, safer way of life. "It really brings you down. People ask themselves what is the use of reconstructing if the entire neighborhood is a dump."
Down the block, Lazaro Roque has already moved back into his house, after living with his family in a small trailer in his driveway through much of the fall. But his insurance settlement did not give him enough money to replace ruined furniture, and it did not cover the tools that someone stole from his house when he and his family stayed briefly with relatives in Hialeah in the days after the storm.
 
Jobs Also Blew Away
 Mr. Roque, a 31-year-old father of a 2-year-old son, John, and a daughter, Ashley, born a month after the hurricane, is also without a job. The gas station where he worked for a dozen years was destroyed by the storm and then sold to a new owner, who wanted to hire his own people.
Before the storm, Mr. Roque and his father supplemented their incomes by selling ice cream from a pair of trucks during the summer. But the storm smashed both vehicles, on which the insurance had recently lapsed, and Mr. Roque has not been able to replace them. He now spends most of his time caring for his children so his wife, who has a Dade County job with health benefits, can continue to work.
 
Government Adds to Woes
 "I don't think you can ever completely come back from something like this," Mr. Roque said. "Everything has changed for all of us, even for the baby. Many of the neighbors have left, and a lot of the good jobs are gone, too."
In a meeting last week with Dade County mayors, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Henry G. Cisneros did not hold out much hope for a quick improvement in conditions here. "It's possible we are looking at four to five years to get it back to where it was," he said.
Other hurricane-related woes have recently complicated the rebuilding effort. The worst was the Pentagon's announced this month that it intends to shut down Homestead Air Force Base, which employed 8,800 people, nearly half of them civilians, and contributed $430 million a year to the local economy.
"First my house gets torn up," said Ray Runshe, a 62-year-old military retiree, "and now they say the base is going to close." As he spoke, he stood in the yard of his newly rebuilt home here, just a mile from the remains of the base, which the Government deems too expensive to rebuild. "They are pulling the rug right out from underneath us."
Homestead's City Manager, Alex Muxo, said the likely closing of the 50-year-old base had been a blow to morale that even the hurricane's destruction could not match.
 
'Why Should I Stay'
 Emilio Pages expects to lose $100,000 a year in business from the base itself, which ordered paint, carpeting and tile from the decorating service he ran here, and an even larger amount spent by the base's employees. But he said what rankles most about the decision to shut the installation is that it negates the impact of the hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal assistance that has poured into the area since the hurricane.
"It feels like they sent us all this help right off the bat, and now they are leaving us and just taking off," Mr. Pages said. He is worried that with the Federal Government appearing to bail out, other people here will say, "If Homestead is not good enough for them, why should I stay?"
A week after the base closing was announced, the Homestead area was struck by the same devastating winter storm that later hit the Northeast. Winds of up to 80 miles an hour overturned trailer homes, killing one woman, and blew down a tent city that had opened the first week in March to provide shelter for some of the estimated 5,000 people still homeless from the hurricane.
Bruce Netter, director of the tent city, which is operated by Dade County and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Miami, said that many of the families flocking to camp had recently been evicted from storm-damaged apartments by landlords who had received insurance checks and wanted to rebuild. Others had been ordered by county inspectors to leave their homes because they were unsafe.
 
Discouraging Odyssey
 Dianna Ackerman and her two sons, Joseph and David, were among the people who sought shelter at the camp as soon as it opened, moving into a brown canvas tent she mockingly calls "our penthouse." That decision was made only after a long, discouraging odyssey.
At the time of the hurricane, Ms. Ackerman was working at a fast-food restaurant and living in an apartment with her children and a friend who had signed the lease. When the building was destroyed, the friend decided to leave town. Ms. Ackerman took her remaining belongings and moved into a trailer camp operated by the Federal Emergency Management Administration.
But a few weeks ago, she said, she was told she was no longer eligible for the housing because she could not prove she had been living in the hurricane zone at the time of the storm. "I didn't have enough documentation, so they told me I had to leave," she said. "They gave me 48 hours to move out."
In some respects, Ms. Ackerman said, moving into the tent city came as a relief after the trailer camp, where she frequently heard gunfire and was robbed six times, losing a microwave oven, a coffee maker, dishes, linen, a bicycle and her children's video games.
"That was what hurt the most, losing the kids' stuff," she said. "And when somebody broke in just before Christmas and stole the presents from under the tree, I just snapped. I threw the tree out of the trailer, I was so angry."
But when residents of the tent city were evacuated to a local high school auditorium on March 12, she was robbed again. "I went to help set things up, and I left my purse on my cot," she said. "When I came back, somebody had rifled through it and taken the $165 I had saved up since the hurricane."
Ms. Ackerman said that while she hopes her lot will improve in the tent city, she still has moments of doubt.
"There are times I just have to go into the tent, close the flap and cry," she said. "It seems like this is never going to end."

HEADLINE: France's Conservatives Drive Home Their Victory

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 28

 BODY:
Confirming its strong showing in the first round of voting last weekend, France's main conservative coalition completed its trouncing of the governing Socialist Party today by winning a huge parliamentary majority in a runoff election.
Projections based on nearly complete results gave the Union for France coalition 487 seats in the 577-member National Assembly, reducing the once-powerful Socialists to an almost marginal 67 seats. The Communist Party and its allies won 23 seats, while the far-right National Front and an environmental alliance won no seats. 
 President Francois Mitterrand, whose second seven-year term ends in May 1995, is expected to name a conservative Prime Minister early this week. The favorite is Edouard Balladur, a former Finance Minister whose neo-Gaullist Rally for the Republic is the single largest party in the Assembly.
The new Government's main challenge will be to revive France's flagging economy. At home, it plans to privatize many state-owned corporations. Abroad, it is committed to defending French agriculture in global trade talks, a stance that could bring it into conflict with the United States.
 
Largest Majority Since 1815
 Although the conservative coalition was the first choice of only 39.5 percent of the voters last Sunday, it will control more than 84 percent of the seats in the National Assembly as a result of the country's unusual two-round voting system. That is the largest parliamentary majority enjoyed by any political group in France since 1815.
The neo-Gaullist leader, former Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, who hopes to succeed Mr. Mitterrand in the Elysee Palace in 1995, said tonight that "our responsibility is now as large as our success." He pledged that the Union for France would govern with "determination, moderation and tolerance."
The debacle for the Socialists is in turn expected to result in an uneasy "cohabitation" between the country's 76-year-old Socialist President and a conservative Government that is determined to exercise its powers to the full. Mr. Mitterrand, who was also forced to cohabit with a conservative Prime Minister from 1986 to 1988, is to address the nation on television Monday evening.
Tonight, Laurent Fabius, the Socialist Party's leader, said the left had experienced "a very severe defeat" and he blamed rising unemployment, corruption scandals, a feeling of insecurity and fatigue with the ruling party. "I don't think our ideals have been sanctioned, but rather some of our practices," he said.
The party suffered a particular setback in the runoff today when Michel Rocard, a former Prime Minister who has been considered the front-runner to become the Socialists' presidential candidate in 1995, lost his parliamentary seat to a little-known conservative challenger in a district of Les Yvelines outside Paris.
Last month, Mr. Rocard tried to raise his party's spirits by promising to form a broad new movement from the ruins of the Socialist Party after its widely predicted defeat. Tonight he said he remained a presidential contender, but his political standing has been badly undermined. "The left has lost and I have lost with it," he said.
Several other prominent Socialists also lost their seats in the Assembly, among them Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, former Education Minister Lionel Jospin, Justice Minister Michel Vauzelle, Industry Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn, Civil Service Minister Michel Delebarre and Kofi Yamgnane, the Integration Minister.
But some key Socialists whose political future had been in the balance held on to their districts, including Prime Minister Pierre Beregovoy, Culture Minister Jack Lang, Interior Minister Paul Quiles, Urban Affairs Minister Bernard Tapie and Mr. Fabius, the party leader.
The only well-known Socialist to emerge untainted from the debacle, though, is Jacques Delors, who currently heads the European Community's executive commission in Brussels and who was not a candidate today. Mr. Rocard's defeat has boosted Mr. Delors's hopes of winning the party's presidential nomination in 1995.
Among other political groups, the long-time Communist Party leader, Georges Marchais, won re-election, benefiting along with almost two dozen other party candidates from a concentration of Communist and anti-conservative voters in specific industrial districts.
 
Le Pen Loses in Nice
 But the leader of the extreme-rightist National Front, Jean-Marie Le Pen, lost with 40.5 percent of votes in his district in Nice, and Marie-France Stirbois, the only National Front lawmaker in the outgoing Assembly, was narrowly defeated. The only two environmentalist candidates eligible to take part in the runoff were also beaten.
The conservative sweep was signaled last Sunday when 80 conservatives -- and no Socialists -- won their seats outright with more than 50 percent of the vote, leaving 497 seats to be decided today. To take part in the runoff, candidates had to take more than 12.5 percent of the registered vote in the first round.
As the results came in tonight, Socialist, Communist and National Front leaders all complained bitterly about a voting system that so strongly favors a dominant party. "This assembly is not in the image of the country," Mr. Lang said. Mr. Le Pen, whose party ran third in the popular vote last Sunday, said the results of the runoff had confirmed the "glaring injustice" of the system.
Although the Union for France ran single candidates in all but 69 districts, its two main parties, the Rally for the Republic and the center-right Union for French Democracy, were nonetheless competing today for the right to nominate the new Prime Minister and assume the mantle of France's largest party.
 
Chirac Gets Edge Over Rival
 Projections gave Mr. Chirac's party 247 seats against 217 seats for the Union for French Democracy, which is headed by former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing. Other conservatives won an additional 23 seats. The results will also give Mr. Chirac a head start over Mr. Giscard d'Estaing in their already open race for the coalition's presidential nomination in 1995.
After the stunning defeat of the Socialists last Sunday, Mr. Chirac called on Mr. Mitterrand to "assume the consequences" and retire from office, paving the way for early presidential elections that polls say the neo-Gaullist leader would win. But Mr. Giscard d'Estaing pointedly reaffirmed Mr. Mitterrand's constitutional right to finish his term.
Two opinion polls taken last week to measure whether the public wants Mr. Mitterrand to leave office came up with contradictory results: the poll by Sofres said 51 percent wished him to remain in office; the B.V.A. poll said 55 percent hoped he would retire.
The President himself has made it clear that he will serve out his term if his health permits. He is suffering from prostate cancer, but remains active and visited Washington and Moscow this month. He also intends to exercise his constitutional right to determine French foreign policy.
Significantly, Mr. Rocard, who blamed Mr. Mitterrand two weeks ago for the Socialist Party's unpopularity, said tonight that he looked to the President to play "a fundamental role in preserving our institutions." He added: "He knows that he will have the support of everyone in France who values democracy."
