HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Secondary Market Is Sought

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Lawmakers in the House and the Senate are mapping out divergent paths to a common objective: creating a secondary market in which small-business loans can be bought and sold in much the same fashion that mortgage-backed securities are traded.
Advocates of a secondary market for small-business borrowings say it could unleash a flood of investment capital that would wash away the biggest obstacle facing many small companies: a lack of credit. 
 The point of creating a secondary market is that a bank that makes a loan to a small business will have a way to sell that loan, at a profit, to investors around the country. And the cash that the bank gets from the loan will enable it to make additional loans. So the secondary market is, in effect, a way to bring more people into the business of lending to small businesses and, at the same time, spread the risk of these loans.
 
 
Fundamental Difference
 But there is a fundamental difference between the approaches being offered by two New Yorkers, Representative John J. LaFalce, an upstate Democrat, and the state's Republican Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato. The House proposal would establish a Government agency to sponsor the transactions, while the Senate bill would just clear away some of the legal underbrush and let private business and finance manage the market.
Some bankers oppose the LaFalce bill, which would set up a Venture Enhancement and Loan Development Administration for Small, Undercapitalized Enterprises -- an elaborate name devised to produce the acronym Velda Sue, which would join a family tree of nicknamed Federal loan backers, like Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac, Ginnie Mae, Sallie Mae and Farmer Mac. The Independent Bankers Association of America contends that Government subsidies, even implicit ones, would undercut banks making traditional loans.
There are doubters of the D'Amato approach, too, including the North American Securities Administrators Association, a body of state regulators. In the association's view, the Senate proposal would not go far enough to standardize commercial loans before allowing investors to buy and trade them, and the resulting market would not be regulated enough.
Still, proponents of a secondary market say that whatever approach is adopted, it would carry enormous potential.
Marianne K. Smythe, director of the division of investment management at the Securities and Exchange Commission, said the commission had not endorsed a particular approach but thought that creating a secondary market was "probably the best -- and quite possibly the only -- technique for really ending the credit crunch that has afflicted small business across the country."
The S.E.C. has already freed some commercial lenders to package and resell certain loans, exempting them from some securities laws' provisions.
 
Shape of First Offering
 Already, the first such offering is being shaped. A thick prospectus now sitting on the S.E.C. shelves describes a share offering of the Fremont Small Business Loan Master Trust. What investors would be buying are shares in a pool of commercial loans made by a big lender, the Fremont Financial Corporation, to small businesses.
But the prospectus repeatedly emphasizes the drawbacks. "There currently is no secondary market" for the securities, "and there is no assurance that one will develop," Fremont cautions.
Despite the commission's decision last fall to exempt offerings like Fremont's from the burdens of the Investment Company Act of 1940, many legal and practical barriers remain to making the practice widespread. In particular, it is hard for banks to package and resell loans under current regulations, which for example can require the banks to retain capital to protect against loan losses even after the loans have been resold to other institutions or investors.
 
Government Guarantees
 A Government guarantee can go a long way toward removing the barriers, as is shown by the experience of the Small Business Administration. Last year, private lenders who arranged S.B.A. loans, which are 90 percent guaranteed, resold the guaranteed portions of the loans for $2.1 billion. Altogether, there are some 35,000 such loans worth $7 billion on the secondary market. The original lender increases its profits by holding onto the unguaranteed part of the loan and collecting service fees.
Other Government-sponsored organizations that sell securities backed by loans include the Student Loan Marketing Association (Sallie Mae), the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae), the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac), the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation (Farmer Mac) and the Resolution Trust Corporation.
But the complexity of doing so with ordinary commercial loans seems daunting, experts have testified in a series of hearings in recent weeks.
"Commercial loans are not standardized in either documentation or in terms of their underlying collateral," said Kenneth J. Bacon, director of Resolution Trust's securitization office, which has used asset-backed securities to work off $35 billion in mortgages previously owned by bankrupt savings and loans.
 "For some types of business loans, the appropriate credit analysis is much more complicated than it is for others, and credit rating agency criteria are much less developed. The servicing is complicated, because most commercial loans take the form of a line of credit. This means that principal balances can change radically from month to month as borrowers either make payments to or advances against their line of credit."
And the debt of small companies would, especially at first, seem like the kind of investment that keeps people awake at night.
Unlike a $20 million package of mortgages, which might spread the risk across 200 borrowers, a similar-size package of small-business loans might involve only a handful of borrowers. Investors would look closely at the borrowers, and the shares would probably be priced and traded more like corporate bonds than like mortgage-backed securities. Rating agencies, meanwhile, might be very conservative in grading the securities. It is not clear that the borrowers' costs would go down under these circumstances.

HEADLINE: Shoreham Plant Is Proposed As Terminal for New Ferry

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WADING RIVER, L.I., March 25

 BODY:
When the Shoreham nuclear-power plant was built here more than a decade ago amid protests and fears of a nuclear accident, no one envisioned it as a peaceful ferry terminal.
But a deep canal built to draw water from Long Island Sound to cool the nuclear plant's reactors may now become safe harbor for a new class of high-speed ferry service to Connecticut. 
 With the controversial $5 billion plant being decommissioned for possible conversion to a gas-powered electric generator, state planners are looking for ways to use the rest of the site.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo envisions a privately operated ferry service from Shoreham to New Haven, using high-speed vessels that could carry cars and tractor-trailers. The service would cut travel time across the sound to less than an hour and would ease some of the traffic congestion on the Long Island Expressway, the Throgs Neck Bridge and the New England Thruway in the Bronx, Westchester County and southwest Connecticut.
 
Advocates and Opponents
 A ferry terminal would be built at the end of the 12-foot-deep Shoreham canal, which could be widened at one end for the ferries to turn around. And since Shoreham occupies about 80 acres of a 449-acre site owned by the Long Island Lighting Company in the Town of Brookhaven, there would be plenty of space for parking and ferry support buildings, said Richard Kessel, chairman of the Long Island Power Authority.
But the ferry project is not without its opponents, and it would require approval of state and local officials in both New York and Connecticut, as well as Lilco, which still owns much of the property around Shoreham.
So far, Connecticut officials have agreed to cooperate with New York in developing the project, and Lilco has taken a wait-and-see position. The power authority, which bought Shoreham from Lilco for a dollar under a state plan to decommission the nuclear plant, is one of the biggest advocates of the ferry proposal.
Mr. Kessel recently led a group of local officials and six potential bidders for ferry service around the site. They walked over landfill to the edge of the canal and peered out over two manmade jetties that extend northward into Long Island Sound.
Mr. Kessel said Long Island had suffered over the last decade because of the Shoreham controversy. "It's been a noose around our neck," he said, "but an alternative use like this would help ease that tragedy, as well as the economic drain on the Island."
 
Bids for Conversion
 He said Mr. Cuomo wanted to consider all alternative uses for Shoreham. And while the state would not subsidize a ferry service, he said, the Urban Development Corporation would help with the financing.
Mr. Kessel said the process of decomissioning Shoreham was several months ahead of schedule and could possibly be completed by the end of this year. He said that three consortiums had filed bids to convert the plant to a gas-powered electric generator and that the power authority would decide on the matter soon.
Among those touring the site was Capt. Brian McAllister, president of the century-old Bridgeport-Port Jefferson Steamboat Company. He said he was concerned that a Shoreham-New Haven ferry service might take away at least 50 percent of his current business and that he would like to make some runs from the Shoreham terminal to hold on to those passengers. His line, founded in 1883 by a group of businessmen, including P. T. Barnum, carries about 700,000 riders a year.
Mr. Kessel said, "The last thing the state wants to do is hurt other businesses." He suggested that perhaps a consortium might be interested in developing the new ferry terminal so that more than one line could use it.
Henry L. Peryebrune, assistant commissioner of the New York State Department of Transportation, said the question about the impact on the Bridgeport-Port Jefferson line had come up in Connecticut. He that it would be up to private investors to determine that impact and risk and that neither state could be expected to subsidize a new ferry line.
A terminal at Shoreham would be linked directly with the William Floyd Parkway, which runs south to Fire Island, crossing the Long Island Expressway at mid-island. Besides the Bridgeport-Port Jefferson line, the only ferry service across Long Island Sound is at the eastern end between Orient Point and New London, Conn., which also serves as a hub for summer service to Block Island and Fishers Island.

HEADLINE: In Russia, It's Business as Usual

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
As they watched the tug-of-war between President Boris N. Yeltsin and Russian lawmakers unfold last week, American companies with operations in Russia went stoically about their business, even as events reinforced the risk and uncertainty of functioning in a country at odds with itself over the pace and direction of economic change.
In part, the lack of reaction reflected a realization on the part of many businesses that nothing much of substance could be done in a situation that was changing by the hour. 
 "We don't think there is much need to react quickly, because our products are part of daily life, and daily life goes on," Rudy Kunert, the senior vice president in charge of Central and Eastern Europe at the Otis Elevator Company, said in a telephone interview from his Paris office.
Otis has four joint-venture companies in Russia, the newest of which began work on March 1.
Since the breakup of the Soviet Union, companies doing business there have come to see developments at the municipal level as having more immediate relevance to their operations than power struggles in the central Government. "Many companies have made their deals with regional authorities, so what happens in Moscow has little effect on them," said Robert Hormats, vice chairman at Goldman Sachs International.
"That is certainly true in cities like St. Petersburg and Volgograd, which are moving further toward reform than the reformists in Moscow," he said. "The fact is that the role of Moscow in many regional decisions has declined substantially. I don't know if that is reversible, even if a hard-line group resistant to foreign investment and foreign companies came in."
And then, too, companies that have operated in the country for some time said events of the last week carried with them a very real sense of deja vu.
"We had tanks moving past our office during the 1991 coup, but in Moscow our office stayed open and helped customers," said Andrew B. Somers, executive vice president and general counsel at American Express, which has offices in Moscow and St. Petersburg and has been doing business in the country since the late 1800's except for a period during Stalin's rule. "We are used to the uncertainty of the system."
Despite Russia's vast commercial potential, the thought of operating amid continuing crisis has kept all but the hardiest from venturing in. And even though the pace of commercial exploration by American companies seems to be picking up, at this point it remains well below that in other Eastern European nations.
 
200 Joint Ventures
 As of now, there are 200 joint ventures involving American companies in Russia, according to the U.S.-Russia Business Council, a Washington-based trade association established earlier this year. The council estimates total direct investment by American companies over the last five years to be only a bit more than $400 million.
During that time 300 companies have opened offices in Russia, the council says, up from 40 just two years ago. Still, the level of activity pales in comparison with what could be expected in a country with 150 million inhabitants and vast oil and natural gas reserves.
In Hungary, which has a population of 10.5 million, Western companies invested $1.5 billion in 1992 alone.
"The uncertain political and legal environment are the big problems in Russia," Mr. Hormats said. "It's not so much that the country is in a deep recession that borders on a depression. It's knowing whether or not the entity you are dealing with is speaking with authority."
 
Oil Companies Waiting
 Indeed, Western oil companies scrambling to nail down deals in Russia and the rest of the former Soviet Union, are holding up what are likely to be tens of billions of dollars worth of investments until critical legal issues are resolved.
Phibro Energy Production, a subsidiary of Salomon Inc., is one oil company that did not wait. But its experience is a testament to why Mobil, Exxon, Shell and Marathon remain on the sidelines.
In the two and a half years since it received approval from the Soviet Government to begin development drilling in three oil fields in western Siberia, Phibro has sunk well over $100 million into its White Nights joint venture.
But Phibro maintains that new tax laws have completely undermined the economic viability of the project. The most significant is an export tax on hard currency earned, a tax that Brian Lavers, the chairman of Phibro Energy, says takes away 30 percent of gross revenues.
 
Tax Exemption Delayed
 Heavy lobbying by then-Ambassador Robert S. Strauss persuaded Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar to exempt Phibro last July from the tax. But late last year Mr. Gaidar, a leading advocate of economic change, was forced out, and Phibro's exemption has not yet been implemented.
"We have submitted documents to various committees for the past nine months," Mr. Lavers said in a telephone interview from his home in Sussex, England, "and all indications are they have everything they need and we will get the exemption in the next few weeks. Present events could crater all of that."
Once the export tax is exempted, Mr. Lavers said, "we should have enough money to slowly but surely build up our production further and get into the black."
Mr. Somers at American Express said the Russian Government's progress toward developing a legal system "in tune" with modern commerce was slow and erratic.
"An enormous amount of work remains to be done," he said. "But they are trying and have extremely bright and able lawyers and judges. I am optimistic that over the next few years they will have developed a commercial framework that will make it easier to operate."

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Rise on Stronger Export Demand

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Machine tool orders rose sharply in February, in part because of strong export orders, the industry's trade association will report today.
The data provide further signs, along with recent figures that showed stronger factory orders, higher production and longer workweeks, that the health of American manufacturing continues to improve. 
 Machine tool orders, which tend to swing wildly from month to month, surged 61.5 percent in February from January, to $283.6 million, according to the Association for Manufacturing Technology in McLean, Va., which plans to release the figures today.
A better gauge of the underlying trend is that for the first two months of 1993, orders were 5.9 percent ahead of those in the corresponding period last year. Shipments, meanwhile, were down 5.1 percent from January, to $236.2 million, but up 17.5 percent for the year to date.
Machine tools are metal-cutting and metal-forming machines that are used in the production of most capital equipment, from aircraft to bulldozers to generators, as well as automobiles and appliances. Forecasters watch the $7 billion machine tool sector because its ups and downs can signal trends in business investment and exports. Exports account for about one-sixth of the market for American tools.
While the report is upbeat, it hardly suggests a boom or an imminent spurt in hiring. Orders so far this year are not running ahead of shipments the way they did last year. And order backlogs are a shade below the average for 1992. The pattern hints that equipment spending for the United States market remains robust, but that it may not necessarily keep rising at the 14 percent annual rate of last year's final quarter.
Prospects for machine tool exports, however, seem to be brighter. Export orders were up 14.5 percent in February, to $39.5 million. For the year to date, export orders were 70.5 percent higher than for the corresponding period last year and were running slightly ahead of shipments abroad.

HEADLINE: Trade Growth Rate Rises

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 28

 BODY:
The growth rate of world trade increased in 1992 for the first time in four years as North America emerged from recession and large developing countries maintained their strong demand for imports, the governing body for world trade says.
In its annual world trade report, to be released Monday, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said the volume of world merchandise trade increased last year by 4.5 percent. That was 1.5 percentage points more than in 1991 and was the first time a slowdown in growth had been reversed since a global recession began in 1989. The overall value of trade rose by 5.5 percent, while trade in commercial services -- including transportation, telecommunications, banking and insurance -- grew by 8 percent. 
 GATT said North America, mainly the United States, and Asian countries excluding Japan were the best-performing regions for both export and import growth. Imports grew sharply in large Latin American states and in the Middle East.
Although there were signs the overall trend would continue this year, the report warned that economic problems in Western Europe and Japan could darken the outlook.
"If the forecasts of a modest pickup in world economic growth in 1993 turn out to be correct, it is plausible to expect an expansion of world trade in real terms of at least equal to the 4.5 percent recorded last year," the report said.
But it said there was a widely shared perception, partly based on a slowdown in trade expansion in the second half of 1992 when the rate was well below the average for the year, that "much of the risk was on the downside."
The report said that the countries expected to show relative strength in 1993 were in North America and Asia, particularly Hong Kong, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan and Thailand.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Health Plan: Sweeping Yet Selective

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
The sweeping plan to change New York State's health care system, unveiled by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on Saturday -- with its proposed regulation of doctors' fees, limitations on high-cost technology and encouragement of primary care medicine -- was perhaps most significant for what it did not say.
The Governor and his advisers faced a complex spectrum of options, many of which have been tried in other states and all of which are before the health care task force forging a national policy in Washington. What Mr. Cuomo chose and did not choose is a measure of the political and emotional status of the debate, a prediction of what the Clinton Administration will propose, and an attempt to respond to the health care crisis and influence the outcome of the debate.
 
Philosophy and Economics
 He did not, for instance, propose that the state insure all its citizens. Hawaii, the only state that currently takes on that responsibility, has been doing so for 17 years, by requiring employers to pick up the cost of insurance premiums for any person working more than 20 hours a week. Vermont, which has the only Governor who is a doctor, has passed a plan that would provide universal health insurance by 1995. And Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey has proposed the state subsidize private-health-care groups, like health maintenance organizations, to pay for the uninsured. 
 Philosophy, as well as economics, led to the decision against state-financed univer sal health care, said Michael J. Dowling, the Governor's director of Health, Education and Human Services.
"That's the job of the Federal Government," Mr. Dowling said in a telephone interview. "If they leave coverage to the states, then we're all in trouble."
The release of the Cuomo report five weeks before the Clinton Administration is scheduled to complete its own report will ideally communicate that message to Washington, Mr. Dowling said.
"We did think of that, yes" Mr. Dowling said. "We would hope the President would look at this."
Something else the Cuomo proposal does not do, which the Clinton task force is believed to be leaning toward doing, is to require a system of managed competition under which organized networks of doctors and hospitals compete for large groups of consumers and businesses by offering low prices and high quality.
Perhaps the best known model of this plan is in California, where the California Public Employees Retirement System, or Calpers, represents more than 875,000 state and local employees and their families. Calpers shops for the best deals from insurance companies, and last year kept its rate increase to 3.1 percent when the state average was 13.2 percent.
 
A 40-Page 'Blueprint'
 The 40-page Cuomo proposal is described as a "blueprint" rather than a detailed plan, but it seems designed to encourage managed competition, not require it.
"We will encourage health-care professionals to join with one another to coordinate a whole range of health-care services for their patients," the report says. "Further, we will encourage professionals to join with institutional providers of care to create comprehensive service organizations or consortia, called 'Preferred Health Networks.' "
The argument against requiring patients and doctors to band into negotiating groups is two-fold, Mr. Dowling said. Most important, he said, competition does not apply to medicine as it does to the marketplace. When two neighboring hospitals compete, he said, they create a "medical arms race" paying ever higher salaries to attract doctors and ever more equipment to attract patients.
Competition has been the rule, he said, "for 100 years and so far it hasn't worked."
In addition, he said, requiring patients to join a health maintenance organization does not sit well with many patients, who polls suggest cherish the ability to choose their doctor. The potential requirement that patients join a health maintenance organization is one of the most controversial topics before the Clinton task force.
"You've got to find a balance between saying to the public this is where you go and who you see," Mr. Dowling said, "but at the same timing keeping some control over the situation."
 
Shift Away From Specialists
 The control in the Cuomo proposal takes three forms. First, it encourages a shift from the higher priced specialists, who currently make up 70 percent of doctors in the state, to lower priced primary care doctors, like internists, family practitioners and pediatricians, who currently account for the other 30 percent. Mr. Cuomo's plan would attempt to flip that ratio by encouraging doctors to go into primary care with such incentives as higher reimbursement for primary care treatment, state assumption of the medical school loans of primary care doctors, and grants to medical schools that emphasize primary care.
Second, the plan would whittle at what the report calls the "overuse" of medical care. Noting that there are more Magnetic Resonance Imaging machines in the eight counties of Western New York than in all of Canada, the Cuomo administration would require the state to approve purchases by doctors of equipment costing more than $400,000. In addition, the state would try to monitor the impulse of doctors and the demands of patients to use new drugs and new machines simply because they are available.
The phrasing of the part of the proposal aimed at reducing such overuse is yet another example of what Mr. Cuomo chose not to do. The Governor did not propose a rationing system similar to the one in place in Oregon, where 688 medical procedures are ranked according to their effectiveness, and the state refuses to pay for any procedures ranked below 568. The money saved by not paying for those categories will provide Medicaid for 120,000 Oregonians who would otherwise have no insurance.
The problem with the Oregon model, Mr. Dowling said, is that it only addresses overuse among Medicaid recipients, and does not touch most of the highest costs of care.
 
Regulation of Fees
 Which leads to perhaps the most controversial part of the Cuomo proposal -- the regulation of all doctors' fees. The capping of fees would be phased in slowly, and the Governor has said that outpatient surgical rates would be the first to be regulated, beginning as early as 1996. The rates could be set either specifically or in ranges and would vary by region. Eventually the state could control all doctors' fees for all procedures and all patients, regardless of how patients were insured.
It is unclear whether doctors could learn to work around the limits. Medicare currently caps fees, but an industry has grown up to help doctors work the system to best advantage -- computer software, for instance, that determines how best to describe a procedure so that it qualifies for the highest possible reimbursement, or breaking up a procedure into several parts, the sum of which is reimbursed at a higher rate than the whole.
It is also unclear whether, and in what form, the Cuomo proposal will finally be approved. Action from Washington might make many of its provisions moot. The Democratic-controlled Assembly has, in the past, favored a system of state-financed universal health care and may quarrel with its absence from the Governor's plan. The Republican-led Senate, in turn, has long been considered a protector of physicians and hospitals and an opponent of regulation.
What is clear is that the plan, if adopted, will make New York the only state with such widespread cost controls.

SECTION: Section C; Page 3; Column 4; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 770 words

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Madness That Goes Past March

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

 BODY:
THE Knight Commission recently released its bold analysis of intercollegiate athletics and told us everything that is required in order to wreak reform: The presidents of the universities, of all people, should take control of their institutions, and they, along with administrators, faculty, coaches, students, athletes, boosters, parents, and, presumably, the librarians, the book sellers, the volunteer fire fighters, the chimney sweeps and the bartenders, among others, must also strive together to advance the notion of "academic integrity, financial integrity and accountability through certification."
And all along most of us thought that that's what these universities were supposed to be up to, to begin with. 
 And the timing of the release -- a four-year study, in fact -- was perfect, at the height of March Madness, when television networks pay billions of dollars to universities to show their scholars chasing basketballs all across the country. For some, this passes for the pursuit of higher education.
And it appears highly unlikely that anything will change significantly. The reason is, few in charge truly want to make major changes or have the courage to do so.
The Knight Commission, as Barbara Bergmann, an economics professor at American University and a former president of the American Association of University Professors, said, was "essentially a cheerleader for the whole regime."
"What we have to deal with, and what wasn't dealt with by the Commission," she said, "was fake students taking fake courses. We have professional athletes on college campuses, and everything flows from that."
The inherent evil in all this is that it corrupts the whole notion of the values and ethics a university is supposed to be teaching. The university essentially holds itself up as a model of virtue. Many, in fact, are a model of hypocrisy. And high-stepping at the head of this parade of 76 trombones plus a trio of 7-footers from the basketball team and a passel of 300-pounders from the football squad is the school president.
What wasn't said by the Knight Commission, a "blue-ribbon panel" funded by the Knight Foundation, is that big-time athletics must be corrupt, or, at least, a distortion of the purpose of a university. How can it be otherwise when, for example, the basketball coach is paid so extravagantly?
Basketball coaches often earn twice the salary of professors in less visible arenas, like a chemistry lab. With other incentives provided and allowed by the university, like lucrative shoe contracts, a basketball coach like Rick Pitino of Kentucky makes close to $1 million a year.
The demands on the time of big-time student-athletes, meanwhile, from practice to travel to weight room, are so great that they can only be the best athletes they can be, not the best students. And this is the emphasis by the coaches, regardless of rhetoric to the contrary. It is a long chain: the best athletes, dreaming of making the pros that only a handful realize, make the best teams, which make the coaches profitable, which puts a glow on the cheek of the athletic director, which makes the president purr, which gets the trustees to puff out their chests, which makes the governor count his votes for reelection.
A small item in the papers last week reflects just how far the "new model for intercollegiate athletics," as the Knight Commission calls its study, has to go:
Pat Foster, the basketball coach at the University of Houston, is taking the job at the University of Nevada at Reno, after that school fired Len Stevens for -- what else? -- not winning enough games. Besides Foster's base salary of $115,000, Nevada will pay him $1 a head for each fan over an attendance of 4,500 at home games. The Wolf Pack last year averaged only 4,427 fans in its 11,140-seat arena.
Surely, Nevada hopes to fill seats the way its in-state rival, that institution of athletic rectitude, U.N.L.V., has. The Nevada-Reno president signed off on this, of course. How does he expect Foster to fill the seats? With a better team. How does Foster get a better team? He recruits it. And who, dear heart, will he recruit? Members of the National Honor Society?
The electricity of March Madness and April Apoplexy is provided by professional entertainers. The last point was not raised in the Knight Commission report. In fact, the only way for legitimate change is for the players to either be paid and retained as students as they themselves decide, or for the schools to return athletics to its original intent, a basic recreation.
The rest, as they say in academia, is cheerleading.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Big Insurer's Path to Crisis Is Study in Mismanagement

SERIES: Lost Millions: The Empire Blue Cross Story -- First of three articles

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH with DEAN BAQUET

 BODY:
Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the nation's largest nonprofit health insurer, has lost tens of millions of dollars over the last decade through a series of management mistakes that have mired the company in financial crisis and undermined its dominant role in New York's health care system.
Empire, which can turn no customer away, has complained loudly of the battering it takes from giant commercial insurance companies, who can pick and choose their customers, offering policies to the healthiest and rejecting the sickest. And commercial insurers concede that their goal is to find the youngest and healthiest pool of customers.
 
Quality Customers Lost
 But an examination of Empire's management, including internal company reports and state audits, and interviews with 16 current and former high-ranking executives, shows that many of the company's problems are of its own making. 
 It lost more than $100 million on what officials concede was a poorly conceived health maintenance organization. Major corporate customers, the gravy of the health insurance industry, have defected from Empire over complaints about poor service. And Empire has created a public-relations nightmare for itself, angering legislators and attracting auditors by spending millions on perquisites and politically connected consultants and lobbyists.
At the core of Empire's problems is a series of computer fiascos that have spanned nearly two decades. Empire's inability to build a computer system that could keep track of tens of millions of claims, the heart of any insurance company's business, has cost it millions of dollars and fostered a reputation for poor service.
 
Costly Computer Problems
 In the mid-1980's, for example, Empire was forced to write off $50 million that had gone uncollected or unbilled because of computer problems dating to the mid-1970's, according to an internal report obtained by The New York Times.
One glitch involved a computer system that could not understand bills of $100,000 or more. A $103,000 premium, for example, would be interpreted as only $3,000, and the smaller amount would be billed to the client. That failure occurred 29 times and cost Empire $3 million, the report said.
Albert A. Cardone, Empire's chief executive officer, said such problems are ancient history. Empire is in financial trouble, he said, because it has stuck to its mission of providing insurance to as many people as possible, despite a national health care crisis.
"Empire deserves an enormous amount of credit for fidelity to a mission that is in the best interest of New York State," he said. He called Empire the "safety net" of the health-care system. "God help us if the safety net breaks," he added.
The problems of Empire are not unique among the 71 companies that make up the nationwide Blue Cross and Blue Shield network. Last year more than a dozen Blue Cross plans were on a financial watch list for failing to meet the reserve requirements of the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association.
 
Under Mounting Scrutiny
 And in recent months, Federal and state regulators have raised questions about the business practices of many of the companies, including the payment of high salaries and pensions to top officials of financially ailing plans. Congressional investigators, who have already looked into Blue Cross plans in several states, are in the initial stages of an inquiry into whether mismanagement contributed to Empire's recent losses.
Empire officials say they have worked mightily to resolve the technical problems that have led to complaints about service. The company spends millions of dollars each year to survey customers to pinpoint problems. And it has recently increased supervision of its customer-service staff.
Still, the computer problems persist. An expensive new electronic system for handling claims -- being developed by a former board member -- was expected to be finished about 18 months ago, but is not likely to be completed until later this year.Empire has invested $17 million in that venture.
Another failed computer system -- purchased from another Blue Cross and Blue Shield organization -- was a primary reason for the huge losses of Healthnet, Empire's health maintenance organization. But more than that, the problems have caused an exodus of some of Empire's most valued customers, and created a lingering aura of incompetence.
The financial troubles of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield organizations have emerged just as the Clinton Administration begins to assess the role insurance companies will play in a reshaped health- care system.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, saying that New York cannot wait for Washington to act, Saturday proposed sweeping changes in the state's health care system that would have a major impact on the way Empire and its commercial competitors do business. Under one part of the plan, every health insurer in the state would have to offer coverage to everyone, as Empire does now.
 
The Threat
Depleted Reserves A Major Concern
 By the late 1980's, Empire found itself in a weakened position, just as big commercial insurers were making significant inroads in luring customers in New York. The increased competition for young, healthy customers, combined with Empire's own mistakes, has depleted the company's reserves and caused it to lose $250 million in the last two years.
By law, Empire should have more than $500 million in reserve, the financial cushion deemed essential by regulators, but in recent years, the state has waived the requirement for Empire. The company ended 1992 with about $40 million, and turned to the state for a 25 percent rate increase and a one-time rebate of $100 million from a state insurance fund.
"I would say that they're in a position where nobody's going to cut them any slack," said Salvatore R. Curiale, the state insurance superintendent. He said he agrees with Empire's assessment that the company's financial problems are largely the result of bruising competition from commercial insurers.
Mr. Curiale said he had met recently with Thomas Kinser, the executive vice president of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, to discuss Empire's fate. He quoted Mr. Kinser as saying that Empire is in danger of being thrown out of the national organization. Losing the affiliation would further damage Empire's image and destroy its ability to share business with other Blue Cross plans.
 
A Nationwide Burden?
 Mr. Curiale said, "The national members, the various Blue Cross and Blue Shield associations out there, are scared to death that here we have a seven-million-plus-subscriber company, the biggest of the plans, that somehow if it fails, they will be saddled with that responsibility."
Mr. Kinser said the association had told Empire that it must bring its reserves to $90 million by the end of 1993.
While acknowledging the financial difficulties, Mr. Cardone said: "We never missed a beat; we never missed a claim payment; we never missed a payroll. We have experienced some incredible distractions around here with all of these barbs coming at us that we're mismanaged."
State officials acknowledge that a health care system without Empire -- something once unimagined -- could have a disastrous effect on a system already in crisis. The Legislature has hired Arthur Andersen & Company to determine whether Empire is well managed.
Some legislators have accused the state Insurance Department of not being more aggressive in overseeing Empire.
 
A Special Mandate
 Mr. Curiale rejects the criticism. "We were regulating the company to the extent that we're permitted by law," he said, "and also to the extent of our expertise. We can't go in there and say, 'This is what you should do with your computer system, this is what you should do with your marketing.' "
Empire provides insurance for 8.5 million people in 28 counties from the New York City area to Albany. Eighty-five percent are in large group policies sponsored mostly by big corporations and labor unions. These are Empire's best customers because they include many young and healthy people.
But 15 percent of the policies are in the individual and small-group markets. These are the customers commercial insurers have long avoided by charging them high rates or simply denying them coverage. The state's health insurance system is built around Empire's promise that it will accept any customer who can afford its premiums, no matter how sick, and set rates without regard to sex, age, or medical condition.
In return, Empire does not have to pay state or city taxes, including property taxes on the skyscraper it owns in midtown Manhattan. Most significantly, it pays hospital charges that are 24 percent lower than those paid by profit-making insurance companies.
But last year Empire complained that the commercial insurers were siphoning their best customers. In response, the Legislature passed a law, which will take effect Thursday, requiring insurers that sell policies to small groups to take all customers, regardless of their health or occupation.
 
The Background
A Merger Creates A Troubled Match
 Although Empire did not begin losing money until 1989, the seeds of its present crisis were planted in 1974, when the state forced the marriage of two nonprofit health care insurers, Associated Hospital Service, which handled hospital claims, and United Medical Service, which handled claims for doctors' bills. The new company became known as Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York.
The state hoped that Associated Hospital would shore up the financially troubled United Medical. While the new company did well financially, the merger created lasting problems involving the handling of claims for doctors' bills. For doctors, claims filing is a haphazard affair. Many still resist using computers, and their rates vary widely. By contrast, hospitals have entire departments devoted to filing accurate and standardized claims.
For the last 20 years, the company has been engaged in a costly, frustrating and largely unsuccessful struggle to build a computer system that can handle these claims efficiently.
In addition to the $50 million write-off in the mid-1980's, Empire encountered another major computer problem involving the handling of claims for New York-based corporations with workers scattered around the country.
 
Massive Computer Problems
 Typically, an Empire customer outside New York sends a claim to the local Blue Cross and Blue Shield plan, which pays the claim and sends the bill on to Empire for reimbursement. Empire then bills the employer. The system began to break down in 1984. The new computer rejected claims missing trivial information, like ZIP codes, creating a backlog of claims worth tens of millions of dollars.
As the company tried to catch up, it double-billed some employers and failed to bill others, according to an internal report prepared for the company by Louis A. Craco, a lawyer hired in 1988 to investigate allegations of mismanagement lodged by the company's former treasurer, Gustave O. Mattia. Altogether, Empire lost as much as $80 million because of the computer problem, company records show.
In a 1989 interview with state regulators, Empire's controller, Stephen B. Bell, said the big corporations became increasingly frustrated with the foul-ups. Some dropped Empire and signed up with other companies.
 
The Medicine
A New Venture Leads to Big Losses
 One of Empire's most troublesome problems in recent years has been Healthnet, the health maintenance organization that has lost more than $100 million. It was set up in 1985 in response to commercial insurance companies that were flooding New York with their own HMOs. Under most HMO plans, customers pay a fee that covers virtually all the medical services they may need throughout the year.
Dr. Michael Bihari, Healthnet's former medical director who left Empire in September 1992, said Healthnet failed for a variety of reasons, including poor planning and bad timing. Despite the popularity of HMOs in other parts of the country a decade ago, he said, New Yorkers were skeptical and preferred to stay with doctors they knew.
But one of Healthnet's chief problems was its computer system, he said. "Anything that could go wrong with a computer system went wrong."
Over the objections of some Empire computer experts, the HMO managers decided to use a system created by the Michigan Blue Cross and Blue Shield plan, according to a former high-ranking executive who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
 
A Costly Failure
 The executive, who was familiar with Empire's computer operations, said the system could not keep track of the complex formula used to calculate payments to doctors who participated in Healthnet. Within two years, Empire had scrapped the system and turned to another computer.
From its inception, Healthnet was headed for problems, Dr. Bihari said. For several months, until Dr. Bihari was hired in 1986, it had no medical director. As a result, when more than 10,000 doctors applied to join Healthnet, the staff was overwhelmed and had trouble evaluating the doctors.
Some doctors lost interest in Healthnet because it became clear that it could send them far fewer patients than it had promised, said Dr. Bihari, who now works for a health care network in Connecticut. And each one required enormous paperwork. "It was a huge network with very few members," he said.
At its peak, Healthnet had about 6,000 doctors and about 120,000 patients, a far smaller ratio than Healthnet had hoped for, Dr. Bihari said. About one-third of the doctors were primary care physicians who, in a normal practice, would have had between 1,000 and 3,000 patients, he said. Instead, they had 60 or 70 patients each.
 
Learning From Mistakes
 Eventually, Healthnet got into a "death spiral," Dr. Bihari said. Because it was losing money, the company had to raise premiums. But the higher premiums drove away the healthiest customers. That left sicker people in the plan, who where more expensive to treat, so rates had to be raised.
He said Empire has learned from its mistakes at Healthnet and used the knowledge to form a second managed care network called Empire Blue Choice.
After a year, it is meeting its early goals and has 58,000 patients and about 6,000 doctors, 2,000 of whom are primary care physicians, the company said. It is expected to lose money in the first years, but could undergo significant expansion if, as expected, the Clinton Administration's health-care proposals include an emphasis on managed care.
Mr. Cardone acknowledged the losses to Empire, but said the harm to the company might have been greater if Healthnet had not been created. Commercial insurance companies, he said, might have lured away even more of Empire's customers.
Mr. Cardone said Empire is "perfectly positioned" to play a major role in an overhauled health care system because of its historic focus on providing insurance to as many people as possible. "Our culture is not to find how to dump people," he said. "It is to find how to insure them."
Despite all of Empire's internal problems, Mr. Cardone said the company was making money until the commercial insurers began their "cherry picking" assault on the company in the 1980's.
"We are up against competitors who are misbehaving," he said.
Empire says it has lost 30 percent of its small-group customers and 35 percent of its individual accounts over the last three years. And these were the healthiest customers, according to the company. The average person who left had $1,590 a year in medical bills, compared to $2,820 for those who stayed, leaving Empire with a customer base that is sicker, older, and more expensive to treat.
Empire said the problem has worsened because commercial insurers have become sophisticated at identifying and luring away low-risk customers. Some refuse to take on high-risk professions, like people who handle hazardous waste, the company said. Others are far less blatant, opting instead to offer the sick and elderly exorbitant rates.
 
Seeking Healthy Customers
 Mr. Cardone said the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America is one of the worst cherry-pickers. But Edward K. Kane, senior vice president and general counsel of The Guardian, said that Empire is looking for a scapegoat for its problems by putting a sinister cast on an essential business practice.
The heart of insurance underwriting, he said, is risk selection, which means going after the healthiest customers.
"We've been doing this for 35 years," he said. "Why are they complaining now. Nothing has changed in the last three years. All the tax breaks they get is to make up for the fact that they do not do risk-selection. I think Empire's financial problems run far deeper."

HEADLINE: How to Break Food-Stamp Cycle

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Food Stamps Users Up Sharply in Sign of Weak Recovery" (front page, March 2): 
 One reason for the continuing growth of food stamps that you do not mention relates to the working poor, who head more than one-quarter of all food-stamp households. A higher proportion of workers are poor than in the past, largely because there are fewer better-paying industrial and unionized jobs. Fewer jobs offer wages based on the value of the employee to the employer, and more and more are based on what an employee will accept as an alternative to no job at all, which is not much of a choice.
But it goes beyond that. Economists, politicians and journalists talk about our market economy, but most ignore the market effects of the food stamp program. Wage levels do not just happen. They are based on what an employee is willing to accept. Thanks to food stamps, a low-wage employee can accept less. The less an employer pays, the more food stamp program pays proportionally.
Each year more and more wages are set at artificially low levels, and the taxpayer makes up the difference, in effect subsidizing employers. That is one reason food stamp costs have risen 50 percent faster than the food stamp population. Unemployment compensation benefits have also been depressed, as well as the wages of many not on food stamps.
The crisis in food stamps has been building since median income started falling 20 years ago. Presidents Carter and Reagan responded by reducing benefits; but this merely lowered the real poverty standard and made more people poor. More than 10 percent of Americans now collect food stamps. Something has to be done.
There is a good solution available, and that is to raise the minimum wage, for example to $8 an hour. This would accomplish several things: It would reduce the effect of food stamp benefits on wages; it would reduce food stamp disbursements without hurting recipients; it would reduce the deficit significantly; it would stimulate the economy; it would reduce crime and social problems.
The costs, which I won't go into here, are well outweighed by the benefits. Note that it should preferably be done in conjunction with a proper trade policy that protects our people from unfair sweatshop competition from overseas, which is brutal to people in this country and abroad.
Our fiscal and economic crisis presents a special opportunity for our Government to change its focus away from disbursing funds and toward passing laws that make the private sector fulfill its responsibilities. It is also a chance to switch from "trickle-down" economics to an economics in which demand is increased from the bottom up.
The 1980's demonstrated that increased demand (from the middle and upper class) was not inflationary, despite what economists have always claimed to the contrary. This was because the economy has plenty of capacity. It is time for the Clinton Administration to learn from this and start solving problems in ways that are fair and cost-effective, and that also work.
 
HUGH FIELD
Norwood, Mass., March 15, 1993
 
The writer is a food stamps data analyst in the Massachusetts Department of Public Welfare.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

LENGTH: 295 words

HEADLINE: Change in Puerto Rico Will Affect Mainland

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Hurricane Bill Threatens San Juan" (Op-Ed, March 11) by Rafael Hernandez Colon, former Governor of Puerto Rico:
Puerto Rico will not be the only victim of a Clinton Administration plan to wipe out tax incentives to companies that build plants in United States commonwealths and territories. The proposal's impact will ripple clear up to New York City. 
 As Governor Colon points out, studies by two respected accounting organizations foresee widespread and devastating economic havoc sweeping Puerto Rico when American pharmaceutical companies leave the island in response to the demise of these tax breaks.
Where do unemployed Puerto Rican workers look when their luck turns sour? Northward to New York City. Through this century, economic downturns in Puerto Rico have spurred large-scale migrations. New York may be in relative economic doldrums, but from the climate of a perpetually struggling economy like Puerto Rico's, these difficulties often seem slight by comparison.
New York City, Chicago, Orlando and other United States cities, which are ensnarled in their own fiscal woes, are ill equipped to provide thousands of new immigrants with jobs, housing and social services. These cities always have embraced new residents, but the added strain of a significant new migration on the social service system would be a great burden on their budgets.
United States cities must bear that burden if called on to do so. But all their residents, old and new, can do without further diluted city services. It would be a shame if President Clinton's generally constructive economic plan inadvertently weakens, rather than strengthens, the economy of the cities.
 
CARLOS D. RAMIREZ
Publisher, El Diario
New York, March 16, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Back to School for Honda Workers

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARYSVILLE, Ohio

 BODY:
For the 5,400 workers who assemble the popular Honda Accord at a factory here, the unthinkable finally happened. Tougher competition from the Big Three and tepid demand for cars have forced the Honda Motor Company to trim production significantly for the first time in the plant's 10-year history.
Organizers from the United Automobile Workers union, which waged an unsuccessful campaign to organize the plant, had warned years earlier that if Honda ever slipped, workers would suffer without protection of a union contract. 
 But instead of laying off hundreds of workers until business improves, or spreading the pain by imposing a holiday on everyone, as American car makers often do in similar situations, Honda is using the extra time to intensify training.
"We've never guaranteed there won't be layoffs," Roger Lambert, a Honda spokesman, said. Nevertheless, "when we decided we would have to reduce output, we didn't see this as a way to cut 200 workers, we saw it as 5 percent more time for training."
In Big Three plants, workers who are laid off receive what amounts to a paid vacation under their union contracts. Honda decided to use this time to teach its workers new skills, reasoning that it would be an investment in future productivity.
Honda says its commitment to training is a strategy for enlarging the capability of its work force so that its rebound will be magnified when tough times improve. For Honda and other Japanese auto makers operating factories in the United States, constant training has been a key tactic in their battle against American auto makers. And it is no coincidence that improved training is a part of the Clinton Administration's program for revitalizing American manufacturing.
"It's hard to find American companies that are going the training route, but they must if they want the flexibility that will allow them to absorb the shocks of the economy and the market," said Harry Katz, professor of industrial relations at Cornell University.
For example, Mr. Katz said, teaching workers concepts that help them analyze their jobs may allow them to spot potential trouble spots before problems occur, reducing scrap and lost production time. Richard L. Cowan, a Honda instructor who also teaches mechanical engineering at Ohio Northern University, was teaching a dozen workers corrosion theory during a recent visit. "Unlike students, these people ask pointed questions because they have real-world experience," he said. "For them, the answers address specific problems."
Many of Honda's classes are as short as an hour, covering technical subjects like pneumatics, hydraulics and electronics. Much of the material is aimed specifically at professional engineers, but many skilled workers also attend. Honda calls many members of the latter group "engineers," though they lack formal degrees.
 
 
More Than 600 Courses
 The course listing, with more than 600 entries, also offers nontechnical subjects like Japanese, export marketing and the methodology of the J. D. Power & Associates quality survey. Every course indirectly reflects Honda's ethic of constant self-improvement, which the auto maker believes is vital to accomplish outsized manufacturing feats like changing new models without stopping the assembly line.
In the course of Japan's steady encroachment on the American automotive market, few years were like 1992. Successful new models like the Jeep Grand Cherokee, higher Japanese prices, soft automotive demand and "Buy American" fever helped the Big Three battle Japan's seven auto makers to a standstill. As a group, the Big Three gained market share, while the Japanese lost. In 1992, the Ford Taurus displaced Honda's Accord as the best-selling car model, a title the Accord had held for three years.
When Accord sales dwindled, many workers at the plant worried. "Our people always thought of Honda as this invulnerable object," said Steve Bishop, assistant plant manager and a former high school shop teacher.
Last fall, Honda announced it would build 110,000 Accords in the first quarter of 1993, down almost 11 percent from the 123,483 built in the first quarter last year. The rate translates to about 200 fewer cars a day. Rather than stopping production, Honda slowed assembly slightly -- which allowed it to move people from the assembly line to the classroom.
Last year, Honda workers attended an average of about 5,000 hours of technical training every quarter; in the current quarter, the down time on the assembly line has allowed Honda to increase technical training to 10,000 hours.
Honda will not say how much training costs. But experienced assembly work costs the company about $16 an hour. By contrast, Big Three auto makers are paying workers nearly their full salaries when they are at home on layoff. When Ford's Dearborn, Mich., assembly plant closed for a week earlier this month, nearly all of the 2,000 workers were at home. The company said that none of the workers were in class.
 
 
Shifting Production
 Among Japanese transplants, Honda is the first to grapple with a significant slowdown. The others have been spared, partly because their parent companies are slowing exports to the United States and shifting more production from Japanese to American factories because manufacturing costs have become very competitive in the United States. Even so, the Subaru-Isuzu assembly plant in Lafayette, Ind., has prepared for slack production by hiring temporary workers, who are more easily let go when orders wane.
If aggressive training at transplants has improved the competitiveness of some American workers, the factories themselves have made life difficult for the Big Three and the U.A.W. In the early 1980's, the United States auto industry and organized labor argued that cars and trucks should be built here if they are sold here, prompting the Japanese to adopt voluntary export restraints.
With every Japanese auto maker except Daihatsu now teaching their methods to American workers, the Big Three's political rationale for keeping the Japanese out has weakened. The Secretary of Labor, Robert B. Reich, has argued that the nationality of a company is far less important than the nationality of workers who learn world-class skills. This line of thinking was reflected when the Big Three decided not to pursue dumping complaints against the Japanese industry in January.
Honda's plant here, 30 miles northwest of Columbus, has undoubtedly raised educational horizons for many whose job prospects were once dim. Honda requires only a high school diploma and a good attendance record from prospective employees. Eventually, however, Honda workers and those at other transplants are pushed to learn more and accept more responsibility.
 
 
'More Thought'
 "Working in a Japanese company requires much more thought, evaluation and planning," said Jim Woroniecki, vice president of human resources for Subaru-Isuzu of America who once worked for Ford.
Workers at Honda must study inspection, cleanliness, safety, low-level maintenance and even the jobs held by co-workers.
Big Three plants are mimicking this training, but are held back in some cases by union contracts that prevent workers in some job classifications from being trained in other specialized tasks. At the same time, many Big Three executives concede they have not been as ingenious as they could be in devising training that would increase workers' skills.
Consequently, transplant workers suffer less from the boredom of assembly work than their American counterparts, one reason that Doubleday & Company listed Nissan's operation in Smyrna, Tenn., as one of the nation's 100 best companies to work for.
The training also gives transplant workers multiple skills: at the Nissan plant, for example, workers are able to switch from the truck assembly line to the car line, depending on where they are needed -- a practice that is far less common at American auto companies.
 
 
'Running' Changeover
 Transplants can also try manufacturing feats that the Big Three are just beginning to learn. Workers at the Subaru-Isuzu plant will perform a "running" changeover this autumn, replacing the current Subaru Legacy model with a new model without stopping the assembly line for a single day. Most Big Three assembly plants, whose traditional work forces are only beginning to wrestle with added responsibility, must close for weeks or months, replace machine tools, and hire numerous outsiders for model changeovers.
Back in Marysville, Honda will try a simultaneous running changeover for three new Accord models: sedan, wagon and coupe. Although running changeovers are routine in Japan, no auto maker in this country has ever tried it on three models simultaneously. Ford, however, has accomplished a running changeover for one truck model.
The heightened training ethos of Honda, Nissan and others has not been lost on the Big Three. "It's gotten more competitive; we're planning better," said Larry Seltz, Ford's supervisor of new-model introductions. Mr. Seltz vowed that Ford would bring out its 1996 Taurus without stopping at plants in Atlanta and Chicago. "I've got launch plans through 2001," he said.

HEADLINE: CLINTON CONSIDERS STOPPING MEDICAID UNDER HEALTH PLAN

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
As part of its health-care plan, the Clinton Administration is considering a proposal to dismantle the Medicaid program and integrate low-income people into the same networks of doctors, hospitals and private insurance companies that would serve more affluent people, Administration officials say.
But poor people would probably receive medical and social services beyond the standard package of health benefits to be guaranteed to all Americans, the officials said. These might include additional dental care, transportation to a doctor's office and translation services for people who do not understand English. And the Government would help pay the insurance premiums and other health costs of low-income people.
 
'Really Serious Problems'
 Confidential work papers from Hillary Rodham Clinton's Task Force on National Health Care Reform say that maintaining a separate Medicaid program "would perpetuate segregation of the poor in the health-care system, with the associated adverse implications for access to and quality of care." 
 How to care for the nation's 35.7 million poor people is one of the most important moral, political and policy questions facing the Administration as it drafts a legislative proposal for sweeping changes in America's health-care system.
Drew E. Altman, president of the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, which is sponsoring a major study of Medicaid, said: "There are really serious problems in putting Medicaid into the new system, but that's what we ought to do. A separate program for poor people will always be a poor program, underfunded and neglected."
 
Questions Regarding the Poor
 Mr. Altman, a former Commissioner of Human Services in New Jersey, said he worried about how poor people, members of minorities and those with special medical needs would fare under the new system. For example, he asked, "How will a drug-abusing pregnant woman fare in a system of managed competition built on competitive bids, lowest price and a minimum-benefit package?"
While no final decisions have been made, the shift of millions of people out of Medicaid and into the networks of doctors and hospitals would probably occur over several years. Established in 1965 to finance health care for low-income people, Medicaid now provides care for more than 30 million people, including several million with incomes just over the official poverty level. It has become one of the fastest growing programs in the Government. The Federal Government expects to spend nearly $80 billion on Medicaid in the current fiscal year, while the states plan to spend $60 billion.
But many people, in and out of the Government, question whether the differing needs of poor people and the middle class can be adequately addressed within the same networks of doctors, hospitals and insurance companies. Doctors say poor people are more likely to have special health needs and problems, ranging from AIDS to drug abuse, tuberculosis, diabetes, high blood pressure and birth defects.
Throughout the work papers of the task force, it is assumed that Medicaid recipients "will be integrated fully or partially" into the new system, which the Administration calls managed competition.
Under that system, huge consumer groups, health insurance purchasing cooperatives, would buy health care from large networks of doctors and hospitals. Advocates of this proposal say the buyers will command so much economic power in the medical marketplace that they can get high-quality care at reasonable prices.
In most states, Medicaid recipients can now generally go to any doctor or hospital that will accept them. The doctors and hospitals are typically paid for each service or procedure they perform. But many doctors take only limited numbers of Medicaid patients, and some doctors and private hospitals do not take any.
Under Mr. Clinton's plan, more people would be enrolled in health maintenance organizations and similar groups. Government agencies and employers would pay a fixed amount, set in advance, for each patient. Rather than having unlimited freedom to use any doctor or hospital, consumers might have to go through one doctor, a "case manager," who would approve their use of specialists and hospitals.
Proposals for Medicaid do not imply any immediate changes in Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly. But the task force's working papers show that the Administration is considering changes in Medicare so it would eventually be compatible with the new health-care system for people under 65 years old.
 
'No Decisions' Yet
 Mr. Clinton has said he will send his health plan to Congress by May 3. He says it will control health costs and guarantee coverage for all Americans. Medicaid now covers fewer than half of the nation's poor people, mainly because of limits on income set by state laws regulating eligibility. For at least five years, states have been complaining about the crushing financial burden of Medicaid, which they say has limited their spending on education and other urgent needs.
Robert O. Boorstin, a spokesman for the health task force, confirmed that the Administration was considering ways for Medicaid recipients to enroll in health insurance purchasing groups. "Those options are on the table," he said. "But no decisions have been made. The details of such a change are incredibly complex."
The work papers list several options for shifting people from Medicaid rolls to the health insurance purchasing cooperatives, or H.I.P.C.'s. One option describes the demise of Medicaid this way: "As people leave Medicaid eligibility for any reason, they are enrolled in the H.I.P.C. No new eligibles enter Medicaid. Medicaid ends when its membership reaches X percent, with the remaining people shifted to the H.I.P.C. en bloc."
The documents say the Government may temporarily have "a residual Medicaid program for certain beneficiaries (e.g., those in institutionalized long-term care)," like nursing homes or institutions for the mentally retarded. Last year 1.5 million Medicaid recipients, or 5 percent of the total, used nursing homes, but they accounted for 26 percent of all Medicaid spending.
At a meeting with the staff of the health-care task force last week, Mr. Clinton affirmed his desire to continue providing and perhaps expand coverage for long-term care, not just for the elderly, but also for younger people who are disabled or chronically ill.
Administration officials said Mr. Clinton's proposal would emphasize care provided to people in their own residences, rather than in institutions. But the officials said Mr. Clinton had not decided how to control the cost of long-term care or how to pay for this or any other part of the health plan.
Ira C. Magaziner, the coordinator of Mr. Clinton's health task force, outlined the Administration's thinking at a meeting last week with four Governors. Gov. Howard Dean, Democrat of Vermont, who attended the meeting, said he received a clear impression that the Administration wanted to "mainstream the Medicaid population," enroll poor people in health insurance purchasing groups and "split off long-term care."
Mr. Dean, a doctor who serves as co-chairman of the health policy committee of the National Governors' Association, applauded that approach.
 
Additional Steps Possible
 Outlining his proposal then, Mr. Clinton said that most people would get private insurance coverage through their employers or insurance purchasing groups. Without giving any details, he said, "We will fold Medicaid into this program for private coverage."
In its work papers, the staff of the task force says managed competition by itself "may not adequately address the special needs" of people now receiving Medicaid.
Accordingly, the Administration may require the networks of doctors and hospitals to establish links with community health centers and other clinics serving poor people in inner-city or isolated rural areas.
Under Mr. Clinton's plan, as described by Administration officials, the Government will prescribe a comprehensive package of health benefits that must be provided by all employers and insurers. But the work papers show that the Administration is considering "supplemental benefits" for low-income people.
Federal and state officials say they assume that under Mr. Clinton's plan states will be required to spend at least as much on health care for low-income people as they now spend through Medicaid. For example, the work papers say, states may have to help the Federal Government subsidize the cost of enrolling poor people in health maintenance organizations or other networks of doctors and hospitals.

Hillary Clinton to Miss Talks
 LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 28 (AP) -- Hillary Rodham Clinton will not attend the first public meeting of the President's health-care task force in Washington on Monday, remaining here with her ailing father, aides said today. Mrs. Clinton, chairwoman of the panel, missed two health-care forums last week to be with her father, Hugh Rodham, 81, who has been hospitalized after a stroke.
