HEADLINE: Cease-Fire in Bosnia Holds for a 2d Day, And Sarajevo Basks

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, March 29

 BODY:
A cease-fire across Bosnia and Herzegovina held for the second day today with only minor violations, encouraging the United Nations military commander here, Gen. Philippe Morillon, in his belief that the truce may be the beginning of the end of the year-old war.
Heavy gunfire broke out shortly before dusk in the bitterly contested western districts of Sarajevo, close to the airport, and there were reports of sporadic exchanges of tank, artillery and small arms fire elsewhere in the former Yugoslav republic. 
 But United Nations military officers in Sarajevo said the cease-fire was holding better than any of the previous cease-fires, which have rarely lasted more than a few hours.
The truce permitted the evacuation of 2,300 desperate Muslims from Srebrenica, the eastern Bosnian town that has been under siege since last May. But two children were killed in the crush and four other refugees died on the way. [Page A6.]
The stilling of the guns over most of Sarajevo was accompanied by the return of sunny weather after several days of heavy snowfalls, and the capital was filled with people strolling casually down roads that have been devoid of pedestrians for months because of the risk of sniper fire.
Some people took their walks along the embankment of the Miljacka River in the center of the city, an area completely open to Serbian gun positions on the nearby mountains, where scores of people have been killed or wounded by sniper and artillery fire.
For some, the sight of the snowbound mountains sparkling in the spring sunshine brought back poignant memories of the time that many Sarajevans cite as the best of all seasons here, the late winter of 1984, when the Olympic Games were held here in an atmosphere of camaraderie among Bosnians of mixed faiths and nationalities.
People sitting in the few cafes still open reminisced about their experiences at a time when Muslims, Serbs and Croats worked together running the Games with little expectation of the bitter nationalist war that has virtually destroyed much of the city.
"Oh, but you should have seen this city then!" said Ademir Kenovic, a director who has spent months gathering film of the war for a documentary that he plans to show this year at film festivals in Europe and the United States. But like many, Mr. Kenovic mixed his remembrances with foreboding about the future.
"Does General Morillon really think that the people on the hills have gone this far to stop now and start conforming to cease-fires and peace plans?" he asked.
A spokesman for General Morillon, Maj. Pepe Gallegos, said the French commander was "pleased with the cease-fire so far" and believed there was a good chance of extending it into a permanent truce.
 
General Expresses Confidence
 General Morillon, who was instrumental in negotiating the cease-fire, has long maintained that personal contacts with Serbian leaders and persistence in negotiating with them, rather than threats of force or increased pressure by the United Nations, would eventually end the Bosnian war.
On his return here on Sunday from Srebrenica, the general left no doubt that he regarded the cease-fire and Serbian guarantees of an end to attacks on Srebrenica as vindication of his approach.
"I'm crossing my fingers like everybody in the world at the present time," the general told reporters. "But I'm more confident because it's the first time in a year here when all three sides in the war have reached the conclusion simultaneously that they can benefit from an end to the fighting."
But many at the United Nations headquarters remain deeply skeptical, fearing that what General Morillon has achieved is less an end to Serbian territorial ambitions than a realization among Serbian leaders that their recent attacks in eastern Bosnia had raised international condemnation to a danger point.
These officials said they suspected that Serbian leaders had resolved to reduce tensions by curbing their attacks for the time being while remaining ready to resume their offensives when international attention wanes.
 
For Diplomatic Advantage
 Similarly, the officials said, they are doubtful that the Government's Army has accepted that the war is over.
Senior Bosnian commanders who gave President Alija Izetbegovic clearance last week to sign a peace pact drawn up by the United Nations and the European Community made it clear beforehand that they considered the plan, which provides for 10 provinces functioning as ethnic enclaves, amounted to a repudiation of their fight for a multi-religious, multi-ethnic state.
The commanders said, in effect, that Mr. Izetbegovic should sign the pact for the diplomatic advantage it would give him in his dealings with Western nations, not because they expected to have to abide by it.
One of those who seemed uncertain that Serbian military ambitions had been permanently curbed was Viktor Andreyev, General Morillon's civilian counterpart in the United Nations hierarchy in Bosnia.
"I have my personal doubts," Mr. Andreyev said when asked if he believed the war would end. "I think we will see ups and downs."
Mr. Andreyev said recent pledges by Slobodan Milosevic, the president of Serbia, that he would press Serbian nationalists in Bosnia to end the fighting were "probably another little step in the right direction." But in general, Mr. Andreyev said, "unfortunately, I'm not very optimistic."
United Nations officials said the general had set a meeting of military commanders from the three warring armies at Sarajevo airport on Wednesday to discuss a proposal for "safe corridors" across the siege lines around the capital. The general has frequently urged the plan on the opposing sides, only to have it thwarted each time by renewed fighting.
The corridors would allow people to leave and return to the city, and they would also link Serbian territories on the periphery of the city that are separated by the fighting.
 
 
 
BALKAN UPDATE
Tuzla, Bosnia
The evacuation of wounded, ill and hungry Muslims who were cut off from aid in enclaves in eastern Bosnia is a mission of mercy that has proved treacherous to some of the very victims it was intended to help. The evacuees, including children, are being crushed and smothered as refugees fight for a space on the crammed flat-bed trucks bound for Tuzla.
 
Sarajevo, Bosnia
After a series of fragile cease-fires in Balkan fighting, forces in Sarajevo were adhering to their promises with only a few exceptions yesterday on the second day of the agreement.
 
Belgrade, Yugoslavia
While the Yugoslav Government awaited the Bosnian Serbs' decision on a peace plan, Serbian commentators on state television said negotiations on the terms might be possible after the plan is signed.
 
Zagreb, Croatia
The Croatian Government of Premier Hrvoje Sarinic resigned after six months in office, the Associated Press reported. Observers said economic failures and rivalries in the governing party played a part.
 
United Nations
The Secretary General asked the Security Council to approve the peace plan and urged Bosnian Serbs to sign it, while Lord Owen, a mediator, said the threat of lifting the arms embargo on Bosnia could put pressure on Bosnian Serbs to join the plan.

A MOVE TO PAY FOR ABORTION

HEALTH PANEL HEARS MANY VOICES

HEADLINE: Groups Laud Health-Care Reform In Theory, but Clash on Practice

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 29

 BODY:
After long clamoring for access to President Clinton's health-policy team, spokesmen for the elderly, doctors, dentists, chiropractors, hospital officers, insurance executives and other groups today fired a fusillade of proposals to remake the nation's health-care system.
At a daylong hearing of the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform, the witnesses offered support for the general idea of a vast overhaul. But they frequently criticized details of the ambitious plan being devised by the Administration for submission to Congress in early May. 
 Many witnesses warned of major practical problems in the changes contemplated by the Administration. But their advice amounted to a crazy-quilt patchwork of conflicting ideas, a jumble that highlights the difficulty of changing the way Americans receive their health care.
The chairman of the American Medical Association, Dr. Raymond Scalettar, supported Mr. Clinton's proposal to require employers to provide basic health benefits for their workers, but he opposed price controls as unwarranted and unworkable.
Small-business owners, on the other hand, denounced the idea of a Federal requirement for employers to provide health insurance; one said such a mandate would be un-American.
Insurance companies warned the Administration not to regulate or limit premiums, saying such limits would threaten their solvency.
Chiropractors said one of the best ways to control costs was to "expand access to non-M.D. health-care providers," like chiropractors. Nurses, psychologists and social workers asked for a bigger role, saying they should be allowed to handle tasks now generally performed only by doctors.
Nursing home executives urged greater use of private insurance to cover the costs of long-term care. But the American Association of Retired Persons warned that "a system based on private insurance will increase total costs and leave millions uncovered."
Raul Yzaguirre, president of the National Council of La Raza, an advocacy group for Hispanic Americans, urged the Administration not to forget undocumented aliens. "These individuals live and work in this country," he said. "Their illnesses can pose a health risk for others in the community."
The hearing, described by the White House as the first formal meeting of the 12-member panel, was held in a basketball arena at George Washington University here. Vice President Al Gore presided over part of the hearing in place of Hillary Rodham Clinton, the chairwoman of the task force.
 
A Diversity of Interest Groups
 The meeting underlined the complexity of the task now facing Mr. Clinton, as well as the diversity of interest groups passionately concerned about health care in America.
The witnesses generally applauded the Administration for its efforts to control health costs and guarantee insurance coverage of all Americans. But many also expressed reservations about features of Mr. Clinton's plan, some details of which emerged during the Presidential campaign last year and in subsequent consultations with Congress.
In speaking against any Government requirement that employers provide insurance for their workers, Stephen Elmont, a vice president of the National Restaurant Association, said, "Mandates really are oppressive for small businesses," and he went so far as to say that "the concept of mandates is un-American."
Mr. Gore observed that restaurants were already subjected to mandates like food safety and sanitation standards. But Mr. Elmont said those mandates were different; he fears, he said, the possibility of "about $3,000 to $5,000 a year in insurance premiums for mandated health-care costs" for each employee in the restaurant industry. "We can't absorb those costs," he said.
The Administration summoned more than 60 witnesses to testify at the 13-hour hearing. The witnesses were organized by industry or constituency group into 12 panels of five or six members each. Each witness was given three minutes to make an opening statement, and each panel responded to the task force's questions for 35 to 45 minutes. When one panel was through, another was immediately called.
 
Ignoring the Cost
 No panel was devoted to the question of how to finance coverage for 35 million uninsured people, or how the nation could afford to guarantee all Americans costly benefits like long-term care and prescription drugs.
One group, the National Federation of Independent Business, which represents 600,000 small businesses, turned down an invitation to testify. Terry Hill, a spokesman for the federation, noted that White House officials had already said the President wanted to require employers to provide health insurance for workers. "It would be futile for us to testify," Mr. Hill said. "Their mind is already made up."
Doctors, insurers, hospital executives and drug makers urged the Administration not to impose price controls. The coordinator of the task force, Ira C. Magaziner, had said Mr. Clinton might ask Congress for the authority to impose such controls temporarily.
But Dr. Scalettar, of the A.M.A., said: "Effective cost control has never been achieved in this or any other economy through arbitrary caps on spending, or price controls. They did not work in the 1970's, only delaying natural price increases and impeding the supply of necessary goods and services."
G. Kirk Raab, president of Genentech Inc., speaking for the Industrial Biotechnology Association, said that if the Government set limits on prices of new biotech medicines, it would "dry up capital investment in our industry." Without that investment, he said, "we will not be able to discover cures and effective treatments for such expensive diseases as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, cancer and AIDS."
But Mr. Gore said the Administration intended to "stop drug overcharges and excessive profiteering."
"The days of business as usual are over," the Vice President said. "We are determined to bring this country sweeping and comprehensive health- care reform." Moreover, he said, "everyone who has been making lots of money off health care in the last 10 years will need to sacrifice in order to make the system work."
Mr. Gore said the Administration was "determined to help doctors by reducing paperwork and administrative costs and by doing something to curb malpractice suits." He said Mr. Clinton wanted to "encourage general practitioners instead of specialists," but he did not say how this goal would be achieved.
 
Fearing 'Managed Competition'
 Several witnesses expressed reservations about the strategy of "managed competition," through which Mr. Clinton hopes to encourage networks of doctors, hospitals and insurance companies to compete for the business of large consumer groups.
Dr. Richard O. Butcher, president of the National Medical Association, which represents black doctors, said this strategy might leave many people without medical care. "There has been no competition for the uninsured, the homeless, lower-income people, ethnic minority populations and the mentally ill," said Dr. Butcher. "It is unreasonable to expect a middle-class delivery system to embrace these populations."
Dr. Butcher said the Government should require businesses with 25 or more employees to provide workers with basic health benefits.
But Samuel A. Carradine Jr., executive director of the National Association of Minority Contractors, said such a requirement was not feasible in his industry.
"The nature of the construction industry demands mobility of workers from site to site and often from employer to employer," said Mr. Carradine. "The cost of employers' continuing to cover their workers in periods of down time or having to frequently cancel and reinstate workers would be financially disastrous."

HEADLINE: Talking to the Task Force on Health: Experts Give Their Views: Physicians;
Doctors Know That Change Is a Necessity

 BODY:

 Dr. Raymond Scaletter
 chairman of the board of trustees of the American Medical Association
I'm Ray Scaletter, chairman of the board of the American Medical Association, and we appreciate this opportunity to state once again our commitment to reform of the nation's health-care system. As we have said publicly the last several years and privately in the constructive opportunities we've had to discuss our views with representatives of the Administration and this task force over the last few months, America's physicians know that change is necessary. 
 As the patients' advocate, we know that far too many of our patients have no health insurance coverage. The hassles of providing care and the burden of paperwork and bureaucratic second-guessing frustrates physicians as well as our patients. And the costs of health care are rising too quickly for our patients and the good of the nation. We have not, do not, and will not defend the status quo.
You have asked what can be done to insure immediate control of health-care costs while insuring quality care and physician choice.There are direct workable solutions that can be implemented immediately.
An employer mandate to provide a federally established essential benefit package with community rating. Before I speak of them -- and our written statement expands on them -- I respectfully ask the task force to do one thing: look at experience. Contrary to perceptions, this nation does have experience in both health-system reform and controlling costs. One lesson to be gained from experience is that true effective cost control has never been achieved in this or any other economy through arbitrary caps on spending or price controls. They did not work in the 1970's, only delaying natural price increases and impeding supply of necessary goods and services. They also will not work in health care.
Price controls, or global budgets, mean arbitrary decisions that will, without basis, limit our ability to deliver needed medical care to our patients. We have suggested a better way, a partnership between government, physicians, employers, and others. By working together to isolate the costly failures in the health-care system, true budget predictability can be brought to this nation's health-care costs without limiting patients' access to medical care.
Another equally important lesson is that health-system reform has already been demonstrated to work in the United States. We are puzzled that more attention is not given to the successes in Hawaii and Rochester, N.Y.

 	 	 		. . .	 	VICE PRESIDENT AL GORE Let me just open it up by asking this question, and invite you to respond. What is the most important element of a new health-care system which can ensure patient choice of their doctor? Whoever wishes to respond.
 
John Tudor
President, American Academy of Family Physicians
I believe the most important is having a personal physician who would provide continuity, and, as Dr. Pearson said, if physicians are involved in more than one plan, even though economic benefit may shift from one plan to another, the option to stay with the same physician, even though you change plans, is an individual choice that families should have. Their personal care, their records, their availability to other specialists -- even the health-care team that works with them, allied health professions -- would all be coordinated under one focus, or medical home, as the pediatricians call it.
 
Dr. Jane Orient
Executive director, Association of American Physicians and Surgeons
The most important thing is to allow the patient to have control over his own money in an individual medical savings account instead of turning it all over to the third party. We believe that medical costs could be decreased probably by 25 percent just by instituting individual medical accounts for all Americans.

HEADLINE: Clinton Soothes Senate Anxiety Over Spending

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 29

 BODY:
For three sleepy days, nobody in the Senate wanted to vote on the spending plan President Clinton had proposed to stimulate the economy. Now, suddenly, they can't vote fast enough.
Spurred by a soothing letter from the President, Democratic lawmakers patched up one spat among themselves, shelved another with Republicans, and began serious legislating over Mr. Clinton's $16.3 billion grab bag of job-making public-works projects. 
 After a comparatively quick 90-minute debate, voting began on a series of Republican amendments, all aimed at restricting the spending package and most doomed to defeat. The threat of a Republican filibuster still exists, but Democrats expressed hope that they could pass the legislation as early as Tuesday.
 
Vacation Looms
 Time is precious. The lawmakers must vote on the spending package and a politically unpopular increase in the Federal debt ceiling before leaving on a two-week vacation, set to begin Friday.
The stimulus package has been stalled since Thursday, in part by the filibuster threat. But the real obstacles were conservative Democrats, who questioned the political wisdom of rushing to add $16.3 billion in public projects to the Federal deficit before voting on the less pleasant spending cuts proposed in Mr. Clinton's budget.
Conservative Democrats had sought to delay spending about half of Mr. Clinton's stimulus funds until the budget passed, probably this summer. "Let's make sure we don't eat the dessert without eating the spinach," Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma said today, alluding to the relative appeal of approving public-works programs and reducing the debt.
 
Conservatives Reassured
 Mr. Clinton has argued that the economy needs a jolt of Federal spending before summer, but he defused the conservatives' objections today by saying in a letter that he shares their concern. In it, he pledged to seek additional Federal spending cuts if Congress passes a budget that does not meet his goals for reducing the deficit.
Mr. Clinton also noted that much of the stimulus spending will not occur until after the budget becomes law anyway, making the conservatives' objections more or less moot.
Another conservative Democrat, Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, hailed the letter, saying it went "a very long way to giving me the confidence" that Mr. Clinton was serious about cutting the deficit.
 
Republicans Not Swayed
 The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, was unmoved.
"It's reassuring to have a letter from the President of the United States saying he agrees with people who didn't want to cut spending all along," Mr. Dole said sarcastically.
He is not the only angry Republican. Democratic parliamentary maneuvers have left Republicans the worthless option of trying to amend a version of the stimulus bill that will be tossed out and replaced by Mr. Clinton's package, when the final vote is taken.
Until today, Republicans rejected that option and threatened a filibuster. But tonight they put aside their displeasure and began offering amendments, led by a proposal to prohibit spending on a variety of parks and recreation projects for which cities are seeking Federal stimulus money.
Republicans argued that the projects are pork-barrel items not worthy of being called Federal emergencies, and in fact, Mr. Clinton has publicly agreed. Democratic leaders nevertheless moved tonight to kill the amendment but lost by 48 to 44. The Democrats will try again to kill it on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Clinton Likely to Seek Even More Russian Aid

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Mar. 29

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is likely to ask Congress to increase direct American aid for Russia next year from the $700 million previously proposed to more than $1 billion, and to direct the assistance to Russian farmers, entrepreneurs and military officers, senior Administration officials said today.
Several key lawmakers involved in foreign aid said they would be inclined to go along with the increased spending for Russia if the President is willing to make the case to the American people. 
 The additional aid would very likely go to pay for housing loan guarantees to build prefabricated homes for demobilized Russian troops returning from Eastern Europe, a fund to help Russian entrepreneurs start up companies, and as food aid that the Russian Government could convert into a program to promote new industries.
All three proposals are on the list of aid programs President Clinton is expected to offer President Boris N. Yeltsin at their April 3-4 summit in Vancouver, British Columbia. The increase in direct aid would be in addition to American proposals to increase the amount of assistance, primarily in loans and loan guarantees, directed to Russia by the International Monetary Fund. The Administration last week said the I.M.F. should increase its aid to as much as $13.5 billion a year.
The direct aid from the United States would be separate from American efforts to increase credit assistance for Russia under the aegis of the International Monetary Fund and joint programs of the major industrial democracies known as the Group of Seven.
Politicians say that even if Mr. Clinton makes a big push for Russian aid, any package would face difficulty winning approval in Congress.
"Any foreign aid bill this year is going to be an uphill battle because no one wants to vote for foreign aid in the same year when we are voting to cut most U.S. domestic programs," said Sen. Patrick Leahy, chairman of the Senate Foreign Operations Subcommittee, which oversees foreign aid.
Senator Leahy said that "there are many of us who would back him all the way" if the President made a strong case, but added that "there is no way they can do all they want to do for Russia for less than $1 billion."
 
A Tough Sell?
 Administration officials said probably the biggest chunk of any additional aid to Russia next year -- over and above the $700 million already being sought -- would likely be in the form of "Food for Progress," an Agriculture Department program in which the United States takes wheat that it has purchased from American farmers to maintain domestic price levels and gives it away overseas. The main cost to the foreign aid budget is the price of shipping the wheat to Russia.
Senator Leahy has suggested to the White House that the United States give such wheat to the Russian Government, which would then sell iton the local market and spend the proceeds on opening bakeries or on other industries or use it to improve the country's food distribution system.
Last year the Congress and the Bush Administration agreed to spend $400 million in fiscal 1993 and in fiscal 1994 on technical assistance and humanitarian aid programs for Russia as part of the Freedom Support Act. In his budget for 1994, Mr. Clinton proposed an additional $300 million to bring the total to $700 million in the coming fiscal year, and now he is considering going even higher, aides said.
Mr. Clinton acknowledged today that increasing aid to Russia could be a tough sell, but that he is ready to propose do so, probably in a speech he is planning to give Thursday to newspaper editors in Annapolis, Md.
"Foreign aid is unpopular in every country in the world," Mr. Clinton told reporters in Little Rock today, where he was visiting his gravely ill father-in-law. "It's always been unpopular here. And I haven't really had a chance to talk much directly to the American people about what's going on there, what our stake in it is, and what their stake in it is."
Asked how members of the House might react to a request for additional assistance for Russia, Rep. David Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Foreign Operations Subcommittee, said the amounts being discussed were not "out of line."
"We have got to make clear to the folks in Russia who say that the West is playing games and not really interested in helping them, that they are dead wrong," he said.

HEADLINE: Talking to the Task Force on Health: Experts Give Their Views: Underserved Consumers;
Farmers Cannot Afford Insurance

 BODY:

Nancy Danielson
Legislative representative, National Farmers Union
To put it very simply, farmers cannot afford not to have health insurance because they risk losing their entire farm, and yet the costs have become so high that this is one of the No. 1 issues any time we go out to a farm meeting. 
 Our principles are universal coverage, which has been a priority for us since 1938, affordability, a cap on the costs, choice of doctor and hospital, access in rural areas, preventive care and long-term access.
Unfortunately, in rural areas, we have a problem with access to physicians and hospitals. In fact, the average age of the rural doctor is 60 years of age, and this is even older than the average age of the average farmer.
Also, it's difficult and expensive to recruit doctors to the rural areas, and hospitals are moving to more and more expensive guarantee plans in order to get any doctors to come to their areas. In rural areas where they're not so lucky to have a hospital, it is even more difficult to recruit.
There are also vast differences involved in the amount of area that we have to travel for emergency care and for day-to-day care, and the Medicare reimbursement rate, which is slowly being equalized, has been a problem for us because rural areas are just as expensive to serve as urban areas.
We fear that managed competition may have some problems for the rural patient. First of all, we just don't have the number of H.M.O.'s to allow for the idea that is supposed to work with managed competition. Also, an aging population is less suited to the economics of H.M.O.'s and the cost savings may not occur.

HEADLINE: Hughes Shift Will Be Blow To California

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 29

 BODY:
In the latest blow to California's ailing economy, the Hughes Missile Systems Company said today that it would move its engineering and product-line management, including 2,000 jobs, from several sites in Southern California to its headquarters in Tucson, Ariz., by the end of next year.
The move, which follows Hughes Missile's $450 million acquisition of the General Dynamics Corporation's missile division last August, will also mean the elimination of an additional 2,000 engineering and management jobs, mainly through layoffs, in California and Arizona. 
 At the time of the acquisition, Hughes Missile had said that it intended to consolidate the company's five missile manufacturing plants under one roof in Tucson, ending major California production activities in San Diego, Pomona and Rancho Cucamonga, as well as production in Camden, Ark.
 
 
'Operating Efficiencies'
 But, until today, the missile company had left open the possibility that engineering and management operations could remain in California. Hughes Missile officials said simply that "operating efficiencies" dictated that the engineering and product management for missiles be consolidated in Tucson, where it would cost between 5 and 10 percent less to run those operations than in California.
In effect, today's announcement means that Hughes Missile will shut all its missile operations in California, except for its Sycamore Canyon facility near San Diego, where the company does loading and fueling and employs 500 workers.
The parent of Hughes Missile, Hughes Aircraft, is a unit of GM Hughes Electronics, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation. The earnings of Hughes Electronics are used to calculate the per-share earnings of General Motors class H common stock, which lost 12.5 cents a share on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $25.
Hughes Missile currently employs about 12,000 workers. Tucson has 4,200; Pomona and Rancho Cucamonga, 3,500; Canago Park, Calif., 1,900; San Diego, 1,600, and several other locations, about 1,000. The company said that when consolidation of its manufacturing and engineering operations was completed, it expected to have about 8,000 employees in Tucson at the end of 1994. When Hughes Missile acquired General Dynamics' missile division, the combined company had about 14,600 workers.
While Hughes Missile officials said that there was little that California could have done to convince them to remain, the officials nevertheless sharply criticized the state for doing little to keep businesses from leaving.
"Although the primary consideration for this move was the consolidation of our missile business into a more efficient operation, a part of this consideration is the economic environment in California," said C. Michael Armstrong, chairman and chief executive of Hughes Aircraft. "California is no longer a competitive place to do business."
Hughes Aircraft, the largest industrial employer in Southern California, announced plans last year to eliminate about 9,000 jobs in the region.
 
 
'Not as Easy' Decision
 At a meeting today with reporters at a Pasadena, Calif., hotel, Michael T. Smith, Hughes Missile's chairman, said that the decision to move to Tucson was "not an easy one but very necessary to successfully merge the two operations and make them competitive." He said that the company would lay off about 2,000 workers in the engineering and product-line management operations and that more than 6,000 jobs ultimately would be eliminated.
For California, which is suffering from its worst recession since the 1930's, the move is just the latest setback in a string of bad economic news. Under the Pentagon's latest proposal for base closings, California would lose 113,000 jobs. The state already has lost more than 200,000 aerospace and weapons jobs in the past five years.
Mr. Smith said that California was an undesirable state to do business for a number of reasons, including a very high cost of living, unreasonable environmental regulations and an expensive workers compensation system.
A spokeswoman for the California Trade and Commerce Agency said the state was developing a program of incentives to retain companies. She also said the state had saved 1,200 jobs at another Hughes unit by negotiating lower electricity rates for the company.

HEADLINE: Talking to the Task Force on Health: Experts Give Their Views: Small Businesses;
The Ruination Of Restaurants, Or a Benefit?

 BODY:

Stephen Elmont
Vice president, National Restaurant Association
Our industry is consumed and concerned about health-care reform. For the past few years, restaurateurs have struggled with staggering inflation and health-care premium costs, with cancellations, with denials of coverage, and now with the frightening prospect of mandates. We are not engaged in hyperbole when we say that mandated employer-provided coverage or higher payroll taxes to pay for health benefits would literally sound the death knell for many restaurants and discourage other restaurants from ever opening. 
 You have asked us to discuss the best ways to insure that employees of small businesses get health-care coverage. We believe the most essential element of health-care reform is cost containment. We adamantly oppose employer mandates, price controls and global budgets. Instead, we support many of the concepts upon which build the strengths of our free market system.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The concept of mandates is un-American, the concept of mandates of anything. We're in a free enterprise system where if one employer wants to do one thing that he or she feels is going to benefit either their customer and/or their employees, they're going to do it. And another employer may look at them with a jaundiced eye and say that's not going to improve my bottom line. So that we all sitting here are successful because we make decisions every single day on what's going to improve the customer experience, what's going to improve the employee experience. And so we oppose mandates for that reason.

 	 	 		. . .	 	VICE PRESIDENT AL GORE You have inspection of your food-preparation facilities and your sanitation and health standards and so forth?
A. Of course.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Is that voluntary?
A. No.
Q. Is it mandated?
A. Yes.
Q. Does it make sense?
A. Does it make sense? I think it makes sense, but there aren't enough resources to do a good job so we employ our own inspection agency.
Q. Would you describe it as un-American because it's mandated?
A. No, that's protecting the consumer.
Q. Well, the point I'm making is that some things when applied universally make sense, even if they're mandated, such as the inspection I'm talking about. You get a benefit from having this mandated health inspection because you don't have to compete with some other restaurant that cuts corners and doesn't provide the minimal standards, and your entire industry gets a reputation with the public of being safe. And you don't have to run the extra risk of some bad actor in your industry cutting corners so much that it gives the whole industry a black eye. So all that's a benefit to your industry from that mandated approach, isn't it?
A. If you want to talk about wellness in that way as compared to catastrophic illness, yes.
 
SECRETARY DONNA E. SHALALA Well, would you talk about Social Security that way? I mean, Social Security clearly is a mandate for the public good. Is there something fundamentally different between Social Security and health care?
A. It's because if I give an inch, I am terribly, terribly concerned about the cost of that inch, and that's why I'm so paranoid in talking about mandate versus not mandate.

HEADLINE: Italy's 'Moral Crumbling'

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, March 29

 BODY:
If only a half or even a quarter of the allegations against them are true, Italy's leaders these last few decades have lived in a twilight world with a "B" movie plot.
Consider, for instance, some of the scams that have emerged from the 13-month-old investigation into political corruption: 
 *The World Cup soccer tournament came to Italy, arguably a great national honor. But when the contracts were awarded for the stadiums for this sporting extravaganza, they immediately became arenas of corruption, with construction companies paying bribes to politicians.
*As a land that has often boasted an increasingly plausible empathy for the third world, Italy draws up a foreign aid budget. But of the funds sent out from Rome for contracts to build highways for the poor in Bangladesh or Ethiopia, a little has stuck to the fingers of the politicians and officials administering the program in Rome.
*An earthquake struck south-central Italy, and more than 2,700 people died. Reconstruction became a free-for-all of diverted funds.
 
Many Draw From the Well
 All that, some veterans of Italy's Machiavellian politics will argue, is no more than was assumed by the country's 57 million people, many of whom drew some sustenance or other from the well-springs of illicit earnings controlled by the political bosses.
In a land where traffic lights, one-way street signs, income tax laws and even the teachings of the Roman Catholic Church are viewed more as challenges than binding instructions, it might have been foreseen that corners would be smoothed, obstacles circumvented, advantage taken where offered.
But with disclosures culminating this weekend in the still unsubstantiated assertions that former Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti and two other former Christian Democrat officials, Antonio Gava and Paolo Cirini Pomicino, associated with the Mafia, the plot has moved from "B" movie to "The Godfather."
This is the land that claims for itself the industrialized world's fifth largest economy, the land that prided itself on a rise from wartime ruin to postwar riches rooted in energy and inventiveness and competitiveness. Now, for some Italians, the vision is different, the bubble has burst.
 
'A Moral Crumbling'
 "There's a moral crumbling that starts at the top and has spread to the very bottom," said Franca Rame, an actress whose satirical monologues draw enthusiastic crowds.
Mr. Andreotti was and is far more than a player in the byzantine world of Italian politics. Before his political demise after elections last year, he was the world's longest-serving office-holder, a central player on Europe's postwar stage, a conservative link-man for the United States in the cold war battle against Communism. Many Italians suspect he is still the keeper of most of the nation's darker secrets.
Up to now, magistrates has uncovered illicit ties between businessmen and politicians. But in recent days, their inquiries have crossed a watershed to confront the politicians and businessmen's ties with the mob -- in Naples, Reggio Calabria and Sicily.
Mr. Andreotti was notified that he was under investigation by magistrates in Palermo, the stronghold of the Cosa Nostra, on Saturday. One day later, Mr. Gava, the Christian Democrat party boss in southern Italy, and Mr. Pomicino, also a Christian Democrat, were told they were being investigated by magistrates in Naples, where the local organized crime syndicate is called the Camorra.
Like Mr. Andreotti, both men denied the charges, but the news nonetheless propelled Italy's scandals into a new phase since it was the first time such high-ranking officials had been accused of affiliation with gangland figures associated with the killing of officials, narcotics smuggling, gun-running and extortion.
 
Focus on the South
 Moreover, it shifted the focus of attention to the relatively poor South, where for decades billion-dollar flows of Italian and European Community aid have built a symbiotic relationship between the politicians who dispensed the aid, the businessmen who won the contracts and the mobsters who offered their protection.
"In the South, a bribe bought you everything: the contract, subsidies and complete protection from competitors," Augusto Graziani, an economist, said.
The South is widely known as the Christian Democrats' electoral fief, but the virus of corruption seems to have infected other parties, too. In Naples, apart from the charges of connections with organized crime, magistrates are investigating allegations of fraud against a former Liberal Party official, Francesco de Lorenzo, and Vincenzo Scotti, a Christian Democrat who was prominent in the fight against organized crime when he was Interior Minister.
Even the deputy head of Italy's parliamentary anti-Mafia commission, Carlo d'Amato, a Socialist, is among a score of politicians under investigation for purported vote-rigging in Naples, where magistrates also suspect fraud in the awarding of contracts for garbage removal and the building of a World Cup soccer stadium.
The overall thrust of the allegations over the last 13 months -- even though many of them are formally unproven -- is that Italy's public visage masked an underworld where real power was transacted between those who were supposed to frame the law, those who disdained it and those whose motives were solely profit. A front-page cartoon in the newspaper La Repubblica depicted Mr. Andreotti removing the mask of his own face to reveal a death's head.
"The gods of the republic are disappearing," said Giorgio Bocca, a respected Milan commentator, "even Giulio Andreotti."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: News Analysis

HEADLINE: Talks on Haiti Shift the Focus to Aid

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 29

 BODY:
As part of an emerging settlement of the 18-month political crisis in Haiti, support is being marshaled from international donors to quickly mount the largest aid program this impoverished country has ever seen.
Diplomats close to political negotiations aimed at securing the return of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, say the assistance is vital to social peace in a country badly torn by poverty and deep class antagonisms. 
 These diplomats and aid experts describe the still embryonic program as a broad effort to rebuild or build from scratch everything from roads, power plants and water systems to a new police force and judicial system and a smaller, professional Army.
"For the first time we are going to have to create something like a real government for this country," a senior Clinton Administration official said. "It is going to be a full-court press. You will see a push to fill need right across the board."
 
$1 Billion May Be Just a Start
 During a recent meeting with Father Aristide, President Clinton used the figure of $1 billion to be spent over five years in Haiti, of which about one-fifth would be direct United States assistance. Already, however, officials are saying that given the breadth of Haiti's needs and the long odds of making a break with violence and poverty, more may have to be spent.
If a settlement can be reached soon, the aid effort will begin officially next Tuesday in Washington at a special two-day meeting of international donors to Haiti. In a measure of the urgency, however, the senior American official said "a lot of heads are kicking in on this right now."
In recent days, diplomats here have spoken with growing assurance that a settlement is near and that it would include Father Aristide's return. The terms would include the resignation of the Army leadership and the military-backed Government, and internationally supported protection from reprisals for the deposed President's supporters and opponents.
After the formation of a broad-based Government headed by a compromise figure of Father Aristide's choice, the plan calls for the President's return to Haiti within six months, buoyed by a bustle of economic activity.
Diplomats and experts on Haiti have long seen the country's stark poverty and a power-hungry Army that consumes over 20 percent of the national budget as the keys to Haiti's seemingly perpetual instability.
"The way things have been working here for so long, it is as if people were on the sinking Titanic," a diplomat said of the economy. "Instead of trying to mount a rescue, everyone has been arguing about which cabin they will sleep in."
The program would pour millions of dollars into an economy that has been shattered by years of instability and by an international embargo imposed to punish the supporters of the coup against Father Aristide in September 1991. It is intended to help secure the cooperation of the country's deeply conservative economic elite, which has bitterly opposed the populist President, and give hope and relief to Haiti's impoverished masses.
While the wealthy few are often fabulously rich, most of Haiti's six million people live without running water, electricity, schools or basic health care.
Some money would also be spent on a trained civilian police force and on the retraining of the armed forces, many of whose troops would be moved out of the capital to handle reconstruction.
"You are talking about the country that was already by far the weakest economic in the hemisphere," one development expert said. "There is just nothing to jump-start here."
Experts say reconstruction efforts will quickly face a shortage of trained Haitians untainted by corruption and intrigue. Father Aristide's first Government faced this problem, diplomats here say, when a combination of inexperience and infighting and overwhelming offers of assistance meant that few projects were undertaken during his eight months in office.
Already, these experts say, plans are being drawn up to recruit Haitians abroad to do everything from staffing ministries and overseeing development projects to investing capital in privatization and setting up new enterprises.

HEADLINE: Uproar Over Killing in China's 'Model' Village

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 29

 BODY:
Until the slaying, Daqiuzhuang was China's model village, the kind of boom town that the newspapers praised and officials made pilgrimages to. But model workers are not supposed to kill people. More important, model villages are not supposed to defy the Government and protect killers.
Daqiuzhuang is China's richest village, where people live in two-story houses and the per capita income is $22,000, a bit higher than in the United States. The confrontation there, in which the village kept out hundreds of police officers trying to arrest the suspects, is the hottest mystery in China. 
 The Government has not explained what happened in Daqiuzhuang (pronounced dah-cheeyoh-JWAHNG), and it has banned Chinese newspapers from writing about the episode. Chinese and foreigners alike are forbidden to visit the village, about 80 miles south of Beijing, and telephone links to Daqiuzhuang have been disconnected, except through special operators who screen all calls.
But from bits and pieces gathered informally from officials in Tianjin and Beijing, and information obtained from the village itself, it appears that a man was killed in Daqiuzhuang around the middle of February. Apparently he was a worker at one of the village's biggest enterprises, the Wanquan Group, which runs several factories including a steel processing operation.
Villagers say company officials discovered he had stolen 29,000 yuan, or about $5,000, from the accounts. The officials reportedly then confronted him -- with their fists.
"They beat 23,000 yuan out of him," said a villager who recently came to Beijing. "It's not that they intended to kill him. It's just that, well, it's possible that he wasn't in good health. And he hadn't eaten in a few days."
The dead man was from nearby Hebei Province, according to Gong Tieying, an official at the Tianjin city foreign affairs office. Daqiuzhuang administratively falls under Tianjin.
Since the men believed to be the attackers were natives of Daqiuzhuang, the village authorities moved to protect their own by blocking a huge posse of Tianjin police officers, a villager and two other Chinese familiar with the incident said. Mr. Gong denied reports that up to 1,000 policemen were involved, but said that 400 took part.
Daqiuzhuang has 4,400 inhabitants, and it came up with a police force that outnumbered the posse. The village police even confiscated the guns of the Tianjin police in a standoff that lasted three days, said another villager, a man in his 20's.
The dispute has apparently been eased by a complex compromise. The Daqiuzhuang authorities say that the four suspects have vanished, and the village has admitted a small team of detectives to investigate the killing.
The rest of the Tianjin police force withdrew from the area, although the Tianjin police maintain a road barrier about six miles from the village and check all cars leaving the area.
Daqiuzhuang itself is a bit of a mystery. Forsaking Communism long ago, it organized itself like a corporation, ran sweatshops with at least 7,000 cheap laborers from outside the village and leaned on its connections between the village's Communist Party secretary, Yu Zuomin, and officials in Beijing. It is widely believed to have a protector in the central Government, probably in Li Ruihuan, one of the seven members of the Communist Party Politburo's standing committee.
The village now has 280 enterprises, some of which are joint ventures with foreign partners who have pledged $34 million in foreign investment.
In a sign of its growing prestige, Daqiuzhuang apparently was on the agenda for a visit by China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping. But after Mr. Deng's advance team investigated the conditions of the village, they decided that someone had to repave a 45-mile road, the village's only link to Tianjin, a Chinese journalist in Beijing said.
But Tianjin refused to pay for the repaving, causing friction between the village and the city even before the killing. Now, with the village's new-found notoriety, Mr. Deng is unlikely to visit. "The effects on us have been enormous," the Daqiuzhuang villager in Beijing said with a moan.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Makes Rounds Of Fund-Raising Parties

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Although Mayor David N. Dinkins has not yet officially announced his candidacy, his campaign was nonetheless in full swing last night as more than 270 supporters opened their homes to hold so-called "House Party" fund-raisers.
Officials of the Committee for David Dinkins said that no specific target amount had been set for the parties last night, but that each host was asked to set a fund-raising goal of $1,000. Guests were asked to contribute amounts ranging from $5 apiece at some parties to $500 at more lavish settings, campaign officials said.
 
Dinkins Attends 3 Parties
 The Mayor managed to attend three events, and he delivered a short speech which -- borrowing a technique from President Clinton's campaign -- was transmitted through a conference call to each of the homes. In his speech Mr. Dinkins outlined the themes that were likely to be at the centerpiece of his campaign, namely that he has been a diligent steward of the city's fiscal affairs during a crushing recession. 
 "I won't be satisfied until our economy is not only recovering, but thriving," the Mayor said. "We've stabilized our city. We've weathered the storm and laid the foundation for growth. But now we've got to better. Given the chance, I know I can lead our city into an even better, brighter future."
The house parties gave the Mayor an opportunity to conduct some vintage campaigning. One of the parties the Mayor attended was at the Upper West Side apartment of James M. Lebenthal, the chairman of Lebenthal & Company, a Wall Street securities firm. There Mr. Dinkins kissed babies and grandmothers while guests nibbled on mini crab cakes and radishes stuffed with cream cheese and chives.
 
'I'm With Him'
 Further uptown, at the Harlem apartment of Raven P. D. Dennis, a 25-year-old caterer, nearly 40 guests ate baked chicken, macaroni and cheese and green beans while they listened to the Mayor, whose voice could barely be heard on the small speakerphone. Mr. Dennis said his guests paid $25 each to the Dinkins campaign.
"Even though my home is small, I just wanted to find some way to show that I'm with him," Mr. Dennis said.

HEADLINE: The Fragile, Beleaguered Biotechs

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 29

 BODY:
These have been bleak days for the biotechnology industry.
President Clinton's public criticism on high drug prices has prompted fears that health-care reform will weaken the industry's profitability. Two high-profile drugs have failed to perform as expected in clinical trials. And Amgen Inc., the industry's largest, most profitable company, recently reported a slowdown in sales and earnings growth. 
 Any one of these factors would have been enough to frighten investors, who only returned to biotech stocks in November after shunning them for most of 1992. Together, they have prompted a huge selloff that has eliminated 33 percent of the industry's value since Jan. 1 amid a general market rally.
 
Little Profit, So Far
 While pharmaceuticals and indeed all health-care stocks have taken a hit while investors await the Administration's health-care proposals, the decline is most threatening to biotech companies. Few of the biotech companies make money yet, one reason they feel wronged by the President's criticism.
The lack of profitability means the biotech companies must rely more on equity capital than traditional drug companies do. If the public stock markets remain closed, many of these companies will not survive. "The industry is very fragile," said Henri Termeer, chairman and chief executive of the Genzyme Corporation in Cambridge, Mass. "Its needs and how it has been created have not played on anyone's minds in Washington."
Even the good news the industry received earlier this month had little impact on investor sentiment. An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration recommended approval of the Chiron Corporation's Betaseron treatment for multiple sclerosis; a denial would have been devastating.
Chiron's shares closed up $1.50 in Nasdaq trading today at $47.75. But that was still well below the 52-week high of $63, and the rest of the group is also depressed.
"What's missing now is investor confidence," said Mr. Termeer of Genzyme. "One way to turn that around is for the industry to come up with some successful products." Otherwise, he said, given the biotech companies' voracious appetite for cash, "this industry would have to be dramatically restructured within the next 12 to 18 months."
A handful of biotech chief executives who have met privately with the President and other high-ranking officials seem reassured that the Administration appreciates the indus try's contribution to job creation, exports and even to the reduction of health-care costs. But they fret over the lack of public support from President Clinton.
"Many of the things that Clinton has been rightly or wrongly accusing pharmaceuticals manufacturers of are not true of biotech," said Stephen A. Duzan, chairman and chief executive of the Immunex Corporation in Seattle.
For instance, the President has accused drug manufacturers of spending more on marketing than on research and development. But because most biotech companies have no products, all their spending is on research and development. The President has also called some drug prices "shocking," implying that the drug industry is gouging customers to keep profit margins strong. Yet only a handful of biotech companies have any profits.
"The issues being taken on in health-care reform have to do with too many me-too drugs and marketing practices devoted to promoting me-too drugs," said Brook Byers, a partner in the venture capital firm of Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers, which has financed many prominent biotech companies.
"The biotech industry is not about me-too drugs at all," Mr. Byers added. "It is about finding the fundamental molecular basis of a disease at the cellular level and intervening at that level by using an exquisitely specific drug with fewer side effects."
The approach has produced some notable successes. Amgen's Epogen, which raises red blood cells in chronically anemic kidney disease patients, has returned thousands of bed-ridden individuals to active life. Genentech's Protropin growth hormone has allowed children affected by dwarfism to grow to normal height. And Chiron's hepatitis-screening technology has vastly improved the safety of donated blood.
At the same time, biotech executives and some analysts say that the industry's failures must be viewed in context. Two drugs that recently proved disappointing in clinical tests, Centocor's Centoxin and Synergen's Antril, were for the treatment of septic shock, an often-fatal syndrome sparked by a runaway bacterial infection that afflicts surgery and wound patients. Sepsis patients are already gravely ill from the underlying condition, making it unlikely that any single drug can be the remedy, biotech executives say.
Curiously, however, until it became politically inexpedient, biotech executives routinely said they aimed to become fully integrated pharmaceuticals companies. Indeed, a corporate partnership with a big drug concern has long been a rite of passage. And leading biotech companies are adopting some of the techniques of medicinal chemistry at the same time the pharmaceutical manufacturers are embracing genetic engineering.
The recent spate of bad news alone is not the only source of the biotech industry's malaise. The sheer numbers of companies seeking public financing has also contributed.
 
$7 Billion in Investments
 Public investors poured nearly $6 billion into 1,000 biotech companies between 1991 and the first two months of this year. Private financings added an additional $1 billion.
"The market was confused by all these offerings," said Sanford R. Robertson, president of Robertson, Stephens & Company.
Still, biotech retains a fascination for investors. In January, before the recent bad news, a record 1,800 investors, up from 1,400 last year, attended the Hambrecht & Quist Life Sciences Conference, the industry's big annual gathering. Venture capital firms, including Kleiner Perkins, the Mayfield Fund and Institutional Venture Partners, financed record numbers of biotech start-ups in 1992 even while the public markets were closed.
But all that investment is predicated upon the assumption that some of these companies will produce drugs and begin earning the healthy gross- profit margins enjoyed by drug manufacturers.
"The public markets have to assume these companies are going to be profitable," said Kirk Raab, president and chief executive of Genentech. "If there are price controls on new drugs, people assume they won't be profitable."
Yet the Administration's position on price controls, some in the industry believe, may not even apply to biotech drugs. They note that even in those countries that regulate drug prices, the constraints typically apply only to price rises on existing drugs, not on introductory prices. The price of only one biotech drug has increased since introduction, Amgen's Neupogen for raising white blood cell counts in chemotherapy patients, and it rose only modestly.
 
'A Gross Overreaction'
 "To me it's been a gross overreaction on the part of Wall Street," said James McCamant, publisher of the Medical Technology Stock Letter. He argues that many biotech drugs actually lower health-care costs. Treatments under development for rheumatoid arthritis, for example, could eliminate the main cause of joint replacements, a costly procedure, he said.
But if Wall Street remains spooked, biotech companies will have to look elsewhere for financing. Already some venture funds are reluctantly providing cash to needy public companies. The cash-rich pharmaceuticals manufacturers are likely to buy into, and in some cases buy up, fledgling biotech concerns. In the last six years, the large drug companies have put close to $400 million into minority equity investments in biotech companies, according to Mark Edwards of Recombinant Capital, a San Francisco market research firm.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chicago Names Professor As Business School Dean

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 29

 BODY:
The University of Chicago today named Robert S. Hamada, a leading professor of finance at its Graduate School of Business, to succeed John P. Gould this summer as the school's dean.
Known as the home of the "Chicago school" of economists, whose advocacy of free markets dominated political thinking in Washington during the Reagan and Bush Administrations, the business school has in recent years gained a reputation as a center for research and teaching on quality control and technology transfer and for training in leadership skills. 
 A recent survey by Business Week of business school graduates and the executives who hire them ranked Chicago second in the nation, behind the Kellogg School at nearby Northwestern University; four years ago it was ranked 11th.
Mr. Gould, who said in a recent interview that he had not yet decided whether to return to "serious academics" when he retired June 30 from administration, has led the school for 10 years. Among his accomplishments has been a quadrupling of the endowment, to nearly $64 million.
 
Trained as an Engineer
 Mr. Hamada, 55, was born in San Francisco, grew up in New Rochelle, N.Y., and was trained as a chemical engineer, with degrees from Yale University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He shifted to finance while pursuing his Ph.D. at M.I.T. and joined the Chicago faculty in 1966.
He has focused much of his research on the effect of risk and taxes on corporate finance and the connection between corporate finance and strategy. He has also worked extensively on international business issues and financial futures markets.
During his years at Chicago, Mr. Hamada has also won several teaching awards, served as director of the school's Center for International Business Education and Research, and held several administrative posts, including deputy dean for faculty from 1985 to 1990.
"One of my strengths is that I know the faculty well," he said.
 
Busy Outside the School
 Outside the school, he has edited journals and been a director of the Chicago Board of Trade. He is on the boards of the A. M. Castle Corporation, the Manville Corporation and the Riverwood International Corporation, Manville's packaging subsidiary, the Northern Trust Corporation and the National Bureau of Economic Research.
Mr. Hamada said the biggest change facing Chicago and other leading business schools in recent years had been that entering students had worked first and were older and more experienced. Businesses expect graduates to be able to "hit the ground running," he said, so schools must provide more chances for them to gain practical experience.
Mr. Hamada and his wife, Anne, have a son, Matthew in the Peace Corps, and a daughter, Janet, studying for a career in social work.
Does Mr. Gould have any advice?
"A dean is not a chief executive and you don't get to run things by announcement," he said. "The faculty is like a bunch of independent entrepreneurs working in one place and you are dealing with people who are by training skeptical. My first line of strategy has been to try to at least convince people not to block innovative activities by others."

HEADLINE: For Clinton, 'Managed Trade' Is Emerging as Policy Option

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
Four years ago, when even Japanese ministers were calling for their country to buy more American goods, the Bush Administration shied away from setting targets because it feared that such action might look like managing trade.
In the Bush Administration lexicon, "managed trade" meant inefficient Government meddling that inevitably did more harm than good. 
 Much has changed since. Although President Clinton professes to share the Bush Administration's admiration for free markets, when he and his senior officials talk about trade they talk about ways Government intervention can help, not hurt. Managed trade is seen as "comparable access" to foreign markets and "aggressive unilateralism" to expand international commerce.
The result is a new and more confrontational tone for American trade policy. Like President Clinton's high-technology subsidy programs, the new strategy is based on a renewed confidence in the ability of Government to step in effectively where unregulated markets appear to produce unsatisfactory results.
 
Evident at News Conference
 That tougher stance -- and the greater emphasis on the need for intervention -- was evident at the President's news conference last Tuesday. Mr. Clinton volunteered that the persistent trade deficit with Japan showed that "the possibility of obtaining real, even access to the Japanese market is somewhat remote." The Bush Administration, in contrast, had emphasized differences in the two countries' economies.
But if the President has been vocal about the need for change, the details of the new trade policy remain blurred and conflicting. The Administration's shifting statements on trade reflect internal policy disputes, a deliberate effort to keep negotiating opponents off balance and a tendency to tell each audience what it wants to hear.
One early signal of Mr. Clinton's activist approach to trade policy was the appointment of Laura D'Andrea Tyson to the chairmanship of the Council of Economic Advisers. She is an advocate of more confrontational trade practices to help American high-technology industries. While free trade is ideal, she said in a recent interview, it is better to expand commerce through managed pacts and "aggressive unilateralism" than to allow barriers to suffocate trade altogether.
 
A New Slogan
 "I would draw a distinction between managed trade arrangements that reduce trade and ones that increase trade," she said.
The new trade policy even seems to be acquiring a new slogan: "comparable access," a term used frequently in various permutations by Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. Apparently adopted from a controversial European Community rule on government contracts, the new term goes beyond the traditional American goal of seeking reciprocal concessions.
The strategy assumes that the United States has a more open market than its trading partners -- as most studies have indicated -- and means that further American concessions must be matched by much larger foreign concessions.
Access is measured by the market shares of American companies in foreign markets. Mr. Kantor, for example, has criticized Japan in recent days because American car makers and computer chip makers have smaller shares of the Japanese market than they do in Europe.
 
The Auto Parts Issue
 And on Friday, Mr. Kantor told Japan's Trade Minister, Yoshiro Mori, that the Clinton Administration expected Japanese auto manufacturers to double their purchases of foreign auto parts by the end of 1994. The Japanese car makers set this as a voluntary goal when President Bush visited Tokyo in January 1992, but Mr. Kantor referred to it on Friday as a "pledge." Though definitions of managed trade vary, almost all include governments' setting market shares for imports.
The new approach has delighted some American industries facing import competition, like Detroit's car makers. But trade experts concerned about the risk of a tit-for-tat trade war are alarmed.
"This should be the spring of hope and instead we might get nuclear winter," said Jagdish Bhagwati, an economics professor and trade specialist at Columbia University. "I think it is going to lead to managed trade."
Foreign trading partners are also bewildered by what appears to be a mix of conciliation and confrontation. "We're all groping in the dark -- they say one thing and do another," said the foreign minister of one of the European Community's 12 member nations, in reference to American trade policy. "I don't expect to get any definitive picture this year, so it's going to be a series of ad hoc negotiations stretching off into the future."
 
Kantor Sees Consistency
 But Mr. Kantor insists American policy is consistent. "The fact is, we know where we're going," he said in an interview. "We're going to lead global growth -- trade is going to be an integral part of our economic plan."
The constant shifts in rhetoric, depending on the audience and the issue, have also given new life to a long-simmering debate over whether American trade policy should be clear and consistent, with Democrats supporting their President's weaving pronouncements while Republicans express alarm.
Senator Max S. Baucus, the Montana Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee's trade panel, contended on the Senate floor on Friday that the new unpredictability was an asset. "Do we really want to be predictable as we sit down to negotiate with our trading partners?" he asked. "Do we want them to know exactly what we'll do -- and when? Or do we want to keep them guessing and get the best deal for our exporters?"
But Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative for the Bush Administration, said that the Clinton Administration's recent swerves in policy were dangerous. "The business community worldwide hates uncertainty, our trading partners loathe uncertainty and frequently miscalculate when the signals are not clear," she said.
The danger perceived by Mrs. Hills and other Administration critics is twofold: that trading nations will blunder into a trade war through miscalculation and that companies will make bad investments and other business decisions because of inaccurate forecasts of international competition.
"You don't want our own business community going down paths that are cul-de-sacs," Mrs. Hills said.
Members of the Clinton Administration also continue to tailor pronouncements on trade to their audiences, much as the candidate did during the campaign, which also produces apparent inconsistencies.
For example, President Clinton vehemently criticized European aircraft manufacturing subsidies in front of cheering Boeing workers on Feb. 22, saying, "We're going to change the rules of the game."
But on Friday, at a news conference with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, President Clinton praised the existing trans-Atlantic rules on subsidies and said that he hoped that the current agreement on subsidy limits would remain in place.
Part of the murkiness in the Administration's trade policy does reflect genuine policy divisions over how aggressively the United States can proceed without undermining trade rules and stifling commerce.
Some officials, mainly at the Treasury Department and State Department, believe respect for existing rules is so fragile that harsh actions could provoke devastating trade wars. Lawrence H. Summers, named to be Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, has led opposition to managed trade ideas in interagency meetings on those grounds, several Administration officials said. Mr. Summers declined to comment.
 
Aggressive Action Sought
 Other officials, including Mr. Kantor, scoff at such warnings, contending that so many countries rely so heavily on exports and imports that any trade dispute would fizzle before it seriously restricted international trade. These officials contend that the world's economy has changed since the 1930's, when tariffs throttled trade and worsened the Depression.
Mr. Kantor and his allies contend that aggressive action is needed to claw back some of the many trade concessions made during the cold war to insure the allegiance of allies.
Most recently, the split has been reflected in the issue of whether imported mini-vans and sport utility vehicles should be labeled trucks instead of cars, which would raise tariffs on them to 25 percent from 2.5 percent. President Clinton said last Tuesday that the issue was under review, and added that the Bush Administration decision to classify the vehicles as cars was "a $300-million-a-year freebie to the Japanese for no apparent reason." Mr. Kantor said on CNN's "Evans & Novak" a few days earlier, "I'm sure we'll have a decision in the near future."
But a Treasury Department official said last week that the review was an investigation of the technical details of how vehicles were classified rather than a process that might eventually change policy.
Policy divisions alone do not explain the sharp swerves in recent American trade rhetoric and bargaining tactics. To a considerable extent, they also reflect the personal style of Mr. Kantor, who has dominated much of the new trade policy.
Two close associates of Mr. Kantor said he relished throwing his opponents off balance by alternating charm with pugnacity in negotiations. Mr. Kantor acquired this tactic as a lawyer in administrative law cases in California and is now applying it to foreign governments, they said.
 
 
 
STYLE AND SUBSTANCE ON TRADE
 Often tough but sometimes conciliatory, the Clinton Administration has left business leaders and trade officials wondering whether the United States is changing its approach to trade disputes.
President Bush, an ardent opponent of government interference in international commerce, left negotiations to his trade representative, Carla A. Hills. President Clinton focuses on the problems as well as the benefits of free trade. His trade representative, Mickey Kantor, talks as tough as the President but has refrained from confrontational actions so far.
Here are the Bush and CLinton administrations' approaches to five simmering trade issues

 MINIVANS: The Bush Administration's Treasury Department ruled in 1989 that minivans and sport utility vehicles should pay the 2.5 percent import tariff for cars instead of the 25 percent levy on light trucks. President Clinton criticized the decision during the campaign and said last Tuesday that he remains opposed to it.
AIRCRAFT: Mrs. Hills negotiated an agreement requiring that future European aircraft manufacturers to repay government subsidies, with interest, but did not require Airbus, a four-nation joint venture, to repay past subsidies. President Clinton criticized European aircraft subsidies in February, but praised the agreement on Friday.
SEMICONDUCTORS: Mrs. Hills negotiated the informal 'expectation' that imported computer chips would take 20 percent of the Japanese market by the end of 1992, a target that Japan met. Mr. Kantor calls the 20 percent figure in the 1991 semiconductor agreement a "commitment" and praises the suggestion that similar figures be used in other negotiations.
NAFTA: Mr. Bush endorsed the North American Free Trade Agreement, which would eliminate trade barriers among Canada, Mexico and the United States. Mr. Clinton has called for three side agreements covering labor, the environment and possible surges of imports that could threaten domestic industries. Negotiations started on March 17.
GATT: In talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the major international trade agreement, the United States and the European Community agreed in November to limit farm subsidies. Mr. Kantor has said the Administration might not immediately accept that agreement but on Friday, Clinton praised it.
