HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Notes and Bonds Up in Light Day

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The price of Treasury bonds and notes shot higher in late but light trading yesterday, after a sharp selloff on Friday raised doubts about whether the 1993 rally could continue.
The sudden rise sent the price of the 30-year bond up 21/32 point and the yield down to 6.89 percent, from 6.94 percent on Friday. But traders said there was little to make of the price rise because it did not make up for the Friday selloff and was caused by technical trading and rumors about some possible Federal Reserve actions later in the week. 
 Even with the drop in the yield on the 30-year bond, it is still above the 6.85 percent level of Thursday and well above the low for the year of 6.72 percent, set on March 8. The price of the 30-year bond dropped one point and 6/32 on Friday.
Traders said two factors might have contributed to the sudden rise in prices at the end of the day. One was the fact that some dealers and speculators had bet that prices would decline more yesterday. But when the market held relatively steady, some of the people who sold short to take advantage of falling prices decided to buy back Treasury securities, which sent prices rising.
In addition, there was talk in the market for most of the day that the Ferderal Reserve would be buying Treasury notes and possibly bonds later in the week as part of an effort to assure that seasonal fluctuations in the availability of dollars do not drive short-term interest rates higher than the central bank would like.
As will be the case all week, traders and investors will focus on the employment data for March that are to be released on Friday. The picture of the economy that these data provide will help determine if interest rates will move lower again, stay in a tight range or move higher.
 
New York City Sale
 New York City will sell about $770 million in bonds today and use the proceeds to pay off older, higher-interest-rate debt.
The issue will include no New York City "mini bonds" -- bonds with a low face value that can be more easily purchased by individual investors. The lead underwriter is Merrill Lynch.
In addition, the much-talked-about sale of New York City bonds in Japan, denominated in yen, will not be done until May, because it could not be included among an all-tax-exempt refunding issue. The sale of so-called Samurai bonds will total $150 million to $175 million and will be part of a sale of bonds to raise new funds that will total $750 million to $800 million, according to Darcy Bradbury, the Deputy New York City Comptroller for finance.
The sale comes at a time when interest rates have moved above their recent lows, which means the city may have to pay a little more in interest than it might have. In the three weeks since the Treasury market hit its lows of the year, the yields on tax-exempt municipal bonds have moved up about a third of a percentage point.
But one underwriter involved in the issue said that slightly higher interest rates could actually help an issue by making it more attractive to investors.
City officials deny that the sale was delayed by the process of selecting a new syndicate of brokerage firms to sell the securities, which involved detailed investigations on the firms' dealings in South Africa.
"We don't believe there was any delay," Ms. Bradbury said. "It is still a great market and you can't hit every low."
Despite these problems, New York will get the lowest interest rates on its bonds in years. The price talk late yesterday was that long-term bonds over 15 years would have yields of about 6.30 percent. The range of maturities will be from 1993 to 2015.
Ms. Bradbury said it was originally thought that the new money issue and the Samurai bonds would be sold at the end of March. But the city had included an expected interest rate saving of $100 million in the budget for the fiscal year 1994, which begins on July 1, and wanted to get the savings secured quickly so it could be shown to the rating agencies, she said.
For New York City residents, the issue is especially attractive because it is triple tax-exempt. That means a 6.30 percent tax-exempt yield will equal a taxable yield of about 9.8 percent for a person in the top Federal tax bracket, which is now 31 percent. At the 39.6 percent top bracket proposed by President Clinton, the taxable equivalent yield is about 13.8 percent.
 
S.& P. Ratings

The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that in the first quarter it had downgraded the credit rating of many more bonds than it had upgraded.
S.&P. downgraded the credit ratings on 130 corporate issues totaling $219.1 billion, compared with upgrading 81 issues worth $30.5 billion. On tax-exempt municipal issues, ratings were cut on 52 issues totaling $3.1 billion while ratings were raised on 42 issues totaling $1,4 billion.

HEADLINE: Further Sign Of Slowing In Recovery

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 29

 BODY:
Consumers spent more and saved less last month, the Commerce Department reported today, but income growth weakened in a further sign of a slowing economic recovery.
The department also said sales of new homes rose only moderately last month, even though mortgage rates were at a 20-year low. February sales rose 4.6 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 595,000, after having plunged by a revised 12.7 percent, to a rate of 569,000, in January. 
 The reports indicate the economy has lost some of the momentum that carried it to a relatively strong 4.7 percent annual growth rate in the fourth quarter last year.
 
 
Spending and Income Figures
 Personal spending was up by six-tenths of 1 percent, to $4.26 trillion, last month after a three-tenths of 1 percent January gain. Incomes from wages, salaries and all other sources edged up only by two-tenths of 1 percent, to $5.23 trillion in February, following a five-tenths of 1 percent rise in January.
It was the sixth straight month of more consumer spending, which fuels two-thirds of national economic activity. But the savings rate dipped to its lowest in more than two years as consumers drained their bank accounts to keep going.
"The consumption data indicate that growth during the first quarter of 1993 will not be as robust as the 4.7 percent reported for the fourth quarter of 1992," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation in New York.
While the growth in new-home sales was a significant improvement from January, sales last month were 5.3 percent lower than February a year earlier, when new homes sold at a rate of 628,000.
 
 
Lumber Costs Cited
 Michael Carliner, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders, said bad weather was clearly a factor slowing sales last month. But there were other negative factors, he said.
"We've had continuing weak growth in employment and in incomes," Mr. Carliner said. "We may also be about to see increases in new-home prices because of rising lumber costs."
The report on personal income covered not only wages and salaries but also income from sources such as dividends, rents, interest and businesses.
Wages and salaries alone, excluding all other income sources, fell in February by $3.5 billion to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3 trillion -- the first decline in wages and salaries since September.
 
 
January Bonuses
 Manufacturing payrolls increased but there was a big falloff in incomes for employees in service industries, in part because the securities industries paid larger-than-normal bonuses in January for income-tax reasons.
Personal savings fell in February to an annual rate of $187 billion from $202.9 billion in January.
The savings rate, which shows savings as a percentage of disposable income and is widely watched by economists, dropped to 4.1 percent in February from 4.4 percent in January. That meant Americans were saving only 4.1 cents out of each dollar they earned after taxes last month -- the weakest savings since they put away 4 cents for each dollar of income last October.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
A Lack of Direction Leaves The Dollar Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar ended narrowly mixed yesterday in listless trading. There was little international political news or economic data to give the market direction.
Gold prices fell 30 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, where bullion for current delivery settled at $332.10 an ounce. A late quote from the Republic National Bank put spot gold at $332.20 an ounce, off 15 cents from Friday. 
 A Commerce Department report showed Americans' income rose a scant two-tenths of a percent in February, while consumption was up a more robust six-tenths of a percent. But analysts attributed the spending rise largely to bad weather last month that forced consumers to pay more for heat and for services like snow shoveling.
 
 
Sluggish Growth
 Analysts said the data confirmed a recent trend of sluggish American economic growth. New home sales, which rose to a 595,000 annual rate in February, were in line with economists' expectations and failed to move the dollar.
"The subpar economic data were enough to keep people from betting on the dollar," said Randolph Donney, senior research director at Pegasus Econometric.
Dealers said they were awaiting a meeting of the Bundesbank on Thursday to see if Germany would lower interest rates again, narrowing its rate advantage over the dollar. A cooling of tensions over the political situation in Russia also depressed demand for the dollar, which often gains in times of international crisis.
Currency trading did react to European political news yesterday. The lira hit new all-time lows against the German mark as an Italian Government corruption inquiry widened. A landslide victory for French conservatives in Sunday's runoff election renewed speculation that the franc could be devalued, but the currency held up well in thin trading.
The dollar closed at 1.6268 marks in New York, down from 1.6330 marks on Friday. Earlier in London, the dollar settled at 1.6318 marks, little changed from 1.6319 marks on Friday.
 
 
Tokyo Trading
 In Tokyo, the dollar ended at 116.88 Japanese yen, up from Friday's 116.76 yen. In London, it rose to 116.85 yen from 116.45 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 116.85 yen, up from 116.50 on Friday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.4905, from $1.4915 Friday. It held steady in New York at $1.4905, above Friday's close of $1.4880.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Baseball Puts Teeth in Minority Job Plans

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., March 29

 BODY:
Major league baseball owners, long impervious to criticism of their minority hiring record, signaled an about-face today, promising new initiatives that will be enforced by the threat of sanctions.
The plan, announced today by Bud Selig, owner of the Milwaukee Brewers and baseball's acting commissioner, comes at a time when the sport and its ruling executive council stand just one week away from the start of a season that has been targeted for possible boycotts by the Rev. Jesse Jackson. 
 In a statement, Jackson criticized the plan for lacking specificity and left open the possibility of protest actions.
 
The Schott Shot
 The owners' program comes less than two months after baseball was caught up in its latest embarrassment on the minority front, with the suspension of Marge Schott, owner of the Cincinnati Reds, on grounds she made racially and ethnically insensitive remarks. Charges of institutional insensitivity resulted, not only from high-profile civil rights leaders like Jackson, but from members of Congress and the players' unions of three professional sports.
The owners' initiative not surprisingly makes the standard calls for the recruitment of minority-group members as owners, employees and paying fans. The new ground broken was found in calls for clubs to actively and aggressively recruit minority vendors, to educate all employees in the area of equal opportunity programs and to make accessible hiring information heretofore deemed confidential in order to assure a monitoring process will work.
 
Minority Businesses Sought
 The owners put great emphasis on the economic bridges to minority communities. Selig said a key point was the directive that clubs identify and seek the services of minority-owned businesses. Among those now being sought are providers of goods, banking and investment services, and physicians, attorneys and broadcast rights holders. Clubs are also being told to assure that non-minority firms they do business with demonstrate that they are equal opportuni
"That's the hardest thing to do, but it could have the most impact," said Jerry Reinsdorf, owner of the Chicago White Sox and co-chairman of the owners' equal opportunity committee, which drew up the program, "because there's a multiplier effect. When we hire an employee, we put somebody to work. But now we're essentially going to be helping to create jobs outside of our organization."
Included in the plan's definition of "minorities" are African-Americans, Hispanic-Americans, American Indians, Asian-Americans and women.
The owners, while refusing to tie their actions to any attempt to negotiate a peace with Jackson and his followers, nonetheless detailed a line of action that, for the first time, emanated not from from a baseball commissioner but the clubs themselves.
 
Jackson's Response
 "The report sets forth a series of good principles and good intentions to be implemented individually and voluntarily, but contains no overall or team-by-team plan to correct the situation," Jackson said in a statement. "It sets forth no specific goals; has no time frame to accomplish the general goals (their goals are immeasurable); there is no directive or incentive involved to implement an affirmative action plan."
Jackson said in a telephone interview that baseball's plan was unacceptable and will lead his newly formed Rainbow Commission for Fairness in Athletics to engage in a campaign of direct action.
"We're going to have a meeting of our leadership in Baltimore on Wednesday, then we are going to give a formal response," Jackson said. Direct action, Jackson said, could emerge "in the form of picketing, or the form of targeting institutional season-ticket holders, or with the E.E.O.C. or Civil Rights Commission which now must consider doing hearings on baseball."
"The Reverend was probably looking for more specifics," admitted Jerry Reinsdorf.
"I'm only interested in getting to a goal and I know that each club has got to do it its own way. We thought very hard about requiring each club to submit a specific plan. We thought about an industry-wide plan, but we were counseled to go in this direction as opposed to more specifics."
Reinsdorf and Selig both insisted that stringent guidelines will not be needed because of the owners' new-found commitments, as well as pledges for self-policing.
"My committee is going to be monitoring this and if we find that clubs are not complying, we're going to go back to the executive council or to the commissioner, when there's a commissioner, and ask for fines," Reinsdorf said.
 
No Set Guidelines
 Under baseball's major league agreement, organizations can be fined up to $250,000 for violation of baseball edicts.
There are no set guidelines as to how much business each club is expected to throw toward minority vendors, an omission Reinsdorf said Alexander & Associates, the Washington-based consulting firm, endorsed.
"They constantly told us that quotas and specific numbers are too difficult because we're dealing with 28 independent and small businesses and when you have such small units, it's hard to establish a quota to any one of them," Reinsdorf said. "So what we're looking for is in the aggregate, to have their numbers just continue to increase."
Clifford Alexander, head of the consulting firm, termed the concept of quotas and set-aside programs unneeded diversions. "That whole discussion would allow people who don't want to see any progress to say 'why are you setting aside money for them?' " Alexander said. "There's no reason to set aside money. There are plenty of minority-owned firms that can provide the services a ball club requires."
Another aspect of the plan deals with minority ownership.
The commissioner's office and the league offices are instructed to encourage minority-group members to seek controlling interests of clubs. Clubs with multiple owners are instructed to seek to attract minorities as investors.
 
Selig's Promise
 Baseball, not only hectored by civil rights leaders but its most recent commissioners, has made some percentage gains. It now has a front-office minority representation of 17 percent compared with 2 percent in 1987. And it will enter this season with six minority managers.
Selig, whose statement today also detailed baseball's contributions to charities, youth baseball, Negro League players and the like, said, "We can do better. And we will."
"I realize we can't do it overnight," said Reinsdorf. "But I want to report a year from now meaningful progress."

HEADLINE: Making Trade Pact Work for the Environment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Save Nafta. But Don't Roll Over" (editorial, March 17) urges United States officials to get tougher in working out the details of the North American Free Trade Agreement. Certainly, much remains to be done, but a strategy that threatens both Mexico and Canada is not the way to do it. 
 On the environment, it would make more sense to push all three countries to recognize a convergence of interests in solving joint problems. Motives that brought them to the bargaining table for freer trade in goods, services and capital across national boundaries should be used to reduce the unintended trade in environmental degradation. This means working together to set priorities, finding the means to enforce laws and international agreements on the books, and creating incentives and institutions that benefit the environment.
Among many environmental issues related to the trade agreement, the highest priority should go to the United States-Mexico border region. The Clinton Administration, rather than growling at our trading partners, needs to convince everyone it will help clean up the border. As a start, the Administration should review the activities of Federal agencies in the border region, establish an Environmental Protection Agency region office and work with Congress to provide secure Federal funds for our portion of the United States-Mexico border plan.
This plan, long neglected by our Government, gives the new Administration an opportunity -- along with Mexico and the border states -- to prove that freer trade's benefits can be used to improve the environment for citizens in both countries.
We also need a North American commission on the environment, to serve as a forum for cooperation on environmental and public health issues, and to help the countries follow through on the environmental provisions of the trade agreement. The commission would go beyond the agreement to tackle difficult issues in enforcing environmental laws and regulating methods of production.
Also, the commission should have authority to receive and investigate citizen complaints, to publicize its findings, to develop and recommend correctives to the parties involved, and to recommend enforcement actions to a national government if a corrective measure is not adopted in a reasonable period of time.
Finally, as a condition of implementing the trade agreement, all three countries -- especially the United States -- should call on the private sector to do more. For example, United States-based companies operating in Mexico can serve as a model by providing public access to information on the environment, public health and safety. Businesses can follow the lead of the El Paso Foreign Trade Association by sponsoring training programs for industry personnel involved in transporting, handling and storing hazardous materials.
Finally, we should take full advantage of new initiatives from the business community, such as the Gulf of Mexico Business Council for Sustainable Development. The decisions of these executives will determine the fate of the trade agreement's promise to "promote sustainable development" and "strengthen the development and enforcement of environmental laws and regulations."
Getting tougher in the negotiations may make sense for some trade matters, but if we want to solve environmental problems the United States strategy needs to help everyone get smarter.
 
PETER M. EMERSON
Senior Economist, Environmental Defense Fund
Austin, Tex., March 19, 1993

HEADLINE: U.S. and Britain Softening Emphasis on Ousting Iraqi

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 29

 BODY:
The United States and Britain have begun to move away from their insistence that the trade embargo against Iraq cannot be lifted while President Saddam Hussein remains in power.
Both President George Bush and Prime Minister John Major had said on several occasions that the sanctions must remain until President Hussein has been toppled, though the Security Council resolutions imposing the embargo contain no such requirement. 
 Their insistence that Iraq remove its dictatorial leader has become increasingly unpopular with other Arab countries because it clearly exceeds the Council's decisions and because many Arab countries are quietly making accommodations with Iraq.
Neither the United States nor Britain mentioned this condition today when the Security Council reviewed the embargo and decided it should remain in place because Iraq has not complied with the terms of the cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war. Instead they submitted long lists of ways in which Iraq refuses to comply with those terms.
 
Window for Administration
 Western diplomats had predicted that today's periodic review, the first since President Clinton took office, would provide an occasion for the new Administration to end the vendetta that Mr. Bush seemed to wage against Mr. Hussein and to adopt a more legalistic policy toward Iraq's compliance.
Appearing Sunday on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Secretary of State Warren Christopher also refused to repeat the Bush Administration's warning that President Hussein must go before sanctions can be lifted.
Instead he said the Clinton Administration was "de-personalizing" its quarrel with Baghdad while insisting that Iraq comply with the cease-fire.
"To the extent we are de-personalizing it, it is only because we want those resolutions to be obeyed not only by Saddam Hussein, but by whoever comes after him," he said.
 
Letting Opponents Do the Job
 But Mr. Christopher also argued that full compliance would in fact undermine President Hussein's Government and lead to its overthrow because they require him to stop oppressing the Kurds in the north and the Shiites in the south. Both groups want to topple him from power.
Pointing out that Resolution 688 requires Baghdad to end its military suppression of the Kurds and the Shiites, Mr. Christopher said: "It's quite inconceivable to me to believe that he can do that and still stay in power, so we are pushing ahead. Our policy is to try to ensure that the United Nations resolutions are lived up to."
After today's review of the sanctions at the United Nations, the United States representative, Madeleine K. Albright, refused to discuss the policy change, saying, "We are not talking about that."
Britain's representative, Sir David Hannay, said, "The instructions I received for conducting the sanctions review did not relate to Saddam Hussein's staying in office."
 
Parading the Violations
 Instead the United States and Britain described what they called violations of the conditions that the Security Council imposed on Iraq at the end of the gulf war.
They noted Iraq's failure to take part in the boundary commission demarcating the border with Kuwait, the suppression of Kurds and Shiites and Iraq's refusal to cooperate with the United Nations personnel charged with eliminating Baghdad's weapons of mass destruction and monitoring its military industries.
Miss Albright accused President Hussein of trying "to charm the international community," a reference to various more temperate statements by Baghdad and the decision to send Nizar Hamdoun, a respected and accomplished diplomat, to represent Iraq at the United Nations.
But she said: "Iraq's facade of apparent readiness to meet its obligations has not been translated into concrete responses. And no such charm has been enjoyed by the people of Iraq, who suffer the policies of their Government."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 1, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about American policy toward Iraq misidentified the television program on which Secretary of State Warren Christopher appeared on Sunday. It was the CBS News program "Face the Nation."

HEADLINE: Ukraine and Arms Accords: Kiev Reluctant to Say 'I Do'

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, March 29

 BODY:
The political unrest in Russia has stalled efforts to substantially reduce nuclear arsenals in the United States and the former Soviet Union.
In Ukraine, new fears of Russian nationalism have encouraged an increasingly vocal group of legislators who advocate keeping some nuclear weapons. President Leonid Kravchuk had promised last year that Ukraine would ratify not only the 1991 Soviet-American agreement reducing nuclear warheads, but also the non-proliferation treaty of 1970, which would oblige it to give up all nuclear weapons.
 
Treaties Need One Another
 The breakup of the Soviet Union left nuclear weapons in four republics: Russia, Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan. All but Ukraine have ratified the July 1991 treaty, which called for one-third cuts in the nuclear warheads on Soviet and American ballistic missiles, and Ukrainian legislators, who are debating the treaty, are hesitant about giving up the weapons they inherited from the Soviet Union. 
 Without final ratification by all four successor states of the 1991 accord, known as Start I, and the 1970 pact, the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear arms, there is no way Moscow and Washington will ratify a follow-up treaty signed in January by President Boris N. Yeltsin and President George Bush.
That treaty, known as Start II, would eliminate heavy, land-based, multiple-warhead missiles and leave the United States and Russia with about 3,500 warheads each, down from a current total of 21,000. The treaty would eliminate any reasonable hope for a successful attack by either side.
Start II is built on Start I and is meaningless without it, but ratification of the second treaty can wait for a year or more, senior Western diplomats say. Much more pressing is the first treaty, which the Parliament of Ukraine is now debating. When the Soviet Union broke up, Ukraine laid claim to all Soviet property on its territory, including nuclear weapons.
Mr. Kravchuk and his Government have not altered their commitment to ratify both Start I and the non-proliferation treaty.
But some influential legislators now say that while they favor ratifying Start I, subject to certain conditions, Ukraine should wait before signing the 1970 accord and becoming a non-nuclear nation. They suggest keeping some nuclear weapons to deter any possible move by Russia to force Kiev back under Moscow's wing.
"The situation in Russia complicates the process of ratifying Start," said Dmytro Pavlychko, the chairman of the Parliament's foreign relations committee. "A few days ago, the idea of a fast transition of Ukraine to a non-nuclear state had more support that it does now."
The Parliament will ratify Start I, he said. "But I don't think we'll join the non-proliferation treaty very soon," he added. "I think we'll move to be non-nuclear, but at a slower pace. In three or four years, things will calm down in Russia."
 
After You, Says Moscow
 Separation of Start I and the non-proliferation treaty would probably derail both Start agreements because the Supreme Soviet of Russia has said it will not implement Start I until Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan also become non-nuclear states. Belarus has signed the non-proliferation treaty and Kazakhstan has promised to do so, a promise that no one seems to doubt.
Before the breakup of the Soviet Union, Moscow could have complied with Start I by destroying the silos of 130 six-warhead SS-19 intercontinental missiles in Ukraine, while leaving other nuclear weapons in place there.
Should Ukraine interpret the treaty this way, it would be left with at least 460 warheads on 46 more modern intercontinental SS-24 missiles, and 30 bombers with an estimated 416 warheads on bombs and cruise missiles.
But maintaining such an arsenal would run counter to President Kravchuk's commitment to President Bush to eliminate Ukraine's strategic weapons within seven years of ratifying Start I. Washington considers that commitment legally binding.
 
The Weight of Friendship
 Western diplomats say the weapons in Ukraine remain under the control of the Commonwealth of Independent States, the tottering association of 11 former Soviet republics.
But one diplomat said: "There's a lot of technical know-how in Ukraine, and they may begin to delude themselves into thinking they can take over, manage and use these weapons. And some in Ukraine's leadership seem to think Ukraine is only important to the United States because of the weapons."
Washington is turning up the pressure on Kiev, which resents it. On March 25 President Clinton met with Foreign Minister Anatoly Zlenko and told him Start I "is a precondition to a long-term successful relationship" with Ukraine. Despite "some opposition at home in Ukraine because of uncertainty in Russia," Mr. Clinton said, "we have to have them sign on, and I encouraged them to go ahead and do it."
But the Deputy Foreign Minister, Boris I. Tarasyuk, warned Washington not to pressure Ukraine.
"It would be counterproductive to put pressure on us and our Government while the Parliament is trying to sort it out," he said in an interview. "It would be a great mistake and could increase the numbers of those who advocate -- not a nuclear Ukraine -- but not acceding to the non-proliferation treaty in order to leave some room for maneuver."
 
'It Will Only Upset Russia'
 Mr. Pavlychko, the chairman of the foreign relations committee, said Ukraine should not admit to any thought of maintaining a nuclear arsenal because "it will only upset Russia." Still, Ukraine can be an important counterbalance for all of Eastern Europe against any Russian expansionism, he said.
"We must remain clever in this period -- to remain a strong state without threatening anyone," he said. "We must ratify Start I, and then we shall have to see."
Some of his colleagues are even more explicit; a few, like Gen. Volodymyr F. Tolubko, a deputy and a commander in the strategic forces, advocate active construction of a nuclear deterrent.
Other voices are also hardening.
Bogdan M. Horyn, Mr. Pavlychko's deputy chairman and deputy chairman of the military affairs committee, has said that Ukraine "has the right to decide to be a nuclear or a non-nuclear state," and that commitments to become a non-nuclear state "were voiced as intentions, not obligations."
 
'Intention' vs. 'Commitment'
 "Time brings some changes," Mr. Horyn continued. "During this period of instability in Russia, it's unwise and dangerous to get rid of our nuclear weapons. There's a big difference between 'commitment' and 'intention.' "
When told of such comments, Mr. Tarasyuk, the Deputy Foreign Minister, sighed. "The position of the Government has not changed," he said, explaining his doubt that Mr. Pavlychko or the others represented a majority view. Most legislators have not concentrated on the issue yet, he said. "It's too early to start to count votes," he added. "The crystallization of attitudes will occur when they're about to make a decision."
Western diplomats are less confident than Mr. Tarasyuk, saying the idea to delay agreement on the non-proliferation treaty was gathering support. Even President Kravchuk has been ambivalent, one diplomat said, promoting the treaties to "foreign presidents and foreign journalists, but not at home."
The diplomat continued: "If Mr. Kravchuk would say to Parliament, 'We're losing favor with the West, and we have no choice -- it's the West or Russia. These weapons offer no real security, so ratify the treaties,' it could make all the difference. But he hasn't. Maybe he will."
 
What Ukraine Wants
 Ukraine has already annoyed its neighbors by attaching conditions to Start I.
The Government, often responding to legislators, says it wants compensation for the nuclear material in any warheads that would be destroyed, including those attached to tactical weapons that have already been transferred to Russia for destruction by June 1992.
Ukraine also wants compensation for the cost of destroying its nuclear weapons, which Foreign Minister Zlenko estimated at $2.8 billion. So far, the United States has promised only $175 million.
And it wants unspecified guarantees from other nuclear powers against attack, and is securing promises to that effect, Mr. Tarasyuk said.
Talks on all these questions continue.
Western officials regard these issues as difficult but resolvable, but they add to existing irritations. "Ukraine is always moving the goal posts," one diplomat said.
 
See Themselves as Good Guys
 Ukrainian officials, for their part, say they resent all the attention being paid by Mr. Clinton to finding money to aid Russia, which they see as unstable and unreliable, while friendly, stable Ukraine gets comparatively little.
"They feel the disparity," a senior Western diplomat said, "and Start is part of the problem. It definitely is a cloud over the relationship with Washington. But Washington has been wrong not to diversify the relationship sooner and push ahead with more economic and cultural aid."

HEADLINE: CLINTON BACKS OFF FROM POLICY SHIFT ON FEDERAL LANDS

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
Bowing to warnings from Western senators that they might oppose his economic program, President Clinton has backed away from proposing a major change in the way Federal land is managed, Administration officials said today.
Coming a month after the White House suggested drastic changes in policies that have encouraged development in the West for more than a century, the turnabout was a significant defeat for environmentalists. 
 President Clinton's plan included raising the fee for grazing livestock on 280 million acres of public range and establishing royalties on gold, silver and other metals now mined from Federal land at no charge.
 
Immediate Resistance
 The Administration had also proposed a ban on logging of national forests at below-market rates. But officials in the Administration and in Congress said they were not sure how the turnaround on mining and grazing would affect logging.
The grazing fees and mining royalties met immediate resistance from Western lawmakers, who told President Clinton at a recent meeting that the changes would mean economic devastation to ranchers and farmers.
The action was seen as a setback for Leon E. Panetta, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, who had fought to keep the provisions in Mr. Clinton's budget framework, and for Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, who had hailed the package as ushering in "a brand new era in land management."
 
'Not a Retreat'
 Nonetheless, Kevin J. Sweeney, a spokesman for Mr. Babbitt, said: "It is not a retreat. It's more bowing to the impact from the Senate on how these things would happen."
After two weeks of negotiations, White House officials said today that the disputed provisions would be deleted from Mr. Clinton's proposal for a budget framework, on which Congress is currently working. The support of Western Democrats is essential for passage of Mr. Clinton's economic program in the Senate.
Contending that the change was not substantive, Administration officials vowed to press forward with the new fees through separate legislation and administrative actions rather than including them in the overall budget package.
 
Other Avenues Possible
 "This is a process argument, not necessarily a policy argument," said George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director. "If we can find a better way to achieve the President's goals, then all to the better."
But environmental groups and lawmakers who had endorsed the Administration's plans said they were furious about the decision.
"This is a fundamental mistake by the Administration," said Representative George Miller, the California Democrat who heads the Natural Resources Committee. "The decision to defer these reforms from the budget sends the message that business as usual has lived to fight another day."
Michael Francis, director of the national forest program at The Wilderness Society, said: "I don't think I've ever seen a white flag get put up so fast. The Clinton White House came out charging but, once close enough to see the whites of the enemy's eyes, turned tail."
 
'Made Their Views Known'
 Asked if Mr. Clinton was caving in to political threats from the Western senators, Mr. Stephanopoulos said, "They clearly made their views known to the President."
Today's action is the latest example of an emerging pattern in which Mr. Clinton proposes bold policy changes but then appears to adjust his course in the face of strong opposition. In the last week, he raised the possibility of restricting the deployment of gay soldiers after pledging to end discrimination against homosexuals in the military.
On another issue, Mr. Clinton first proposed restricting donations to national parties and by political action committees but later offered a compromise after negotiations with House Democrats who depend on those contributions for their campaigns every two years.
Despite the reversal today, Democratic lawmakers said they still believed Congress would pass legislation to set the new fees on using public lands, though they might not be enacted as fast, and they might not be as high as the Administration had proposed.
In proposing the restrictions on the use of publicly owned resources, White House officials had said they knew Mr. Clinton risked losing Democratic support in the Rocky Mountain states in 1996. But they had said they had also expected to gain support on the West Coast, where environmental protection is particularly important among voters.
In the end, however, today's decision demonstrated the political strength of Democrats in Colorado, Montana, New Mexico and Nevada, whose support for the budget plan is considered critical in the Senate, where less populous states wield more power than they do in the House.
In interviews today, Senators from the Western states called the Administration's decision a victory that resulted from their negotiations with the White House.
 
No Threats, Just Hints
 Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell, Democrat of Colorado, said that although he did not personally tell the President that he would oppose the budget package, he made his concerns clear to White House officials.
Asked whether Western senators could support the President's budget if it included the mining and grazing provisions, Mr. Campbell said: "There is no question that some of the Western senators would not have been able to do that. None of us were threatening to take a hike. But I think the President saw the impossibility of many Western Democrats not being able to support it knowing we'd be beaten over the head.
"How would you go back to a public-land state facing an election in four years and say that you voted to basically end mining and ranching and the using of public lands?"
Another Democrat who played a major role in the negotiations, Senator Max S. Baucus of Montana, preferred not to describe the White House decision as the result of pressure tactics.
 
Emphasizing Teamwork
 "We didn't criticize the President publicly," Mr. Baucus said, "and he realized we made a good case.
"This is just teamwork basically; we're together on the same team. Reform is needed in all these areas. It just has to be done in an even-handed and balanced way."
Some environmental groups said they were surprised that Mr. Clinton would bow to the Western senators on the eve of his trip Friday to Portland, Ore., for an important meeting on forest policy. The Administration organized the meeting as a way of settling the dispute about logging in areas where northern spotted owls live, one of the nation's most intractable and publicized environmental battles.
"Before the summit has even begun, Clinton has surrendered the public interest," said Peter Bahouth, who oversees the forest protection efforts by Greenpeace, an environmental group. "Clearly he's cutting deals behind closed doors, and that means that not only will our public forests continue to be destroyed, but taxpayers will continue to pay for it."
But the senators who opposed Mr. Clinton's plan said they did so because smaller ranchers would be driven off their land, rural communities would be threatened and a recent rise in mining claims would be snuffed. They noted that they were already troubled by the Administration's proposed energy tax, which would adversely affect states in the West, an area that produces energy and where residents drive long distances.

HEADLINE: 3 Seen in Legal Circles As Solid, Tough and Fair;
Patrick Henry NeMoyer

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Patrick Henry NeMoyer is described by his political friends -- and even his opponents -- as a hard-working lawyer and a pragmatic intellectual.
Since 1988, Mr. NeMoyer, 40, has served as the Erie County Attorney, supervising 50 employees, including 20 lawyers, who handle all civil litigation for the county. 
 The Erie County Executive, Dennis T. Gorski, called Mr. NeMoyer, whom Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan recommended yesterday for United States Attorney for the 17 counties of western New York, a "consummate attorney and intimate political adviser and a significant player in virtually every public policy issue this government has faced over the past six years."
In December, Mr. NeMoyer succeeded in reaching a settlement in what citizens of Buffalo came to know as the "domed stadium case." It was a 20-year-long dispute with a developer who was supposed to build a stadium and sued the county after its Legislature voted not to appropriate sufficient funds. The county ultimately agreed to pay $10 million, significantly lower than the damages originally sought by the developer.
Mr. NeMoyer received his bachelor's degree from the State University of New York at Binghamton in 1974, his law degree from the State University at Buffalo in 1977, and a master's in economics from the same school in 1984. He is married and a father of four.

HEADLINE: Court Supports Editor on Rights to Dead Sea Text

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 30

 BODY:
In a verdict that could have significant implications for future research on the Dead Sea Scrolls, a Jerusalem court ruled today that an Israeli professor had a copyright on his reconstruction of one of the most important of the ancient Jewish manuscripts.
The District Court awarded Dr. Elisha Qimron of Ben Gurion University in Beersheba $44,000 in damages for infringement of copyright by the publisher of a book that included, without permission or credit, his deciphering of one of the 2,000-year-old scrolls. Dr. Qimron had sought $200,000. 
 Lawyers for both sides said the ruling established for the first time that a copyright could be claimed for a reconstruction of an ancient text.
 
Victory for Authorized Editors
 The case was the first court test in a swirling controversy over publication of the Dead Sea Scrolls that has swept the scholarly world since tight limits on access to the documents were lifted more than a year ago. The verdict appeared to bolster the status of a team of authorized scroll editors, of which Dr. Qimron is a member.
About 800 scrolls, considered one of the great archeological finds of the century, were discovered more than 40 years ago in caves near the Dead Sea. Written between the second century B.C. and A.D. 70, they contain the oldest known copies of the Old Testament and are believed to provide valuable insights into the history of Judaism and the origins of Christianity.
Dr. Qimron had sued the publisher and editors of "A Facsimile Edition of the Dead Sea Scrolls," a collection of more than 1,700 photographs of scroll fragments published in 1991 by the Biblical Archeology Society.
 
Reconstruction of Scroll
 The defendants were Hershel Shanks, president of the society and editor of The Biblical Archeology Review, Dr. Robert H. Eisenman of California State University at Long Beach and Dr. James M. Robinson of the Claremont Graduate School in California. Mr. Shanks has waged a campaign to permit free access to the scrolls, and had published the fascimile edition to bring previously unpublished documents to light. An appendix to his forward to the edition included a 121-line reconstruction from a scroll known as MMT, considered important because it lists differences over religious laws that divided the sect responsible for the scrolls from mainstream Judaism.
Dr. Qimron said the reconstruction was a leaked version of his work done with John Strugnell, a Harvard scholar and former chief of the scroll editing team. The reconstruction, with a translation and commentary, is to be published at the end of the year.
Judge Dalia Dorner ruled that Mr. Shanks had knowingly violated Dr. Qimron's copyright by reprinting the bootleg version of MMT, and had also caused "economic damage and mental anguish" to Dr. Qimron by depriving him of first publication rights.
Mrs. Dorner rejected arguments by Mr. Shanks that Dr. Qimron could not claim a copyright for reconstructing an ancient text he did not write. Deciphering and arranging scores of scroll fragments while filling in extensive gaps in the text was a creative enterprise, she said.
 
Warning on Inhibiting Scholars
 After learning of the verdict today, Mr. Shanks warned that it could inhibit scholars from republishing reconstructed texts for further commentary and interpretation. "It's clearly an impediment to scholarship," he said.
Dr. Norman Golb, professor of Jewish history and civilization at the University of Chicago, said, "This represents a grave danger for the future of manuscript research."
But Dr. Qimron and other scroll experts disagreed, saying that today's ruling had upheld existing scholarly conventions while sending a strong signal to would-be plagiarists.
"This will serve as a precedent for the future," said Dr. Emanuel Tov, who heads the team of scroll editors. "It justifies the work of our team, and I hope that other people planning to make improper use of our group's material will now think twice."
Mr. Shanks said he would probably appeal the verdict to Israel's Supreme Court. A countersuit he has filed in Federal District Court in Philadelphia is still to be heard.

HEADLINE: House Rejects Big Cuts In Committee Spending

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
Rejecting Republican demands for a deep reduction in staff, the Democratic-controlled House voted today to cut spending on its committees this year by only 5 percent below the 1992 level.
Virtually all the savings, which require no further approval, will come from the abolition of four small "select" committees, panels that hold hearings and otherwise review policy but do no legislating. 
 The 224-to-196 vote followed a largely partisan debate over what kind of change the voters sought in November. Republicans, who had proposed a 25 percent cut in committee financing, contended that the people had wanted to clip the wings of an unresponsive Congress.
But Democrats argued that only a strong Congress could investigate and cut the Government waste that voters demand to be slashed.
In all, the measure approved today cuts spending on committees by $2.75 million from the $55 million of last year. Of those savings, $2.7 million will come from the dismantling of the four select committees, which dealt with hunger, children, the elderly and illegal drugs.
Several powerful standing committees, including Ways and Means, Energy and Commerce, and Armed Services, will receive slight increases. Twenty-one other committees face cuts, but they total only $57,746.
 
More Cuts Possible
 The sum in overall savings is roughly equivalent to a tenth of a percent of the cost of a Stealth bomber. The House, whose vote today was on an authorization bill, will get a chance to cut more during the appropriations process in the coming months.
After the House bank scandal and controversies over Congressional perquisites, spending on the legislative process has become the Republican battleground of choice. The debate today was a good example.
Led by their freshmen, the Republicans contended that the cuts approved amounted to little more than a shell game.
And they noted that the Democratic leaders had agreed to abolish the four select committees only after it became clear that there were not enough votes to save them.
"This is a slap in the face of the American taxpayer," said Representative Jay C. Kim, a Republican freshman from California. "Congress must take the lead, not play games with numbers."
 
Response by Dellums
 But Representative Ronald V. Dellums, the California Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, countered by saying Congress needed strong committees to keep watch on the executive branch's bureaucracy and insure its efficiency. "For a few measly thousand dollars," he said, "we can bring you savings of billions of dollars."
All 169 Republicans voting opposed the measure, while 223 Democrats were joined by one independent in voting for it.
Twenty-seven Democrats broke with their leadership, joining in a coalition of conservatives and freshmen who sought deeper cuts and liberals who supported the select committees.
"We clearly have the responsibility to tighten our own belts," said Representative Anna G. Eshoo, a freshman Democrat from economically strapped California, who voted with the Republicans.
"For some it may seem symbolic, but in fact it is reality because of what my constituents are going through."
 
A Freshman Surge
 The vote came against a backdrop of maneuvering by Republican and Democratic freshmen on behalf of various plans to overhaul House procedures and privileges.
The 47 Republican freshmen issued their own program of improvement and streamlining, which includes such proposals as abolishing the Appropriations Committee by combining the authorization and appropriations processes.
The Republicans also advocate requiring roll-call votes on all appropriations and revenue bills and imposing term limits for House members. Few of their proposals, if any, have a chance of being adopted.
The 63 Democratic freshmen are struggling to come up with their own package.
But since their ranks are divided over to what extent they should challenge the seniority system and traditional perquisites, they are not expected to reach a consensus on any sweeping changes.

HEADLINE: Congress Agrees On Compromise For Deficit Plan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a five-year plan for cutting the deficit by just under $500 billion, a measure that would lay the foundation for enactment of President Clinton's economic program.
The agreement is to be announced Wednesday and will be followed quickly by House and Senate votes. 
 Few details were available immediately after the compromise was reached. The two houses' plans were similar to begin with since both were based on Mr. Clinton's proposals: tax increases on the rich, military cuts and other savings, along with increased spending on certain domestic programs, including roads and research.
Majority Democrats hoped to pass the legislation in the House as early as Wednesday, and the Senate the next day. It would be the earliest a deficit-reduction plan was approved since the budget law was enacted in 1974.
 
Holding Military Costs
 In reaching a compromise, the Senate agreed to lower its total tax increase by roughly $22 billion to about $273 billion over five years. The House, meantime, backed away from the limits it sought on cost-of-living increases for Federal workers and retirees.
Like the House-passed version, the compromise package would also hold spending on the military and most domestic programs over the next five years to no more than the $548 billion the Government will spend this year. Excluded from this freeze would be benefit programs like Social Security and Medicare.
The outline of the package was included in a $1.5 trillion budget for fiscal 1994, which starts on Oct. 1. The measure, which does not require the President's signature, sets goals for tax and spending bills lawmakers will consider later this year.
The agreement came as Democrats erased an embarrassing setback the Senate had dealt to Mr. Clinton's jobs bill, another important piece of the his recovery economic program. The $16.3 billion measure would provide money for mass transit, summer job and other employment-heavy programs.
In a 52-to-48 vote, the Senate reversed itself and killed a Republican amendment trimming $104 million from the bill. Lawmakers had given the Republican provision preliminary approval the night before.
The tally showed that the chamber's majority Democrats will probably be able to keep enough of their 57 members together to muscle the jobs measure through the Senate largely intact.

HEADLINE: Dow Advances by 2.17 in Moderate Trading

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Investors continued yesterday to abandon their cyclical favorites of recent months for the consumer growth stocks that have fared so poorly this year.
Yesterday's turn toward companies that can resist a weak economy came after a disappointing report on consumer confidence. 
 Food, beverage, tobacco and especially drug stocks have fallen to levels that have tempted some money managers who have not touched them in years.
"Even we have succumbed and recently put some money into Warner-Lambert," as well as Upjohn, said Tony Hitschler, president of Brandywine Asset Management. His search for good values has caused him to shun drug stocks for a decade. But now, he said, "Some of these stocks in the noncyclical area are suffering perhaps too much."
Opposing tugs on various groups of stocks left the major market averages up only narrowly. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 2.17 points, to 3,457.27, on moderate volume of 231.2 million shares. Sharp gains in Microsoft and several medical issues gave the Nasdaq market much more of a ride. The Nasdaq Composite index gained 5.49, to 686.25.
With money managers indulging in trading techniques peculiar to the close of their quarterly reporting periods, some analysts were cautious about saying whether the flow of money from cyclicals to consumer growth stocks would continue.
Thomas Gallagher, head of trading at Oppenheimer & Company, is still doubtful about the drug stocks. "This group has gone from being the ugliest group in the world to being the group everybody likes," he said. "There's no rhyme here."
The most prominent reason for yesterday's run-up in drug stocks, however, was some statements by Administration officials that their health-care plans might not include price controls. Abbott Laboratories rose 1 1/2, to 26; Merck 1 1/4, to 35 1/2; Eli Lilly 1 7/8, to 48 3/4; Medtronic 3 5/8, to 75, and U.S. Surgical 3 7/8, to 56 1/2.
Among other consumer growth stocks, Coca-Cola added 1 1/8, to 43, and Philip Morris 1 3/4, to 64.
Retailers were among the worst performers, and steel and aluminum stocks were treated as if made of very base metals indeed.
The Conference Board reported yesterday that consumer confidence fell sharply this month, and the Johnson Redbook survey of retailers indicated that sales have recently declined. Wal-Mart fell 2 3/8, to 30 7/8; Dayton Hudson 1 3/8, to 80, and Lowe's 1 5/8, to 33 1/4.
Among the metals, Nucor, USX, Inland Steel, Reynolds Metal and Alcoa each dropped at least a point.
Among yesterday's victims of downbeat news, Fisher-Price, a toy maker, fell 3 1/8, to 20 3/8, after forecasting a quarterly loss.
I.B.M. fell 1 5/8, to 50 1/8, on speculation by some analysts that the company might cut its dividend in coming months. The Nasdaq computer stocks surged, however led a 4-point gain in Microsoft, to 91, on the release of a new version of its DOS software for personal computers. Intel added 1 1/4, to 115 1/2, and Sun Microsystems 1 3/8, to 29 5/8. Nasdaq medical stocks also climbed, with US Healthcare up 3, to 44 3/4; Amgen up 2, to 37, and St. Jude Medical up 1 1/2, to 32 1/4.

HEADLINE: Budget Politics Exposed in Fight for Supercollider

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
While posing for television cameras as tightfisted accountants, lawmakers are fighting behind the scenes to protect one expensive program or another as Congress votes on President Clinton's plans for cutting the Federal deficit.
Like land mines half hidden in the sand, these programs could block the progress of Mr. Clinton's economic plan. Removing them means grappling with complex combinations of local and political interests. 
 Nowhere are the intricacies of budget politics more evident than in the all-out effort by the otherwise frugal Texas and Louisiana delegations to save the superconducting supercollider, the gigantic proton smasher that is being built under the plains of Waxahachie, Tex., and outfitted with huge magnets from Hammond, La. It is worth more than 7,000 jobs in its construction and operation.
But it will also cost $8.4 billion over six or seven years, a figure that White House budget-cutters are sure to find tempting when the country is hard pressed to pay for more prosaic needs, like the interest on the national debt.
 
Economics Versus Politics
 Mr. Clinton and the Congress must negotiate through an obstacle course of hundreds of individual spending items, as diverse as subsidies for cotton growers in Arizona or money for construction of Seawolf submarines in Connecticut. Economists can make a powerful argument to cut any of them, but the political logic often goes in another direction.
In the case of the supercollider, Mr. Clinton is thought to have doubts on its economics, but he is well aware that its future is closely tied not only to jobs in the battleground state of Texas, but also to the Democratic Party's hopes to maintain control of the Senate. So far, he is standing by a campaign pledge to support the project, a promise that helped him win Louisiana and stay competitive in Texas in the Presidential election.
For all the political maneuvering expected in the coming months over the supercollider, the arguments so far virtually never refer to politics. With its potential to form new alloys and stronger metals, proponents concentrate on the supercollider's vital role in keeping the United States competitive in industry and dominant in science.
 
Secret of Energy and Matter
 "This is fundamental, basic science that can give us the answer to what energy and matter are made of," said Senator J. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana.
But Senator Dale Bumpers of Arkansas, a Democrat who is a strong advocate of cuts to lower the Federal deficit, views the proton-smasher as an unaffordable example of high-technology pork. "I'm not saying there isn't a lot of elegant science that can be gleaned from this, but that's what it is: elegant," he said. "We can't afford elegance now."
The arguments against the supercollider were bolstered last month by a General Accounting Office report estimating a $630 million cost overrun in its $1.25 billion construction budget alone.
But in the end, said Representative Sherwood Boehlert of upstate New York, "the superconducting supercollider is raw hardball politics."
After the first inning, the project's proponents are ahead, as Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who was a Texas Senator until two months ago, prevailed over the budget director, Leon E. Panetta, and persuaded President Clinton to include the project in his budget proposal. And allied with Mr. Bentsen are some of the most powerful members of Congress, which is why the supercollider is likely to survive, though perhaps in a somewhat scaled-back form.
 
Not Taken for Granted
 But this year no one is taking anything for granted, as public pressure for shrinking the deficit is changing the political calculus on the Hill, said Representative Sam Coppersmith, an Arizona freshman Democrat on the Science, Space and Technology Committee. "In the old days, the dynamic was, He got his project, I got mine," said Mr. Coppersmith, who is torn between costs and merits of the project. "Now the psychology is, My project got cut, now cut his."
In the Senate, at least three members -- Senators Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut and Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona -- are rethinking their past support. "Before you raise taxes, you cut spending," Mr. D'Amato said, explaining his switch.
Against those new pressures to cut, the supercollider proponents have a powerful lineup including these lawmakers:
*Senator Johnston, the chairman of the Energy Committee and a subcommittee chairman on the Appropriations Committee, who has heavy sway over his colleagues by holding the keys to mining on public lands, offshore drilling and other energy projects.
*Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who as chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, holds the purse strings for some incumbents facing tough fights in 1994.
*Representative Tom Bevill of Alabama who is chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee that handles the supercollider. Even if the House votes kill the project, as it did last year, he is in a position to work to revive it in a Senate-House conference committee.
But Mr. Johnston, Mr. Gramm and Mr. Bevill face a fight. Last year, the Senate voted 62 to 32 to save the proton-smasher, which is designed to investigate the most profound secrets of the origin of the universe. But at least a handful of lawmakers say they are ready to change their votes, and most of the Senate freshman are thought to be skeptical.
"I'm not confident," Mr. Gramm said. "It's a hard sell every year. If the President made an all-out effort it would help."
 
More Scrutiny
 Mr. Johnston voiced more confidence, but he added, "I'm acutely aware that all projects are subject to increased scrutiny."
Under the Bush Administration's budget estimate for 1993, expenditures for the supercollider would come to $859 million. The new Administration is expected to ask for $640 million in its budget next month.
Opponents say their best hope goes something like this: under public pressure, the House rejects the project by a greater margin than last year's 231-to-181 vote; then, the margin to approve the project in the Senate is slashed by at least a dozen votes, and finally, as the supercollider goes to a Senate-House spending conference, probably sometime in the fall, Mr. Clinton lets Mr. Bevill and other Democratic lawmakers know that he no longer supports the program.
The large freshman class must supply the nay votes to increase the House margin, and many of them have caught the budget-cutting fever.
 
All Up to Clinton
 That leaves matters in the hands of Mr. Clinton. Mr. Panetta, who voted against the project as a Representative last year, put the supercollider on his cut list this year. But when Gov. Ann Richards of Texas was at the White House watching the Super Bowl with Mr. Clinton, she convinced him that if he slashed the project, he would undercut whatever hope Senator Bob Krueger -- the Democrat she appointed to replace Mr. Bentsen -- has of winning the the special election on May 1, an election that could weaken the Democrats' already uncertain control of the Senate.
"I don't know where the President's true feelings lie," said an Administration official involved in budget matters. "It was never a firm decision." Still, Vice President Al Gore, a strong supporter of the supercollider in the Senate, is working to reinforce Mr. Bentsen's argument that Mr. Clinton should stand by his campaign promise whether or not Mr. Krueger wins.
Mr. Bumpers, who has close ties to the President, said he hoped that Mr. Clinton would come around and drop his support for the supercollider. "He knows he is not going to get anything like all the cuts he requested in Medicare, farm subsidies or pay freezes on federal employees," the Arkansas Democrat said. "So then he'll have to look someplace else for the big bucks."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New York City Yields at 18-Year Low

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
New York City sold $758 million worth of bonds yesterday, with yields at the lowest level since the eve of the city's fiscal crisis 18 years ago.
The bonds will be used to refinance about $664 million of old, higher-interest-rate bonds. The city is taking advantage of the sharp decline in interest rates since the Presidential election, which has brought long-term rates to their lowest levels since the 1970's. The new bond issue is expected to help the city save about $100 million in interest costs in the fiscal years 1993 to 2000. 
 The bond issues include several kinds of so-called derivative products to lower the costs for the city.
 
35-Day Adjustable Rate
 One, which was created by Lehman Brothers, involves $73 million of bonds due in 2013 and 2014. The bonds offer one group of investors an interest rate that is adjusted every 35 days. A second group of investors would get a much higher rate of interest. But if short-term interest rates rise, then the return to the second group of investors is cut to pay a higher rate to the first group.
Other regular long-term bonds that were sold yesterday went at a yield of 6.35 percent, while the derivatives went at a lower yield -- or cost to the city -- of 6.25 percent. In a statement the city said this deal saved it approximately $1.4 million.
In addition, derivatives can reduce the total amount of conventional bonds in the offering. By offering fewer conventional bonds, New York City hoped to make the offering more attractive.
 
Total Offering Reduced
 But as the bonds were priced yesterday, the demand for these derivative products was much less than expected and the total offering was cut from a possible $200 million or more to about $135 million, according to Dennis Boyle, a managing director of the municipal bond syndicate at Merrill Lynch & Company, the lead underwriter for the city issue.
Mr. Boyle said retail demand was fairly strong for the city's conventional issues up to 1999 and for the maturities from 2004 out to 2016, which the yield was 6 percent or over. The demand for the maturities of 2000 to 2003 was weaker because they were in the intermediate range but the yield was under 6 percent. He said that he expected that the portion of the bond issue that will be left in the hands of the underwriters will total about $235 million.
The yields on the tax-exempt issues range from 3.25 percent on the bonds due in August of 1994 to 5.20 percent on 1998 maturities; 5.90 percent in 2003 and 6.35 percent on 2009 through 2011 and 2014 through 2016. The 6.35 percent yield is the lowest since the spring of 1975.
The taxable equivalent yields are much higher, especially for triple tax exempt New York City residents. The taxable equivalent yield on the long-term bonds with a tax-exempt yield of 6.35 percent is close to 13 percent for a New York City and state taxpayer in the top Federal tax bracket of 39.6 percent, including a 10 percent surtax, proposed by President Clinton.
 
Flood of New Issues
 The New York City bonds are part of a flood of new issues this week that could total $8 billion, according to Bloomberg Business News. That flood has been weighing on prices, which have fallen recently. Yesterday, traders said prices of actively traded municipal bonds were unchanged in light trading.
The rush of new issues because of the fall in interest rates is reflected in the preliminary figures for the first quarter of the year from the Securities Data Corporation. These show there was a record $61.64 billion of new issues in the first three months of the year, a 23 percent increase over the first quarter of 1992, according to preliminary data. The total issuance last year of $232.4 billion was a record for the tax-exempt municipal market.
The rush to take advantage of lower interest rates is clear in the preliminary totals. More than 67 percent of the total new issues refinanced older debt with higher interest rates.
The pace of the refinancing this year, if it continued, would lead to another record year. This is in sharp contrast to the forecasts at the end of last year for a decline in new issues and refinancings this year. But those forecasts were made on the assumption that interest rates would remain relatively stable.
 
Treasury Market
 Prices of Treasury notes rose slightly yesterday, but the price of the 30-year bond fell. Treasury notes seemed to get some support from local governments, which buy these securities to put into escrow funds to pay off higher-rate debt.
The price of the 30-year bond rose early in the day but then fell 8/32 as the yield rose to 6.91 percent, up from 6.89 percent Monday. Traders said there was renewed focus on inflation, as the price of gold rose sharply. Yet, the decline in the Conference Board's index of consumer confidence was another indicator that economic growth will be slower, which would ease inflationary worries.
Because of the uncertainty about the outlook, prices ought to remain in a tight range until Friday, when the Department of Labor will release the March employment report.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Off Sharply

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The prospect of higher taxes and deeper spending cuts under President Clinton's economic plan seems to have dampened consumers' spirits -- and spending -- in March.
The index of consumer confidence released yesterday by the Conference Board, a business research group, fell a surprisingly sharp six points in March, to 62.6, following an eight-point decline in February. 
 In all, two-thirds of the post-election surge in the confidence measure had evaporated, as fewer consumers said in March that they expected their incomes to improve in the next six months and more foresaw a decline.
 
'A Real Softening'
 "I don't think anyone expected him to raise taxes only on the top 1 percent of income earners," Michael Gould, chairman of Bloomingdale's, said in a recent interview, referring to the reaction to President Clinton's plan for cutting the budget deficit in a Feb. 17 speech to Congress. "Nonetheless, there's been a real softening after his speech."
Economists say consumers seem to think the President's plan to cut the deficit is apt to slow economic growth. That might have been borne out by the component of the confidence survey that measures consumer expectations for six months hence. That index fell almost 8 points in March, and has lost about 27 points since December.
Consumers were gloomier in March in spite of signs that jobs might be getting a little more plentiful. Another Conference Board survey released yesterday -- one that covers help-wanted advertising in 51 major newspapers -- showed that advertising for job openings jumped in February, especially in the South and Midwest.
Retailers said that March sales pretty much mirrored the slump in spirits, with ferocious winter storms adding to consumers' woes. According to the latest report from Johnson Redbook, which surveys more than 25 retailers every week, sales in the first four weeks of March were nearly a percentage point lower than in February. And analysts expect uniformly downbeat reports from the nation's largest retail chains next week.
 
'Additional Things'
 But consumers had already turned more cautious before the bad weather hit. In January and February, the Commerce Department reported earlier this week, consumer spending grew at roughly half the robust rate of last fall -- a 2.8 percent annual rate versus 5.1 percent.
"My C.E.O.'s and I all have this sense that there are additional things on customers' minds," said George R. MrKonic, the executive vice president for specialty retailing at Kmart who overseas seven of the company's national specialty chains, including Waldenbooks and Builders Square. Even stores that weren't in the storms' paths complained of mediocre results, he said."That's one piece of evidence that something else was going on in March."
The Conference Board's consumer confidence measure does tend to zig and zag more than another widely followed consumer poll. But the University of Michigan survey for the first half of March, released to clients last week, also showed an erosion in expectations since December -- although the Michigan decline looks a lot less alarming than the Conference Board's 15-point drop over the last three months.
"Consumers clearly recognize the improving economy, and they're still quite positive about current conditions," Richard Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Surveys of Consumers, said. "But they are also re-evaluating how quickly things are going to get better."
Although expectations for a rebound in April and the rest of the year remain, the current state of consumer finances seems to point to the modest 3 percent gains in consumer spending that the Blue Chip consensus of economic forecasters has been predicting.
 
A Sensitive Issue
 One sore point clearly is taxes. "Taxes are a very sensitive issue," Fabian Linden, director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center, said. "Because Bush had the Treasury withhold less from people's' paychecks, people realize that they are going to have to pay more on April 15."
Further, the trend of inflation and long-term interest rates -- which, when declining, enables homeowners to refinance mortgages and reduce their monthly bills -- is no longer downward. And the savings level is near an all-time low, making it less likely that consumers can squeeze savings further to finance big increases in buying.
Most important, wages and salaries have been growing sluggishly, partly because the unemployment rate has been just inching down and partly because lots of companies, worried about holding down costs, are still reluctant to hand out raises.
 The March consumer confidence reading was the lowest level since July, although significantly higher than a year ago, when the index totaled 56.5, and from the recession readings of 50 or lower.
The index, calculated on a base of 100, is derived from a survey sent to 5,000 households nationwide, which covers questions ranging from home-buying plans to local job conditions.
The index is regarded as an important indicator of household financial and employment security, which plays a direct role in consumer willingness to borrow and spend. Consumer spending, in turn, is responsible for about two-thirds of the nation's overall economic activity.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Farm Product Prices Up
 WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The prices farmers get for raw products rose seven-tenths of 1 percent from February to March, but stood 2.8 percent lower than a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.
Price gains in the month for cattle, corn, eggs and hogs more than offset price declines for apples, lettuce, milk and sweet corn. When compared with last March, prices for corn, oranges, tomatoes and wheat dropped more than enough to offset increases for cattle, celery, eggs and hogs.
Crop prices collectively dropped 1.7 percent from February and 13 percent from the average a year earlier. Vegetable prices declined 9 percent from February and 22 percent from a year earlier. The all-fruit price index in March was down 10 percent from February and 45 percent from a year earlier.
Feed grains and hay rose 2.8 percent from February but dropped 12 percent from a year earlier. The March corn price, at $2.08 a bushel, was up 8 cents from February but still the lowest March price in five years.
Meat animals moved up 2.1 percent from February and averaged 7.9 percent above March 1992.
Poultry and egg prices rose 7.4 percent during the month and 17 percent from last year.
