HEADLINE: India Cancels Dam Loan From World Bank

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
The Indian Government today canceled much of a $450 million World Bank loan for a vast irrigation and hydroelectric project, because it cannot meet the bank's environmental and resettlement standards.
Bimal Jalan, India's representative on the bank's board, told his colleagues today that his country would not seek the remaining $170 million that had been authorized for the project, but not yet allocated, for the $3 billion project on the Narmada River, in the drought-prone northwest part of the country. 
 The decision is a major victory for international environmental groups who have fought the huge irrigation and hydroelectric project and the bank's involvement in it. For many environmentalists, the dam was a symbol of misguided support of heavy-handed development projects that sometimes do more harm than good.
But Indian officials emphasize that they intend to complete the project on their own, adhering to the bank's environmental and resettlement requirements. World Bank officials said privately that India preferred to complete the project without interference from multinational lending institutions. The Indian Government has viewed the criticism by environmentalists as an affront to its sovereignty, and an example of Westerners telling a developing nation how to run its affairs.
The enormous project includes the 535-foot-high Sardar Sarovar dam and more than 3,000 others, 47,000 miles of canals and a plan to provide 1,450 megawatts of power -- enough energy to provide electricity to 1.4 million American homes for a year -- irrigation for 4.4 million acres of land and drinking water to 40 million people. The project is sponsored by three Indian states: Gujarat, Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh.
The World Bank chose to finance a portion of the Narmada River Valley project in 1985, without the benefit of a full environmental impact study. Concerns raised by environmental groups forced the bank to undertake its first independent review of a bank-financed development project.
The review, done in 1991 by Bradford Morse, an American who was the former head of the United Nations Development Program and Thomas Berger, a Canadian Supreme Court justice, cited a number of environmental and resettlement problems and called for the bank to "step back from the project and consider it afresh."
Despite the report, the bank board kept funding for the project alive in October, over the objections of American and Japanese representatives. At the same time, the board gave India until March 31 to meet a series of standards, called "benchmarks," covering environmental concerns and how to resettle the more than 140,000 villagers who would be forced off their land by the rising waters.
Unable to meet the standards, the Indian Government decided today to forgo World Bank funding rather than try to plead for more time to comply. "They knew as well as anyone else that getting an agreement for relief of the benchmarks would have been a very contentious and politically charged task," a World Bank official said.
The remaining part of the World Bank loan represents a small fraction of the total cost of the project, and work is far along on major portions. Still, whether the Indian Government can complete the project without World Bank financing is an open question.

HEADLINE: Cairo Journal;
Fury of Islam Dims Expatriate Sparkle on the Nile

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, March 30

 BODY:
Despite its congestion and pollution, heaps of garbage and bureaucratic ineptitude, Cairo offers many foreigners what their home countries do not: entrance into the upper echelons of society, legions of servants and the glow that the elite derive from privilege.
But the cocoon spun around most expatriates in Egypt is crumbling. And the self-assuredness of the Europeans and the Americans, who socialize at hotels and clubs beyond the means of most Egyptians, has given way to fear. 
 "Life was very easy when I first came," said Patricia M. Goltermann, who is from Riverside, Calif., and has lived in Cairo for five years. "There was no place you did not feel safe and comfortable. Now things have changed."
 
A Deadly Warning
 The Islamic Group, which has carried out violent attacks against foreign tourists, said recently that it would strike at foreign businesses and foreign workers. The group told expatriates three weeks ago to leave Egypt "to preserve their lives." But so far there has been no visible evacuation undertaken by foreigners, although tourism has been way down.
Today, the Islamic Group issued what it said was a final call for all expatriates to leave Egypt, "because the time for warnings has ended."
The statement coincided with an explosion inside the burial chamber of one of the three pyramids at Giza, Egypt's most-visited tourist site. There was no apparent damage to the 4,500-year-old Chephren pyramid, but two Egyptian workers were wounded.
Officials said later that the explosion was accidental. But it underscored the jitters in this country, where tourism has been severely damaged. .
The threats by the Islamic Group, given force by the violence against foreign tourists that has left three dead and about two dozen wounded, have seen most of the 35,000 Americans and Europeans alter their daily routine.
Many foreign residents no longer go to the city center, where three bombs have exploded in the last month, and most dress more conservatively. A few foreign women have even begun to wear an Islamic veil in public, and others wear glasses to protect themselves from the vials of acid tossed at foreign women by Islamic militants.
 
Westerners 'Are Bracing'
 Family trips out of Cairo, to places like the pharaonic sites in Upper Egypt, are out of bounds. Some foreign workers are not renewing contracts, and companies are making contingency plans to evacuate foreign employees.
"Everyone who comes into our building now is searched," said the manager of one of the largest European companies in Egypt. He added that all cars parked in the garage were searched, too. "We are bracing for attacks."
In a city with little violent crime, and a low-paid servant class, many of the burdens of urban life, from phone bills to child care, are alleviated for expatriates by maids, errand boys, drivers, cooks and nannies.
The political and cultural systems that created the wealth and power of the industrialized nations were accepted in recent years as something worthy of, if not imitation, then at least deference. And some upper-class Egyptians, who admire the manners and customs of the West as fervently as the Islamic militants spurn it, speak French or English to their children.
But the mood of the country, burdened by overpopulation and crushing poverty, has changed in the last year with the rise of Islamic militancy. Increasing numbers of Egyptian women now wear veils, pubs and bars are being closed, and the influence of the West is blamed in militant tracts for everything from economic deprivation to AIDS.
 
Luxury Amid Squalor
 The frustration is increasingly vented on the foreign residents, many of whom live in the luxury suburb of Maadi, with its large houses and lawns, or Zamalek, the exclusive Nile island.
Ibrahim Ali Khalil, a 24-year-old truck driver who earns $50 a month, sat in the cab of his battered pickup on a dusty street in the Imbaba slum.
"Money means nothing to these foreigners," he said, looking toward an elderly man selling chickens in wooden cages. "They are ruining our country by dressing provocatively and implanting their ideas in the minds of Egyptians."
When asked about the attacks against foreigners, he paused.
"Whoever does wrong," he said quietly, "gets what they deserve."
The discontent is not lost on many expatriates, although few speak Arabic and many isolate themselves from all but the upper crust of Egyptian society.
"Egyptians are not as warm and friendly as before," Paul F. Allam, a Scottish physical-education teacher, said. "We know that these attacks come from a small group, but most locals, who are not extremists or fundamentalists, have changed, both in the way they dress and how they behave."
The schools and cultural institutions that are linked to the West, likethe Cairo-American College, which received a bomb threat three weeks ago, or American University in Cairo, have made concerted efforts to lower their profiles and have increased their security staff. The wrestlers at the Cairo-American College, for example, have been told to remove their varsity jackets in public.
 
Acid Hurled at Women
 There have been a few attacks against foreign residents, most commonly the tossing of acid on the legs of women wearing pants or short dresses.
"I warned my uncle and aunt, who are visiting here from the United States, not to go to Aswan," said 29-year-old Michael Slade of Minneapolis, who is a student at the American University in Cairo. "But they didn't listen to me. When they got there three bombs went off."
Jayne E. Cookson, a 60-year-old artist from Eugene, Ore., who has lived in Cairo since 1990, wears glasses in public to protect herself from acid-throwing militants. Although in love with Egypt, and often seen in the past sketching the crumbling Islamic monuments around the city, she rarely ventures out now.
"I see my friends less," she said, "and I have made the hours of my visits earlier. I do not go into town at night. I was thinking of staying indefinitely, but now I wonder how much longer I will be here."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The specter of violence is being cast over foreigners who have chosen to settle in Egypt as well as tourists who visit it. In an atmosphere made tense with daily warnings, an accidental explosion yesterday in the Chephren pyramid caused alarm. A mounted police officer kept watch. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Are Impatient to Start Pentagon Cuts

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
In Congress's first formal response to the Administration's proposed $263 billion military spending plan, lawmakers reacted coolly today to what the Pentagon concedes is a "holding budget."
Les Aspin, in his first appearance as Defense Secretary before the House Armed Services Committee he formerly headed, seemed almost apologetic at times in proposing a military budget for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. It would postpone decisions on canceling costly weapons programs until the Pentagon completes a comprehensive "bottom-up" review this summer. 
 Mr. Aspin's successor, Representative Ronald V. Dellums, Democrat of California, accused the Defense Secretary of clinging too closely to the budget he inherited from the former Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney. He said Congress needed to examine possible cuts for fiscal year 1994 -- suggestions have included attack aircraft, submarines and the expensive C-17 transport plane -- without waiting for the complete Defense Department review.
 
Why Wait Another Year?
 "This committee will need to act on next year's defense budget before the completion of the bottom-up review," Mr. Dellums said. "It should not blindly accept 'treading water' as the proper course for fiscal year 1994. There would be a significant cost to delaying for another year our inevitable adjustment to the post-cold war world."
The talk of the hearing today was of transition: from George Bush to Bill Clinton, cold war to post-cold-war, Mr. Cheney to Mr. Aspin, and from Mr. Aspin to Mr. Dellums.
As committee chairman, Mr. Aspin, a moderate Democrat from Wisconsin who supported early military action in the Persian Gulf war, wielded power through his mastery of military issues and by rewarding loyal committee members by financing pet projects in their districts.
Mr. Dellums, for years the most outspoken Congressional advocate of slashing the Pentagon's budget, now assumes the difficult task of leading a disparate group of liberal Democrats, conservative Republicans and some 20 new lawmakers on the panel, including 17 freshmen, to agree on a common committee spending plan.
 
A Time for Speeches
 Indeed, today's hearing featured more speeches from lawmakers than questions to Mr. Aspin and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Many lawmakers expressed concerns about parochial interests like base closings and National Guard forces, while some Republicans said Mr. Clinton's long-term budget cuts would hurt military readiness.
"I want to, in the very outset, express my concern for what many feel are cuts that are too deep in our military," said Representative Floyd Spence of South Carolina, the committee's ranking Republican.
Mr. Spence and other Republicans contended that Mr. Clinton's proposal to cut more than $120 billion through 1998 beyond what Mr. Bush had proposed dangerously exceeded the President's own campaign promise. Mr. Clinton had vowed in the campaign to cut $60 billion more than Mr. Bush through 1997. Mr. Aspin said the additional savings resulted mainly from a freeze on government workers' pay and revised assumptions about inflation, and that it did not mean deeper troop cuts or weapons cancellations.
Mr. Aspin repeatedly emphasized the Administration's aim to maintain current training levels for troops and shrink the total number of troops, rather than let military readiness slip.
 
Feeling the Uncertainty
 In a reflection of the effects of the uncertainty on the armed services, General Powell said that military officials were "a little concerned" about "early warning signs" in recruiting.
The Army, in particular, is having to accept more recruits without high school diplomas, although 94 percent of all recruits are still high school graduates, said Maj. George Wright, a spokesman for the Army Recruiting Command at Fort Knox, Ky.
Major Wright attributed the trend to declining advertising budgets, a misperception that the military was no longer signing up new recruits and fewer recruiters. Spokesmen for the Navy, Marine Corps and Navy said goals have been more difficult to meet, but that virtually all recruits are high school graduates.

Mr. Aspin implied that Mr. Dellums was more dovish than past chairmen. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Study Sees Rising Distress For Landlords

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
The number of privately owned rental apartment buildings in New York City showing signs of financial distress has risen sharply in the last five years, an indication that a new wave of abandonment may be around the corner, a study has concluded.
The study, by the Community Service Society of New York and the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, estimates that 140,000 rental units -- one out of six rental buildings in the city -- is either behind in taxes, or mortgage payments or both. 
 The study concludes that a serious new surge in abandonment could occur, though not of the proportion that ruined many neighborhoods in the 1960's and 70's. That wave, which at its peak had the city taking over as many as 10,000 buildings a year, turned the city government into a major landlord, owner of a huge and decrepit stock of buildings that are still a management headache and a financial drain.
 
Affecting Poor Areas
 The report, "Housing on the Block: Disinvestment and Abandonment Risk in New York City Neighborhoods," is to be released today. It found that most of the buildings in jeopardy are in poor neighborhoods, in many of the same areas that suffered widespread abandonment before. At the top of the list of neighborhoods at risk, for example, are Central Harlem in Manhattan, Bedford-Stuyvesant, Crown Heights and Bushwick in Brooklyn and the Mott Haven section of the Bronx.
But not all neighborhoods at risk are characterized as poor. Also at risk for a decline in housing stock, the report said, is the Chelsea-Clinton area on Manhattan's West Side, a neighborhood with many small, quaint buildings that had attracted wealthier tenants and many new stores and restaurants in the 1980's.
The increase in property-tax arrears follows a period in the mid-1980's when the city experienced a slowdown in the number of properties that were being abandoned and had to be taken over by the city. In the 1980's the region was buoyed by an extraordinary rise in real-estate values and home prices.
But in recent years the city's real-estate market has slumped, the recession has made it harder for many tenants to keep up with rents and landlords have faced higher operating costs. Many owners are reeling from increases in water and sewer fees. The increase is a result of the new metering system that the city is now reviewing.
The Community Service Society of New York is a 150-year-old private nonprofit organization that is concerned with issues like the housing, health, education and welfare of the city's neediest residents. The social-service agency has no connections with the real-estate industry.
The research by the Community Service Society found a 71 percent increase in tax arrears on rental properties from 1988 to mid-1992. Moreover, in 1992 more than 4,000 rental properties reached the courts in foreclosure proceedings compared to 100 in 1986.
 
Fewer Redeeming Properties
 A spokesman for the city's Department of Finance confirmed tax delinquencies had risen sharply in the last five years, but said he could not coment on the accuracy of the study's data or conclusions because he had not read the report.
The Department of Finance statistics show, for example, that in 1989, $152.7 million, or 2.45 percent of the property-tax roll, was in arrears. In 1992, $370.3 million, or 4.45 percent of the rolls, was delinquent.
Another significant indicator of the potential for widespread abandonment, the report said, was in the declining rate of ownership redemption, when landlords pay off taxes to halt a takeover by the city. In 1988, 9 out of 10 landlords with tax delinquencies settled their tax bills to avoid losing their properties. The study found that in 1992 only one out of four owners redeemed their properties.
David R. Jones, president of the Community Service Society, said: "The problem is that some these neighborhood are becoming intensely poor. Without the sort of income mix present even two decades ago, the core of these neighborhoods, working people, is lost. If this process is allowed to continue without intervention, the cost of rebuilding will be vastly more expensive in the end."
 
Rents Don't Cover Payments
 One significant difference from previous periods of serious default is that this time a contributing factor was the real-estate boom of the 1980's, the authors of the study said.
Victor Bach, director of the housing policy and research unit of the Community Service Society and who with Sherece West, researched and wrote the report, said many of the landlords had gone into the real-estate market when values were rising and refinancing loans were easier to obtain. They had expected the value of the property to keep climbing. Now some of those owners are not getting rents that meet their higher mortgage payments.
One positive finding, the study said, was a decrease, 27 percent, in reported incidents of arson from 1987 to 1991.
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said the survey's findings were another reflection of the continued recession in the region.
"There is still a crunch in the general economy of New York," he said. "There has been a slight strengthening, but we have yet to see a significant move to job recovery. We are still bumping along. When tenants can't pay their rents, it impacts property owners."
Michael D. Lappin, president of the Community Preservation Corporation, a lending company founded by New York banks to make loans for redevelopment in poor neighborhoods, said the findings in the report were troubling but did not necessarily spell disaster for the city's rental housing stock.
"There are troubling indicators to suggest that the recession has put rental housing in danger," he said. "Foreclosures in apartment buildings continues to occur. But what is different from the situation in the 1970's is that these buildings still have value. There are buyers for these foreclosed buildings and there is still a demand for housing."
Among the recommendations in the study, was that the city establish a task force to develop a strategy to save buildings in jeopardy.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold and Silver Prices Soar, But Rally May Be Fleeting

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices surged to their highest level of the year yesterday as commodity funds poured money into precious metals.
Analysts said there was no clear fundamental reason for the rally and cautioned that prices could quickly reverse course without broader support. 
 Gold for April delivery jumped $4.80 on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $337 a troy ounce, the highest settlement price for near-term deliveries since Dec. 17. May silver soared 14.7 cents, to $3.90 a troy ounce, the highest level since Nov. 5.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, April platinum leaped $5.10, to $363.70 a troy ounce.
 
Germany the Trigger
 The high-volume buying began in Europe overnight. The overseas buying was prompted by the German central bank's announcement that it will stick to its policy of lowering interest rates in small steps, in part to avoid driving up the value of the American dollar, said Peter Cardillo, research director with Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York.
A stronger dollar makes investments denominated in the American currency more attractive, which weakens investment demand for gold.
The surge continued in the United States as metal prices moved above longstanding resistance points, including $3.80 in the silver market, which brought in more buyers.
Fund managers, who tend to base trading decisions on the market's technical behavior rather than external factors, were big buyers, analysts said.
"They all went like dominoes in a row once the market got rolling," said Martin Reichenberg, manager of trading services for Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
But Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc., said the rally needed to be confirmed by further advances.
"If this move is for real, we should have more gains tomorrow, possibly big gains," he said. "If it sputters, and we go down tomorrow, that could indicate this is just a technical rally."
In other markets, energy prices ended the day mixed in advance of the weekly report on inventories from the American Petroleum Institute. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil for May delivery slipped 1 cent, to $20.28 a barrel; April heating oil fell 0.89 cent, to 55.96 cents a gallon, and April unleaded gasoline fell 0.61 cent, to 59.01 cents a gallon. But May natural gas rose 0.15 cent, to $2.042 for 1,000 cubic feet.
